headline: Chinese Back Nuclear Arms
abstract: A senior Chinese official told a European Parliament delegation today that China supports a nuclear deterrent in Western Europe against the Soviet Union. ''If a lion is going to attack you, you've got to be in a position to frighten it away,'' Peng Zhen, chairman of the National People's Congress, was quoted as telling the delegation from the legislative branch of the Common Market. It was the first time a Chinese leader has been quoted as endorsing nuclear weapons in Western Europe.

headline: The U.N. Today June 13, 1984
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Subcommittee on Petition and Information - 10:30 A.M.  ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Commission on Transnational Corporations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Trusteeship Council - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: PIZZA TIME LOSS FOR '83
abstract: Pizza Time Theatre Inc., a restaurant chain that went into Chapter 11 proceedings last month, said yesterday that it had a loss of $81 million for 1983. For the fourth quarter, the loss was $75.3 million, which included $45.2 million in provisions for the closing of certain company units, compared with net earnings of $2.5 million, or 42 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: Woodward Sues Dissident Holders
abstract: Woodward & Lothrop, the Washington, D.C., department store chain, said it filed a countersuit in Federal District Court against several shareholders who oppose the company's proposed $220 million merger with Taubman Holdings Inc. The countersuit charged that the group had violated sections of the Securities and Exchange Act in forming a shareholders' committee.    Separately, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Woodward disclosed that Taubman Holdings had granted to three of Woodward's top officials options to buy about 20 percent of the company for about $5 million if the merger was completed. Based on the Taubman offer, 20 percent of the company would be worth at least $40 million.

headline: Computer Linkups Spurred by France
abstract: As treasurer of a small engineering company in this dour eastern French town, Hubert Swalduz used to call the bank every day to ask about his company's accounts. Since the start of this year, however, all the information he wants comes to him on a little television screen in his office by touching a key.    Mr. Swalduz is a beneficiary of a Government campaign to keep France in the forefront of communications technology by placing - free so far - a telephone-connected computer terminal known as a Minitel in every French home and office.    His company, Guermont Weber, does business with the Banque Populaire de Lorraine, a cooperatively owned local bank that has pioneered ''home banking'' in Europe.

headline: Rockwell Profit Up 32%
abstract: The Rockwell International Corporation reported a 32.3 percent gain in profits for the quarter ended March 31. Earnings totaled $132.7 million, or 86 cents a share, compared with $100.3 million, or 65 cents a share, a year ago. Sales rose 15 percent, to $2.3 billion, from $2 billion.

headline: U.S. FINANCIAL ACCORD WITH JAPAN ANNOUNCED
abstract: The United States and Japan, as expected, announced a major agreement today that could substantially expand the international role of the yen and provide new business opportunities in Japan for American financiers.    Japan also agreed to take ''step-by- step'' action to relax tight Government controls of its domestic capital markets.    But the reaction was guarded among some analysts in the United        Excerpts from paper, page D6.  States, Exporters welcomed the move, with one representative calling it ''an important first step.'' but international experts speculated that as a result the yen could become even cheaper in the short term.

headline: SURGING COFFEE PRICES THREATEN QUOTA SYSTEM
abstract: Stubbornly high coffee prices, which threaten to disrupt the stability of the world market, have forced the 73-nation International Coffee Organization to call a special meeting of its executive board today in London.   Since mid-December, the group has been unable to keep prices within the agreed range of $1.20 to $1.40 a pound. In recent weeks, coffee for July delivery on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York has climbed as high as $1.5842 a pound, the highest price in at least four years.    On Friday, the coffee organization released an extra one million bags onto the market. That was the fourth and final such increase in supply it is allowed under its rules. If prices do not stay down, the group faces the possibility of suspending its quota system and allowing a free market in coffee.

headline: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
abstract: Amax Inc. $8,200,000  -*  Avon Products 26,700,000  -0.4  Beatrice Foods 133,000,000   -*  Becton, Dickinson 13,600,000  -17.6  Bethlehem Steel (54,600,000)  -  Borg-Warner Corporation 50,200,000  x41.4  Bristol-Myers Company 110,000,000  x19.4  Consolidated Freightways 12,200,000  x8.9  Dart & Kraft Inc. 107,800,000  x9.4  Eastern Air Lines  (28,100,000) - Exxon Corporation  1,480,000,000  x39.6 Hershey Foods  19,600,000  -  17.6 Kerr-McGee Corporation  40,300,000  x 70.0 Kroger Company  18,800,000  -12.6 National Can Corporation  (187,000) - Norfolk Southern  103,200,000  x 81. 7 Phelps Dodge  (5,000,000) - Phillips Petroleum  193,000,000  x 49.6 Santa Fe Southern Pacific  107,000,000  x 85.1 Squibb Corporation  36,900,000  x 10.8 Standard Oil (California)  378,000,000  x 21.9 Texas Eastern Corporation  59,200,000  x 57.0 United States Steel  171,000,000  -* Warner-Lambert  54,200,000 x 17.6 Zenith Radio  14,000,000 x 68.7   See accompanying notes for special items.   (Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

headline: Iran Says It Downed Iraqi Jet; Iraq Reports Artillery Duels
abstract: Iran said its air force shot down an Iraqi MIG-23 today and that 35 Iraqi soldiers were killed or wounded in artillery shelling in the past 24 hours.   An Iranian communique issued in Teheran also said that artillery duels on the northwestern front in the Persian Gulf war had left 35 Iraqi soldiers killed or wounded.   In Baghdad, an Iraqi communique said Iranian artillery hit Basra, killing one person and wounding 10 others.

headline: AFTER THE I.B.M.; A CASE FOR KEEPING I.B.M. BIG
abstract: Those who lament the fact that the  Justice Department dropped its  antitrust case against I.B.M. two years ago need some basic understanding about competition and monopolies. The American computer industry is in better shape today than if I.B.M. had been broken into little pieces.   Contrary to popular belief, monopoly power does not consist of a high share of some market. It is the persistent and substantial ability to raise prices above competitive levels or to hold back technology without losing so much business as to make such actions unprofitable.

headline: SOVIET ASSAILS U.S. DECISION TO PULL OUT OF UNESCO
abstract: The Soviet Union's representative to Unesco today sharply criticized the United States' decision to leave the organization, saying it reflected a deliberate attempt to undermine the organizations of the United Nations.    He added that Washington was seeking to ''use financial and economic levers to compel developing countries to follow in the wake of the United States' foreign policy.''   But the Soviet delegate, Yuri Khilchevsky, said proposals to deal with Unesco's ''structural, budget, management and personnel problems'' deserved ''to be studied with attention.''

headline: Williams Will Sell Its Edgcomb Unit
abstract: The Williams Companies said yesterday that it had agreed to sell most of the assets of its Edgcomb Metals Company unit to a subsidiary of Edgcomb Steel of New England Inc. for more than $100 million.   In addition, Williams said that it would receive five-year warrants to buy up to 100,000 shares of Edgcomb Steel at $15 a share.

headline: ECONOMIC INDEX FALLS STEEP 1.1%
abstract: The Government's principal gauge of the economy's prospects for coming months showed a steep 1.1 percent drop in March, the Commerce Department reported today.    The decline in the gauge, the index of leading economic indicators, broke an 18-month string of monthly increases, the longest since World War II. It was the sort of shift that can portend the onset of a recession.   However, both private and Administration analysts were quick to insist that the economy was merely moderating, not declining. They said the index simply confirmed what many other reports had suggested of late - that the economy was slowing to a pace that was normal after the initial rush of recovery from a recession.

headline: FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS DROP ON CREDIT REPORT By The Associated Press
abstract: Industrial demand for money appeared to unsettle the futures markets and drove financial instrument futures prices lower yesterday.   A report by the Federal Reserve Board that commercial paper outstanding reached $4.5 billion last week prompted concern about the market's ability to meet the demand for money from industry, said Bill O'Neill, director of research in New York with Rudolph Wolff Commodities Inc.

headline: REAGAN, IN U.S., SAYS CHINA TRIP ADVANCED TIES
abstract: President Reagan, back in the United States from his six-day visit to China, said today that he was heartened by ''the injection of a free market spirit'' into China's economy and optimistic about the prospects for friendship and economic cooperation ''with this so- called Communist China.''    After a nine-hour flight across the Pacific, the President took an overnight stop here to meet Wednesday morning with Pope John Paul II, who will touch down in Fairbanks en route to Asia.    Shifts His Language    Summing up the China trip, the President said that he was impressed by Chinese curiosity about this country and that he felt his talks with the Chinese leadership had raised Chinese-American relations to ''a new level of understanding.'' But he said the trip had ''not particularly'' changed his own thinking about China.

headline: Bill Called Costly to Insurers
abstract: A proposed law that would ban sex discrimination in insurance would mean higher benefits for policyholders but billions of dollars in liabilities for insurance companies, the General Accounting Office said today.    The Congressional auditing agency recommended that Congress, if it passes a ''unisex'' insurance bill, consider lengthening the transition period between the measure's enactment and its effective date from the proposed 90 days to at least a year, and exempt insurance contracts taken out by individuals.   The G.A.O. said the bill ''would be likely to increase unfunded liabilities by $7.7 billion to $15.1 billion in private and public pension plans.''

headline: NATIONAL CITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GOLDEN TEMPLE IN PUNJAB IS REOPENED
abstract: The inner sanctuary of the Golden Temple in Amritsar was opened to the public today for the first time since the Indian Army raided the complex three weeks ago in an attempt to crush a two-year-old Sikh terrorist movement in Punjab.   Officials in Chandigarh, the capital of Punjab and the neighboring state of Haryana, said about 12,000 people from several religious groups visited the Harimandir Sahib, the gold- covered holy of holies that is the center of the Sikh religion, during the three hours it was open this morning.   A crowd that had gathered outside the temple this evening in the hope of visiting the Harimandir Sahib was turned away by security forces. As a result of the large number of peaceful visitors this morning, the authorities were said to be considering opening the inner temple for a few hours every day.

headline: CONNECTICUT UTILITY'S BACKLASH
abstract: When the Public Service Company of New Hampshire announced in 1971 that it would build twin nuclear reactors at Seabrook for $1 billion to provide cheap and abundant electricity for itself and neighboring electric companies, no utility was more enthusiastic than the United Illuminating Company, which quickly bought one-sixth of the project, the second-largest share.    Now costs are up 800 percent and Public Service, at the edge of bankruptcy, has defaulted on its role as leader of a 16-utility construction consortium. That leaves United Illuminating right behind Public Service as the company facing the greatest financial pain.   The company doggedly insists that, at least, Seabrook 1 will be saved, but it is making contingency plans for cancellation, which would include filing for rate relief, cutting back on other capital expenditures, and ''cutting back on expenses,'' according to James F. Cobey Jr., the company president, who would not be more specific.

headline: Cable Systems To Change Hands
abstract: Sammons Communications Inc. and a unit of United Artists Communications Inc. separately announced plans to acquire cable television systems.

headline: ADDENDUM
abstract: * General Mills European Toy Group consolidated all of its advertising at Grey Advertising.

headline: New I.B.M. Model
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced a modified version of its Personal Computer XT for industrial locations, saying it could withstand he temperature extremes, vibration, shock and voltage conditions on a plant floor. The basic system, which will cost $6,740, can be used to help in production planning and maintenance dispatching, the company said. The XT is a sophisticated version of the Personal Computer and includes a hard disk drive for mass storage.

headline: Enstar Bid Suit
abstract: Roy M. Huffington, the largest stockholder of the Enstar Corporation, said he is filing suit to enjoin the offer for the company made on Tuesday by the Unimar Company. Unimar, a partnership of subsidiaries of the Allied Corporation and Ultramar P.L.C., sweetened its offer for 51 percent of Enstar to $20 a share in cash. Mr. Huffington said the restructured offer cannot be legally consummated under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935.

headline: Vote Backs Plant For Detroit Edison
abstract: Shareholders of the Detroit Edison Companpy today overwhelmingly rejected a proposal to halt construction of the $3.08 billion Fermi 2 nuclear power plant, which is 98 percent complete.

headline: Soviet Delegate at U.N. Assails Mining of Ports
abstract: The Soviet delegate to the United Nations said today that Nicaragua's harbors were being mined by ''terrorists, supported, equipped and financed by the United States'' in what he called a ''new chapter of international terrorism.''   The delegate, Oleg A. Troyanovsky, also said at a news conference that the Soviet Union and the United States were in ''one of the darkest periods'' in their relations and that an early summit meeting would be counterproductive.

headline: STATE UNITS FACE LOSS ON FUNDS
abstract: More than 30 New York school districts and counties are exposed to possible losses from their investments with Lion Capital Group, according to bankruptcy papers filed by the small government securities dealer.     A court-appointed trustee said yesterday that it was not clear yet how the losses would be distributed among the different creditors.    Meanwhile, several local officials raised questions yesterday about the adequacy of state supervision.    The localities' investments, which are known as repurchase agreements, are a widely used method of borrowing money. Such investments led to losses of $17.5 million at the New York State Dormitory Authority after a bankruptcy filing by Lombard-Wall Inc. in 1982. In such transactions, a dealer sells a security to a lender of money, such as a school district, and simultaneously agrees to repurchase the security at a later date. The difference between the prices represents interest to the school district.

headline: West German Output
abstract: Preliminary figures showed industrial production in West Germany was unchanged in February from January after seasonal adjustment, but rose 8.4 percent from a year earlier, the Economics Ministry said today.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: * Kollmorgen Corp., an electrical equipment manufacturer, has filed a $35 million offering of converible subordinated debentures, due 2009 through First Boston.      Debt Ratings    * Mead Corp., paper and paper products producer, had the rating of its commercial paper raised to prime 2 from prime 3 by Moody's.

headline: Angeles, Quinoco
abstract: The Angeles Corporation said it had agreed in principle to acquire the Quinoco Companies for $50 million.

headline: DOW IS AT LOWEST IN OVER YEAR
abstract: Stock prices fell broadly yesterday for the third consecutive session, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at its lowest level in more than a year.     The average, which was in the minus column during most of the session, ended 8.48 points lower, at 1,125.31. This was the lowest finish since April 8, 1983, when it closed at 1,124.71.

headline: FEDLSTEIN ASSAILS CAR CURBS
abstract: CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH        WASHINGTON, April 15 - Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, today urged abandonment of import curbs on Japanese cars, joining two other Cabinet officers who have spoken out against them.    It was a further sign of widening differences between the Reagan Administration and Walter F. Mondale, one of the Democratic challengers, over import restraints to protect the domestic auto industry.    Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige and Bill Brock, the United States special trade representative, have both said they would advise against continuing the curbs, which have just gone into their fourth year and are due to expire next March 31.    Appearance on TV Program    ''I think the quotas have kept prices higher for American consumers,'' Mr. Feldstein said on ''Meet the Press,'' the NBC News television interview program. ''I think they do threaten to put inflationary pressures into wage-setting in the auto industry, and I think it's about time we think about getting rid of those quotas.'' By contrast, Mr. Mondale has endorsed a House-passed ''domestic content'' bill, supported by the United Auto Workers. With this bill, up to 90 percent of the material and labor content of cars sold in the United States would be required to come from the United States.

headline: LIFE AT MATSUSHITA: PORTRAIT OF A BOSS
abstract: -   year-old blue-collar worker at   the Matsushita Electric plant just outside Osaka. He joined Matsushita 22 years ago and has dedicated his working life to one facet or another of television-set manufacturing.   In the course of his career, Mr. Shiroyama, a solidly built man dressed in a light blue company uniform, estimates that he has submitted to his superiors more than 3,000 suggestions for improving efficiency.

headline: ROBUST BEGINNING FOR THE 2D QUARTER
abstract: Explanations that bad weather caused lackluster economic data for March seem to be borne out by much improved reports for April. Housing starts, which plunged in March, gained 19.3 percent in April, and were running at an annual rate of 1.96 million units. Although that pace probably cannot be sustained in the face of rising interest rates, total housing starts are expected to exceed 1.8 million this year. Personal income rose five-tenths of 1 percent, but personal spending jumped, indicating more confidence in the recovery. Industrial production rose 1.4 percent, three times the March rise, and factory utilization jumped to 81.9 percent.    The healthy numbers bolstered predictions that the second quarter will be another sizzler. Gloomy outlooks of a 3 to 4 percent annual-rate increase are being replaced by predictions of a growth rivaling the expansion in the first quarter, which was revised to an robust 8.8 percent. But, as always, caution lurked behind the optimism: a high growth rate in the second quarter is almost sure to indicate expansion that borders on the uncontrolled.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM SALVADORAN LEADER'S ADDRESS
abstract: Following are excerpts from an address by President-elect Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvaldor to the Foreign Policy Association and the World Affairs Council this evening:    Our problems are many, but they are not impossible to overcome. To defend democracy we must do more than simply fight Communist guerrillas and death squads, we must also fight injustice, inequality, poverty and ignorance. These are threats equally dangerous.   We call upon the United States to join in our efforts and the glory of success. We the Salvadorans are going to do our best. But if together we fail to defend and preserve democracy in El Salvador, we will also share the consequences of defeat. If the Soviets, the Cubans and the Sandinistas succeed in reversing our achievements and prevent us from restoring the people's full rights, then the challenge will have to be faced by the United States alone, because you may be certain that we, the Salvadoran people on the front lines of the fight for freedom today, will not be here to help you. Tomorrow they will be dead, in prison, or exiled.

headline: China Cites Output Rise
abstract: China said today that heavy industry output grew 12 percent in the first quarter, and light industry rose 11.9 percent, even though energy shortages, transportation delays and waste plagued many factories. Xu Gang, deputy director of the State Statistical Bureau, said the value of the output of heavy and light industry each totaled $36.4 billion. Balanced development between light and heavy industry ''is very rare in recent years,'' he said.

headline: Ford and Chrysler GetHigher S.&P. Ratings
abstract: The Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday announced higher ratings for debt securities of the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation. General Motors Corporation ratings were unchanged.

headline: WEDDING DAY FOR REPUBLIC AND LTV
abstract: In separate meetings today, shareholders of the LTV Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation will give their blessing to the two steelmakers' $770 million plan to merge, telling management, in effect, to get on with the task of combining operations and slashing payroll.    So the marriage begins, but the debate goes on. The merger of the huge steelmakers, which the Justice Department first opposed and then approved, remains the focus of debate over whether combination is a solution to the steel industry's weakened state. If marriage is good for the two companies, it is asked, is it also good for the country?

headline: ITT Telecom
abstract: The ITT Telecom Products Corporation, a unit of the ITT Corporation, said it had signed a $150 million agreement to sell switching products to United Telephone Systems Inc. The ITT unit said the agreement is for the recently introduced ITT 1240 digital switching system.

headline: Digital Adds to Computer Line
abstract: The Digital Equipment Corporation yesterday introduced a new computer that will be the most powerful in its VAX line of superminicomputers.     The new machine, the VAX-11/785, offers a 50 percent to 70 percent improvement over the existing most powerful model, the VAX-11/780, and will sell for 15 percent to 35 percent more, Digital said.    Analysts described the new machine as a needed and expected ''mid- life kicker,'' as one put it, for the aging VAX line. The first models in the line were shipped in 1978.

headline: Ex-Aide at White House In Congressional Post
abstract: Dan C. Roberts, a former White House economic aide who has just been named executive director of Congress's Joint Economic Committee, thinks it will be ''very interesting'' to work at the other end of Pennsylvania Avenue.     Mr. Roberts, who at 28 is the youngest executive director ever named at the committee, worked in the White House for two years as an economist for the President's Council of Economic Advisers. He is returning to Washington, and to a job at the Capitol Hill end of the most political artery in the capital, after a year at the Chase Manhattan Bank in New York.

headline: Caterpillar Narrows Its Loss
abstract: The Caterpillar Tractor Company reported today that it had narrowed its first-quarter loss to $109 million, from $172 million a year earlier, when the company was struck by the United Automobile Workers. Revenues also improved after the strike, increasing 74.6 percent, to $1.39 billion, from $796 million a year earlier.

headline: CANADA'S LIBERALS PICK A NEW LEADER ON SECOND BALLOT
abstract: John N. Turner, a lawyer and former Cabinet member, was elected leader of the Liberal Party of Canada today, replacing Pierre Elliott Trudeau.    On Mr. Trudeau's retirement as Prime Minister, expected later this month, the 55-year-old Mr. Turner will become head of the Government.   Mr. Turner, who received 54 percent of the vote, defeated Jean Chretien, the Energy Minister, on the second ballot of the party convention by a margin of 1,862 to 1,368. Donald Johnston, Minister of Economic Development, ran third, with 192 votes.

headline: RISING RATES BENEFITING INVESTORS
abstract: The rise in interest rates, including this week's increase in the prime rate, is painful for the Federal Government, because the cost of borrowing to cover its deficit has soared. The same complaint comes from corporations, which borrow to finance new plants and machinery, and developing countries, which are trying to repay their ballooning debts.    Rhoda Schwarz is delighted, however.   Higher interest rates mean that she collects higher income from her investments - income that is not being eaten up by inflation. ''It's allowed me to be a little bit freer,'' said the widow, who lives in Hallandale, Fla. ''I bought my daughter a car last year. I can take people out for dinner and be kind of a sport. It's allowed me to do a little refurnishing in my apartment. On the whole, it helps.''

headline: The U.N. Today April 11, 1984
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Human Rights Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: U.S. SAYS 2 COPTERS MAY HAVE STRAYED INTO EL SALVADOR
abstract: United States diplomats here said today that they could not rule out the possibility that two American helicopters that came under fire Wednesday may have strayed over rebel-controlled territory in El Salvador.   But they denied that the aircraft, one of which carried two United States Senators, were engaged in anything other than taking the two legislators and the wife of the American Ambassador to a camp for Salvadoran refugees near the border.   The two Army UH-1H helicopters were first reported by Congressional and Administration officials in Washington to have been forced down by groundfire. But officials said today that only one of them had been hit, and that the gunfire had not forced it to the ground.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Official Dismissed By United Artists
abstract: Robert Rosencrans, president of the United Artists Cablesystems Corporation, was dismissed by its owners earlier this month, just two weeks after engineering the merger of the cable company with another major cable concern.    Mr. Rosencrans, who is 57 years old, said he was told in mid-June that United Artists Communications Inc., the San Francisco-based parent of the cable company, was planning to replace him.   ''I was completely taken by surprise,'' said Mr. Rosencrans, reached by telephone yesterday at his Greenwich, Conn., home. ''There was no disagreement that I was aware of.'' Officials with the parent company did not return calls to their offices yesterday.

headline: Chief Is Appointed At Stelco of Canada
abstract: Stelco Inc., Canada's largest steelmaker, has a new chief executive officer.     The company said yesterday that John D. Allan, 59 years old, would succeed Peter Gordon, who remains chairman. Mr. Allan has been president and chief operating officer.

headline: MODERN PROBLEMS FOR AN OLD LIQUEUR
abstract: Behind the walls of the 900-year-old Monastery of La Grande Chartreuse high in the French Alps, a community of Carthusian monks guards one of the best-kept business secrets in the world: the formula for making Chartreuse.    The sweet, green or yellow liqueur is the chief means of support for the Carthusians, the strictest contemplative Roman Catholic order. It is also the cause of a predicament. For sales have been falling, and the tactics most businesses would use to meet such a crisis are morally distasteful to many of the monks.

headline: Mayor in Peru Hanged By Maoist Guerrillas
abstract: Maoist guerrillas hanged a leftist Mayor, shot a Lieutenant Governor dead and briefly captured a radio station in attacks on Sunday, the Civil Guard has announced.   The civil guard said Shining Path guerrillas made the attacks to mark the fourth anniversary of the start of their rebellion.

headline: JAPAN'S SEX INDUSTRY: BESIEGED BUT STILL BOOMING
abstract: The Japanese Government has set out, as it does now and then, to do battle against Japan's prosperous sex industry.    Officials do not want to do away entirely with the selling of sex. It is a business with a long, even honored, history in this country, which once referred to its red-light districts as ''flower and willow worlds.''   But an explosion of often seamy sex- related establishments has hit Japan in the last few years. Despite a national tradition of tolerance in such matters, politicians and bureaucrats have begun insisting that a crackdown is overdue.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN ADVERTISING ; THE LATEST SINGLE-AD 'MAGAZINE'
abstract: DEPENDING upon their specialties, doctors in the United States receive 50 to 85 professional journals every month. That's a lot of advertising - especially for pharmaceuticals, which account for the bulk of the ads. The problem for drug companies and the ad agencies representing them is to rise above the crowd - and the competition for the physician's reading time.

headline: MOVE TO REPLENISH PENSION AGENCY FUNDS GAINS
abstract: The Senate Labor Committee today approved a measure to replenish the deficit-ridden Federal insurance program that guarantees 37 million workers and retirees against the collapse of their pension funds.    The legislation would raise the annual premium employers pay to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation to $7 per pension plan participant from $2.60. The money would begin rebuilding assets that are an estimated $520 million short of the benefits the agency has promised to pay present and future retirees whose employers have ended pension plans.   The measure would also impose new limits on a company's ability to abandon its pension fund and dump unfunded liabilities on the Federal corporation. Proponents of the legislation, including many large corporations, said abuses by employers seeking to dodge their pension responsibilities had contributed to the depleted condition of the Pension Benefit Guaranty trust fund.

headline: UTILITY SAID TO BE FACING BANKRUPTCY
abstract: An independent auditor for the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, the lead builder of the Seabrook nuclear power plant, said yesterday that unless the company found additional sources of credit in the next three weeks, it might be forced into bankruptcy and find itself ''unable to continue in existence.''    The report came only three days after the 16 utilities that own the Seabrook project voted to cancel the plant's second reactor, if the partners could find a way to help Public Service of New Hampshire recover its $293 million investment. Last Wednesday, the utility said its banks, led by the First National Bank of Boston and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, had demanded that it find back-up sources of credit for Unit 1, which is 76 percent complete. The utility has repeatedly vowed to finish the project.

headline: Australia-China Flights
abstract: Direct flights between Australia and China are to begin in September, the Government announced today. Aviation Minister Kim E. Beazley said there would be two flights a week, one each by the Australian national airline, Qantas, and the Civil Aviation Administration of China.

headline: Vietnam Accuses China Of Killing Hundreds
abstract: Chinese forces have killed hundreds of civilians in cross-border artillery bombardments and raids on Vietnamese territory in the last two months, Vietnam charged today.   The Hanoi radio said that more than 130,000 artillery and mortar rounds had been fired by China but that Vietnamese border guards and civilians had repulsed the cross-border attacks, ''putting out of action'' more than 5,500 Chinese troops.

headline: PHONES HIGHLIGHT EXHIBITION
abstract: ASK the question: ''What's new at the Premium Incentive Show?''     And the answer comes back from Thalheim Expositions, which is running the 46th annual event: ''Telephones.''    There was almost everything at the shows in the past, but it's hard to remember any telephones. Now, though, among the full house of exhibitors that jammed all available space at the New York Coliseum, were about 75 that featured phones or phone accessories. All this because the breakup of the Bell System allowed all-out competition in the hardware field.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Chase Manhattan Corp.  said the New York State Banking Board had unanimously approved its application to acquire Lincoln First Bank Inc.     * Dow Corning Corp. , a joint venture of Dow Chemical Co. and Corning Glass Works, said it had acquired Oak Industries' interest in DDC, which had been a joint venture with Dow Corning. DDC produces silicone- coated architectural fabrics.     *  Conagra Inc.'s proposal to sell 7 Western baking flour facilities to Cereal Food Processors Inc. of Mission Woods, Kan., was approved by the Federal Trade Commission. The divestitures were required under a 1983 consent order that settled F.T.C. charges against Conagra.

headline: Market Place; Home Health Care Stocks
abstract: AS in many a Wall Street story, the concept is great but finding a way to invest in it is another matter.     The concept, in this instance, is home health care, a way to get people out of costly hospitals for less expensive treatment at home. Just a year ago, there was talk of a boom in this industry, with Government efforts to contain hospital costs increasing new entrants' chances of success.   The possibilities are still there - the overall business is expanding rapidly, said Herman Saftlas, an analyst at Standard & Poor's. But many small companies that looked to have a bright future just a year ago are now struggling, their stocks having fallen sharply.

headline: BABY BOOM AND PEOPLE MAGAZINE
abstract: NEXT week, People magazine is going to begin promoting itself to the trade as a way of reaching the products of the much-talked- about baby boom. And the tagline - from the prolific pens of Young & Rubicam - will be: ''People. We're Booming.''

headline: Yields Rise On C.D.'s
abstract: Annual effective yields on six- month certificates of deposit and money market accounts climbed across the country yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.   The Monitor's national index of six- month certificates, based on a survey of 50 major institutions in the five largest area markets, jumped to 9.91 from 9.80 last week, for an all-time high.

headline: Seat for Union Now in Doubt DETROIT, April 4 - Despite
abstract: the insistence of the United Automobile Workers union that it   is entitled to a place on the   Chrysler Corporation board,   the union's president, Owen F.   Bieber, evidently will not be   nominated for a seat at tomorrow's board meeting. Mr. Bieber recently met with   Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman   of Chrysler, concerning the   seat held by Douglas A. Fraser,   the retired president of the   U.A.W. Mr. Fraser has said he   plans to step down from the   board in June and has said the   seat should go to Mr. Bieber. Although union officials said   that the meeting had been cordial, and that Mr. Iacocca suggested that Mr. Bieber meet   with the board's nominating   committee, no date had been   set for such a meeting.

headline: 500,000 AFGHANS ARE REPORTED TO FACE STARVATION
abstract: About 500,000 people in Afghanistan are in imminent danger of starvation, according to a report released yesterday in Manhattan by an independent British group that is urging the United Nations to provide aid.   The study by the group, a British organization called AfghanAid, a charitable group that sends relief supplies to Afghanistan, was conducted between September and December 1983 and was based on an investigation of the circumstances of more than 5,000 children in 30 Afghan provinces.   Speaking at a news conference at Freedom House, a human-rights organization that has been monitoring the situation in Afghanistan, Dr. Frances D'Souza, the director of the project, said regions of Afghanistan where the Soviet presence is the heaviest were particularly vulnerable.

headline: IRAN IS APPARENTLY DEBATING FATE OF THE 'FINAL OFFENSIVE'
abstract: A debate has apparently arisen within Iran's leadership over what to do about its long-anticipated ''final offensive'' against Iraq, American and Western European officials said today.   The prevailing view of experts, questioned here and in London, Paris and Bonn, is that Iran, which since March has committed about 400,000 troops and volunteers to the ''offensive,'' has to go ahead with some kind of assault in the vicinity of the Iraqi port city of Basra.   Some American officials, who acknowledge that they may be overly optimistic, contend that the Iranians will probably launch a less than all-out attack, and that once a new stalemate develops they will finally agree to discuss terms for ending the war, which Iraq started nearly four years ago.   Khomeini Said to Back Fight    In this view, which is shared by some European intelligence officials, the main force for continuing the war is Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian spiritual and political leader. According to these officials, the Iranian leadership is actively debating how to proceed, with some seeking ways to persuade Ayatollah Khomeini that it is time to end the war.

headline: MUBARAK'S PARTY WINNING IN EGYPT
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak's National Democratic Party appeared to be winning a commanding majority in Egypt's parliamentary elections, official returns showed today.   The center-right opposition New Wafd Party was trailing a distant second, but stood the best chance among the four opposition parties of claiming seats in the 458-member People's Assembly.   Interior Minister Hasan Abu Basha said final results from Sunday's elections - the first for Parliament since Mr. Mubarak succeeded President Anwar el-Sadat in 1981 - were expected to be announced Tuesday. The elections were marred by two shooting incidents and charges by the opposition parties of vote-rigging.

headline: Consumer Debt Gains
abstract: Consumers took on a record $6.61 billion more in installment debt than they paid off during February, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.   The report said the increase compared with a rise of $4.47 billion in January and surpassed the previous record increase of $5.89 billion registered in December.

headline: FRENCH OFFICIAL IS TARGET OF CAR'S DRIVER
abstract: The brother of one of nine French soldiers killed Saturday in Chad tried to run down Defense Minister Charles Hernu with his car today at the funeral of the men. Bodyguards opened fire and wounded the driver before the car could reach Mr. Hernu.   Mr. Hernu and other members of the official party, including the Army Chief of Staff, Jannou Lacaze, were not hurt. But the car knocked over at least one coffin before Mr. Hernu's bodyguards wounded the driver, 26-year-old Lionel Rehal, and the car rolled to a halt.

headline: A 1980'S MISSIONARY PURSUES THE SOULS OF AFRICA
abstract: When Dr. David Livingstone died in what is now Zambia in 1873, there were but a handful of retainers to attend him at his final resting place - a modest hut. In his last days, he had become so weak with fever that he had to be carried. His quest to evangelize Africa was over.    One hundred and eleven years later, another figure says he has decided to assume the same mantle as the Scottish explorer and missionary who burned, in his own words, ''to try to open up a path to commerce and Christianity'' in a mysterious continent.

headline: China Says Tourism Climbed By 11.5% in Peking Last Year
abstract: More than half a million foreign tourists visited the Chinese capital last year, the city statistical bureau said today.

headline: ARAB-AMERICANS IN ISRAEL: A CASE OF DUAL IDENTITIES
abstract: One by one, Arab-Americans are coming to Israel to engage in a complicated search for their roots.    The young Americans, whose fathers or grandfathers emigrated from the Middle East, are choosing to take a year or so away from their studies and spend it here, living with Arab families in East Jerusalem, in Galilee or in the occupied West Bank in an effort to learn the politics of the conflict and to absorb the culture and language of their forebears.   There are no statistics on how many have come this way, but they appear mainly to be young men in their 20's who are doing graduate work in Middle Eastern studies. For many, the experience has engaged their pro-Palestinian political sympathies, but it has also reinforced the American side of their dual identities, showing them how steeped they are in American values and how far they stand from Arab society.

headline: Penn Square F.D.I.C. Pact
abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that it had worked out a $2.5 million settlement with 15 former officials of the failed Penn Square Bank in Oklahoma.   The agreement, which would be the first in the insurance agency's claim against former directors and officers of the bank, must still be approved by the United States District Court in Oklahoma City.

headline: MOSCOW HINTS SAKHAROV'S WIFE FACES ARREST FOR ANTI-SOVIET ACTS
abstract: The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia declared today that Andrei D. Sakharov's wife, Yelena G. Bonner, had ''gone too far in her anti-Soviet activities'' and that law enforcement agencies were taking measures against her.   The implication that criminal charges, which it did not specify, were being prepared against Miss Bonner came at the end of a bitter personal attack on her. She figured in the article as the instigator of Dr. Sakharov's dissident activities and as a woman prepared ''to sneak to the West over his dead body.''   The Izvestia article gave no indication of Dr. Sakharov's health or his whereabouts. The last information about him, which came Saturday from sources close to the family, said Miss Bonner sent a telegram reporting he was taken away on May 7, five days after he began a hunger strike.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Commercial Bancshares Inc.  of Jersey City, said shareholders of Wood-Ridge National Bank had approved Commercial's acquisition of the bank.     * Imperial Life Assurance Co. of Canada said it and its associated companies intend to buy all the common and preferred shares of Anglo- Permanent Corporate Holdings Ltd.

headline: 3d World's Food Needs Seen Growing by U.S.
abstract: The Agriculture Department said today that third-world countries would have to import 31 million tons of food next year, a rise of 3 percent, simply to keep hunger in check at a level far below accepted nutrition needs.   While rising production in some countries, notably India, has made the third world more self-sufficient, drought and poverty are forcing southern Africa to rely on charity for two- thirds of its import needs, the department said in a report.

headline: 19 Trucks Hijacked By Both Sides in Beirut
abstract: Rival militiamen hijacked 19 semitrailer trucks traveling between the Christian and Moslem sectors of the Lebanese capital in the morning rush hour today, prompting officials to close the only crossing briefly.   The drivers were released unharmed, but the six-wheel trucks carrying fuel and food remained in the hands of the militias, which may have commandeered them to carry arms and ammunition, the police said.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  American Cytogenetics Inc., a Los Angeles-based specialty laboratory company, has appointed Hal L. Lawrence president.     *  Ashland Oil Inc., Ashland, Ky., has promoted William H. Harkins to vice president, and named William R. Sawran a vice president of the company and president of its Ashland Services Company.     *  Batus Retail Group has appointed Cheryl Farnsworth senior vice president and fashion merchandising director.

headline: Gloom Marks E.E.C. Talks
abstract: The leaders of the European Common Market countries met yesterday at a semiannual summit meeting, still discussing the deadlocked issue of British budget contributions that has brought development of the Common Market to a near standstill.    After poor turnouts last week in European parliamentary elections in the 10 member countries, a mood of barely masked pessimism prevailed at the meeting in Fontainebleau's 16th-century palace.

headline: Polish Communists Oust Marxist Philosopher
abstract: The Polish Communist Party announced Thursday that it was expelling Adam Schaff, the Marxist philosopher, because his recent writings were incompatible with party membership.   Mr. Schaff, 71 years old, is the author of a number of books on the theory of Marxism and has been a party member for 53 years. Reached by telephone, he said he would have no comment on his expulsion.

headline: TEXT OF F.D.I.C. ANNOUNCEMENT
abstract: Following is the text of the announcement by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation regarding the financial aid arranged for the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company:    The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the Federal Reserve Board and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, together with a group of leading banks, have assembled a comprehensive financial assistance program for the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company. The program will provide assurance of the capital resources, the liquidity and the time needed to resolve in an orderly and permanent way the bank's problems.   Under the program, the F.D.I.C., together with a group of commercial banks, will provide a total of $2 billion in capital to the bank in the form of subordinated notes. This capital will be available for the period necessary to enhance the bank's permanent capital, by merger or otherwise. The subordinated notes bear interest at a rate equal to the one-year Treasury bill rate plus 100 basis points. The F.D.I.C. board of directors voted to grant assistance pursuant to Section 13(c)(2) of the F.D.I. Act.

headline: ;  People
abstract: *  Robert H. Cherins elected an executive vice president, and  Bruce Kramer and  Steven M. Bernstein senior vice presidents at McCaffrey & McCall.

headline: Brazil Steel Ruling
abstract: Imports of government-subsidized steel from Brazil threaten to do major harm to American steel companies, the United States International Trade Commission ruled today, opening the way to the imposition of import duties. The Commerce Department will shortly order the imposition of duties ranging from 17 percent to 62 percent of the value of Brazilian steel products, the I.T.C. staff said. The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, had brought the complaint, which involved carbon steel plate and sheet used in construction, shipbuilding and home appliances.

headline: Mortgage Rates Rise
abstract: Mortgage rates rose sharply in April, with conventional fixed-rate loans reaching 14.11 percent, according to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.   The new rate, quoted by major lenders on long-term mortgages for newly built homes, was up from 13.85 percent in March, the agency said.

headline: ISRAELI LABOR LEADER CAMPAIGNS ON VOW OF LEBANON PULLOUT
abstract: Shimon Peres, the Labor Party's nominee for Prime Minister in the July 23 elections, said today that if he won he would quickly relieve the Israeli Army of ''the burden of deployment in Lebanon.''    ''We believe an Israeli Army presence in Lebanon is not required to assure peace for Galilee,'' Mr. Peres said in an acceptance speech after he was officially nominated today.   Mr. Peres also pledged that he would adopt a more flexible stance to attempt to break the impasse in negotiations for Palestinian autonomy.

headline: Peking Planning an Increase In Trade With Eastern Europe
abstract: China is to increase trade ties with Eastern Europe, a Chinese official indicated in an interview published today.

headline: INVESTMENT BANKING LAWYERS
abstract: Allen Finkelson was no slouch in the law world. He graduated from Columbia Law School in 1971, and made partner at Cravath, Swaine & Moore - perhaps the most prestigious firm in the nation - a mere six years later.    But it was not enough for him: ''I was very happy at Cravath,'' he said. ''I loved the people, but the prospect of doing what I was doing for 20 or 30 more years, without much change . . .'' he trailed off. ''Well, it was disquieting.''    So last October, Mr. Finkelson threw away the security of his hard- earned partnership - and partnership profits of hundreds of thousands of dollars a year - to become an investment banker at Lehman Brothers, now Shearson Lehman/American Express Inc.

headline: No Headline
abstract: The Treasury market faces a month of relatively light activity, with few financings except for the Monday auctions of three- and six- month bills.    By reducing the size of weekly Treasury-bill auctions to $12 billion, the Government will be reducing its debt outstanding by $400 million or more each week. Maria F. Ramirez, an economist at Merrill Lynch Economics, said the weekly reductions in debt could allow the Treasury to proceed with its large note and bond financing in May, without passage of legislation to increase the legal limit for Treasury debt outstanding.

headline: Arco Drops Leasing Plans
abstract: The Atlantic Richfield Company notified the Interior Department that it is withdrawing from the purchase of seven environmentally sensitive offshore oil and gas tract leases. The company said it would forfeit its $10 million deposit on the central California tracts that it bought for $172 million with four partners.

headline: Flickinger's Talks With Pneumo End
abstract: The Pneumo Corporation and the S.M. Flickinger Company said they had ended talks concerning Pneumo's possible acquisition of Flickinger.

headline: MEXICO RETRACTS ANNOUNCEMENT OF ROLE IN U.S.-NICARAGUA TALKS
abstract: Mexico today retracted its announcement on Friday that it had been invited to be a witness at talks between the United States and Nicaragua.   The Foreign Ministry, in a statement issued through the Government-owned press agency, Notimex, said that ''there has not been defined any presence of Mexico in talks between Nicaragua and the United States.'' It called its earlier statement ''inexact and unauthorized.''   The Foreign Ministry said its role would be restricted to using its good offices in ''creating a climate of lowered tension and in facilitating diplomatic negotiations.'' It added that ''it has not been decided to witness the talks.''

headline: U.S. EXPECTED TO SEEK COMPETITION TO INTELSAT
abstract: The Reagan Administration is expected to propose opening up satellite communications across the North Atlantic to competition, Administration officials said today. Intelsat, an international cooperative, has monopolized the market for two decades.    The move, which would require Federal Communications Commission approval, has provoked sharp objections from Intelsat and its member nations. About 30 governments have protested to the State Department and the F.C.C., in an effort to head off the proposal, which is expected soon. These nations fear that such a change could set back Intelsat's business and cause higher rates for its customers.

headline: Business Help For Democrats
abstract: WASHINGTON THE Democratic National Committee says 230    business executives have agreed to contribute $10,000 each (if it's their own money) or $15,000 (if it's their companies' money) to qualify for membership in the committee's three-year-old Democratic Business Council.    That is far more than ever before, says the committee's finance chairman, Peter G. Kelly, and it means that business contributions to the party's 1984 campaign are likely to exceed the $2 million to $3 million that the party gets from its customary No. 1 contributor, organized labor.    Until the council was organized, Mr. Kelly said, business fund-raising was mingled with appeals to other groups such as labor and trade organizations, so there was no concerted effort to ask for money from business executives. For their contributions, the executives get to join the committee leadership in defining the party's major campaign issues.

headline: CONFEREES ADOPT PLAN TO OVERHAUL BANKRUPTCY LAW
abstract: A House- Senate conference committee today approved a major overhaul of the Federal bankruptcy system that has required two years of struggle.    In a victory for labor unions on an issue they had declared their top lobbying priority of the year, the conferees agreed to limit employers' freedom to escape union contracts by declaring bankruptcy. That agreement, reached early this morning in a marathon bargaining session, removed the last major impediment to passage of the bankruptcy bill.    The bill was originally intended to reorganize the bankruptcy courts in compliance with a Supreme Court ruling issued two years ago today.

headline: HIGH COURT RULES RIGHTS LAW COVERS LAW PARTNERSHIPS
abstract: The Supreme Court, acting in a sex discrimination suit, ruled unanimously today that law firms may not discriminate on the basis of sex, race, religion or national origin in deciding which young lawyers to promote to the status of partner.   In an opinion by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, the Court said that once a law firm offers its associates the chance to become partners, the partnership decision is covered by the Federal law that prohibits discrimination in employment.   The Court reinstated a discrimination suit by a woman who was rejected for partnership in an Atlanta law firm where she had worked for seven years as an associate. Under the ''up or out'' policy used by many law firms, the woman, Elizabeth A. Hishon, had to leave the firm.

headline: Penney's Net Rises by 19%
abstract: The J. C. Penney Company reported today that net income in the first quarter rose 19 percent, to $69 million, or 92 cents a share, from $58 million, or 78 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.

headline: Warning Given On Brazil Debt
abstract: Brazil will ruin itself if it continues to pay half its export earnings to service its $93 billion foreign debt, Vice President Aureliano Chaves said in an interview published today. ''Brazil runs the risk of self-destruction if it is forced to allocate, for a long time, half of the receipts from its exports to pay interest on foreign debt,'' Mr. Chaves was quoted as telling the daily newspaper Correio Braziliense.

headline: Hecla-Ranchers
abstract: The Hecla Mining Company has increased its stake in Ranchers Exploration and Development Corporation, a mining concern based in Albuquerque, N.M., to 2.6 million shares, or about 43 percent of the shares outstanding, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. Hecla, a Wallace, Idaho, company that has a merger accord with Ranchers, said it bought 103,700 common shares in open-market transactions Wednesday.

headline: SCIENTIFIC AMERICAN EFFECTS TRANSITION
abstract: The guard has begun to change at Scientific American Inc., the privately held magazine and book publishing company.    At its annual meeting, the board elected Jonathan Bird Piel as president. Mr. Piel, 45 years old, succeeds his father, Gerard Piel, 68.    Along with Dennis Flanagan and Donald H. Miller Jr., Gerard Piel founded Scientific American in 1948, and he has been the company's president ever since. In a statement, the company said Gerard Piel had been elected chairman of the board.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  American Petrofina Inc., Dallas, has elected to its board David C. Treen, former Governor of Louisiana.     *  Chicago Board Options Exchange, Chicago, has elected Richard E. Luri chairman of the executive committee and a vice chairman of the exchange.

headline: Charterhouse
abstract: Charterhouse Group International Inc. said it had acquired the Stanley Interiors Corporation for $56 million from an investor group led by Clayton & Dubilier, a private investment firm.

headline: S.E.C. SAYS DATAPOINT INFLATED SALES
abstract: The Datapoint Corporation, one of the stock market's high-technology favorites in the early 1980's, was charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission today with engaging in a plan to inflate its sales and earnings in 1981 by tens of millions of dollars.    Also named in an S.E.C. complaint was John V. Thornton, a former vice president for the computer and telephone systems maufacturer. The defendants, without admitting or denying the charges, agreed to a consent degree with the S.E.C., promising not to violate Federal securities laws in the future. The S.E.C. imposed no penalties.

headline: Lazard Senior Partner To Coordinate Change
abstract: Michel Alexandre David-Weill, the chairman of a new partnership intended to forge closer links between Lazard's independently-run banking houses in New York, Paris and London, admits he is very excited by the new arrangement.    ''Already I feel a fantastic current of interchange between the firms,'' said Mr. David-Weill, 51, senior partner of Lazard Fr eres in New York and of Lazard Fr eres & Cie. in Paris, in a telephone interview. ''It's rather amazing. There's much more openess and less secrecy'' between the three houses now.

headline: REAGAN AGAIN ASKS A SOVIET DIALOGUE
abstract: President Reagan has sent a congratulatory note to Konstantin U. Chernenko on his assumption of the Soviet presidency last week. Mr. Reagan said in the message that he was ready for ''constructive dialogue aimed at reducing the risks of war and the levels of armaments.''    ''We must insure that our differences, however large, are resolved without the use of force,'' he said in the letter, dated April 11. ''And we must seek to build a better set of relationships based on those values that are common to all mankind.''

headline: RETHINKING THE MEANING OF DIVIDENDS
abstract: DIVIDENDS may not be the stuff of suspense novels, but so far this year they have made headlines. A reinvigorated Chrysler reinstated its quarterly payout, American Telephone and Telegraph threatened to cut its dividend for the first time ever, two big utilities - Long Island Lighting and Public Service of New Hampshire - halted their common stock dividends, and just last week, General Motors surprised Wall Street by raising its quarterly payout by 25 percent.     But whether dividends are actually good for shareholders is not altogether clear. While some old-line companies, such as General Electric, have paid dividends for years, rapid-growth, high- tech concerns, such as Apple Computer, often do not pay dividends at all. Nor is the meaning of dividend changes easy to decipher.

headline: U.S. SURGICAL'S CHECKERED HISTORY
abstract: NORWALK, CONN.      IT was one of those quirks of fate.   Back in the spring of 1963, Leon   Hirsch recalls, he was talking with a patent broker about helicopter frames, when he spied a bizarre contraption lying on the broker's desk and picked it up, wondering what it could be.   It was a Russian surgical stapler, a device that closed wounds mechanically so a surgeon didn't have to stitch them up with needle and thread. A hopelessly clumsy instrument, it was seen as a kind of medical curiosity.

headline: PAPUA NEW GUINEA GREETS POPE WITH RELAXED JOY
abstract: Pope John Paul II received a joyous and informal welcome here today as he arrived from South Korea on the second leg of his Far Eastern tour.    After the military formality and precision of his four-day South Korean stay, the Pope responded with delighted warmth to the relaxed and spontaneous airport reception and the cheers that accompanied him as his open vehicle made its way through town to Hubert Murray Stadium, a rugby field where he celebrated a floodlighted evening mass.   At the airport, where he was welcomed with a 21-gun salute, each round was greeted by the welcoming crowd with squeals of delight. A strong wind blew the smoke from each round back on the papal party and the welcomers led by the Governor General, Sir Kingsford Dibela, and Prime Minister Michael Somare, causing much laughter.

headline: Market Place; The Confusion Over Shell Bid
abstract: STOCKHOLDERS of the Shell Oil Company surely must be confused by now whether the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, which owns nearly 70 percent of Shell, is offering a fair price to get the rest.     Thousands of them have already tendered their shares to Royal Dutch at $58 each. Royal Dutch has cautioned them in a telephone campaign that $58 is the best it will offer for at least 18 months and that, once the offer expires, the stock could go back to its previous $40 price.    But under a court order expected to be issued today in a class-action suit by Shell stockholders, they would be given the opportunity to take back their shares. This would give investors another chance to decide what to do with their stock after Royal Dutch and its adviser, Morgan Stanley & Company, provide them with additional information about the value of the shares.

headline: TEMPLE RAID: ARMY'S ORDER WAS RESTRAINT
abstract: The Indian Army that captured the Sikhs' Golden Temple here last week was under orders to damage the shrine as little as possible, the officers who led the assault said today.   Lieut. Gen. Ranjit Singh Dyal, a Sikh who was in overall charge of the temple assault, told the first foreign reporters who were allowed into the temple complex that he consequently decided to use only infantrymen, armed only with small arms.   Maj. Gen. K. S. Brar, the immediate commander of the temple operations, told the reporters, who were given a conducted tour of the temple grounds, ''It was a very difficult, sensitive task.''    During the tour today there was no one in the temple complex but the reporters and the military, and the visitors were not given an opportunity to talk to people in the streets of Amritsar to compare their version of events with the army's.

headline: People
abstract: *  Gordon L. Link has joined McCann- Erickson USA as executive vice president and director of media services.

headline: D'AUBUISSON BACKERS PREDICT A LOSS
abstract: Many supporters of the presidential candidate of the far right say privately that they will lose the runoff election Sunday because of what they term the negative tone of their campaign and their candidate's reputation as a man associated with death squads.    Some of the supporters of Roberto d'Aubuisson, the candidate of the far- right Nationalist Republican Alliance, said in interviews this week that they were skeptical the ability of Mr. d'Aubuisson's opponent, Jose Napoleon Duarte of the moderate Christian Democratic Party, to unify the country, and they predicted he would be vindictive as President. But they indicated a willingness to accept the election results and to see what Mr. Duarte does in office.   The supporters of Mr. d'Aubuisson said that the reaction of extremist fringe groups associated with death squads could not be controlled but that they did not expect a destabilizing level of violence after the elections.

headline: Hewlett's Net Jumps 29.4%
abstract: The Hewlett-Packard Company reported yesterday that its earnings in the fiscal second quarter rose 29.4 percent, on a rise in sales of 29.9 percent.

headline: FOR MRS. REAGAN, A DAY FOR CHILDREN
abstract: Amid bobbing yellow balloons and waving British and American flags, Nancy Reagan toured the London Zoo today accompanied by 41 children, in her only official engagement during the seven-nation economic summit meeting that ends here Saturday.   Criticized by the British press on previous visits for her busy social schedule and her refusal to curtsy to the Queen, the First Lady is keeping in the background during her third trip to Britain. She has given no interviews.

headline: NURSING AM INTERNATIONAL BACK TO HEALTH
abstract: TIMOTHY S. JARRELL    CHICAGO SHORTLY after Merle H. Banta   was elected chairman of the   financially troubled AM International Inc. in January, he received a present from one of the company's creditors: a poster of a baby chick that has just pecked its way out of the shell, asking, ''Now what do I do?''   Mr. Banta, who has the poster taped to his office wall, does not yet have the answer to that question. But for AM, it is an old refrain. The darling of Wall Street analysts back when it was known as the Addressograph-Multigraph Corporation, AM has now come full circle.   The cycle began when former chairman Roy L. Ash tried to make AM grow by expanding from outdated office machines into high technology. That decision led to the staggering losses that the next two chairmen, Richard Black and Joe B. Freeman Jr., stanched only by selling the high- tech acquisitions and going back to the old core businesses: offset duplicators, photo-typesetters and engineering graphics products.

headline: AIDES DEFEND ARGENTINE LOAN
abstract: Although American banks benefited from a $500 million loan that the Treasury organized recently for Argentina, senior Treasury and Federal Reserve officials testified in Congress today that this had not been their main objective.    The loan agreement helped the banks ''avoid an unpleasant earnings experience,'' David C. Mulford, Assistant Secretary for International Affairs, told skeptical Representatives of both parties on the House subcommittee on international trade.    ''We were motivated solely by our concern for Argentina,'' Mr. Mulford said, and for other developing-country debtors. If American banks' loans to the country had been declared nonaccruing, indicating that interest payments were more than 90 days overdue, he said, some banks would have stopped making loans that the countries rely on for development.

headline: C.D. Rates Go Higher
abstract: Annual effective yields on six- month certificates of deposit continued an upward trend, averaging 9.97 percent, up from 9.91 the previous week, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index. The six- month products have reached their highest levels since the October 1983 deregulation.

headline: Reaction By Vatican
abstract: The office of Archbishop Paul C. Marcinkus today dismissed as ''preposterous'' reports that a loan made by the Vatican bank he heads might be improper.   The Milan state prosecutor, Maurizio Grigo, said in a telephone interview that the American Archbishop and two other top Vatican bank officials had been notified they were being investigated in connection with the 1972 loan.

headline: LATIN CHIEFS ASK SUMMIT DEBT STEPS
abstract: Seven Latin American heads of government sent a plea today to participants at the economic summit meeting that begins here Thursday evening, urging them to initiate steps to ease Latin America's debt burden.     The plea, coming on top of renewed criticism of American economic policy by West German and French officials, threatens to strain the relaxed and optimistic atmosphere that the United States and British Governments are encouraging. They have presented the meeting as an occasion for the seven major industrial powers to congratulate themselves on the success of their economic policies and to declare that major new initiatives are unnecessary.   The Latin plea, in the form of a letter to the British Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, who is chairman of the three-day meeting, is signed by the Presidents of Brazil, Mexico, Argentina, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Venezuela. Collectively these countries owe Western and Japanese banks and governments about $350 billion.

headline: U.S. STEPS UP PLANNING FOR POSSIBLE OIL CUTOFF
abstract: The Government and the oil industry, prompted by intensified fighting in the Persian Gulf, have stepped up efforts to determine how to respond to a possible cutoff of oil shipments through the gulf.    Although the complete loss of the seven million barrels a day that flow through the Strait of Hormuz is regarded as unlikely, and four million barrels a day could quickly be made up by other producers, the situation is so volatile and uncertain that it has prompted the Reagan Administration and Congress to review the adequacy of preparedness plans.   So far, the intensified fighting in the gulf has caused virtually no reduction in the flow of oil to the West and Japan. The markets, with oil in abundant supply, have generally remained calm. Insurance premiums on cargoes and hulls have soared, but that has largely been offset by equivalent price-cutting by gulf producers eager to sell their oil.

headline: ;  Airline Offering
abstract: A $60 million issue of 14 3/4 percent secured certificates of People Express Airlines is offered at a price of 97 1/4 to yield 15.22 percent to maturity in 1999, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. The certificates, rated Ba-2 by Moody's, are secured by aircraft.

headline: COSTA RICA SEEKS U.S. ARMS AID
abstract: A State Department official said today that the United States received a request for emergency military aid from Costa Rica last week totaling more than $7.5 million.   The official said the request was mainly for small arms, machine guns and ammunition for the lightly equipped Costa Rican security forces.

headline: Swiss Protester Run Down
abstract: A cyclist who sat down on a busy roadway to protest traffic was run down and and badly injured by a car today.

headline: Continental Rally
abstract: The stock of the Continental Illinois Corporation rallied yesterday, following a sharp decline Thursday on rumors about the bank's financial situation.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
abstract: Georgia Power Bonds Priced to Yield 16.02%        The Georgia Power Company, a subsidiary of the Atlanta-based Southern Company, yesterday offered $150 million worth of 30-year, first mortgage bonds due June 1, 2014, at competitive bid.    As the first such offering in some time of long-term paper by a medium-grade electric utility, the issue, which was won by the Paine Webber Group, was watched closely by analysts.

headline: Massey Profit First in 4 Years
abstract: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., which has lost more than $1 billion since 1978, today announced its first quarterly profit in four years. The company, at its annual meeting, reported profits of $2.4 million for the quarter ended April 30, compared with a loss of $17.9 million in the period a year earlier.

headline: FREE-MARKET BELIEVER
abstract: ONE of George P. Shultz's first moves when he became Secretary of State in late June 1982 was to appoint W. Allen Wallis to a key position in the department. That should have been no surprise. The two economists had developed a fast friendship in the mid-50's, when Mr. Wallis, then dean of the Chicago Graduate School of Business, hired Mr. Shultz to be a professor of industrial relations.    After the stormy days of his predecessor, Alexander M. Haig Jr., as Secretary of State, ''George Shultz wanted to bring in several people in whom he had great confidence and whose loyalty he did not doubt in the slightest,'' recalled another noted Chicago professor, Nobel laureate economist George Stigler.

headline: BOSTON BANK PLANS OUT-OF-STATE UNITS
abstract: The Bank of Boston Corporation said yesterday that it had filed applications to establish consumer banks in 16 locations in 10 states along the East Coast and in the South, including New York City.   The Bank of Boston, which made the filing with the Comptroller of the Currency, follows other banks in recent weeks in making use of a loophole in Federal law to avoid restrictions on interstate banking.

headline: Israel Court Orders Candidate To Begin a Bribery Jail Term
abstract: Shmuel Flatto-Sharon, a financier wanted in France, today lost a 12-year struggle to stay out of prison.   The Israeli Supreme Court ordered him to jail on Aug. 8 to start a three- month sentence for bribery during his campaign for the Israeli Parliament in 1977, which was successful.

headline: Dow Is Off 6.68 as Volume Declines
abstract: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday in less active trading after advancing sharply in the two previous sessions.    The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the minus column throughout the day, finished off 6.68 points, to 1,124.89. In the last two trading sessions the average had climbed almost 27 points.

headline: ARGENTINE COURT FREES EX-PRESIDENT
abstract: The Argentine military's highest court today ordered former President Reynaldo B. Bignone freed from barracks arrest.   Major General Bignone, who ended eight years of military rule by turning over power to the elected Government of President Raul Alfonsin in December, was indicted and jailed in January on charges of covering up the disappearance of two draftees under his command when he was head of the Military College in 1976.   The court's ruling angered human rights leaders but was expected to lessen resentments inside the military.   The Supreme Military Tribunal, a nine-member court martial board, allowed General Bignone to go home this morning after he testified behind closed doors for nearly three hours. The charges against him, though, are still under investigation, and he was ordered to be at the court's disposition, court officers said.

headline: REAGAN MAY PRESS FOR SALVADOR AID
abstract: White House officials, alarmed about the military situation in El Salvador, expect President Reagan to give a televised address this month charging that Congress will be to blame if the Salvadoran Government is not given the military aid he says it needs.   ''It's extremely important that the President lay it out for the American people so they know what's involved,'' a senior White House official said today. ''The people should know that if El Salvador goes down the tube, it'll be the result of the failure of appropriations by Congress.''   The source of concern among White House aides was said to be recent intelligence reports that a major Cuban- sponsored guerrilla offensive is being planned in El Salvador this fall, timed for the height of the American election campaign.

headline: HOMESTEAD FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ARGENTINA FACES ANOTHER DEADLINE
abstract: Argentina teetered on the brink.  A last-minute loan for $500 million, put together by United States officials, appeared imminent late Friday to save Argentina from becoming the first nation since the eruption of the foreign debt crisis to have its loans declared nonperforming. The emergency loan would allow Argentina to pay some of the $650 million in interest that must be paid by this weekend if United States banks are to avoid a sharp reduction in first-quarter earnings. In the talks leading up to the loan agreement on Friday, Argentina's blunt-talking Economics Minister, Bernardo Grinspun, said the banks' accounting problems were not his concern. His nation, now $47 billion in debt, has an estimated $1 billion in reserve, but Mr. Grinspun wants to use the funds at home, and put off payments on the nation's foreign debt until later in the spring, at the earliest.   The Bank of Boston said that if it had to declare its $100 million in loans to Argentina as nonperforming, its first-quarter earnings would suffer ''substantially.''

headline: Meredith Start-Up
abstract: The Meredith Corporation, a publisher that feels particularly comfortable covering homey topics, is next going to bring out Wood, a six-times- a-year magazine about woodworking.

headline: U.S. PAPERS TELL OF '53 POLICY TO USE A-BOMB IN KOREA
abstract: Documents released today give details on a decision by President Dwight D. Eisenhower's Administration in 1953 to use atomic bombs in North Korea and Communist China, if necessary, to end the Korean War.   Once the armistice was achieved, on July 27, 1953, the Eisenhower Administration continued to define plans to use nuclear weapons if the Communists renewed the war, which the North Koreans started in 1950.   President Eisenhower took office in January 1953 after talks for a cease-fire had dragged on for two years and the war had settled into a standoff, with casualties being incurred but with no change in the front line, which today still separates North and South Korea.   The fact that the Eisenhower Administration was ready to use nuclear weapons is not new. President Eisenhower, in his memoirs, said he came into office prepared to use them, if necessary, to break the deadlock. What is new in the 2,000 pages of documents now made public is the high level of planning and the detail of discussion on possible use of these weapons, and Mr. Eisenhower's interest in overcoming reluctance to use them.

headline: CARRIERS RAISE SOME AIR FARES
abstract: Most of the nation's major airlines raised some of their fares as of May 1, in a move led by American Airlines.    American based the increases on a comprehensive plan that it introduced in March 1983 that links fares to distance traveled, eliminating many discount fares. That plan was also adopted by most of the other airlines.

headline: ;  People
abstract: *  Louis M. Schultz has been named executive vice president and director of media services for Campbell- Ewald.     *  Larry Levenson is joining Henderson Friedlich Graf & Doyle as senior vice president and co-creative director.     *  Patrick J. O'Shea appointed senior vice president, marketing and planning for Air Florida.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Ad Pages Up 13.7%
abstract: The Magazine Publishers Association has announced that member magazines of the Publishers Information Bureau increased their advertising pages a healthy 13.7 percent in April over the same month last year and their advertising revenues 23.9 percent. The totals were 13,824 pages and $$425.1 million.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; AM International Files Debt Repayment Plan
abstract: AM International has filed a plan listing provisions for repaying about $285 million in debts that accumulated before the company filed two years ago for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy regulations.    The plan, submitted in United States Bankruptcy Court, calls for distribution of about $201 million in cash and 40 million shares of new common stock, the company said in a statement.

headline: Press Group Criticizes Closure of Israeli Paper
abstract: The International Press Institute has sent a cable to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel protesting his Government's decision to close an Israeli daily for four days for violating military censorship.   Peter Galliner, director of the international press organization, said in a cable Friday to Mr. Shamir that the closure of the newspaper, Hadashot, caused ''dismay and concern throughout the free world, and we urge you and your Defense Minister to insure that such actions do not take place.''

headline: Europe Trade Rise Pledged
