abstract: Members of the European Economic Community and the European Free Trade Association ended their first joint meeting today, pledging to extend free trade throughout Western Europe and to ''oppose protectionist pressures.''   In a statement, foreign ministers of the 17 nations said that with the end this year of the ''last remaining tariff barriers and quantitive restrictions'' in trade, their countries ''have attained the goal set more than 10 years ago.''

headline: A BULLISH BENT FOR MARKET TECHNICICANS
abstract: TO the average investor, technical stock market indicators might as well be written in   Sanskrit. Closely followed, but not always understood, these indicators - which are used to predict broad market movements on the basis of historic price and trading volume patterns - can prove frustratingly enigmatic. But a knowledge of what technical indicators are saying has proved a valuable resource to many investors, both large and small.    It requires a minor education to interpret the tea-leaf patterns of the technician's breadth-momentum indicators, sentiment indicators and monetary indicators, as well as a good Wall Street lexicon. The insider buy-sell ratio can seem to say something different than the Big Board specialist short sale ratio. The 10-day New York Stock Exchange volume index can appear to throw off different signals than the 30-day advance-decline ratio. But for those who believe in their prophetic wisdom, technical indicators almost always have a story to tell about the coming movement of stock prices.

headline: ISRAEL VOWS TO REPLY ON TERROR
abstract: The Israeli Cabinet secretary, speaking after the Cabinet met to review last week's hijacking of a civilian bus by Palestinian guerrillas, said today that Israel would respond ''appropriately'' to any future terrorist attacks,   After the meeting, some officials said Israel held the Syrian Government responsible for the recent increase in terrorism against Israelis.   The Cabinet secretary, Dan Meridor, did not mention Syria by name in his statement.

headline: American Stores
abstract: The American Stores Company said stock representing 67 percent of all common shares outstanding of the Jewel Companies had been tendered to it in an acquisition valued at up to $1.1 billion.

headline: Accounts
abstract: *    *    * Campbell Soup Co., to Richardson, Myers & Donofrio in Baltimore, for its affiliate, Triangle Manufacturing Corp., Raleigh, N.C. - ADVERTISING

headline: CONTADORA GROUP'S ENVOYS VISIT NICARAGUA
abstract: Foreign ministers of the four-nation Contadora Group began a tour of Central America today, seeking a peace treaty for the troubled region.   The Foreign Ministers of Colombia, Mexico, Panama and Venezuela arrived in Managua from San Jose, Costa Rica, where they had a 90-minute conversation with the Vice President, Alberto Fait.

headline: People
abstract: *  Robert W. Hinson of Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson, named media director for The Tuesday Team, the advertising unit created to handle the re-election effort of the Reagan-Bush ticket.

headline: Chock Full To End Bid, Add Official
abstract: The Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation yesterday abruptly withdrew an offer to acquire the financially troubled Chase & Sanborn Corporation, clearing the way for Hills Brothers Coffee to acquire Chase & Sanborn. But Chock Full o'Nuts then said that once Chase's assets are sold, Arthur R. Berman, Chase's president and chief executive, would join Chock Full o'Nuts as president and chief operating officer.     Mr. Berman, 42, said in an interview that an agreement about his affiliation with Chock Full o'Nuts was reached last Thursday.

headline: I.B.M. CUTS PRICES ON PC LINE
abstract: In a move to step up pressure on competitors, the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday announced deep price cuts on its entire Personal Computer line, including its troubled PCjr home computer. The reductions, which have long been expected in the industry, range from 18 percent to about 23 percent.    The computer giant, whose three- year-old Personal Computer has become an industry standard, also quadrupled the amount of internal memory it offers with its entry-level models - making even the most basic machines capable of running some of the most popular and increasingly complex software packages.    But it did not announce any changes in the much-criticized design of the PCjr, which has floundered since its introduction in January.

headline: Details of Seabrook Rescue Bid; Exchange of Power Involved
abstract: The Federal Government has agreed to back a new deal that will help save the troubled Seabrook nuclear project because the revised arrangement will leave the New Hampshire Electric Cooperative with a plant no matter what the fate of Seabrook, according to the Rural Electrification Administration.   Under the plan, which was described yesterday at a meeting of the 16 partners in the project, the cooperative will pay the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, the main Seabrook builder, $57 million that the company needs to convince investors that it can pay interest on new loans. In exchange, Public Serice will give the cooperative 38 mega-watts of power from its holdings in existing nuclear plants, probably Maine Yankee, a 12-year-old reactor in Wiscasset, Me.   This deal is in addition to the co-op's 2.2 percent ownership of Seabrook 1. The R.E.A. is already backing the co-op's participation in the Seabrook project, but the co-op, like Public Service's other 14 partners, is in danger of losing its investment if Public Service is forced into bankruptcy. Public Service is almost completely out of cash and is counting on the completion of a new financing package for Seabrook to allow it to return to the credit markets.

headline: GREATER FINANCIAL ACCESS TO JAPAN IS EXPECTED
abstract: Following two days of talks here with Japanese financial officials, the Reagan Administration expects Japan shortly to announce measures to provide greater access to the Tokyo capital market by foreign financial institutions, it was announced today.    Beryl W. Sprinkel, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, said at a news conference: ''I believe that substantial improvements in current conditions will be forthcoming.''    But he said it would not be appropriate for him to specify what the Japanese Government might do. Treasury officials said they expected Japan to take measures that would, for example, permit foreign banks to borrow more yen in Japan or to provide specialized financial services, such as trust account management.

headline: Sikhs' Golden Temple Closed by Indian Army
abstract: Indian authorities closed the Golden Temple in Amritsar today, a day after the holiest Sikh shrine was reopened for the first time since army troops stormed the complex three weeks ago.

headline: BRIEFS ;  Debt Issues
abstract: CPC International Inc., a grocery products company in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., said it had completed the sale of $75 million of senior extendable notes due June 1991. Salomon Brothers assisted in the private placing of the notes with institutional investors.     * Citicorp said it had sold $100 million of 91-day paper at 11.189 percent, down from 11.195 percent last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at 11.355 percent, down from 11.563 percent.

headline: SATURDAY, MAY 19, 1984
abstract: The Economy    The economy surged ahead at an 8.8 percent annual rate in the first quarter and after-tax corporate profits rose in the quarter, following a dip late in 1983. The figures were seen as new evidence that the recovery will continue well into 1985. (1.)   The Senate approved a budget resolution for fiscal year 1985, projecting a deficit of $181.7 billion. (9.)   Companies    The run on Continental Illinois has apparently been halted by the $7.5 billion emergency aid package extended by the U.S. and private banks. The rescue package also helped to calm world financial markets. (Page 1.) Government architects of the plan describe what was probably the quickest defense of a failing bank ever undertaken by Washington. (33.)

headline: No Headline
abstract: SAMUEL SLATER was a sneak. Despite Britain's tight laws preventing anyone who knew the secrets of the thriving textile mills from leaving the country, the 21-year-old apprentice in Richard Arkwright's Derbyshire mills disguised himself as a farmhand and, in 1789, dashed off to the United States. There he promptly re-created the Arkwright mill from memory and gave birth to the industry that was to nurture New England's economy for generations.   History does not record what his British bosses said, but the dismay they must have felt two centuries ago about the theft of their cloth-making secrets is a thoroughly modern phenomenon. The enormous fracas two years ago over Hitachi's attempts to buy secret information about I.B.M.'s computers - and the International Business Machines Corporation's aggressive litigation against former employees who have gone off knowing too much - is only the tip of the iceberg:      * The international marketing director of Medtronic, the world's largest heart pacemaker producer, was indicted in December in connection with a plan to sell trade secrets to Cordis Laboratories, a rival company. James J. Krieger, the executive, was arrested in Miami while delivering 19 confidential documents to an undercover agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The excuse: Mr. Krieger claims he was insane at the time.

headline: No Headline
abstract: The first semi-submersible oil drilling rig built in China was completed today at the Shanghai Shipyard, the New China News Agency reported.

headline: Penney Property
abstract: The J. C. Penney Company and Western National Properties said they had formed a joint venture to develop an apartment community in Orange, Calif., containing more than 500 units. Penney said the project is the first residential real estate venture undertaken by its real estate subsidiary, JCP Realty Inc. The value of the completed project is estimated at $30 million.

headline: Husky Oil Project
abstract: Husky Oil Ltd. said it planned to build a $3.5 billion (Canadian) crude-oil upgrading plant in Saskatchewan, the largest Canadian energy project in five and one-half years. Company officials declined to give further details of the project, but industry sources said it would be supported by more than $1 billion in Government-guaranteed loans. The plant will process 50,000 barrels of heavy crude oil a day into high-grade crude.

headline: MARKETS ROLE AIDS GROWTH AT REUTERS
abstract: For millions of newspaper readers, the name Reuters has been familiar for more than a century on news stories from every corner of the globe. But to investors considering the merits of Reuters' 114 million-share stock offering that will come on the market here and in New York Thursday, the company's main attraction is its other, nonnews side.   The stock issue, which is meant to raise up to $370 million for Reuters' institutional and newspaper owners, is structured to leave up to 28 percent of the company in public hands. The actual share price will be set Thursday on the basis of tenders and consultation between investment bankers here and in New York.

headline: A NOSE FOR TALENT-- AND FOR TRADITION
abstract: IN 1953, Lee Stevens turned down a    job in the accounting department   of the William Morris Agency to work in the mailroom. At $35 a week, the mailroom job was less lucrative, but Mr. Stevens took it because that was the traditional place where would-be agents started out. ''The only way to learn the agency business is by osmosis,'' he explained.   Tradition prevailed, as it tends to at William Morris, the oldest and one of the largest talent agencies, with 500 agents worldwide. Next month, Mr. Stevens, who is 53 and has run the New York office for the past four years, will become the agency's president.

headline: Chartercorp In Settlement
abstract: Chartercorp said that Stanley Durwood and three companies he controls had agreed not to acquire or offer to acquire any shares of Chartercorp for 10 years. They also agreed not to solicit proxies or otherwise act to seek control or to influence the company's management, board or policies.

headline: JACKSON BIDS ASSAD FREE ISRAELIS
abstract: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that he had sent an appeal to President Hafez al- Assad of Syria urging him to release three Israeli diplomats.   Mr. Jackson sent a telegram to the Syrian President Thursday from San Antonio, where he is campaigning for the Democratic nomination for President.

headline: Banks Trying to Lure Last-Minute I.R.A.'s
abstract: As taxpayers race to meet the Monday income tax filing deadline, a number of banks in New York City and elsewhere are opening up their branch offices this weekend in hopes of luring more people to sign up for Individual Retirement Accounts.    Deposits made to the account by midnight Monday can be claimed as a deduction on 1983 tax returns.

headline: REAGAN DISMISSES SATELLITE ARMS TALKS
abstract: President Reagan cautioned Congress today against seeking talks on control of weapons designed to destroy orbiting satellites.    The President asserted that antisatellite controls are unverifiable and that the United States needed to complete an antisatellite missile system to deter the Soviet Union.   ''Until we have determined whether there are, in fact, practical solutions to these problems,'' Mr. Reagan said in a letter to Congress. ''I do not believe it would be productive to engage in formal international negotiations.''

headline: EUROPEANS AIM ACTION AT I.B.M.
abstract: The Commission of the European Economic Community will charge the International Business Machines Corporation in June with abusing its dominant market position in Europe to stifle competition, a Common Market official in Brussels said yesterday.    The action would end what experts say is the longest and most complex antitrust investigation in the history of the Common Market, and it could significantly alter I.B.M.'s business practices and competitive edge in the multibillion-dollar European market.   The Common Market official, who declined to be identified, said that a preliminary decision to make the charge had already been drafted but that it was not clear what sanctions the computer giant might face.   Negotiating Pressure Seen    Some analysts in the United States suggested that the Europeans might have disclosed the decision in an effort to force I.B.M., now negotiating with the Commission, into a settlement agreeable to the Common Market's 10 member countries. The Commission, the Common Market's executive body, has reportedly already rejected one compromise plan offered by the company.

headline: SEABROOK UTILITY BARS DIVIDENDS
abstract: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire omitted dividends yesterday on both common and preferred stock for the first quarter. The utility, squeezed by ever-rising costs at the Seabrook nuclear power project, also ordered more layoffs and salary reductions, for a total saving of $38 million this year.    The company's auditors said Public Service may be in default by next week unless it is able to secure additional credit. The company has a 35.5 percent share in the two Seabrook reactors, which are over budget by $6 billion to $8 billion, depending on the estimate used. Public Service is building the reactors as the head of a group of New England utilities.

headline: LESS BUOYANT HOUSING VIEW
abstract: The U.S. Home Corporation, based in Houston, is one of the nation's largest home builders, with operations in 28 states. Its main product is the single-family attached or detached home for the first- time buyer.    The housing industry, whose fortunes are tied to interest rates, has weathered some bad times in the last few years as rates climbed. In 1983, sales and earnings benefited from lower interest rates on mortgages. Last month, the number of housing starts shot up, largely reflecting a comeback from depressed levels in March, when bad weather hampered builders.

headline: NEW BANK OF AMERICA CENTER IN CITY
abstract: The Bank of America, long considered an out-of-town cousin when it comes to New York financial dealings, formally opened its new regional headquarters on Madison Avenue yesterday.     To do so, it had gutted the Biltmore Hotel and its famous Palm Court.    But the San Francisco-based bank retained the legendary Biltmore lobby clock as the centerpiece of the renovated 28-story structure, perhaps hoping to receive the kind of attention that the clock had as the designated New York meeting place for people the world over.

headline: Loews Profits Off 14.6%
abstract: The Loews Corporation reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter fell 14.6 percent as revenues slipped 3.3 percent from the comparable period a year ago. Loews, which has interests in insurance, hotels and tobacco, said that net income dropped to $65.9 million, or $2.43 a share, from $77.2 million, or $2.75 a share. Revenues fell to $1.28 billion, from $1.32 billion.

headline: Mexico Buys Wheat
abstract: Mexico has purchased 242,000 tons of weather-damaged wheat from Australia, the Australian Wheat Board said today. Mev Connell, acting general manager of the wheat marketing panel, said the sale was the first to Mexico in 40 years and that Mexico had indicated it might become a regular buyer of damaged wheat for its livestock industries.

headline: EMPHASIS ON TECHNICAL INDICATORS
abstract: Pems Market Trend Analyzer   Hardware Requirements: 128K internal memory, at least one double- sided disk drive. I.B.M. color adapter and color display recommended, graphics printer, modem for a separate communications package. Price: $350 for basic program. Available from Personal Equity Computing, Ocean, N.J.       Trend Analyzer is a different type of technical analysis program. Instead of focusing on individual stocks, the Pems - short for Personal Equity Management Systems - covers close to 50 indicators of overall market activity, everything from the Dow Jones industrial average to the Specialist Short-Sale Ratio. The premise is that successful investing depends on an examination of the market as a whole first, and individual stocks second.

headline: Austria Prices Up 0.3%
abstract: Consumer prices in Austria rose three- tenths of 1 percent in March from February and were up 5.8 percent from March 1983, the Central Statistics Office said today.

headline: Beating at Police Station Cited in Polish Death
abstract: A team of medical experts told a court today that a beating that killed a supporter of the outlawed Solidarity labor federation must have been inflicted while he was in custody at a police station.   Dr. Andrzej Jaglinski, who represented the team, concluded that the police station was the only place that Grzegorz Przemyk, 19 years old, could have been fatally beaten between the time he was detained on a disorderly conduct charge and two days later, when he died.

headline: JUSTICE DEPT. SUES TO BAR TAX SHELTER
abstract: The Justice Department filed suit today to block the promotion of a tax shelter involving the sale of vacation time- share interests in a still-unfinished hotel in Barbados. The suit asserts that the promotion violated several provisions of the tax code.    Assistant Attorney General Glenn L. Archer Jr., head of the department's tax division, said the shelter promotion in the Admiral Beach Hotel was one of the largest in the nation.   More than $200 million in Federal income tax deductions could result from the 1,000 units already sold, he said. And if the promoters were able to sell the 30,000 units they planned to offer, he said, improper deductions would exceed $6 billion, with a potential tax loss to the Treasury of about $3 billion.

headline: Three Children in West Beirut Are Killed Playing With Shell
abstract: Three children playing with an artillery shell on a West Beirut street were killed today when the shell exploded.

headline: FRENCH CRITICIZE SOVIET AS NATO MEETING BEGINS
abstract: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson of France accused the Soviet Union today of trying to intimidate the Western powers and of having contempt for human rights.   Speaking at the opening ceremonies of the 35th annual spring Foreign Ministers meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Mr. Cheysson, the honorary chairman for the three- day session, said the NATO countries were ready to work for agreements with the Soviet bloc but that the Soviet Union was not pursuing the same course.   His comments were echoed by Vice President Bush, who told the audience at the State Department, including the 16 Foreign Ministers of the NATO alliance, that Moscow was blazing ''a trail of adventurism'' in the third world.

headline: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
abstract: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.36     An index of yields for long-term   A-rated general obligation bonds   compiled weekly by The Bond   Buyer.   Aa Utility Bonds*14.75     Salomon Brothers' estimate for   new long-term issues.

headline: New Creative Director For Smith, Burke
abstract: Smith, Burke & Azzam of Baltimore is simply crowing over the fact that it has captured Thomas S. Little, who was co-founder of the highly successful McDonald & Little, Atlanta, to be its creative director.

headline: Iraq and Iran Delegates Doubt Early Cease-Fire
abstract: The chief delegates of Iran and Iraq to the United Nations held out little hope today of a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war.   In separate interviews on the CBS News program ''Face the Nation,'' each diplomat repeated his nation's vow to persevere in the conflict.

headline: No Headline
abstract: New Computer From NEC NEC Information Systems, the United States subsidiary of the NEC Corporation, a major Japanese electronics company, introduced a desktop computer to compete with the I.B.M. Personal Computer. The company said its new system would retail for $1,995, including a single disk drive for data storage and 128,000 characters of internal memory.

headline: ;  Ford Executive Named President of Credit Unit
abstract: Stanley A. Seneker has been elected president of the Ford Motor Credit Corporation, the financing arm of the Ford Motor Company.    Mr. Seneker succeeds Kenneth Whipple, who was elected a Ford Motor vice president in March and named to head its corporate strategy and analysis staff.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * CPC International Inc. , a diversified foods company in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., said its Corn Wet Milling division plans to construct a large- scale wheat processing facility at Sas van Gent, The Netherlands.     * Cardinal Capital Corp. of Dallas said it was leading an investment group exploring a possible business combination involving Galaxy Oil Co. and other individuals or business entities. The group members hold 6.6 percent of Galaxy's total outstanding common shares.

headline: ;  Oil Mergers
abstract: To the Editor:      Prof. Charles A.S. Hall of Cornell (''Oil Mergers: The Effect on Drilling,'' Letters, March 25) reminded this reader of the thinking that underpinned the ill-fated National Energy Plan I, first proposed in 1977. Arguments about finite oil and natural gas resources, running out of natural gas, a nuclear resurgence and the switch to electricity were the popular fads of the day. More realistic wellhead prices, the product of the Natural Gas Policy Act of 1978, have demonstrated that this finite resource mentality is wrong. The gas resource base is for practical purposes finite only for a particular set of economic and technological assumptions. The essential point is that technology and economics are constantly changing.

headline: CONFEREES ACT ON FOUNDATIONS
abstract: Conferees from the House and Senate today approved a requirement that private tax-exempt foundations pay out a minimum of 4.35 percent of the value of their investment assets each year as charitable contributions.     The rule marks the first time that Congress has imposed a minimum contribution requirement on foundations. Present law requires a 5 percent payout, but any or all of that can be for operating expenses.

headline: Addenda
abstract: * Scholastic has acquired the rights to Microkids magazine from Microkids Publishing.

headline: Data Bank; May 20, 1984
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: THE DAY THE SIRENS GREATLY ALARMED THE KUWAITIS
abstract: The air-raid sirens wailed at 11 A.M. sharp.    Ample warning of the test was given. For a week Kuwaiti newspapers, radio and television had advertised its date and time.  Nevertheless, the siren's blare sparked temporary panic in many quarters of this Persian Gulf nation.

headline: BIG TELECOMMUNICATIONS TRADE GAP SEEN
abstract: Through the breakup of the American telephone monopoly and other moves toward deregulation, the United States is opening up its telecommunications market to foreign competitors at a much faster clip than foreign countries are opening their markets to the United States, a Government study showed today.    The 218-page report by the International Trade Commission said that American telecommunication equipment imports exceeded exports last year for the first time, and predicted a trade deficit in such equipment of $3 billion by 1993.    The commission, an independent investigative agency with jurisdiction over trade laws, began the study last December at the request of John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, the chairman of the Senate Trade Subcommittee. It was the first time that any government body has examined the trade implications of the breakup of the 22 Bell operating companies, effective last Jan. 1.

headline: ADVERTISING;
abstract: Computer Account To Fredericks Kullberg      Fredericks Kullberg Amato Piscane had a get-together at its 15 West 44th Street location last night ''in celebration of life, love, success, beauty and continued solvency,'' as well as its first anniversary.

headline: ;  Dean Witter Analyst Named Research Chief
abstract: Lawrence Adelman, a senior vice president and securities analyst who has covered the food, beverage and tobacco industries at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. since 1978, yesterday was named the company's director of research.    Mr. Adelman, 44, succeeds Lee H. Idleman, who resigned last month to become director of research at Neuberger & Berman, a smaller Wall Street house.    ''Lee wanted the opportunity to go back to a smaller firm and was looking for the opportunity to become an active portfolio manager,'' Mr. Adelman said in an interview. ''I owe a lot of my success to him.''

headline: Xerox Typewriter Offered for $4,900
abstract: The Xerox Corporation introduced an electronic typewriter capable of word word processing, the $4,900 Memorywriter 640. The machine has a display that shows 20 lines of type and a control panel that moves a cursor and performs other word processing.

headline: Bank of Boston Awaiting Data
abstract: The last-minute financial moves to head off an Argentine default came just as the Bank of Boston Corporation prepared to place a third of its $300 million interest exposure in that country on a nonaccrual basis, a bank official said yesterday. Barry M. Allen, first vice president of the bank, said, ''Now everything is up in the air, but we really don't have to do anything until the bank's accounts for the quarter are analyzed and this normally takes about 10 to 12 days after the end of a calendar period.''

headline: Staff Reduced At Visicorp
abstract: Visicorp, the privately held software company that marketed the first popular electronic spreadsheet, said that it had laid off 40 employees, about 20 percent of its staff, to reduce operating overhead. ''We are still growing,'' Ronald D. Fisher, vice president of marketing for the San Jose, Calif. company, said.

headline: American Slain in Mexico
abstract: An American employee of the Agriculture Department has been found shot to death in northern Mexico beside his United States Government vehicle, Mexican officials and the United States Embassy said today. William H. Cross, who worked for the Agriculture Department in Starkville, Miss., was found Monday about 60 miles west of Durango on the route to the Pacific resort of Mazatlan. All objects of value except a wedding ring were missing.

headline: Rights Group Assails Killings in Libya
abstract: Amnesty International today appealed to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, to stop what it called liquidation of his opponents. The London-based human rights organization expressed alarm at the execution of seven Libyans between June 3 and 7, saying they ''had all been arbitrarily arrested and hanged publicly withouttrial.   The group also said that hundreds of Libyans had been arrested and that some might have been tortured after an attack May 8 on Mr. Qaddafi's headquarters in Tripoli.

headline: Ratings Lowered For Socal and Gulf
abstract: Ratings were reduced for $1.3 billion of Standard Oil Company of California debt and $1.2 billion of Gulf Corporation debt, Moody's Investors Service said yesterday. The rating agency cited the large amount of borrowing that accompanied Socal's $13.4 billion acquisition of Gulf.

headline: WAITING FOR THE AX TO FALL
abstract: WASHINGTON IN early 1981, when Edward E.   Noble finished his work as head of   Ronald Reagan's transition team studying the Synthetic Fuels Corporation, he came to a very strong conclusion - the fledgling organization was an ill-conceived affront to free enterprise and was embarked on a dubious mission. He flatly recommended that the S.F.C., created with great fanfare the summer before, be abolished.    ''I said that it was a ticking bomb set to go off in 1984,'' he now recalls. ''I didn't know I was going to be quite that prophetic and that I was going to be sitting here when the detonator was pushed.''    Such are the fortunes of men in politics. Mr. Noble, chairman of the Synthetic Fuels Corporation for the past three years, finds himself today in a fierce struggle to keep the corporation alive, while opponents, including many of President Reagan's top advisers, are trying to carry out what Mr. Noble recommended three years ago.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: FRIDAY, APRIL 27, 1984   Companies    Ford Motor earnings rose fourfold, to a record $897.2 million in the first quarter, leading analysts to predict record profits for the industry as a whole. The gains were attributed to higher sales, especially of larger cars. (Page D1.)    Mobil's profits jumped 52 percent and Standard of Ohio posted a 37.5 percent gain, but Texaco's net rose only 0.6 percent. (D16.)

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
abstract: Initial Public Offerings        The dollar volume of initial public offerings doubled in May from April, according to New Issues, an investment service in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.    Norman G. Fosback, the editor of New Issues, said that 41 companies went public in May, only slightly more than the 39 that did so in April.

headline: Braniff Posts Loss in Period
abstract: Braniff Inc. yesterday reported a loss of $30.6 million for its first quarter, ended April 30, which included the company's intital two months of operations as an airline.

headline: ;  International Marketnet Selects Its Top Officers
abstract: International Marketnet, a competitor to such market data services as Telerate, Quotron and Reuters, is on the move with the selection of its top officers.    Merrill Lynch and the International Business Machines Corporation, whose joint venture was formed last March, said in a release yesterday that Joseph P. Castellano, formerly division director of Merrill Lynch's corporate service division, had been appointed as president and chief executive officer of International Marketnet.    Intended to compete initially with companies like Quotron that provide stock quotes, International Marketnet's system will combine I.B.M. computer-based work stations and host computers with market data and financial services programs developed by Merrill Lynch.

headline: D.D.B. Creative LeaderJoins Tuesday Team
abstract: Marvin Honig, the talented agency creative leader, while out at Doyle Dane Bernbach, which once helped defeat Senator Barry Goldwater by electing Lyndon Johnson, is in at the Tuesday Team, the group that has been pulled together to re-elect the Reagan-Bush team. That is the news from James Travis, the Team head.    Among his credentials, Mr. Honig once wrote greeting cards, which means he can be cheerful, and he also wrote the classic ''Groom's First Meal'' commercial for Alka-Seltzer, which shows he can be compassionate.

headline: 40 YEARS AFTER PACIFIC D-DAY, NO CROWDS AND NO PARADES
abstract: Just about no one visited Saipan's velvety beaches this morning to recall D-day in the Pacific part of World War II. The 40th anniversary came and went, bold only in its contrasts with the emotions and speeches that flowed in Normandy on Europe's D-day, June 6.   A few American veterans returned to this Mariana Island, certain that a commemoration would take place. Robert T. Kline of Paoli, Pa., came. So did Frank Moeller of Salt Lake City. Memories moved them. The lack of public acknowledgement disappointed them.

headline: Companies
abstract: Dow Chemical and six other makers of Agent Orange agreed to set up a $180 million fund to compensate thousands of Vietnam veterans and their families who have said they were harmed by exposure to dioxin in the herbicide. Dow and the other companies - Monsanto, Diamond Shamrock, Uniroyal, T.H. Agriculture and Nutrition, Thompson Chemical and Hercules - all denied any liability for the claimants' health problems. (Page A1.) Both the companies and the veterans reserved the right to file claims against the Government; the major companies involved said the accord would not hurt their 1984 earnings materially. (B4.)   MCI is to end monthly fees for long-distance service on July 15. The dropping of the $5 or $10 fees heightens price competition in the long-distance area between A.T.&T. and its rivals. (D1.)

headline: Scot Lad in Talks
abstract: Scot Lad Foods Inc., a food wholesaler based in Lansing, Ill., said it is negotiating the sale of most of its assets, including the company name, to Roundy's Inc. for about $40 million.

headline: CONTROLLING THE PURSE STRINGS ABROAD
abstract: THE recent strength of both the United States   economy and the dollar suggests that sizable   numbers of Americans will once again be traveling abroad in the summer vacation months. And for many of them, the most bewildering part of their journey will be the process of changing their dollars into the local coin of the realm.    For those who haven't been abroad in a few years, perhaps the most important financial news is the increasing acceptance of American credit cards. You may think you've discovered that exotic little island, but chances are that intrepid representatives of American Express and Diners Club have already been there and signed up a host of local hotels, restaurants and merchants. And no matter how exotic the names of the local bank charge plans, if you look closely, you'll see familiar emblems indicating an affiliation with Visa or Mastercard. Carte Bleu in France and Barclaycard in Britain are both Visa affliliates, for example, while in much of Europe, Access and Eurocard are Mastercard affiliates.

headline: A UNIFORM PLAN FOR NEWSPAPER DESIGN
abstract: BY July 1, a sweeping revolution in newspaper design will have taken place that readers may barely notice, but which many big advertisers are greeting with relief.  The change - a minor revolution for the newspaper business - is the standardization of newspaper size and basic format so that the same advertisement will fit perfectly into newspapers from Maine to Hawaii.   The nation's newspapers have brought about this change in an unusual cooperative effort that has cost them collectively an estimated $750 million. But the publishers seem willing to invest even more money and cooperation in their drive to forge the nation's daily newspapers into a single vast network that can compete more effectively for advertising with mass mailers and television.

headline: INSURING COMPANIES FAR FROM HOME
abstract: IT'S been more than five years since    the Iranian revolution, and over   three since the hostage crisis ended. Yet for many of the American companies with major investments in Iran, the nightmare is still not over. Most have filed claims with The Hague Tribunal, set up to disburse the $1.4 billion escrow account established by Iran to compensate such investors.   A few, however, have collected on policies taken out with the Overseas Protection Investment Corporation - or O.P.I.C., a United States Government agency - and the Foreign Credit Insurance Association, an association of 10 private insurance companies formed in cooperation with the Export-Import Bank. The organizations issue what is called ''political risk'' insurance, for foreign investors and exporters, respectively.

headline: Software Arts Reduces Its Staff
abstract: Software Arts, the Wellesley, Mass., company that developed the Visicalc spreadsheet program, said it was laying off 60 of its 125 employees because of greatly reduced revenues.

headline: Stocks Decline, With Dow Off 8.58
abstract: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday in slower trading, with equities responding to specific news posting the biggest price moves.    The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the minus column throughout most of the session, closed off 8.58 points, to 1,149.50. In the general market, losing issues outscored winners by almost a 2-to-1 ratio.

headline: Article 239739 -- No Title
abstract: The Cole National Corporation said yesterday that it was discussing a deal with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the leveraged buyout specialists, under which Cole shareholders would receive $39 a share.    Analysts estimated that the completed transaction - after deducting debt - could be worth about $290 million, based on the company's 7.9 million common shares outstanding.   The stock of the Cleveland-based Cole National, the nation's second- biggest toy retailing chain after Toys ''R'' Us, rose $2.25, to $34, on the New York Stock Exchange on Friday and, after its opening was delayed until 2:51 P.M., advanced another $2.50 yesterday, to close at $36.50.

headline: People
abstract: *  W. L. Abbott , vice president of Nabisco Brands USA, was elected chairman of the American Advertising Federation.

headline: THE ELUSIVE BOOM IN PRODUCTIVITY
abstract: ''THE long-awaited boom in productivity growth is here,'' proclaimed a recent report by Michael J. Drury, senior economist at A. Gary Shilling & Company, an economic consulting group based on Wall Street.     ''I think we are going back to the higher productivity trend we saw between 1948 and 1973,'' said John W. Kendrick, of George Washington University and the American Enterprise Institute, a leading productivity expert.    ''It looks as if we have turned the corner on productivity,'' proclaimed Nestor Terleckyj, an economist at the National Planning Association in Washington. ''Business has sweated out the bad times. I think we have had real structural change.''

headline: BUYOUT BID FOR REVLON WEIGHED
abstract: Revlon Inc. said yesterday that an investor group was trying to put together a leveraged buyout of the giant cosmetics company.    While Revlon would not identify the participants, Wall Street executives said one was Martin E. Revson, the company's former executive vice president. They said the price would likely amount to about $50 a share, or a total of about $1.8 billion.

headline: BEIRUT ECONOMY STILL SQUEAKS BY
abstract: THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN    BEIRUT, LEBANON LEBANON these days has no up-to-   date economic indicators to tell   businessmen which way the economy is going, no fancy government graphs that will outline the latest trends in consumer confidence.    The best way to find out how the Lebanese economy is doing and what both consumers and producers are expecting is to talk to the people who sell window glass.   Window glass has become Lebanon's all-purpose economic indicator. When Beirutis feel confident the fighting is over and are primed to spend and invest again, they go out and replace all of their blown-out windows. When they expect only more clashes and are retrenching, they simply tape up their cracked windowpanes or fill their empty window frames with plastic wrap better suited for sandwiches.

headline: Ingram Sells Its Stake in Corroon
abstract: Ingram Industries said the 628,196 shares of Corroon & Black Inc. held by Ingram and its chairman, E. Bronson Ingram, had been sold separately to six financial institutions.

headline: JAPAN'S WARY FINANCIAL REVOLUTION
abstract: Steve Loh r TOY TRADE talks between two nations typically have   their theatrical aspect, as both sides position for   advantage. Understatement is not part of the formula. Even so, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan's fist-pounding performance in Tokyo last month was extraordinary.

headline: American Maize
abstract: Sol Goldman, a New York real estate investor, has increased his stake in the American Maize-Products Company, the food products and real estate concern, to 613,642 class A common shares, or 16.2 percent of the shares outstanding, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Goldman said he made the purchases for investment purposes.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD
abstract: Beirut Fighting Raises Weekend Deaths to 19    BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 13 (AP) - Sporadic mortar and grenade fire persisted in and around Beirut today.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * A. H.Robins Co., to Jordan, Case & McGrath for a new product.     * New England Journal of Medicine and Interactive Data Corporation, a subsidiary of Chase Manhattan, to Mullen Advertising, Beverly Farms, Mass.

headline: Washington Watch; Clarifying Antitrust Rules
abstract: WASHINGTON     THE off-again, on-again LTV-Republic Steel   merger left many puzzled about the Reagan   Administration's antitrust policy.    The Administration's antitrust chief, J. Paul McGrath, first moved to block the marriage. Then two Cabinet officers and the President said it should go forward. Finally, after the companies agreed to sell off some assets, it did.

headline: NICARAGUAN REBEL EJECTED BY GROUP
abstract: The Costa Rica-based organization of groups battling the Nicaraguan Government voted Monday night to expel Eden Pastora Gomez, one of the rebel leaders, a spokesman for Mr. Pastora said today.   The spokesman, Orion Pastora, said in a telephone interview from Costa Rica that the rebel leader ''has been fighting for democracy in Nicaragua for 25 years and will continue to fight.''   The vote appeared to be a response to Mr. Pastora's refusal to consolidate forces with anti-Sandinista rebels based in Honduras.

headline: Weinberger Confers With Military in Greece
abstract: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, concerned with longstanding problems in Greek-NATO relations and the status of American military bases in Greece, met with senior Greek military officials today.   ''The talks concerned Greek demands from NATO, including a proposal that the United States should supply Greece with 10 Phantom jet fighters to counterbalance 15 supplied to Turkey,'' a statement by the Defense Ministry said.     ANKARA, Turkey, March 31 (Reuters) - Prime Minister Turgut Ozal said today that restrictions on visas for Greeks would be eliminated as a sign of good will.

headline: G.M. Callback
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said it is recalling 1,000 hourly workers from indefinite layoff to augment its components operations, effective Monday. G.M., which did not break down the plants to which the recalled workers will be assigned, said the callbacks would reduce the number of its hourly workers on indefinite layoff with recall rights to 48,000.

headline: LONG DISTANCE PHONE BATTLE
abstract: When historians look back on the war of the long-distance telephone business years hence, they are likely to note the major battle that is being fought here.     The competition in Charleston has the American Telephone and Telegraph Company testing its ability as a competitive marketer against eager, low-priced suppliers rushing to sign up customers.    With $45 billion of toll revenues at stake nationally, the battle in Charleston is spreading to other cities and may profoundly reshape the structure of the nation's communications system, analysts say.    ''It's absolutely one of the most vicious battles our industry is going to see,'' said Dixon Doll, president of DMW Group, a telecommunications consulting firm. ''What does a 1 percent change in market share mean in a $50 billion industry? About $500 million. It has enormous financial consequences.''

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: Nucor's Chief Executive Adds Chairman's Title      The Nucor Corporation, an operator of steel minimills based in Charlotte, N.C., has named F. Kenneth Iverson, its president and chief executive officer, to the chairman's post. He will continue as chief executive officer, a position he has held since 1965.    Mr. Iverson, who is 58, will succeed Harold G. Shelton, who has been chairman for almost 20 years. Mr. Shelton, who is believed to be in his 70's, will remain a director.

headline: DUARTE VOWS TO CRUSH DEATH SQUADS
abstract: Jose Napoleon Duarte, the Christian Democrats' candidate for President of El Salavdor, said today that if elected he would set up a special commission to investigate slayings by the death squads.    The candidate, speaking in an interview at his guarded home, said that his priority as President would be to rid the country of ''cultural violence,'' abuses of authority and death squads, including those believed to involve members of the military   ''We cannot achieve peace,'' Mr. Duarte said, ''without first achieving the security of all Salvadorans.''   Mr. Duarte is running against Roberto d'Aubuisson, the candidate of the far-rightist Nationalist Republican Alliance, in the runoff election next Sunday. He predicted he would win with 60 percent of the vote.

headline: MOSCOW TALKS END FOR NORTH KOREAN
abstract: President Kim Il Sung of North Korea today ended his first visit to the Soviet Union in 20 years amid indications that he might have succeeded in obtaining enhanced Soviet military assistance.    Before leaving for Poland and other East European countries, Mr. Kim held a third round of talks with the Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko, during which the state of the Korean forces appeared to have been a leading topic.   A report by Tass, the Soviet press agency, said that ''special emphasis was made on issues of strengthening security in the Far East and in the Pacific Ocean zone.''   Diplomatic reports before Mr. Kim's arrival said one of his priorities would be to win Soviet agreement to provide North Korea with new fighters to replace its aging Soviet-built MIG's, confronted by advanced planes of the United States and South Korean forces.

headline: DU PONT, MONSANTO PROFITS SOAR
abstract: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, helped by the general improvement in the economy and strong performances by several of its businesses, reported yesterday that net income in the first quarter of 1984 soared 83.7 percent on an 8.5 percent gain in revenues.    The Monsanto Company reported a 73.3 percent gain in earnings on a rise of 16.9 percent in revenues.     Du PontDu Pont, based in Wilmington, Del., and the nation's largest chemical company, said net income in the period rose to $373 million, or $1.55 a share, from $203 million, or 85 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose to $9.33 billion, from $8.60 billion.

headline: Two Spanish Bus Crashes Kill 16 Tourists and Soccer Fans
abstract: Nine British tourists and seven Spanish soccer fans were killed and 80 people were injured today in two bus crashes, the Spanish police said.   The nine Britons died on Majorca in the Balearic Islands after a bus carrying 44 tourists from Palma airport to their resort plunged off a bridge into a ravine.

headline: CBS RECORDS REPORTED NEAR MTV VIDEO PACT
abstract: Neither company would confirm or deny yesterday that such a accord was in the works. If completed, however, an exclusivity agreement would give MTV, already the dominant video-music channel, a virtually insurmountable edge in the growing business of airing music videos.    Until now, record companies have generally given new videos and records to broadcasters at no cost as a way of promoting new albums. By locking up a major record producer with an exclusivity contract, however, MTV would effectively constrict the flow of new videos to other, competing broadcasters.

headline: U.S. PUTS TOGETHER $7.5 BILLION IN AID FOR ILLINOIS BANK
abstract: The Government action is its biggest, most complete defense of a troubled bank. Page D15.             CHICAGO, May 17 - Unable to stem an outflow of billions of dollars in deposits and mired in persistent rumors that it was about to fail, the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company today won support for the biggest aid package ever assembled by the Federal Government.    The assistance - $2 billion in new capital and an expanded line of credit for $5.5 billion - will continue until a permanent solution to the bank's problems is achieved or until a buyer can be found to take it over.     In addition, the Federal Reserve System, which supervises the nation's commercial banks, has agreed to meet any ''extraordinary liquidity requirments,'' Continental said.

headline: MAY COSTS IN REGION UNCHANGED
abstract: Consumer prices in the New York- northeastern New Jersey area were unchanged in May, the first time since December 1982 that they have not increased, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.     Over the last 12 months, the area's inflation rate, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, was 4.7 percent, according to Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the bureau's regional commissioner in New York.   Since the start of the year, Mr. Ehrenhalt said at a news conference, the regional price index has increased by 2.2 percent, with rises of three-tenths of 1 percent recorded in both April and March, six-tenths of 1 percent in February and 1 percent in January.

headline: MOYNIHAN HAS DOUBTS OVER MORE AID FOR NICARAGUAN REBELS
abstract: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said today that the United States-financed covert operations in Nicaragua were not working and that he had doubts about whether he would continue to support the program.    The New York Democrat, who has played a key role in bringing bipartisan support in the Senate for the covert activities, appeared to be near the point of breaking with the Administration on the wisdom of the operations.   On Thursday Senator Moynihan withdrew his resignation as vice chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence after the Director of Central Intelligence, William J. Casey, apologized for not keeping the panel better informed. Mr. Moynihan had submitted his resignation on the ground that the C.I.A. had not properly informed the committee of its activities, partciularly its role in mining Nicaraguan harbors.

headline: Sears Trade Unit HeadTo Practice Law Again
abstract: After two years as chairman of Sears World Trade Inc., a subsidiary of Sears Roebuck & Company, Roderick M. Hills is leaving the company to return to his law practice.     The announcement, by the Sears chairman and chief executive, Edward R. Telling, added that Richard M. Jones, vice chairman and chief financial officer of the parent company, would replace Mr. Hills.   Some analysts were surprised by the announcement, but a Sears spokesman said Mr. Hills, who joined the Sears subsidiary when it was formed in 1982, had only agreed to stay for two years.

headline: Software Deal
abstract: -Computer Associates International Incorporated said it had acquired the assets of the Sorcim Corporation, which is involved in the microcomputer software market.

headline: NEW 'REPOS' WARNING TO SCHOOL DISTRICTS SET
abstract: The New York State Comptroller's office is to mail a warning today advising local governments and school districts not to invest in repurchase agreements following the bankruptcy filing last week of a second government-securities firm. A similar warning was issued by the Comptroller earlier this month in the wake of the first such filing.     Seven school districts and one municipality in the state were among the 14 largest unsecured creditors listed by RTD Securities Inc., a small New York government-securities firm that filed for bankruptcy protection on Friday. The 14 creditors are owed nearly $7 million.

headline: NATO'S MINISTERS DISCUSS OPTIONS ON PERSIAN GULF
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and other NATO foreign ministers discussed today what steps, if any, their nations could take individually to limit the spread of the conflict in the Persian Gulf, alliance officials said.   Although by statute the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is committed only to the security of Europe, Mr. Shultz raised the issue of the Iran-Iraq war in the meeting at the Wye Plantation, an 18th-century mansion on the eastern shore of Chesapeake Bay.   The ministers reached no decision, officials said. The talks took place as Iraq reported hitting another ship near Kharg Island, Iran's oil terminal, as part of an effort to cut back Iran's exports and force it to accept a cease-fire. The State Department said it could not confirm the report. (Page A7.)

headline: Y.& R. Chairman Backs Election-Process Study
abstract: Convinced that the American electoral process is badly in need of repair - and that television is responsible for much of the problem - Edward N. Ney, chairman of Young & Rubicam, has pledged $25,000 to help set up an independent group to study ways of fixing it.     Mr. Ney told the San Francisco Advertising Club yesterday that the Georgetown Institute for Strategic and International Studies had shown enthusiasm for establishing a Task Force on TV Political Reform.

headline: IN PLAIN ENGLISH, QUEBECERS DEFY FRENCH PURISTS
abstract: The Commission for the Protection of the French Language, a Quebec provincial agency, is sometimes referred to as the vocabulary constabulary, or the tongue troopers, by disdainful English-speaking Quebecers.   At the moment it is threatening to fine the town council here unless it immediately removes two words of English from the facade of the town hall and another three words of English from a sign at the garbage dump.   The seven town councilmen, five of whom are French Canadians, voted overwhelmingly early this month to ignore the order to remove the English words and to fight any fine in the courts. Their decision represents the newest serious challenge to Quebec's Charter of the French Language, a measure whose authority was somewhat eroded last week by a court ruling that allowed storekeepers to offer bilingual catalogues rather than the French-only brochures that the provincial government asserted were required by the charter.

headline: 'Smart Money Bank': What Went Wrong
abstract: The announcement yesterday that the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company was considering merging with another big bank was the culmination of a series of events that started nearly two years ago. It was then that the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma failed, touching off severe financial difficulties for Continental, once regarded as ''the smart money bank'' - a term it uses in its advertising.     These are among the events that led to yesterday's announcement:  July 5, 1982: Continental Illinois discloses that it would have large losses as the result of the failure of the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma, either through the purchase of its energy loans or in loans directly to the bank itself. These losses, Continental later said, totaled more than $1 billion.

headline: Pope Praises Efforts By Solidarity in Poland
abstract: Pope John Paul II said today that the efforts of Poles represented by the banned Solidarity labor union ''cannot be erased.''   ''One must think with respect at this great effort of the Polish spirit which, under the name Solidarity, finds recognition in many societies the world over,'' the Pope said in an address to Polish pilgrims at the Vatican.

headline: SANDINISTA REBELS SAY THE U.S. HAS PLEDGED CONTINUED SUPPORT
abstract: Anti-Sandinista guerrilla leaders said Wednesday that the Reagan Administration had assured continued support for their efforts to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government.   Despite a House of Representatives action last week refusing an additional $21 million for the rebels, who have the backing of the Central Intelligence Agency, leaders of the Democratic Nicaraguan Front expressed confidence that if they needed more money to keep fighting, it would be available.   The leaders conceded, however, that they were searching for alternative sources of money because supplies and munitions might be scarce enough in a few months to curtail their operations inside Nicaragua.   ''I'm confident we will pull through this crisis caused by the Congress,'' said Adolfo Calero Portocarrero, one of the Democratic Nicaraguan Front's top leaders. ''We believe we are still going to get support, but maybe not on the level we need it to bring about a turning point now. There is no sense in denying we need U.S. aid.''

headline: SETTLING DISPUTED CASES BY ARBITRATION
abstract: LAST Sept. 30, Sheila Farnill, a 51-year-old office worker from Newburgh, N.Y., was driving on an upstate highway when her car was hit head-on by an auto whose driver had lost control. She suffered multiple cuts and required 29 stitches in her hand and forehead, leaving her permanently scarred.    While Mrs. Farnill's own insurance policy covered her medical costs and damage to her car, her lawyer, Howard Finkelstein, began negotiating with the other driver's insurer, The Hartford Insurance Company, to collect damages for pain and suffering.   The parties disagreed on the amount of the damages, but Mr. Finkelstein wanted to avoid a protracted legal battle. ''The courts are so clogged that this kind of case could take 18 months to two years to come to trial, and then it could be appealed,'' he said.

headline: THE FORGOTTEN FRONT: FOR SOLDIERS WHO TOOK ROME, GLORY WAS FLEETING
abstract: Herbert Mitgang of The New York Times served as an Army correspondent in North Africa and Italy during World War II.           On June 5, 1944, American infantrymen captured Rome, the first Axis capital to fall in World War II. It was ''a famous victory'' that almost immediately was overwhelmed by the bigger news on June 6 of the D-day landings in northern France.   On the day Rome fell, the banner headline in the first edition of Stars and Stripes, the American Army paper put out by soldier-correspondents, read, ''WE'RE IN ROME.'' The correspondents had raced to a ''liberated'' newspaper plant, Il Messaggero on the Via del Tritone, to put out the paper.

headline: International Borrowing Off
abstract: The amount of new borrowing on the international capital market in May fell $5.9 billion from April and was down $2 billion from a year earlier, to $10.5 billion, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today. The volume of new bank lending and credit guarantees in May fell $3.4 billion from April, to $3.7 billion, while new bond offerings fell $2.4 billion, to $6.8 billion.  Gross new borrowing through bond issues and bank loans from March through May totalled $41 billion.

headline: Funds Rise $647 Million
abstract: The assets of the nation's money market mutual funds recovered slightly, rising $647 million, to $172.27 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.   This latest increase signals the end of a downturn and brings the funds' assets close to where they were last April 27, when assets reached $173.3 billion, the institute said.

headline: Transcanada Plan
abstract: Transcanada Pipelines Ltd. said it had filed an application with the National Energy Board for an $811 million program to expand its pipeline system.

headline: Blue Jeans and Rock: Pro and Con in Soviet
abstract: The Soviet Communist Party daily Pravda published a sharp clash of views today over Western fashions and rock music, with elderly readers calling for a strict ban and young ones telling them to keep quiet.   The newspaper said it received a flood of letters in response to an article last October in which it complained about people wearing Western jeans and United States flags on their shirts and listening to Western rock groups.

headline: Coffee Account To McCaffrey
abstract: McCaffrey & McCall, which last month got a special project assignment from the National Coffee Association of USA, yesterday won the whole ball of wax. And it will probably bill around $14 million.

headline: Computervision
abstract: The Computervision Corporation said it had added two new series of integrated, distributed systems for computer-aided engineering, design and manufacturing. The company also announced the first major enhancement of its CDS 4000 system. In addition, Computervision announced a major restructuring of its pricing policies to more accurately reflect ''the additive value of its applications software.''

headline: ARGENTINE DEBT PLAN IS EXTENDED
abstract: The Treasury Department said today that it had extended by one month its offer of $300 million in short-term financing for Argentina to help it meet the terms of an austerity program to be worked out with the International Monetary Fund. The Argentine- I.M.F. accord is intended to permit Argentina to resume payments on its $47 billion in foreign debt.    As a result of this extension, four Latin American countries to which Argentina owes $300 million will extend their collection dates as well.

headline: MEXICO PRESIDENT ENDS VISIT TO U.S.
abstract: President Miguel de la Madrid of Mexico ended his visit with President Reagan today, saying the two leaders had progressed in learning ''respect for one another's truth.''    President Reagan, praising the Mexican leader at a White House meeting, said, ''We've had good conversations, and we both listened to what the other had to say.''   The two leaders had breakfast at the White House, and a senior Administration official later insisted that they had found their disagreements ''not as far off as they may have perceived.''

headline: KARAMI IS ASKED TO FORM NEW LEBANON CABINET
abstract: President Amin Gemayel today called on former Prime Minister Rashid Karami, a pro-Syrian Moslem leader, to form a government of national unity.   The Prime Minister-designate, who is 62 years old and has previously served as head of government nine times, is expected to include in his new cabinet representatives of all of Lebanon's main religious and political factions as well as the country's top militia leaders. The hope is that they might be able to resolve their differences in debates around the cabinet table and not through shootouts.   Mr. Karami was named to replace Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan, who submitted his Cabinet's resignation on Feb. 5 in the midst of widescale fighting between the Lebanese Army and Moslem militia forces. Mr. Wazzan has been Prime Minister throughout Mr. Gemayel's presidency, which began in September 1982.

headline: Money Fund Assets Drop
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds tumbled $1.24 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to $170.07 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. In the previous week, the assets declined $357 million, to $171.3 billion.

headline: Ethiopian Jews Backed
abstract: A House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on human rights passed a resolution today calling for increased attention to the plight of Ethiopian Jews, who it said had been reduced to 25,000 from hundreds of thousands. The resolution calls on President Reagan to help them emigrate.

headline: MOSCOW CHARGES ANTI-SOVIET BIAS AT OLYMPIC GAMES
abstract: The Soviet Olympic Committee charged today that an anti-Soviet campaign was taking shape for the Games in Los Angeles this summer and asked for an emergency session of the International Olympic Committee to look into security and to demand American adherence to the Olympic charter.   In a statement issued by Tass, the official Soviet press agency, the Soviet Olympic Committee did not directly threaten a boycott of the Games by its athletes. But it noted that the time was drawing ever nearer for the Olympic committees of the various nations to make a decision on participation. The deadline for registering is June 2.

headline: Rio Algom Deal
abstract: Rio Algom Ltd. said it had acquired the metal service center business of the Vincent Brass and Aluminum Company from the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation for about $47 million, subject to final adjustments. Vincent operates 10 metal service centers in the United States and had 1983 sales of $145 million, Rio Algom said.

headline: Cameroon Says a Leader Of Uprising Was Caught
abstract: Authorities in Cameroon arrested a colonel who was one of the leaders of the unsuccessful coup last week in which scores of people were killed, the Government-run Cameroon radio said today.   The radio, in a report monitored here, identified the man as Col. Saleh Ibrahim, a commander in the Republican Guard responsible for presidential security.   According to Government reports, members of the 700-man Republican Guard from Moslem northern Cameroon attempted the coup last Friday and were crushed by loyalist troops.

headline: Weinberger Ends Trip To Europe and Africa
abstract: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger ended a weeklong trip through Europe and North Africa today and left for home, a day after signing an accord that extends United States rights to a vital mid-Atlantic air base for seven years.   Before leaving for Washington today, Mr. Weinberger discussed defense issues with Prime Minister Mario Soares at the Pedras Rubras international airport in the northern industrial city of Oporto. Mr. Weinberger said the two NATO allies were in ''full agreement in many areas.''

headline: Nigeria Plans Budget Cuts
abstract: Nigeria's military head of state, Maj. Gen. Mohammed Buhari, announced a tough austerity budget today for 1984 featuring hefty cuts in Government spending, higher interest rates and cuts in credit growth.   General Buhari said in a nationwide broadcast that Government spending this year would be cut by 15 percent from a budget presented by the ousted civilian Government only two days before its overthrow on New Year's Eve.

headline: THREATS BY C.I.A. SAID TO INFLUENCE ANTI-SANDINISTAS
abstract: The Central Intelligence Agency has been directing the military strategies of a Nicaraguan rebel group based in this country by threatening to withhold aid if the insurgents failed to pursue the agency's objectives, guerrilla officers, Costa Rican Government officials and diplomats here say.    The C.I.A. has suspended aid to the Costa Rica-based Nicaraguan rebel group more than once, the officers and officials said. But only recently has the agency begun using the threat of reduced aid to prompt military actions, they said.   A spokesman for the C.I.A., George V. Lauder, said the agency would not comment on reports of connections with the Costa Rica-based rebel group, which is commanded by Eden Pastora Gomez. The agency has also helped other Nicaraguan insurgents who have been attacking Nicaragua from the north from bases in Honduras.

headline: Investment in Korea
abstract: Foreign investment in South Korea rose 148 percent in the first quarter, to $48.69 million for 18 projects, the Finance Ministry said today.

headline: POLES RELUCTANTLY JOIN OLYMPIC BOYCOTT
abstract: In what it called ''an unpleasant decision,'' Poland today became the 10th nation to announce that its athletes would not take part in the Olympics in Los Angeles this summer.    After voting to follow the Soviet lead, the 45-member Polish Olympic Committee said it was ''fully aware'' its decision was unpleasant for its athletes and ''for the millions of sports fans in Poland.'' Like Moscow, it criticized the security arrangements made for athletes in Los Angeles, but it did so in milder terms than those of the Soviet Union.

headline: HOLDOUT NEARLY RUINED ARGENTINE DEBT DEAL
abstract: Hundreds of millions of dollars had already moved into the New York banks by 5 P.M. Friday, but it remained unclear whether the $500 million international rescue operation for Argentina was going to succeed because there was a holdout. Lloyds Bank of London still had not said it would take part.   Danger of failure at the 11th hour was real. ''It was hanging by a thread,'' said a high official of a major New York bank.

headline: State Dept. Fights Bill Favoring Salvadorans
abstract: A State Department official said today that Salvadorans illegally in the United States should not be given special status to stay here because of what might happen to them if they were deported.   ''Some groups argue that illegal aliens who are sent back to El Salvador meet persecution and often death,'' Elliott Abrams, Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, told a House subcommittee on immigration and refugees.

headline: BUSH, IN GENEVA, OFFERS CHEMICAL ARMS BAN
abstract: Vice President Bush presented a new American proposal today for banning chemical weapons. He said the United States was ''willing to pay the price'' of openness by allowing inspections on short notice to verify compliance.   Mr. Bush, addressing the Geneva Conference on Disarmament, said the verification provisions of the 66-page draft presented by the United States were ''indispensable to an effective treaty'' that would seek to eliminate ''the possibility of chemical warfare forever.''

headline: OCCIDENTAL, CHINA IN COAL PACT
abstract: More than four years after it opened negotiations, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation today signed an agreement with China to begin developing what could become the world's largest open-pit coal mine.   The project at Pingshuo, in north China's Shanxi Province, involves an investment of more than $600 million, making it China's largest venture with a foreign company.   Occidental will be joined in the project by Peter Kiewit Sons Inc., a construction and mining company based in Omaha.   Rumors had circulated in Peking early last month that the negotiations might collapse, after a drop in the world price of coal made the project less profitable for Occidental. The company asked to renegotiate portions of an interim agreement reached earlier and the Chinese side hinted that it might undertake the mammoth project alone.

headline: LONDON TALKS TO TEST HOPE FOR ECONOMY
abstract: A year ago the leaders of seven major industrial democracies met in the restored colonial village of Williamsburg, Va., for three days of cloistered discussions. At the end they arrayed themselves on the world stage, before a sea of television cameras and journalists, and issued a communique promising a stronger world economy.     The economy has indeed improved. But with the intractable debts of the developing world, spreading protectionism in trade, stubbornly high unemployment in Europe and Canada and the high-valued dollar, it has turned out to be a vastly more troubled economy than the leaders envisioned.   ''Their promises were meaningless,'' said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington and the Treasury's principal summit planner in the Carter Administration. ''They did nothing to follow them up.''

headline: RISE IN PRIME STIRS DEBTORS
abstract: THE action by United States banks in raising    the prime rate to 13 percent from 12 1/2 percent   has evoked a storm of criticism from Latin American debtors, who accuse the banks of having held up the rise until the end of the recent meeting of the Latin countries in Cartagena, Colombia.   The 11 countries in the Cartagena group had agreed to meet again, probably in September, in Buenos Aires. But now it looks as though the debtors will meet again much sooner.   Franklin Proano, group vice president of the central bank of Ecuador, said in a telephone interview yesterday that the rise in the prime ''will provoke another meeting,'' which he expected to take place in July in Buenos Aires. ''People are already in touch,'' he said.

headline: Limited Files Suit
abstract: The Limited Inc. said it had filed a lawsuit in California to prevent the proposed change in Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc.'s state of incorporation to Delaware, from California, and is soliciting proxies to elect its two nominees to the Carter Hawley board at a special shareholders meeting scheduled for July 26. If Carter Hawley reincorporates in Delaware, it could eliminate cumulative voting for directors, under which a shareholder gets one vote for each position but can allocate all those votes for one or two positions. Carter Hawley, based in Los Angeles, said it plans to take ''appropriate steps'' to protect the rights of its shareholders.

headline: Jurists Criticize U.S.
abstract: The International Commission of Jurists today condemned the decision by the United States not to recognize the jurisdiction of the International Court of Justice on matters relating to Latin America. The United States move was announced April 6, before a ruling by the World Court last Friday that the United States should stop attempts to blockade or mine Nicaraguan ports.

headline: NICARAGUAN BISHOPS URGE TALKS WITH REBELS
abstract: Nicaragua's nine Roman Catholic bishops issued a pastoral letter today criticizing the Sandinista Government and urging it to open negotiations with leaders of armed insurgent groups.    ''If this does not happen,'' the bishops warned in their Easter message, ''there will be no chance for an agreement, and our people, especially the poorest among them, will continue suffering and dying.''   Sandinista commanders have repeately vowed they will never negotiate with rebel leaders, asserting that the rebels have no domestic base and depend entirely on the United States for support. Interior Minister Tomas Borge referred to insurgent fighters last week as ''Reagan's mercenary army.''

headline: Denmark Expels Two In Soviet Group as Spies
abstract: Denmark expelled two members of the staff of a Soviet trade delegation today after charging they were involved in espionage.

headline: April's Toll Put at 130 In Peruvian Violence
abstract: About 130 people were killed in April in a surge of violence by Peruvian Maoist guerrillas, an army commander said today.   The commander said that 61 guerrillas belonging to the Shining Path group, 58 peasants, 7 soldiers and 2 civilian government officials were among those killed.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: American Stock Exchange has elected Daniel P. Tully vice chairman of its board of governors, succeeding Frederick B. Whittenmore, who was ineligible for re-election.     *  Bankers Life, a life insurance company in Des Moines, has named John R. Taylor president and chief executive officer, Charles E. Rohm senior vice president in charge of individual insurance operations (replacing Jack T. Watson, who will now be responsible for special insurance projects), Charles E. Farr vice president and chief actuary and Theodore M. Hutchison senior vice president, counsel and secretary.     *  Barclays-American/Business Credit Inc., a business lender in East Hartford, Conn., has promoted Gary W. Burdick to loan officer in its industrial financing division.

headline: Gulf and Western Finance Unit Files
abstract: The Associates Corporation of North America, a consumer and business finance subsidiary of Gulf and Western Industries, has filed a shelf registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for offerings of up to $600 million of unsecured debt securities.

headline: AMEX HAD 1ST INQUIRY ON JOURNAL
abstract: Executives at TIE / Communications Inc. were frustrated and angry last October. Despite strong earnings for the latest quarter, the company's stock had plunged more than 20 percent in a week, following a negative article in The Wall Street Journal. Following that, the executives sensed that a Journal reporter, R. Foster Winans, was preparing a downbeat ''Heard on the Street'' column.   The column appeared in The Journal on Oct. 20, and TIE called the American Stock Exchange, where its shares are traded. The question: Why, just before the column's publication, had so many shares been sold short - that is borrowed and sold on the chance they could be repurchased and returned later at a lower price?

headline: Economic Scene; Post-Election Slowdown?
abstract: THE United States economy is expanding so    strongly that it is driving up interest rates   and alarming the stock and bond markets.    Tough monetary and fiscal measures would have been required to moderate the boom, but the Administration has brought pressure on the Federal Reserve not to tighten money and credit in an election year. Nor has it moved to chop Federal spending or raise taxes, although it has promised action after the November election.    After the election, the Federal Reserve will presumably feel free to tighten monetary policy further, to arrest incipient inflation. And fiscal policy is also likely to be tightened, but with a longer lag.

headline: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
abstract: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.59     An index of yields for long-term   A-rated general obligation bonds   compiled weekly by The Bond   Buyer.   Aa Utility Bonds*14.38     Salomon Brothers' estimate for   new long-term issues.

headline: Chemical Applies For Florida Bank
abstract: Chemical Bank said it had applied to Federal banking authorities for permission to convert its trust company in Palm Beach, Fla., into a consumer banking unit.

headline: Advertising; Western Union's Easylink
abstract: ELECTRONIC mail is one of the computer revolution buzzwords that excite communications giants. ''The guy who gets out there first gets the lion's share'' of the business, said Richard F. O'Brien, executive vice president at Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, the agency handling the account for one of those giants, the Western Union Corporation.     Electronic mail consists of messages sent from one computer to another that can be read on the computer screen or printed out, like a traditional letter. Commercially, such messages represent a market that is expected to grow from about $40 million in 1983 to $148 million this year and $4.3 billion by 1990, according to research conducted by International Resource Development Inc. in Norwalk, Conn., and the Gartner Group of Stamford, Conn.

headline: Accounts
abstract: GEICO (Government Employees Insurance Company), Washington, to Doremus Direct for all auto insurance programs.

headline: Denny's Halts Trading; Acquisition Rumored
abstract: Denny's Inc., which operates fast- food restaurants and coffee shops, yesterday asked the New York Stock Exchange to halt the trading in its shares pending an announcement ''of significance to its shareholders.''     Vern O. Curtis, the company's president and chief executive, would not comment further. But there was speculation on Wall Street that Denny's might acquire Church's Fried Chicken or might itself be acquired, perhaps by Church's.

headline: DOW SLIDES BY 10.37 IN HEAVY TRADING
