abstract: Stock prices plummeted yesterday in heavy trading touched off mainly by growing apprehension over the financial stability of some banks. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at its lowest level in more than 15 months.    The Dow average dropped throughout most of the session and finished with a decline of 10.37 points, to 1,103.43, its lowest close since Feb. 23, 1983, when it ended at 1,096.94.    In the last nine sessions, the widely followed barometer has plunged 54 points primarily because of the problems confronting the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, the tense Persian Gulf situation and increasing interest rates.

headline: North Korea Reports Killing a Seoul Soldier
abstract: North Korea said today that a South Korean soldier was killed on the northern side of the demilitarized zone on Thursday.

headline: Atlantic Resignation
abstract: David Auchincloss, the 41-year-old president of The Atlantic magazine, has resigned to work on a new magazine project. Mortimer B. Zuckerman, The Atlantic's chairman, has appointed two associate publishers: Susannah Pask, 32, who will be the New York ad director, and James Sheridan, 57, who will be the national ad director. Mr. Auchincloss, formerly a publisher of Newsweek, will be available to The Atlantic as a consultant for two months. Miss Pask was formerly with Penthouse and Mr. Sheridan with Reader's Digest.

headline: ; Hood, Hope Promotes Three to Top Positions
abstract: Fourteen-year-old Hood, Hope & Associates, Tulsa's gift to the advertising world, has made some major executive changes.

headline: FOR MANY AFRICANS, MANY LANGUAGES ARE THE RULE
abstract: A Kenyan gardener, with little formal education, was once asked how many languages he spoke. Three, came the reply.    The first was Ki-Luhya, ''Ki'' meaning ''language of'' and ''Luhya'' being the tribe into which he was born. The second was Ki-Swahili, the hybrid of Arab and African tongues that provides a rare lingua franca in East Africa. The third was Ki-Sungu, the language of the Msungu, or white person - that is to say, English.

headline: A COMPANY THAT NURTURES SMALLNESS
abstract: THERE are decentralized conglomerates, and then there is the   Kollmorgen Corporation.   Its international headquarters, in Stamford, Conn., is one room with six people, including Robert Swiggett, the chairman.   The 4,500 other employees work at 13 different divisions and subsidiaries, mainly in Glen Cove, L.I., Northampton, Mass., and Radford, Va. When a division grows beyond a few hundred employees, it is split, and workers get a bonus for the good work that made the growth possible.

headline: Prudential Stake
abstract: Prudential-Bache Securities will soon acquire a 7.9 percent stake in Cortis & Carr, a Melbourne stockbroker, in the first such venture between American and Australian companies, Cortis & Carr said.

headline: Chinese Back Nuclear Arms
abstract: A senior Chinese official told a European Parliament delegation today that China supports a nuclear deterrent in Western Europe against the Soviet Union. ''If a lion is going to attack you, you've got to be in a position to frighten it away,'' Peng Zhen, chairman of the National People's Congress, was quoted as telling the delegation from the legislative branch of the Common Market. It was the first time a Chinese leader has been quoted as endorsing nuclear weapons in Western Europe.

headline: The U.N. Today June 13, 1984
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Subcommittee on Petition and Information - 10:30 A.M.  ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Commission on Transnational Corporations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Trusteeship Council - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: PIZZA TIME LOSS FOR '83
abstract: Pizza Time Theatre Inc., a restaurant chain that went into Chapter 11 proceedings last month, said yesterday that it had a loss of $81 million for 1983. For the fourth quarter, the loss was $75.3 million, which included $45.2 million in provisions for the closing of certain company units, compared with net earnings of $2.5 million, or 42 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: Woodward Sues Dissident Holders
abstract: Woodward & Lothrop, the Washington, D.C., department store chain, said it filed a countersuit in Federal District Court against several shareholders who oppose the company's proposed $220 million merger with Taubman Holdings Inc. The countersuit charged that the group had violated sections of the Securities and Exchange Act in forming a shareholders' committee.    Separately, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Woodward disclosed that Taubman Holdings had granted to three of Woodward's top officials options to buy about 20 percent of the company for about $5 million if the merger was completed. Based on the Taubman offer, 20 percent of the company would be worth at least $40 million.

headline: Computer Linkups Spurred by France
abstract: As treasurer of a small engineering company in this dour eastern French town, Hubert Swalduz used to call the bank every day to ask about his company's accounts. Since the start of this year, however, all the information he wants comes to him on a little television screen in his office by touching a key.    Mr. Swalduz is a beneficiary of a Government campaign to keep France in the forefront of communications technology by placing - free so far - a telephone-connected computer terminal known as a Minitel in every French home and office.    His company, Guermont Weber, does business with the Banque Populaire de Lorraine, a cooperatively owned local bank that has pioneered ''home banking'' in Europe.

headline: Rockwell Profit Up 32%
abstract: The Rockwell International Corporation reported a 32.3 percent gain in profits for the quarter ended March 31. Earnings totaled $132.7 million, or 86 cents a share, compared with $100.3 million, or 65 cents a share, a year ago. Sales rose 15 percent, to $2.3 billion, from $2 billion.

headline: U.S. FINANCIAL ACCORD WITH JAPAN ANNOUNCED
abstract: The United States and Japan, as expected, announced a major agreement today that could substantially expand the international role of the yen and provide new business opportunities in Japan for American financiers.    Japan also agreed to take ''step-by- step'' action to relax tight Government controls of its domestic capital markets.    But the reaction was guarded among some analysts in the United        Excerpts from paper, page D6.  States, Exporters welcomed the move, with one representative calling it ''an important first step.'' but international experts speculated that as a result the yen could become even cheaper in the short term.

headline: SURGING COFFEE PRICES THREATEN QUOTA SYSTEM
abstract: Stubbornly high coffee prices, which threaten to disrupt the stability of the world market, have forced the 73-nation International Coffee Organization to call a special meeting of its executive board today in London.   Since mid-December, the group has been unable to keep prices within the agreed range of $1.20 to $1.40 a pound. In recent weeks, coffee for July delivery on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York has climbed as high as $1.5842 a pound, the highest price in at least four years.    On Friday, the coffee organization released an extra one million bags onto the market. That was the fourth and final such increase in supply it is allowed under its rules. If prices do not stay down, the group faces the possibility of suspending its quota system and allowing a free market in coffee.

headline: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
abstract: Amax Inc. $8,200,000  -*  Avon Products 26,700,000  -0.4  Beatrice Foods 133,000,000   -*  Becton, Dickinson 13,600,000  -17.6  Bethlehem Steel (54,600,000)  -  Borg-Warner Corporation 50,200,000  x41.4  Bristol-Myers Company 110,000,000  x19.4  Consolidated Freightways 12,200,000  x8.9  Dart & Kraft Inc. 107,800,000  x9.4  Eastern Air Lines  (28,100,000) - Exxon Corporation  1,480,000,000  x39.6 Hershey Foods  19,600,000  -  17.6 Kerr-McGee Corporation  40,300,000  x 70.0 Kroger Company  18,800,000  -12.6 National Can Corporation  (187,000) - Norfolk Southern  103,200,000  x 81. 7 Phelps Dodge  (5,000,000) - Phillips Petroleum  193,000,000  x 49.6 Santa Fe Southern Pacific  107,000,000  x 85.1 Squibb Corporation  36,900,000  x 10.8 Standard Oil (California)  378,000,000  x 21.9 Texas Eastern Corporation  59,200,000  x 57.0 United States Steel  171,000,000  -* Warner-Lambert  54,200,000 x 17.6 Zenith Radio  14,000,000 x 68.7   See accompanying notes for special items.   (Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

headline: Iran Says It Downed Iraqi Jet; Iraq Reports Artillery Duels
abstract: Iran said its air force shot down an Iraqi MIG-23 today and that 35 Iraqi soldiers were killed or wounded in artillery shelling in the past 24 hours.   An Iranian communique issued in Teheran also said that artillery duels on the northwestern front in the Persian Gulf war had left 35 Iraqi soldiers killed or wounded.   In Baghdad, an Iraqi communique said Iranian artillery hit Basra, killing one person and wounding 10 others.

headline: ROCKET HITS GEMAYEL HOME BUT FAMILY ESCAPES INJURY BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 14 (AP) - A rocket struck the residential quarters of President Amin Gemayel's palace in suburban Baabda Friday night, destroying three rooms, but he and his family escaped injury, the state-run television said today.
abstract: The police reported that 9 people were killed and 42 were wounded in fierce overnight exchanges of rocket, artillery and tank fire that tapered off at dawn.   At least four more were killed when the battles between Christian and Moslem militias resumed this afternoon, the police and hospital officials said.   The television said a rocket exploded on the third floor of the palace's western wing shortly before midnight Friday. There was no explanation of why the incident was not reported until late today.

headline: Computerland
abstract: The Computerland Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent with China's Ministry for the Electronics Industry to form a joint venture to sell microcomputer products in China.

headline: Leaseway Expects Drop in Profits
abstract: The Leaseway Transportation Corporation said it expects first-quarter profits to be below last year's $4.8 million, or 40 cents a share, which included an extraordinary gain of 8 cents a share from the sale of a unit.

headline: Bigger Bonn Surplus Seen
abstract: The leading economic institutes of West Germany said today that surging exports would increase Germany's current account surplus to 20 billion marks, or $7.6 billion, in 1984, from 10.1 billion marks in 1983, bolstering the value of the mark against the dollar.   The institutes' spring forecast contrasted sharply with the Government's own official report, which maintained that the surplus would stay at about the 1983 level.   The institutes also predicted that the country's economic growth would reach 3 percent in 1984, up from 1.3 percent in 1983, while unemployment would average about 2.15 million, down from 2.26 million.

headline: PAYING DUES TO UNCLE SAM --BELATEDLY
abstract: MILLIONS of taxpayers burned the midnight oil last weekend to get their tax returns in under the deadline. But many took advantage of a provision in the tax law that gives them an additional four months until the day of reckoning.   The provision grants an automatic extension, until Aug. 15, for the filing of 1983 tax returns, no questions asked. To obtain the delay, you would have had to file Form 4868, available at most Internal Revenue Service offices, by April 16.

headline: SALVADORAN VOTE FOR LEADER TODAY TO TEST U.S. POLICY
abstract: El Salvador's Central Election Council, trying to limit the confusion that plagued the last vote, finished delivering ballots and ballot boxes today for the presidential election Sunday.    The election will choose who will determine the Salvadoran Government's policies on resolving its guerrilla war and restructuring the country's battered economic and social system.   It will also provide a key test of the Reagan Administration's policy in Central America, which is to combat leftist movements by creating democratic governments that can win political support from their people and military and economic aid from the United States Congress.   Duarte Considered Favorite    Voters will choose Sunday between Jose Napoleon Duarte of the moderate Christian Democratic Party and Roberto d'Aubuisson of the far-right Nationalist Republican Alliance.

headline: JACKSON CRITICIZES REMARKS MADE BY FARRAKHAN AS 'REPREHENSIBLE'
abstract: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today disavowed as ''reprehensible'' the words of Louis Farrakhan, a Black Muslim supporter who had described the creation of Israel as an ''outlaw act'' and called the nations that helped found and now support Israel ''criminals in the sight of Almighty God.''    In a statement issued through his campaign office here, the black Democratic Presidential contender said: ''I find such statements or comments to be reprehensible and morally indefensible.   ''I am a Judeo-Christian and the roots of my faith run deep in the Judeo- Christian tradition. Such statements and thoughts have no place in my own thinking or in this campaign.''

headline: Tanzania Bus Crash Kills 33
abstract: A bus hit a tree on Monday at Bukoba on Lake Victoria in northwest Tanzania, killing 33 people and injuring 74, the Tanzanian radio said today.

headline: Chrysler Extends Mitsubishi Pact
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said it had extended through 1995 its agreement to import and sell vehicles made by the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation of Japan.

headline: ;  Inexco's Rating Cut
abstract: The Standard and Poor's Corporation said it had reduced the rating on the Inexco Oil Company's $60 million of convertible debt to Bx, from BB-.

headline: FUTURES/OPTIONS ; Sugar Falls Sharply;Cocoa Also Plunges
abstract: World sugar futures fell sharply near the close of trading today on a burst of selling in the July contract, which expires Friday.    Liquidation in the July contract, which dropped 0.22 cent a pound, also dragged down other months. Prices were under pressure from Brazil's threat to withdraw from the International Sugar Agreement if the European Economic Community did not join the price stabilization pact.

headline: Kissinger Joins Board
abstract: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has been elected to the board of the American Express Company, James D. Robinson 3d, the company's chairman and chief executive, announced yesterday. Mr. Kissinger was Secretary of State from 1973 to 1977 and recently headed the National Bipartisan Commission on Central America. He is a member of the Chase Manhattan Bank's international advisory committee and a director of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation.

headline: Glemp Urges Release Of Political Prisoners
abstract: Cardinal Jozef Glemp has called on the Polish authorities to release prisoners held for political opposition.

headline: MOSCOW CALLS NATO'S PLEA ON TIES 'ULTIMATE HYPOCRISY'
abstract: The Soviet press said today that the statement issued by NATO foreign ministers after their meeting in Washington was ''imbued with the spirit of bellicosity'' and dismissed calls for East-West talks as ''the ultimate in hypocrisy.''    The Soviet reaction was aired through several commentaries distributed by Tass, but there was no direct response from the Soviet Government.    The commentaries all treated the three-day session of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, which coincided with NATO's 35th anniversary, as an exercise in aggressiveness and militarism. The only positive element noted in the articles was the disagreement among the 16 ministers.

headline: REAGAN LISTS HIS GOALS FOR CHINA TRIP
abstract: President Reagan arrived here today on his way to Peking after declaring in Honolulu that his trip to China was intended to strengthen Chinese-American friendship, open new markets for American trade and establish a foundation for ''opposing expansionist aggression.''   This was apparently an allusion to expansionist policies of the Soviet Union.   ''Together,'' the President said, speaking of Chinese-American cooperation, ''we can go forward in a mighty enterprise to build dynamic growth economies, and make the world safer, by working for peace and opposing expansionist aggression.''

headline: Soviet Submarine Is Trapped By Norwegian Fishing Wire
abstract: A Soviet submarine was trapped for three and a half hours today in the fishing wire of a Norwegian trawler in international waters, the Norwegian Navy reported.   The Soviet submarine, a conventional diesel-powered vessel, was caught in a trawler's fishing wire in the North Sea, some 50 nautical miles off southwestern Norway, the naval operation center at Stavanger said.   The 240-foot submarine tried for half an hour to free itself from the Norwegian trawler Bentin before surfacing, still entangled in the wire, the navy said.

headline: CBS Profit More Than Doubles
abstract: CBS Inc. reported yesterday that its profits in the first quarter more than doubled from a year earlier, reflecting increased revenues from the broadcasting and recording divisions.     The company earned $38.9 million, or $1.31 a share, in the three months ended March 31, up from $17.8 million, or 60 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: A LINKING NETWORK BY I.B.M.
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced the first part of its long- awaited local area network. It will link independent computer systems, usually within a large building, so they can exchange information at high speed.     But the company only offered a ''statement of intent'' to market a full network in two to three years.   The announcement surprised analysts, who had expected the entire system to be available this year. It prompted speculation that I.B.M. had encountered technical problems and chose to announce the system piecemeal to encourage customers not to install competing products.

headline: Nicaragua Aide Seeks Arms in North Korea
abstract: Defense Minister Humberto Ortega of Nicaragua arrived in North Korea on an arms purchasing mission Monday, the official North Korean press agency reported today.   Nicaragua's Sandinista Government said last week that, because of increased attacks by United States- backed rebels in Nicaragua, Mr. Ortega would visit North Korea and the Soviet Union in search of arms supplies.

headline: AS IRELAND VISIST ENDS, 5,000 PROTESTERS MARCH
abstract: Five thousand anti-Reagan demonstrators paraded through the meandering, largely treeless streets of central Dublin today, culminating three days of protests against the President's visit to Ireland and his foreign policies, particularly in Central America.    ''Reagan! Reagan! Reagan!'' a protester with an electronic megaphone cried, beginning the chant that has became the theme of anti-Reagan protests in Ireland.   ''Out! Out! Out!'' the crowd responded.

headline: Moscow Denies Report Of U.S. Aide's Beating
abstract: The Soviet Union denied today that a United States diplomat had been beaten up recently outside a Leningrad restaurant, and it rebuked the American correspondent, Robert Gillette of The Los Angeles Times, who first reported the incident.   The official Tass press agency said the allegation of an attack on the diplomat, Vice Consul Ronald A. Harms, was fabricated by the United States Government in order to divert attention from what Moscow asserted was lack of security at the Los Angeles Olympics.   The United States Embassy confirmed reports last month that Mr. Harms, 35 years old, had been repeatedly hit by several young men and knocked to the ground as he left a restaurant near the American Consulate in Leningrad on April 17. Mr. Harms was reportedly meeting with dissidents before the incident.

headline: Domestic Trade Minister Dies in Crash in Poland
abstract: Zygmunt Lakomiec, Poland's Minister of Domestic Trade and Services, was killed today when his car collided with a gasoline truck in a blizzard, the official press agency P.A.P. reported.

headline: CULTURAL REVOLT BUDDING IN POLAND DESPITE ARRESTS
abstract: A vast underground counterculture, much of it operating under the protection of the Roman Catholic Church, has quietly taken root all across Poland in recent months.    But at the same time, the stubborn intellectual resistance to the Communist authorities has brought a sharp new crackdown that, according to the Government's own figures, has doubled the number of political prisoners since the beginning of the year.   Some 200 arrests were being made as the United Nations Human Rights Commission was issuing a report praising the Polish Government for improvements it had made, including the release of political prisoners.   The underground culture includes a wide range of intellectual and creative life: independent publishing houses turning out works of history and literature, scholarly journals and weekly news sheets; lectures delivered in churches by leading academics and artists; independent study groups known as ''flying universities''; troupes of actors putting on performances in apartments, and clandestinely duplicated cassettes of political lectures and topical songs. All of it has a strongly anti-Government content.

headline: Some Export Curbs Eased
abstract: The Government said today that it was easing controls on the export of certain sophisticated laboratory equipment.

headline: ; JWT and BBDO Post Net Gains for Quarter
abstract: The JWT Group and BBDO International, the former the parent of J. Walter Thompson, and the latter, of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, both issued first-quarter statements yesterday.

headline: ;  People
abstract: *  Craige Johnson has joined the Marschalk Company as executive vice president and chief operating officer of the Houston office.     *  Brian Palmer elected a senior vice president at Kenyon & Eckhardt, Detroit.     *  Christopher Sinclair , director of marketing, named a vice president at Newsweek.

headline: NEW ANTITRUST MERGER GUIDELINES ISSUED
abstract: Attorney General William French Smith issued new antitrust merger guidelines today that indicate greater flexibility in the way the Justice Department will decide whether to challenge merger proposals.     Signaling the end of a public dispute between himself and the Secretary of Commerce, Malcolm Baldrige, Mr. Smith declared, ''We had concurrence across the board.'' The guidelines, he said, ''represent Administration policy, not just Department of Justice policy.'' Separately, A spoke sman for Mr. Baldrige praised the guidelines.

headline: BRITISH ALLIANCE WINS UPSET
abstract: The Liberal-Social Democratic alliance, which has languished in the political doldrums since the Falkland War gave a lift to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her Conservative Party, came back to life today with an upset victory in a key by- election.    Michael Hancock, a 39-year-old Social Democrat, captured the constituency of Portsmouth South against the predictions of the opinion polls and the major party leaders.

headline: Effect on Beatrice Of Esmark Deal
abstract: The Beatrice Foods Company said it expects its pending acquisition of Esmark Inc. to accelerate its marketing plans by five years. James L. Dutt, chairman, said at the annual meeting that the chief objective of the Chicago-based company would be to reduce the debt incurred to finance the acquisition, noting that divestiture of a number of units yet to be determined is expected to reduce debt by ''at least $1 billion.''

headline: WALL ST. COLUMNS GET WIDE SCRUTINY
abstract: Members of the financial community say they always take a somewhat skeptical view of investment columns, but their wide following among the public makes such columns an important market force.   Attention was focused on such columns last week, when The Wall Street Journal reported that one of its reporters, R. Foster Winans, had admitted to the Securities and Exchange Commission that he periodically provided information to outsiders about forthcoming ''Heard on the Street'' columns. These columns discuss the stock prospects for a company or industry, and can move stock prices sharply, if only temporarily.   Other columns with an impact on the market are Alan Abelson's front- page column in Barron's, the financial weekly published by The Journal's owner, Dow Jones & Company; Dan Dorfman's syndicated column, and Vartanig G. Vartan's ''Market Place'' column in The New York Times. Louis Rukeyser's Friday evening television program, ''Wall Street Week,'' plays a similar role.

headline: Airline's Chief Resigns
abstract: Michael E. Levine has resigned as president and chief executive of New York Airlines, the company said yesterday. The carrier, which specializing in low-cost, short- to medium-haul service, is a subsidiary of the Texas Air Corporation. Mr. Levine joined New York Air in early 1982. The company said he would return to his academic and consulting career, and would continue as a consultant to New York Air.

headline: Nigeria Plans New Currency
abstract: Nigeria's military government announced tonight that the country's local currency, the naira, is to be replaced within two weeks in a move to root out corruption.

headline: CHINA TO PRESS REAGAN ON TAIWAN ARMS
abstract: The Chinese leadership is ready to press the issue of United States arms sales to Taiwan when President Reagan visits China next week, a leading foreign affairs magazine here has indicated.   In its issue appearing Monday, World Affairs, a magazine published every other month, said dicussion of Taiwan could not be bypassed in developing relations between the two countries. It said the issue was central to three joint communiques signed by Washington and Peking and had been included in every set of American-Chinese negotiations since the first talks at ambassadorial level in 1955.   ''It is to be hoped that the U.S. President will use his discretion to insure that the principles and commitment duly acknowledged by the two nations in the three joint communiques will be implemented, especially with regard to arms sales to Taiwan,'' the New China News Agency said today in paraphrasing the article. Mr. Reagan is to visit China from April 26 to May 1.

headline: ZIMBABWEAN SAYS 6 ARE ALIVE
abstract: A rebel leader says six tourists, including two Americans, who were abducted in July 1982 are still alive and will be released if the Government meets political demands.   Gilbert Ngwenya, 42 years old, a rebel commander in Zimbabwe's war for independence, made the statement Monday before a magistrate in Bulawayo.

headline: Ex-Mexico Police Chief Arrested in Puerto Rico
abstract: The former Mexico City chief of police, Arturo Durazo, who is wanted by the Mexican Government for questioning on suspicion of embezzlement of public funds and extortion, was arrested tonight at San Juan airport, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced.   Richard W. Held, special agent in charge of the F.B.I. office in San Juan, said Mr. Durazo was wanted for questioning in connection with charges that he extorted a month's salary from every member of Mexico City's 30,000- strong police force.   Mr. Durazo, a friend of former President Jose Lopez Portillo, in whose administration he served, disappeared from Mexico when President Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado took office in 1982.

headline: NICARAGUANS OPEN WORLD COURT CASE
abstract: Nicaragua called on the World Court today to issue a restraining order to stop the United States from supporting military activities against the Sandinista Government.    Nicaragua's attorneys, making their appeal before the 15-member Court in the Great Hall of Justice of the Peace Palace here, asked the Court for ''interim measures of protection.'' Essentially this protection would be a ban on all United States military activities relating to Nicaragua while the Court examines the Nicaraguan application to declare that United States support for guerrilla groups fighting the Managua Government is illegal.   Lawyers for the United States were not heard during the first day of proceedings. After the first presentations today, Davis R. Robinson, legal adviser to the State Department, described the Nicaraguan arguments before the Court as ''basically political.''

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: Chiat, Ogilvy Top Winners    Mather Inc. tied for the title of  ''most honored ad agency'' at  Friday night's 20th annual  Andy Awards Presentation of  the Advertising Club of New  York. Each won seven of the 60  awards for excellence.

headline: LEADER OF STRIKING BRITISH MINERS OPTIMISTIC ABOUT OPENING TALKS
abstract: The National Union of Mineworkers and the National Coal Board, locked in a dispute that has closed most of the nation's coal mines for nearly three months, moved toward negotiations today for the first time in weeks.    A letter from the Coal Board suggesting talks ''might offer a prospect of finding a solution'' was warmly received by Arthur Scargill, president of the union, who termed it ''a completely new departure from the Coal Board's intransigent attitude.''   However, Mr. Scargill's reply emphasized that there could be no talks until the board, which controls virtually all of Britain's coal mines, withdraws its plan to reduce the coal industry's workforce by 20,000 and close a number of mines it calls obsolete. As a result, it was not clear if either side had shown any sign that it would change its basic position.

headline: Market Place; Analysts Split On Car Makers
abstract: FORTUNES of the Big Three auto makers rebounded dramatically in 1983 as General    Motors almost quadrupled its per-share earnings, while Ford and Chrysler raced into the black after a string of money-losing years. Currently, despite general agreement that profits should show robust gains this year, analysts remain sharply divided on their advice to investors.    In a sense, the division boils down to this question: How much of the good news has already been discounted by the stock market?   Firmly entrenched in the bullish camp is the Value Line Investment Survey, which rates G.M., Ford and Chrysler all as ''timely purchases.'' The nation's largest investment advisory service, in fact, now ranks the automotive industry as its leading candidate among 93 industries to outperform the general market over the next 12 months. Its choice as the least timely commitment for the year ahead is the securities brokerage industry.

headline: AS ALLIES RECALL D-DAY, RUSSIANS SAY IT WAS JUST A SIDESHOW TO THEIR WAR
abstract: As Western Allies prepare to celebrate the 40th anniversary of the D-day landings in Normandy, the Soviet Union is pressing a counteroffensive aimed at showing that the invasion was of relatively minor significance when compared with the Red Army's battles against the Germans and the Soviet drive to Berlin.    Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov has been joined by Soviet generals and military historians to assert that the ''historical truth'' is the war was decided on the Soviet-German front - at a cost in casualties that made Western losses seem light by comparison.   Soviet officers and writers have long contended that the Normandy landings were intentionally delayed by Western intrigues aimed at pushing a still greater burden onto the Russians, and that Allied commanders, including Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Field Marshal Bernard Law Montgomery, botched the planning and execution.   Soviet Sees Propaganda Show    The commemorations in Normandy next week, at which President Reagan, Queen Elizabeth II and President Francois Mitterrand of France will preside, have been mocked here as an American propaganda show designed to drum into Western Europeans their dependence on United States military might and to further American might for nuclear war in Europe.

headline: CONGRESS FAILS TO ACT ON BANKRUPTCH SYSTEM
abstract: The nation's bankruptcy courts went out of business at midnight Wednesday, as Congress failed to meet a deadline for extending their authority.   The House and Senate adjourned early this morning before a House- Senate conference committee could resolve differences between the bankruptcy bills passed by each.    A spokesman for the Administrative Office of the United States Courts predicted the impasse would have no immediate impact. Toni House, the spokesman, said the bankruptcy courts would hear cases today under an emergency plan worked out by the governing body of the Federal courts, the Judicial Conference of the United States. But Miss House could not provide details of the plan.

headline: ;  President of Wyle Labs Is Appointed Chairman
abstract: Stanley A. Wainer, president and chief executive officer of Wyle Laboratories, has been named chairman, the company announced yesterday.    Mr. Wainer, 58, succeeds Frank S. Wyle, who founded Wyle Laboratories 35 years ago. The company said that Mr. Wyle had been named founder chairman, and that he would continue as chairman of the board's executive committee.

headline: Mortgage Corp. II
abstract: The Guaranteed Mortgage Corporation II yesterday offered $175 million worth of collateralized mortgage bonds. The bonds were issued in four series, all using coupons of 12.5 percent, and were priced to yield between 13.87 percent and 14.55 percent.

headline: Soviet Assails Japan For Honoring a Hero
abstract: The Soviet Union has protested Japan's celebration this weekend honoring Heihachiro Togo, the hero of Japanese naval victories over czarist Russia in 1904 and 1905.   Moscow said the commemoration is aimed at rekindling militaristic and anti-Soviet sentiment.

headline: Xerox Canada Inc. Sets Sale of Units
abstract: Xerox Canada Inc., a unit of the Xerox Corporation, said it had filed a final prospectus for the sale of 5.3 million units for $19 (Canadian) each, to raise a total of $100.7 million.

headline: NCR OFFICER TO RUN COMPUTER DIVISION
abstract: The NCR Corporation announced yesterday that it had established a personal computer division. It named a vice president, Vernon W. Yates, to be the new division's general manager.    In making the announcement, Charles E. Exley Jr., chairman and president of NCR, said the company ''intends to be a major participant in the personal computer market.''

headline: U.N. Votes for Greek Cypriots On Turks' Secession Efforts
abstract: The Security Council voted 13 to 1 on Friday to condemn ''secessionist actions'' on Cyprus, including an exchange of ambassadors between the self-proclaimed Turkish Cypriot Republic and Turkey.   Pakistan, a Moslem nation, cast the sole negative vote in the 15-member council, and the United States abstained.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Talking Textbooks Inc. to B. A. Margan & Associates.     * The Home Furnishings division of the Allied Corp. to Rumrill-Hoyt/ New York, for its Anso IV nylon carpet fiber.

headline: A FINAL WORD; TAXES AND GRANDMA'S SHOPPING LIST
abstract: AMERICANS sometimes fancy   themselves as rational, cold-  eyed decision-makers. Our businesses claim to practice zero- based budgeting, and our consumer- driven economy ruthlessly rejects unwanted products and services. In short, we like to think we are like the man my grandmother said was ''not the sort of feller to go shoppin' without a list.''   Yet each year the Federal Government spends an awful chunk of our money, an amount that in 1984 will be equal to 22 cents for every dollar of total personal income earned by all Americans, equal to $3,000 for every man, woman, and child - and for the most part, we who are the source of the largesse say little about it, leaving its disposition in the hands of politicians. We taxpayers, Grandma would say, are shoppin' without a list.

headline: 2 SENATORS SAY DUARTE PROPOSES NICARAGUA TALKS
abstract: Two United States Senators said today that Jose Napoleon Duarte, who is running for the presidency of El Salvador, told them he would seek negotiations with Nicaragua if he was elected.   Reagan Administration officials have accused Nicaragua of seeking the overthrow of the Salvadoran Government through its support of rebels in that country. Much of the support is believed to be in the form of clandestine shipments of ammunition.

headline: RETIRED GENERAL TAKES OVER ISRAELI-BACKED SOUTH LEBANON MILITIA
abstract: A retired Lebanese general, Antoine Lahad, formally took command of the Israeli-backed South Lebanese militia today and said he would not merge it with the Lebanese Army until Lebanon ''comes to terms with the Israeli Government.''   He succeeds Maj. Saad Haddad, who died in January.

headline: IRAQ REPORTS ATTACK ON 2 SHIPS, BUT IRAN DENIES IT
abstract: Iraq announced today that its planes had hit two large ships north and west of the Iranian oil terminal at Kharg Island Friday night. Iran quickly denied the report and it was not confirmed elsewhere.   Early this morning the official Iraqi press agency quoted a military spokesman as saying that at midnight Iraqi planes successfully attacked ''two large naval targets,'' the standard Iraqi formulation for an air strike against ships in the war zone it has declared near Kharg Island.   Later today, however, the official Iranian press agency, quoting official sources, denied that any ships had been hit near Kharg Island. The denial was unusual, since Teheran does not usually comment on either its own attacks on Persian Gulf tankers or on Iraqi strikes against ships taking on oil at Kharg Island.

headline: Preway in Pact To Add Arkla
abstract: Preway Inc. said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the business and assets of Arkla Industries Inc., an Arkla Inc. subisidiary, in a transaction valued at about $110 million.

headline: S.E.C. NAMES HEAD OF JOURNAL INQUIRY
abstract: Gary Lynch, the 33-year-old associate director of the Securities and Exchange Commission's enforcement division, has been named to head its investigation into whether a reporter for The Wall Street Journal improperly gave outsiders sensitive information on articles he wrote and whether the outsiders traded securities illegally on the basis of such information.   Mr. Lynch, who has been with the agency eight years, is known as something of a boy wonder. People at the S.E.C. say Mr. Lynch was the choice of John Fedders, the head of the enforcement division. Last week Mr. Fedders disqualified himself from the case after one of the subjects of the investigation hired a lawyer, Milton V. Freeman, who is a partner at Arnold & Porter, the firm Mr. Fedders left to join the S.E.C. in 1981.

headline: 6 Tourists Die in Mexico
abstract: A bus carrying a group of French tourists plunged into a ravine, reportedly killing six people and injuring 26, including the driver, the French Embassy said today.

headline: MEXICAN OFFICIAL CONDEMNS MINING OF NICARAGUA'S PORTS
abstract: Mexico's Foreign Minister today denounced the mining of Nicaragua's ports as a violation of international law and called for ''the total elimination of all armed violence, direct or indirect, against Nicaragua.''   The Foreign Minister, Bernardo Sepulveda Amor, also asserted that countries cannot on their own withdraw from the jurisdiction of the International Court of Justice.   The Reagan Administration announced Sunday that it would not accept decisions by the World Court in disputes over Central America for the next two years. Nicaragua later asked the court to declare United States-backed activities against its territory illegal.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM PAPER BY TREASURY ON ACCORD
abstract: Following are excerpts from a Treasury Department background paper on the measures agreed to today by Japan and the United States that are aimed at broadening the use of the yen as an international currency and at deregulating Japan's domestic financial markets:      The policy changes announced by Japan will occur in three broad areas: the Euroyen market, the operation of Japan's domestic capital market, and the access of foreign financial institutions to the Japanese capital market.     The Euroyen Market    Effective Dec. 1, 1984, the number and types of issuers of Euroyen bonds will be expanded significantly with the result that any borrower meeting credit criteria can issue. Of particular importance is that non-Japanese corporations will for the first time be able to issue yen-denominated Eurobonds.   The credit criteria initially applied will parallel those in the Samurai market - that is, the domestic Japanese market for foreign yen bond issues. However, these credit criteria will be further liberalized from April 1, 1985, to permit any borrower rated AA or better as well as a reasonable portion of those world corporations that would be rated A to issue such bonds.  These corporations, as well as all other foreign issuers of Euroyen bonds, will face no restrictions on the number or size of issue, and will not be required to use the Samurai market as a prerequisite.

headline: Dorsey Holdings
abstract: An investment group led by Shamrock Associates told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its holdings in the Dorsey Corporation common stock to 1,038,700 shares, or 27.7 percent of the total outstanding.

headline: Trust Issue Priced
abstract: A $100 million 30-year first mortgage and collateral trust bond issue for the Texas Utilities Electric Company was priced yesterday by an underwriting team lead by Morgan Stanley & Company to yield 13.70 percent. The bonds, due in 2014, were given a 13 5/8 percent coupon and priced at 99.44. The issue is rated Aa-2 by Moody's and AAx by S. & P. The proceeds from the sale will be used to meet expenditures for the company's construction program, and other corporate purposes.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: *  Ajinomoto Co.  said that its issue of convertible Eurodollar bonds due in 1999 had been increased to $100 million, from $80 million, and that the indicated coupon had been lowered to 3 percent, from 3 1/4 percent, through Nomura International Ltd.     *  Beneficial Corp.'s $75 million issue of 12 3/8 percent notes due in 1988 was priced at 99 7/8, to yield 12.42 percent, through First Boston Corp. The issue is rated A3 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's Corp.     *  Morgan Guaranty Trust Co.'s $150 million issue of 12 1/4 percent Eurobonds due in 1989 was priced at par, through Morgan Guaranty Ltd.     *  Naugles Inc., an operator of fast- food restaurants, filed a shelf registration for 25,000 units, each consisting of $1,000 of senior subordinated debentures and warrants to buy an undetermined number of common shares, through Prudential-Bache Securities.

headline: Corco Marine In Chapter 11
abstract: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company said its Corco Marine Inc. unit had filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. Commonwealth Oil also said it may have to file for bankruptcy if its proposed recapitalization plan is not completed.

headline: 4 in Group Raise Offer for Enstar
abstract: Four companies said they had sweetened their bid for the Enstar Corporation to the equivalent of $19 a share, plus 12.5 percent interest on the cash amount.

headline: RUMOR ON LOAN CURBS IS DENIED
abstract: Henry C. Wallich, the Federal Reserve Board's senior governor, denied today that the Fed is considering putting controls on ''nonproductive'' lending - that is, bank loans that companies use to finance takeovers of other companies.    Rumors that the Fed might attempt to relieve pressure on interest rates by curbing such lending began circulating in financial markets earlier this week. Markets have been in turmoil in recent weeks because of rising rates and because of the near collapse of the Continental Illinois National Bank of Chicago earlier this month.   An Old-Hat Rumor    But, Mr. Wallich suggested in an interview, the rumor is pretty well old hat. ''That has come up many times'' in the past, he said. ''But once you get into classifying loans as productive and nonproductive, that quickly becomes a nonproductive activity.''

headline: VESCO REPORTED IN CUBA, AS TANGIBLE AS A GHOST
abstract: Diplomats here say that Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive American financier, has been living a reclusive life in Cuba for more than a year, dividing his time among modest houses at three beach resorts and aboard a 50-foot ocean-going yacht.     But the diplomats discount reports that Mr. Vesco has been welcomed to Cuba by the Cuban leader, Fidel Castro, because he has helped in drug smuggling or ''money laundering'' operations. They also discount reports that he is here because he has pirated machinery and technology to Cuba.   Instead, the diplomats say, they believe Mr. Vesco is being sheltered here simply because he is spending a lot of money, which Cuba especially needs because of poor world prices for sugar, its main export, and because his presence might be regarded as an embarrassment to the United States.   One diplomat estimated that Mr. Vesco was spending $50,000 a month to maintain his houses and vehicles here and to care for his wife and two young daughters, who have been seen with him.

headline: Continental Illinois To Cut 1,000 Jobs
abstract: The Continental Illinois Corporation, still reeling from a series of problem loans, announced that it would cut another 1,000 jobs and freeze executive salaries this year.    David G. Taylor, chief executive officer of the nation's seventh-largest bank holding company, told the annual meeting that this year and next would be ''a time to get tough and get lean.'' He said that his salary, that of Edward Bottum, Continental's president, and of all executive vice presidents would stay at 1983 levels.

headline: South Korean Cabbies Riot
abstract: Taxi drivers demanding higher pay vandalized their company's offices in the southern city of Taegu, destroying more than 30 cars and other property, the police said today.

headline: MONEY SUPPLY UP $2.2 BILLION
abstract: Interest rates fell slightly yesterday, with most of the decline coming after the Federal Reserve's 4:30 P.M. announcement of a $2.2 billion increase in the nation's money supply for the week ended March 26, to $538.3 billion.     The slight drop in short- and long- term interest rates came after sharp increases earlier this week, leading some analysts to conclude that credit market participants might have overestimated the rapidity and degree to which the Fed was encouraging higher interest rates.   The absence of an increase in the discount rate, which the Fed charges on loans to financial institutions, was more responsible for the modest drop in rates yesterday than any revival of investor demand or change in the widespread perception that the Fed is tightening monetary policy and fostering higher interest rates.    The discount rate has been at 8 1/2 percent since December 1982, but many analysts expect an increase soon to bring it into closer alignment with other interest rates and to make it easier for the Fed to discourage banks and other institutions from borrowing at the window.

headline: Legislator Says Panel Was Misled by C.I.A.
abstract: The House intelligence committee learned last October about the Central Intelligence Agency's direct supervision of a commando raid on the Nicaraguan port of Corinto, but only because ''we were persistent in ferreting out the information,'' a panel member said tonight.   Representative Norman Y. Mineta, Democrat of California, said the C.I.A. initially informed the panel that the Oct. 10 raid on Corinto, in which a major oil fire was touched off, had been carried out by a Nicaraguan rebel group.

headline: Litton Expansion
abstract: Litton Industries said it plans to buy 25 acres of land in Orlando, Fla., and build a $14 million headquarters for its International Laser Systems division. An announcement from Litton's Washington office said construction is scheduled to start this summer and occupancy is expected in early 1985. Litton's Laser division employs about 400 people in developing and production of laser systems for military and law enforcement markets.

headline: Executive at Showtime Unexpectedly Resigns
abstract: In an unexpected move, Michael Weinblatt has stepped down as president and chief operating officer at Showtime/The Movie Channel Inc., the nation's second-largest pay television service. Mr. Weinblatt's resignation is effective July 31.     ''This is a surprise to me,'' said John S. Reidy, an analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. ''Last week, Mr. Weinblatt met with analysts at the National Cable Television Association in Las Vegas, and we had no impression at that time that he was going to go away. In view of his accomplishments, I think it's a loss to the company.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: FRIDAY, APRIL 13, 1984   Markets    Stock prices surged. The Dow Jones industrials rose 26.17 , to 1,157.14, the strongest gain in more than six weeks. Volume rose to 96.3 million shares. Analysts said investors were encouraged by a run of strong earnings results and higher bond prices. (Page D1.)    M-1 fell $5 billion, twice the drop expected.  But the money supply data had little effect on the credit markets; prices remained strong and interest rates fell a bit. (D14.) The Municipal Assistance Corporation is to sell about $225 million of bonds. (D15.) Money market mutual funds increased their assets by $647 million. (D6.)

headline: Metalworkers' Chief Sees Gains in German Pact
abstract: The head of the International Metalworkers Federation said today that a new 38 1/2-hour week for West German workers, achieved after a strike, would lead to a 30-hour week for most workers within 10 years.   ''The achievement of the German metalworkers in winning the 38 1/2-hour week in Europe's most important industrial economy means that the 40- hour week is now in the dustbin of industrial history,'' the federation's general secretary, Herman Rebhan, said.

headline: Advertising; Citizen Watch in U.S. Push
abstract: ALTHOUGH it has only been selling its products in the United States for seven years, the Citizen Watch Company of Japan, the world's largest maker of watches, is determined to move into a lead role in this country. That means pushing out K. Hattori & Company, Japanese maker of the Seiko, Pulsar, Lorus, Alba and Jazz brands.     To that end, Citizen's United States marketing company, based in Lyndhurst, N.J., has brought in Masao Ito, No. 2 man in Citizen's international operation, to be chairman; has eliminated all distributors and has 60 salespeople selling direct to retail; has retained Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver for the biggest spending advertising campaign in its American history, and plans to spend more on advertising in the remaining months of this year than it has spent collectively in the last seven.    The budget is set at between $12 million and $15 million and will all be spent on television, concentrated in 23 spot markets between now and the end of the year. According to James Sottile, senior vice president of Citizen and a former Pulsar executive, the budget is more than the total of the company's ad spending up to now.

headline: Filipino Opposition Lauds Aquino as Hero
abstract: Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the slain opposition leader, was proclaimed a national hero of Filipinos at an Independence Day gathering of opposition parties tonight.   Salvador Laurel, head of the United Nationalist Democratic Organization, extolled Mr. Aquino for his ''infectious courage and patriotism,'' which he said had inspired significant gains by opposition candidates May 14.

headline: SENATE VOTES $47 BILLION TAX RISE TO HELP TRIM THE FEDERAL DEFICIT
abstract: The Senate, after four long days of debate, early this morning wearily approved a $47 billion tax increase that is its first step toward a $143 billion deficit reduction package.   The bill, approved at 5 A.M., raises liquor taxes, modifies some individual income tax breaks and restricts some business tax breaks. A provision that diminishes the tax-shelter value of real estate investments could raise taxes for individuals and corporations.    The bill also includes billions of dollars of miscellaneous, small measures of tax relief, including an expansion for contributions to Individual Retirement Accounts for one-income couples.

headline: LAWS RESTRICT BRITISH ACTION AGAINST LIBYA
abstract: International law dictates broad immunity for accredited diplomats and makes embassy grounds inviolable, limiting the British Government's ability to act against those responsible for the shootings from the Libyan Embassy in London today.    Experts said that even a murder suspect who enjoys diplomatic status would be immune from criminal prosecution, and that the British police would ordinarily be barred from entering the Libyan Embassy without the consent of its officers.   On the other hand, the British Government could expel any or all Libyan diplomats from its territory, close the embassy and prosecute any suspect who does not have diplomatic immunity, experts said.   In addition, the fact that the Libyan Embassy in London was taken over and its accredited diplomats were ejected by revolutionary students in February, without formal notification to the British authorities, could cast doubt on whether those now occupying the embassy were entitled to diplomatic immunity.

headline: LOW DEMAND FOR U.S. BONDS
abstract: The credit markets were sent reeling yesterday by a lack of investor demand at this week's three-part Treasury financing, combined with growing fears that the Federal Reserve is tightening monetary policy.    Evidence of weak investor demand came at the 1 P.M. auction of $4.75 billion of new 13 1/4 percent 30-year Treasury bonds, which resulted in an average yield of 13.32 percent.    After the Treasury announced results of the bidding, securities dealers concluded that demand was even weaker than they had estimated, and many were willing to take a quick loss and sell bonds they had bid for only hours earlier.    By late in the day, the new 13 1/4 issue was offered with a yield of 13.43 percent, while the old 12 percent bonds due in 2013 were offered at 89 3/4, down nearly 1 1/4 points on the day.

headline: 10 Are Reported Killed In Ugandan Army Clash
abstract: Two Ugandan Army units hunting for rebels clashed with each other at Kirolo, about 40 miles north of Kampala, and more than 10 people, including civilians, were killed, the newspaper Munno reported today.   The Government had no immediate comment on the report and no motive for the clash was given.

headline: PATENTS;  Interferon Process
abstract: The Cetus Corporation, a genetic engineering company in Emeryville, Calif., received a patent this week on a process for recovering human fibroblast beta-interferon from microorganisms, by extraction using specific alcohols.

headline: CONTINENTAL DEPOSITORS GET OFFER
abstract: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, the troubled Chicago bank, said yesterday that it was trying to woo back individual depositors by offering to repay the penalties they had suffered when they withdrew their funds in the recent run on the bank.    In an unusual move in an effort to improve its condition, Continental sent a letter to more than 150 depositors saying that ''as an accommodation to'' customers who suffered a financial penalty as a result of an early withdrawal on an investment certificate, it would repay the penalties to those customers who reopen investment certificates. Normally, the early withdrawal penalty comes to several months' interest.    The letter was addressed to former holders of certificates of deposits, who were among the depositors who participated in the run that followed rumors that Continental, the nation's eighth-largest and the Middle West's largest bank, was about to fail. These certificates, a bank spokesman said, could have ranged from $2,500 to millions of dollars.

headline: LOCAL COSTS SHOW AN INCREASE OF 0.3%
abstract: Prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose three- tenths of 1 percent in April, primarily as a result of increases in housing and transportation, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.    Food prices fell, however.     Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the bureau, said that prices, over all, continued on a ''moderate path'' last month and, between April 1983 and April 1984, had gone up 5 percent. That year-to-year increase, he added, was lower than in 12 of the last 16 years.

headline: Explosion in Athens Leaves 53 Injured
abstract: Fifty-three people were injured, 10 of them seriously, by a powerful explosion in the crowded city center of Athens today, the Athens News Agency quoted police officials as saying.   Ioannis Skoularikis, Greece's Minister of Public Order, said the explosion, in the kitchen of a fast-food outlet near Omonia Square apparently resulted from a leak in a gas bottle and was not a bomb.   ''We are almost certain the explosion resulted from a gas leak and not from a bomb,'' Mr. Skoularikis said, ''but we are still examining all possibilities.''

headline: Quaker Oats Assigns Celeste Pizza Account
abstract: Last month Backer & Spielvogel got an unidentified cereal product assignment from the Quaker Oats Company.

headline: No Headline
abstract: The U.N. Today May 18, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M.

headline: CAMPBELL'S SOUP-TO-NUTS PLAN
abstract: ''If you think of the food business as being your desk top, picture a wide segment in the middle that takes up about half of the desk,'' says John Morris, vice president of corporate development at the Campbell Soup Company.  ''that's where Campbell is today.  What we want to do is get on either side.''   Campbell, which opened its first factory here 113 years ago, has been following a strategy to expand beyond its base of soups, Swanson frozen food and Pepperidge Farm baked goods, and that activity has increased in the last three months.  a company long known for its conservative approach to business, Campbell is now committed to a growth-through acquisition strategy and a new emphasis on marketing.   In January, it entered the frozen sandwich market when it purchased for an undisclosed sum Snow King Inc., a Pottstown, Pa., maker of frozen sandwich meat whose sales in 1981 were $32 million.

headline: CARTER ACTS TO FOIL BID BY LIMITED
abstract: Carter Hawley Hale Stores, finally moving on several fronts to fight a tender offer by The Limited Inc., said yesterday that it had sold a million shares of a new convertible preferred stock to the General Cinema Corporation for $300 million in cash and would also purchase up to 15 million shares of its own stock.     Carter Hawley said the planned stock purchase ''is intended to defeat the attempt by Limited to gain voting control of the company.''    Carter Hawley also gave General Cinema a six-month option to purchase the Waldenbooks chain for about $285 million.    Offer Called 'Inadequate'    The Los Angeles-based Carter Hawley, one of the nation's largest retailers, recommended that its shareholders reject The Limited's cash and stock merger offer as ''inadequate.''

headline: ON T.V. IN BAGHDAD, SICKENING IMAGES OF WAR
abstract: At odd times during the day and every night when regular programs have ended, Iraqi television reruns the same film. For about an hour the hand-held camera wanders around the field of the recent battle in the marshes along the southern end of the border with Iran.    The camera stops for a long view of dark objects lying scattered on the ground. It approaches one of the objects slowly. It offers a close-up of the object and then closes in further, to show a detail. The camera holds, to let the detail be viewed at length. Then the scene changes.

headline: NICARAGUA POLICY IS AFFIRMED BY U.S. AFTER SHULTZ TRIP
abstract: President Reagan will pursue his request for more military aid for Nicaraguan rebels even as he plans additional talks with the Nicaraguan Government, according to Secretary of State George P. Shultz.    Mr. Shultz, flying home from his visit to Nicaragua on Friday, said the Administration would continue to seek the $21 million in aid that the House of Representatives has rejected.   In Managua, the Government called the talks with Mr. Shultz a good beginning, but called for concrete United States actions to resolve the conflicts in Central America. (Page 23.)   In Ireland, a senior Reagan Administration official expressed ''dissatisfaction'' that the meeting had achieved no change in either side's position. He also said that American officials were ''irritated'' that Nicaragua issued what they considered to be a condescending communique afterwards.

headline: Market Place; 'Defensive' Stock Picks
abstract: IT looks more like a bear market than a bull market on Wall Street these days. The Dow Jones industrials yesterday sank to their lowest closing in 13 months, while the transportation average posted a 15-month low on Monday.     Small wonder, then, that selectivity and caution have become bywords of the stock-picking process at brokerage houses. After all, when Treasury bills yield 10 percent or more, it hardly seems time to sell the ranch and plunge headlong into equities.

headline: U.S.-SOVIET PARLEY ON ARMS ENDS MOSCOW, April 28 (AP) - James Goodby, the United States delegate at the Stockholm Conference on Disarmament in Europe, concluded two days of talks here today.
abstract: A United States Embassy spokesman said Mr. Goodby met Friday and today with Oleg A. Grinevsky, the Soviet delegate, as ''part of the regular consultations that they are conducting prior to the reopening of the Stockholm talks.''   The Soviet press agency Tass reported the talks, but provided no details.   Mr. Goodby will lead the United States delegation to the Stockholm conference when the second round of talks begins May 8.

headline: TRW, Trico End Merger Meetings TRW Inc. and Trico Industries said they had terminated negotiations under their letter of intent calling for the acquisition of Trico by TRW. The companies said they expected to continue exploring various options, including the possible purchase by Trico of the 1,339,530 shares of its common stock held by TRW. That represents about 16.4 percent of Trico's shares outstanding.
abstract: The letter of intent, announced in January, called for TRW to exchange 0.137 share of its stock for each Trico share. Trico, based in Gardena, Calif., is a supplier of oilfield equipment and services. TRW, based in Cleveland, is involved in high-technology products and services.

headline: IN SIERRA LEONE, LAND OF DIAMONDS, DECAY SETS IN
abstract: A European diplomat who has served in this wet and mountainous West African country for nearly two years was asked recently what had changed in that time.    He pointed out his office window past streets lined with faded clapboard houses and dingy shops to a tall yellow construction crane looming over the rusted skeleton of a building.   ''You see that crane?'' he said. ''In the past 18 months the only time that crane has moved has been when it was swinging in the wind. That's what has happened to Sierra Leone. It's just swinging in the wind.''

headline: Borman Contract
abstract: Eastern Airlines' directors offered a five-year contract today to Frank Borman, its chairman, and he is expected to accept it, a company spokesman said.

headline: Election Being Held In Guinea-Bissau
abstract: Guinea-Bissau today held its first election since a coup in 1980 brought President Joao Bernardo Vieira to power in the former Portuguese colony, the Portuguese state radio reported.

headline: SENATE VOTES TO DELETE $4 MILLION FOR TWO U.S. BASES IN HONDURAS
abstract: The Senate voted today to delete funds for construction of two military bases in Honduras that were originally sought by President Reagan.    The action came on an amendment, offered on behalf of the Administration, to cut $4.4 million from the defense authorization bill for the fiscal year 1985.    Jeff Bingaman of New Mexico, a Democrat, had been expected to offer the amendment next week, but John Tower, Republican of Texas, brought it to the Senate floor early this morning in a surprise move as the Senate began its second day of debate on the legislation.    Meanwhile, the latest large-scale military exercise involving United States, Honduran and Salvadoran troops ended today and as a result, American officials said, the number of American servicemen in Honduras will be reduced from 1,700 to 700. The officials said no new large-scale exercises were scheduled in Honduras between now and the Presidential elections in November. (Page 3.)

headline: 7,000 Flee Zulu Strife In South Africa District
abstract: More than 7,000 people have fled their homes in the South African south coast district of Umbumbulu as the death toll in clan strife last week climbed to 44, local residents and a priest said today.   The discovery of three more bodies today at Umbumbulu, about 20 miles southwest of Durban, brought the number of deaths in the area to 69 in the last month, the police said.

headline: THE BASQUES: ANCIENT TUG-OF-WAR GOES ON
abstract: The oak tree of Guernica, an ancient hollow tree stump some 15 feet high, sits inside a columned monument on a small bluff. On these warm spring days, busloads of children from all over the Basque region come to see it.    They listen as the guide explains that in the Middle Ages the monarchs of Castile had to stand in that very spot to swear obedience to the fueros, the laws by which Basques exchanged limited homage to the Spanish crown for the right to run their own affairs.   A surprising number of the children peer at the stump solemnly, as if to divine a message there. They seem lost in the contemplation of their own Basqueness.

headline: HOLDING DOWN COSTS AT A COMPLEX IN SULLIVAN COUNTY
abstract: Since the mid-1970's the shortage of attractive new housing costing less than $100,000 has become much talked about. But there are some builders who have been able to turn out such homes and make a profit.    One such entrepreneur is Steven A. Klar, a 36-year-old developer based on Long Island. In the last two years, Mr. Klar, who has also built custom homes in the $350,000 range, has opened two developments of homes priced well under $100,000.

headline: National Steel
abstract: The Justice Department said it would not challenge on antitrust grounds a proposal by Nippon Kokan Kabushiki Kaisha to purchase 50 percent of the shares of the National Steel Corporation. J. Paul McGrath, head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, said the transaction did not present competitive problems. Under the proposal, Nippon, Japan's second-largest steelmaker, would pay $292 million for 50 percent of the shares outstanding of National Steel, which is a unit of National Intergroup Inc. The purchase marks the largest move by a foreign steelmaker into the American market.

headline: Feldstein Sees Faster Growth
abstract: The American economy will likely grow faster than the Administration's latest official estimate of 5 percent this year and inflation will remain under control, the chief White House economist, Martin Feldstein, said today. ''And, looking ahead to 1985, all of the current indicators suggest that the economy will continue to expand at a desirable rate with rising incomes and falling unemployment,'' he added.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Bell Industries , a Los Angeles- based aircraft parts company, said it had terminated by mutual agreement its merger discussions with Astrex Inc., a distributor of electronics.   * Custom Creamery Systems Inc. , a gourmet desserts company, said it had agreed in principle with Zayre Corp. to install its flavor factory outlets in 70 Zayre stores nationwide.

headline: Celanese Earnings Soar
abstract: The Celanese Corporation, one of the world's largest producers of man- made fibers, said net income in the first quarter increased more than sevenfold, to $44 million, or $2.74 a share, from $6 million, or 32 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 9.3 percent, to $837 million, from $766 million.

headline: Iraq Reports 142 Raids On Iranians' Positions
abstract: Iraq asserted that it carried out intensive bombing raids against Iranian positions today, inflicting heavy losses.

headline: German Car Imports
abstract: Foreign makers increased their share of the West German new car market to 28.3 percent in first quarter from 25 percent a year earlier, the national motor office said Friday. First-quarter sales by foreign producers totaled 194,780, up from 163,900 in the 1983 period.

headline: Sears Halts Sales Of Coleco's Adam
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company disclosed that it had suspended sales of Coleco Industries' Adam home computer system about a month ago, for reasons it would not specify. ''We are trying to tell the consumer that at this point we prefer that they wait'' before buying the system, a Sears spokesman said.

headline: ; Chiat Wins at Cannes For '1984' Apple Spot
abstract: Despair no more, oh ye of little faith. The nation's advertising creativity is not as dead as a dodo. Chiat/ Day won the Grand Prix at the 31st annual International Advertising Film Festival in Cannes, France, over the weekend - the first such win for an American agency in five years.

headline: Debt Problem Downplayed
abstract: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said the world debt problem had been blown out of proportion and had caused exaggerated concerns about the health of many United States banks.   Mr. Volcker told a meeting of Princeton University alumni there were problems with some debtor nations, but the overall situation was manageable. ''I do not think it is possible to apply an across-the-board cure,'' he said, adding each debtor country needed individual attention.

headline: Market Place; Stock Buyback Advantages
abstract: WHILE leveraged buyouts like the recent $2.4 billion offer for Esmark Inc. are creating the greatest excitement in Wall Street, corporate buyback programs also are on the rise.    Under a corporate buyback, a company uses its own money to repurchase part of its outstanding common stock when it considers such a move the best investment for its cash. A leveraged, or management, buyout has the effect of taking a publicly owned company private, with senior executives usually investing more heavily in their companies. These buyouts often utilize the corporate assets as collateral for loans to finance the purchase of at least a major part of the company's stock.

headline: CZECH MISSILES ARE SAID TO BE AIMED AT U.S. BASES
abstract: The Czechoslovak Chief of Staff was quoted today as having said that new Soviet missiles in his country were aimed at United States nuclear missile bases in Western Europe.   The officer, Col. Gen. Miloslav Blahnik, also said in an interview with Rude Pravo, the Communist Party daily, that Czechoslovakia was upgrading its air defense system and that these defensive measures would not affect neutral and nonaligned countries.   The Soviet bloc will ''never allow the United States and NATO to achieve military supremacy,'' C.T.K., the Czechoslovak press agency, quoted General Blahnik as having told Rude Pravo.

headline: ;  Chief Is Outside Family At Vermont American
abstract: The Vermont American Corporation has named a president and chief executive who is from outside the Thomas family.     Robert I. Baker, 43, succeeds Lee B. Thomas Jr., who becomes chairman. Mr. Thomas, who is 58, succeeds his father, who at age 83 becomes chairman of the board's executive committee.    The senior Mr. Thomas founded the company, then known as American Saw and Tool, in 1947. ''Dad and I will continue to be active in the business,'' his son said. ''But it's time for the younger people to take on additional responsibilities. I think it's time for a marketing man to head the business.''

headline: GRENADA'S FIRST PREMIER TO RUN IN NEW VOTE
abstract: Grenada's first Prime Minister, who took office while the Caribbean island was still under British rule, says he plans to run for the office again in the next elections.     Herbert Blaize, the 64-year-old leader of the Grenada National Party, said in New York this week that he was a candidate for Prime Minister in elections tentatively scheduled for the end of 1984. The elections will mark the first time that residents of Grenada have elected a leader since 1977.   Since the United States invasion Oct. 25, Grenadian affairs have been administered by an interim government headed by Nicholas Brathwaite. The invasion, which also involved forces from other Caribbean nations, began after a hard-line Marxist faction toppled the leftist Government of Prime Minister Maurice Bishop.

headline: Rosenfeld, Sirowitz Handling Smith-Corona
abstract: Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson has been named the ad agency for the Smith-Corona Group of the SCM Corporation, a major manufacturer of electronic and electric typewriters.

headline: Tropicana Account To Benton & Bowles
abstract: Beatrice Foods, Chicago, completed its decision-making process yesterday and assigned its Tropicana Products account to Benton & Bowles, New York.

headline: DOWNING OF KOREAN JET HAILED
abstract: A senior Soviet military official, marking the official ''Day of Antiaircraft Defenses,'' today hailed the downing of the Korean Airlines 747 jetliner last September.   The official, Marshal of Aviation Aleksandr I. Koldunov, a deputy Defense Minister, said the destruction of the plane was a feat of arms comparable to the shooting down of the American U-2 spy plane in 1960.

headline: TEMPLE RAID OPENING RIFTS IN INDIAN CITY
abstract: On the surface, life appears normal in this industrial city in the heart of Punjab state, 10 days after Indian troops raided and cleared the Golden Temple of hundreds of Sikh terrorists.    The markets are open and crowded, although business is slack. Long lines of Sikhs and Hindus cycle to work to the hundreds of manufacturing units that produce the cycles, woollen goods, hosiery and machine parts for which Ludhiana is renowned in other parts of India.   Small armed groups of army, policemen and paramilitary forces stand guard and check vehicles entering the city. Along the broad, bumpy highway they also patrol the congested markets where people, cycle rickshaws, cars and motorcycles jostle for space.

headline: Unicorp Discusses Its Stake in Amrep
abstract: A group including the Unicorp American Corporation and the Unicorp Canada Corporation told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it is talking with the Amrep Corporation about the repurchase of Amrep stock.

headline: FRENCH WEIGH ASYLUM FOR IRANIAN HIJACKERS
abstract: As Iranian exiles marched through the streets of Paris today, French officials weighed a request for political asylum by four Iranians who commandered a navy plane and forced it to land in Nice.    Government spokesmen said it might take a few days before a decision was reached. Agence France-Presse said today that the four men had been moved to an unidentified place in northern France.

headline: SOUTH AFRICANS AND ANGOLANS SAID TO MEET ON TROOP RECALL
abstract: Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha of South Africa met today with senior Angolan officials in Lusaka, the Zambian capital, to discuss a South African troop withdrawal from southern Angola, according to Zambian officials.    The encounter was apparently part of a South African effort to resolve the 17-year-old conflict in South-West Africa on its own terms and establish a regional settlement.   The United States, according to Western officials in Zambia and South Africa, has not been included in the diplomacy, although the newest of many efforts to end the low-key guerrilla war was undertaken in December by Chester A. Crocker, the Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs.

headline: The U.N. Today April 18, 1984
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Working Group of Experts on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights Covenant - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.  ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Commission on Transnational Corporations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: KEY C.I.A. ROLE SEEN IN POLICIES ON NICARAGUA
abstract: The White House rejected Nicaragua's Deputy Foreign Minister as the next Ambassador to Washington at the insistence of the Central Intelligence Agency, Administration officials said today.     They said the decision overruled a recommendation made by Secretary of State George P. Shultz and reflected the dominant role the C.I.A. has taken in determining United States policy toward Nicaragua.    At the urging of the C.I.A., Administration officials said, the White House is also considering imposing economic sanctions against Nicaragua, including an embargo of banana imports and the cancellation of landing rights in the United States for Nicaragua's national airline, Aeronica.   Those measures have been opposed by the State Department, the officials said. A final decision on the sanctions has not been made.

headline: SAKHAROV LETTER CALLED ON U.S. TO SHELTER WIFE
abstract: A Sakharov letter is on page 4.           WASHINGTON, May 18 - State Department officials said today that the wife of Andrei D. Sakharov gave American Embassy officials in Moscow letters last month in which he disclosed plans for a hunger strike and asked that his wife be given temporary refuge in the embassy.   But the officials said that Yelena G. Bonner, Dr. Sakharov's wife, had not discussed the hunger strike, which Dr. Sakharov began May 2, or the appeal for her to stay in the embassy. The State Department said the embassy did not know of the plans until after Miss Bonner had left for Gorky, where her husband has been exiled since 1980.

headline: ARGENTINE DEBT: A CASE STUDY
abstract: It is one of the anomalies of the Argentine foreign debt crisis that the country's largest company is mired in debt and has barely anything to show for it.   Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales - or Y.P.F., as it is more commonly known - is Argentina's state oil company, and it has run up a debt of $4.5 billion, or 10 percent of the country's entire $45 billion debt.    Yet in contracting the debt, Y.P.F. got its hands on just $300 million of it, a mere 6 percent, company officials say. The remaining $4.2 billion was used by the previous military Government to subsidize extremely low gasoline prices, to buy arms and to finance Argentine tourists traveling abroad.

headline: Raytheon Unit
abstract: The Raytheon Company said its Badger Engineers Inc. subsidiary had received a $100 million contract from the Chevron Chemical Company to design and build a phosphate fertilizer complex near Hot Springs, Wyo. Under the contract, Badger is responsible for the engineering, design, procurement and construction of all facilities at the site. Raytheon said the plant is scheduled to be completed in late 1986.

headline: NICARAGUA TAKES CASE AGAINST U.S. TO WORLD COURT
abstract: Nicaragua asked the World Court today to declare illegal United States support for guerrilla raids on its territory and what it said was Washington's role in the mining of Nicaraguan harbors.
