In a statement made public by its embassy here today, Nicaragua said that its suit ''asserts that the U.S. Government is training, supplying and directing military and paramilitary actions against the people and Government of Nicaragua, resulting in extensive loss of lives and property,'' in an effort ''to overthrow or destabilize the Government of Nicaragua.''   The Reagan Administration says Nicaragua is trying to overthrow the Salvadoran Government and that the mining of Nicaraguan harbors is therefore justified as a form of self-defense for El Salvador and its allies. It has said that it is supporting anti-Government insurgents in Nicaragua to stop arms it says Nicaragua is sending to Salvadoran guerrillas.

headline: Cullinet to Rizzo
abstract: Rizzo, Simons, Cohn, a three-year- old Boston ad agency, has been appointed by Cullinet Software of Westwood, Mass., to handle its $6 million account. The appointment brings the agency's annualized billings to some $18 million and its high-tech clients to four. Cullinet formerly was served by HBM/Creamer, also in Boston.

headline: The U.N. Today May 7, 1984
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on Strategy for the Third Development Decade - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: SAN JOSE BOND RATINGS CALLED INTO QUESTION
abstract: Bond ratings of San Jose, Calif., were called into question yesterday after the city announced a $60 million loss from investing in long-term Treasury bonds. The city's general obligation bonds carried high-grade ratings of Aa-1 from Moody's Investors Service and AA from the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

headline: COMPANY NEWS ; A.T.& T. Feels The Rising Cost Of Phone Fraud 83 Loss $100 Million; Drug Link Suspected
abstract: It can begin with something as ordinary as a business traveler making a long-distance credit card call at an airport. Someone standing nearby jots down the card number as it is read to the operator. A few weeks later, the card holder receives a bill for thousands of dollars of overseas telephone tolls.    Such false billing - often on a much smaller scale - has happened to thousands of residential and business telephone subscribers. Invariably, they ring up the local telephone company business office, explain or complain, and are told they will not have to pay.

headline: HARDEE'S BEGINNING CAMPAIGN
abstract: IF the answer is ''It's All Here At    Hardee's,'' could the question be   ''Where's the Beef?''   If the consumer wants to believe it is the answer he can, said Ron Wertheim, executive vice president-marketing of Hardee's Food Service. Then he noted that his new line is ''a much larger statement than just answering the 'Where's the beef?' question.'' He added: ''It says we've got the best promotions. We've got the best breakfasts. We've got the best lunch-dinners.''

headline: DUBLIN PROTEST OVER REAGAN VISIT
abstract: About 1,000 demonstrators led by a group of nuns chanted anti-American slogans and marched in Dublin today to protest President Reagan's visit to Ireland next weekend, the police said.   The police reported no arrests.

headline: Dart Drug Gets Bid For 73 Pharmacies
abstract: The Dart Drug Corporation said today that it had received a ''tentative offer'' of $160 million for its 73 retail drugstores from a group being formed by two Dart Drug executives.   Herbert H. Haft, chairman of Dart Drug, said the sale would take Dart Drug out of the pharmacy business and leave it with only its automotive and retail books divisions.

headline: Yes, Await a Request From the Gulf for Help
abstract: The letter that President Reagan sent this week to King Fahd of Saudi Arabia reiterated a standing American offer of military support on the condition that the United States had access to airfield, radar and other facilities near the head of the Persian Gulf, The President emphasized, and right so, that the United States would be willing to help only if publicly requested to do so by the Gulf states. Saudi Arabia has made no such request, and Washington should stand by its original position.   At this point, and unless there is a direct threat to American vital interests, the administration is right in letting the Gulf states handle the escalating conflict by themselves. Acting without the collaboration of Britain and France and a clear invitation from the Gulf states would only play into Soviet hands in the Persian Gulf.

headline: South African Students Rally on Behalf of Blacks
abstract: More than 1,000 students held a demonstration today on the campus of the University of the Witwatersrand, a major university where most of the students are white, to support black students campaigning for equal education.   About half of the protesters were white and half of them black.

headline: Violence in Ulster Marks Anniversary of '81 Fast
abstract: Youths hurled stones, gasoline bombs and bottles at the police early today in several Northern Ireland cities on the third anniversary of the death of Robert Sands, an Irish Republican Army hunger striker.

headline: CONTINENTAL RESCUE IDEA IS REPORTED
abstract: The investment adviser to the troubled Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company has been circulating a proposal under which the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation would commit more than $4.6 billion in loans and guarantees to entice a buyer for the Chicago bank, according to banking sources.     A key element in the innovative and complex proposal is an indication by Goldman, Sachs & Company, the adviser, that Continental's problem loans could amount to about $4 billion, far higher than than the $2.3 billion in nonperforming assets reported by the bank at the end of the first quarter. It thus confirmed market reports that the bank was in worse shape than many had believed.    There is no danger to depositors, however, because the F.D.I.C., the Federal agency that insures bank depositors, and the Federal Reserve System have said they will fully protect all Continental's depositors and creditors.

headline: ISRAEL ACCUSES 4 JEWS OF A DOZEN GRENADE ATTACKS
abstract: The police announced today that they had arrested four young Jews on charges of planting at least a dozen booby-trapped hand grenades outside churches, mosques and Arab houses in recent months.    The four, all Jerusalem residents in their 20's, were what are referred to here as born-again Jews, members of a movement of the formerly nonreligious who have embraced a fervent Orthodoxy, becoming baalei teshuvah, which literally means those who repent or return.   The suspects used grenades that had been stolen from the Israeli army, the police said. Nobody was killed in the incidents, but several people were wounded. After each attack or attempted attack, an anonymous caller telephoned news organizations and took responsibility in the name of ''Terror Against Terror.''The police said today that the suspects had not made the calls and had laughed when they heard news reports about them.

headline: '88 ELECTION OFFER DROPPED IN BRAZIL
abstract: Brazil's military regime today withdrew an offer to permit presidential elections by popular vote in 1988.     The decision, announced by President Joao Baptista Figueiredo, was apparently made after the Government concluded that it had lost control in Congress over its proposed constitutional amendment on future elections. The amendment was scheduled for a vote today.   Opposition groups, it appeared, had unexpectedly mustered enough support, including the backing of some dissidents from the Government, to force a change that would have scheduled Brazil's first free presidential elections in two decades for this November.

headline: South African Plans Tour
abstract: Prime Minister P. W. Botha will visit Switzerland on a West European tour, in addition to West Germany and Britain, a Government spokesman said today.

headline: Ford Dividend Up
abstract: The Ford Motor Company raised its dividend on common stock by 10 cents, to 40 cents a share, for the second quarter.

headline: Bank Money Accounts
abstract: Annual effective yields on money market accounts and six-month certificates of deposit at selected institutions on Wednesday, May 23, 1984. Some six-month C.D. yields assume reinvestment after six months.

headline: Guatemalan Refugees Are Shifted by Mexico
abstract: Some 230 Guatemalan refugees arrived in a temporary camp as part of the Mexican Government's program to move them from camps on the southern border with Guatemala, a Government agency said today.

headline: STARTS IN HOUSING OFF 10.5%
abstract: New home construction dropped 10.5 percent last month, the Commerce Department reported today. The decline, to a still-strong seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.78 million units, had been expected in light of rising interest rates. It followed a 19.7 percent gain in April.

headline: PATENTS; SOLAR POWER CONVERTER
abstract: WASHINGTON A NEW solar power converter will greatly reduce the cost of home equipment for production of electricity, according to its inventor, Alvin M. Marks of Athol, Mass. The device, which was granted patent 4,445,050 this week, is one of many inventions by Mr. Marks, who holds more than 100 other patents.    The converter, called the Lepcon, uses an array of submicron antennas deposited on a glass plate. This picks up light and converts it to a high-frequency alternating current, which is then changed to direct current by a miniature circuit. It is unnecessary to use the expensive silicon crystals required in other systems.

headline: Changes at I.B.M.
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation said a variety of graphics capabilities previously available on its larger computers would be offered for its System/38. I.B.M. also said that terminals used with its intermediate and large systems could now be attached to System/38 by remote communications lines. The company said it had also improved its Office/38 application programs, and added communications lines and PL/1 programming language capabilities. All enhancements will be available this month.

headline: FOR CANADA'S FISHERMEN, A COLD WIND FROM U.S.
abstract: To the people of this hilly fishing village, the hub of Canada's scallop fishing industry, their economic fate hangs on a case that the United States has been pressing before the International Court of Justice at The Hague.    The United States says it owns the Georges Bank, an area between Nova Scotia and New England where scallop fishing is done. Canada says it owns slightly less than half of it.    Canada contends that, if the United States wins, the effect might be to force 3,600 fishermen and workers in support industries in Lunenburg and other areas along the Nova Scotia coast off the job.

headline: U.S. NOTES AND BONDS STAGE PRICE REBOUNDS
abstract: After declining sharply earlier in the week, prices of Treasury notes and bonds rebounded yesterday and closed with gains of as much as 1 1/4 points.     Government securities dealers said prices rose in response to a modest amount of buying by investors who were finally attracted by yields of nearly 14 percent for Treasury issues due in five years or more. Temporary purchases of securities by the Federal Reserve to supply reserves to the banking system helped sustain the higher prices, because some traders concluded the central bank's action was a sign it is not trying to make bank reserves scarcer and tighten monetary policy.    The final boost in prices followed the Fed's late afternoon announcement of a $3.3 billion increase in the nation's basic money supply for the week ended May 21. Although the increase was at the upper end of the range forecast by economists, Leonard Hess, a partner at Gruntal & Company, said traders were encouraged because the increase was not disastrously large.

headline: DOME'S LOSS FOR 1983 IS $1.1 BILLION
abstract: Dome Petroleum Ltd. yesterday reported a loss of $1.1 billion (Canadian) for 1983, the largest loss in Canadian corporate history. Most of the loss was caused by an $896.9 million write-down of oil, natural gas and mining reserves.   Despite these losses, the company, which is seeking to reschedule its huge long-term debt, said that its ''core businesses are fundamentally sound.'' ''Dome believes its major problems have been financial rather than operational in nature,'' the company said.

headline: Hecla Purchases Ranchers' Shares
abstract: The Hecla Mining Company said it had bought 36 percent of the stock of the Ranchers Exploration and Development Corporation for cash and Hecla stock. It said major shareholders in the transaction were the First Mississippi Corporation and members of the family of the late Maxie Anderson, former Ranchers chairman.

headline: Toshiba Plans Plant in Britain
abstract: The Toshiba Corporation said today that it would begin manufacturing microwave ovens in Britain to meet growing demand in European markets. Toshiba also said it would increase its investment in its microwave oven plants in the United States and Japan in an effort to attain a 15 percent world market share in 1985 with a production of 1.6 million ovens annually.

headline: OUTLOOK IN THE GULF: A WIDENING WAR
abstract: News   Analysis    KUWAIT, June 4 - Western officials and Arab diplomats in the Persian Gulf region say they have been persuaded that the war between Iran and Iraq is almost certain to be stepped up.  Today, there were reports that the Iranian leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, had told his army that Tuesday could be an ''epic day.'' Intelligence officials in Washington noted that June 5 is the anniversary of the beginning of uprisings in 1963 against Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi that led to the exile of Ayatollah Khomeini.   Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and other gulf countries that support Iraq are said to have hoped that the approval by the United Nations Security Council on Friday of a resolution that indirectly condemned Iran for air attacks on shipping might help ease tensions. But the resolution appears to have strengthened the resolve of each belligerent, Western and Arab officials said.

headline: Braniff Air Adds Service
abstract: Braniff Inc., citing substantial gains in air traffic, has added its first new destination since resuming operations on March 1.

headline: Bechtel Plans Own Inquiry WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI) - Bechtel Group Inc., facing Federal inquiries into allegations that it funneled bribes to South Korean officials, plans its own investigation.
abstract: Separate investigations by the Justice Department and the Internal Revenue Service have focused on allegations by Daniel Charboneau, a former Bechtel employee, about the activities of Joon Sik Cho, a Korean- American consultant hired by the giant construction company's Bechtel Power unit to help win contracts to build nuclear power plants in Korea.   In a memo to employees this week, Steve Bechtel Jr., chairman of the San Francisco-based Bechtel Group, said Mr. Cho ''confirmed that he made no illegal payments.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: SATURDAY, JUNE 9, 1984   The Economic Summit    American budget deficits were openly criticized at the London talks, but Donald T. Regan, the Treasury Secretary, challenged finance ministers from the other industrial democracies to prove that the deficits were linked to rising interest rates. The British called such a position ''simple-minded.'' Otherwise, the seven nations undertook point-by-point deliberations on economic and political issues. (Page 6.) The subject of the budget deficits intruded despite efforts by President Reagan to explain the issue away. (7.)

headline: No Headline
abstract: Following are excerpts from Pravda's interview with Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, as distributed today in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:    Q. What is your assessment of the situation in the world at the present moment? In particular, are there any signs of positive changes in the policy of the United States of America?   A. Alas, the situation in the world is not improving. It remains very dangerous. And this is explained by the U.S. Administration's continued gamble on military force, on the attainment of military superiority, on the imposition of its order of things on other peoples. This was confirmed once again by President Reagan's recent speech at Georgetown University.

headline: Brazil to Curb Exports
abstract: The Brazilian Government announced today that it would put into effect voluntary export curbs on certain carbon steel products shipped to the United States, effective May 1. It said the action was being taken in an effort to resolve a trade dispute with the United States.

headline: Iraq Reports Attack On 2 Ships in Gulf
abstract: Iraq said today that its fighters had attacked two large ships sailing from Iran's main Persian Gulf oil terminal. Shipping sources in Bahrain said a Saudi Arabian tanker had been hit and set ablaze.

headline: K.G.B. Offers Prizes to Works Glorifying Soviet Intelligence
abstract: The Soviet Union's State Security Committee, apparently in an effort to improve its image, has offered prizes for the best books, motion pictures and television movies that deal with its internal security and foreign intelligence activities.

headline: G.M.'S SILICON VALLEY STAKE
abstract: For the first time since the early days of the auto industry, the General Motors Corporation has bought a minority interest in a small company rather than swallowing it whole.     Last week, in a little-noticed move, G.M. paid $3 million for an 11 percent interest in Teknowledge Inc. of Palo Alto, Calif., a small computer company that specializes in applications of artificial intelligence.    To the auto giant, $3 million is cash for postage stamps. In this case, however, it is a small bet on what could be a major technological advance. The goal, G.M. officials said, is to develop automated systems that can diagnose problems in the increasingly complex cars of the future.

headline: ISSUES RAISED BY S.E.C. IN CARTER SUIT
abstract: In its suit against Carter Hawley Hale Stores, the Securities and Exchange Commission has raised several relatively narrow legal issues, among them whether the retailer violated securities law by buying its own shares on the open market without giving shareholders the prior notice the commission says was required by law.    Because Carter Hawley Hale is engaged in a bitter fight to repel another company's tender offer, the agency by filing suit at this juncture has directed attention to a larger issue that is increasingly concerning lawyers and merger experts: the extent to which management acts out of self- interest, and contrary to stockholder interest, when faced with a hostile tender offer.    ''It is highly unusual for the S.E.C. to enmesh itself in the middle of an ongoing tender offer case,'' said Harvey Pitt, a former chief counsel of the commission. ''I have no doubt that the S.E.C. is motivated, in part, because they see an opportunity to vindicate their own views about the behavior of corporate directors.''

headline: Reagan Tells of Gaffe With Mrs. Mitterrand
abstract: President Reagan departed from the text of his foreign policy address today to speak of one of the ''intricacies of diplomacy'' that he said had almost caused an international incident.   He said that at a state dinner on March 22 he was escorting Danielle Mitterrand, the wife of the French President, to the table when she suddenly stopped.

headline: The Bad Guys
abstract: To The Editor:   Why do bad guys sell (''The Businessman as Villain,'' April 15)? Because people feel helpless. If you look through newspapers and magazine you'll see that the bad guy or girl is the one that gets the most coverage. And they are easier to write about. Try to write about someone who is really altruistic and you find that you've written something that is sappy. It is really easier to write about crooks and connivers.

headline: MEXICANS RESCHEDULED AT PRICE OF AUSTERITY
abstract: Mexico, with foreign debts of about $80 billion, has succeeded in the last nine months in restructuring nearly all the payments that were to come due by the end of this year.   The price of this restructuring is a set of austerity measures that has sent the economy into severe recession. The Bank of Mexico, the country's central rank, reported last week that the gross domestic product declined 4.7 percent in 1983, the sharpest drop in modern Mexican history. Domestic investment fell 25.3 percent.

headline: OBSTRUCTION OF CONTADORA EFFORTS IS CHARGED
abstract: A Mexican Government official said Friday that the Contadora peace initiative was nearly sabotaged by several Central American governments seeking to boycott an April 30 meeting of foreign ministers in Panama.   The official said that one manifestation of the attempted sabotage was a ''war of rumors'' that the meeting would be postponed. He said another element had been the ''surprise'' publication of demands and complaints by foreign ministers from Costa Rica, El Salvador and Honduras without consulting the Contadora group.

headline: People
abstract: *  Lawrence H. Spiegel elected an executive vice president of Tracy- Locke/BBDO, Dallas.     *  Roger Beahm has been promoted to vice president of marketing for No Nonsense Fashions Inc., Greensboro, N.C.

headline: HOUSE TO BLOCK AID FOR REBELS, O'NEILL ASSERTS
abstract: The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., said today that the Reagan Administration's request for $21 million in new aid to Nicaraguan rebels would not be approved by the House.    ''I can't conceive of it passing the House,'' Mr. O'Neill, a Massachusetts Democrat, said at a news conference.   Mr. O'Neill and Representative Jim Wright, the majority leader, said that reports of the involvement of the Central Intelligence Agency in mining Nicaraguan harbors had killed any chance that the financing measure would be approved. The Republican- controlled Senate approved the bill last week.

headline: China Buying U.S. Wheat
abstract: China has bought an additional 200,000 metric tons of wheat - about 7.34 million bushels - under the terms of a four-year agreement with the United States, the Agriculture Department said today.   The pact calls for China to buy a minimum of six million tons of wheat and corn annually.

headline: SCA Studying Merger Proposals
abstract: SCA Services Inc., a waste management concern, said it had delayed its board meeting that had been scheduled for today to allow time to engage a new legal counsel and to have time to study new merger proposals from other companies. Western Waste Industries was the latest company to express an interest in SCA, saying it had made a proposal to explore a possible business combination with the company.

headline: REAGAN ASSERTS TIES WITH SOVIET ARE PARAMOUNT
abstract: President Reagan said today that the United States and its NATO allies recognized that there was ''no more important consideration than the development of a better working relationship with the Soviet Union.''   The President spoke after he had conferred at the White House with the NATO foreign ministers here for the 35th anniversary meeting of the alliance, and as the North Atlantic Treaty Organization issued a ''Washington Statement on East-West Relations.''   Mr. Reagan's comments came as Administration aides said the President, in a ''modest'' agenda for an economic meeting in London next week, plans to ask Western allies to pledge to continue current policies for economic growth. A senior White House official said Mr. Reagan was adopting a ''laid back'' attitude toward the meeting, and another official said the White House was almost casual in its preparations. (Page A8.)

headline: Spain's Trade Gap Cut
abstract: Spain's foreign trade deficit narrowed by about half, to the equivalent of $2.13 billion in the first five months of 1984, from the period a year ago, the Directorate General of Customs said today. Imports rose 10 percent but exports went up 46 percent, the agency said.

headline: CHINA SAID TO OUST HIGH OFFICIAL
abstract: The propaganda chief of the Chinese Communist Party has been forced to resign, apparently after losing a power struggle over the recent ''spiritual pollution'' campaign, a diplomatic source said today.   Deng Liqun, 68 years old, lost his job as head of the party's propaganda department, the source said, but retains membership in the party secretariat.

headline: MADRID GETS A MESSAGE FROM REGIONS: AUTONOMY
abstract: The nationalist Catalan party was the decisive winner in regional elections in Catalonia last month and the victory is beginning to have an impact far beyond the question of who rules locally in the powerful industrial area of northeastern Spain.    The surprisingly strong showing of the party, Convergencia i Unio, has rattled the national political parties. In particular, it dealt a blow to the main opposition party to the Socialists, the right-wing Popular Alliance, which campaigned heavily and yet performed poorly.   The outcome also seemed to open up opportunities for a new and struggling center party, the Reformist Party, which was created last year as a middle alternative to the Popular Alliance and the ruling Socialists. The party's leader is Miguel Roca, the No. 2 man in Convergencia i Unio and its spokesman in the national Parliament, who now has more weight behind him as he tries to put together a combination of liberals and centrists from earlier governments to fight for power on a national level.

headline: NEW RISES SEEN IN '84 STEEL PRICES
abstract: After declining throughout 1982 and much of 1983, steel prices are finally gathering strength, and analysts predict increases through the rest of the year, perhaps as much as 10 percent.   In the $30 billion industry, these price increases, along with expected rises in volume, will return most steelmakers to profitability, analysts said.   The price increases, steel analysts and traders said, are being led by flat-rolled steel, which has enjoyed heavy demand from the automobile and appliance industries and represents about half of all steel sales.    ''Sheet prices are up about 10 percent since last fall,'' said David S. Soble, president of the Interstate Steel Company, a steel distributor based in Des Plaines, Ill. ''I foresee another 10 percent between now and the end of the year.''

headline: S.E.C. STUDYING TRADES ON THE S.&P. 100 INDEX
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has joined an inquiry into unusual trading last Thursday in the Standard & Poor's 100 stock index options on the floor of the Chicago Board Options Exchange.    Exchange officials said today that the commission requested information about the trading, but a commission spokesman indicated that the inquiry was not yet a formal investigation.   The exchange began its own investgiation after many of its traders lost thousands of dollars last Thursday on the maturing April 155 contract. The floor traders, who sold contracts in early trading Thursday, later complained about a flurry of purchases of S.& P. 100 call options by First Boston, Salomon Brothers and Bear, Stearns shortly before the close of trading.

headline: Ex-Government Leaders Call For Reagan-Chernenko Talks
abstract: A group of 26 former Government leaders concluded a three-day meeting today with a call for a meeting between President Reagan and Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader.

headline: Transco Settles Supplier's Dispute
abstract: The Transco Energy Company said yesterday that it had agreed with a major natural gas supplier to settle about $140 million of potential ''take- or-pay'' obligations of two Transco units, the Transcontinental Gas Pipeline Corporation and the Transco Gas Supply Company.     Transco did not disclose the terms or the supplier's name, but said the agreement had reduced to an estimated $240 million from $380 million the ''take-or-pay'' obligations of the two subsidiaries as of Nov. 30.

headline: Money Funds In Big Jump
abstract: The assets of the nation's money market mutual funds showed their second-largest weekly gain since Feb. 8 in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.   The assets of 327 funds rose $1.8 billion, to $173.37 billion, against the Feb. 8 surge of $1.9 billion.

headline: Income Halved At Firestone
abstract: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said today that its second-quarter income from continuing operations fell 50 percent, to $11 million, or 22 cents a share, from $22 million, or 44 cents a share, a year earlier.   Sales rose 14.5 percent in the quarter, to $988 million, from $863 million a year earlier.

headline: THE WORRIERS OF WALL STREET
abstract: THE ''flash'' report from the Commerce Department that the gross national product, adjusted for inflation, has expanded at an annual rate of 5.7 percent in the second quarter, following the upward revision of the first-quarter rate to a sensational 9.7 percent, drew mixed reviews in Washington and New York.    President Reagan called it ''remarkably good news.'' Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan seconded the President, saying, ''Outside the canyons of Wall Street, this should be good news for most people.''   But within Wall Street's canyons, apprehension reigned. Richard A. Debs, president of Morgan Stanley International and a former officer of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, said he had reacted ''nervously.'' He commented, ''The Fed thought it was being tight, but I guess it wasn't tight enough for the domestic economy.''

headline: China Goal Up For Car Output
abstract: China has raised its 1984 motor vehicle production target by 50,000, to 290,000, but demand, especially from newly rich rural residents, will still outstrip supply, the New China News Agency said today. It quoted an official of the China Automotive Industry Corporation as saying that domestic demand would reach 350,000 vehicles this year. Ownership of trucks and tractors in the countryside has increased sharply.

headline: SAKHAROV KIN ASK NEW HELSINKI PACT
abstract: The stepdaughter of Andrei D. Sakharov said today that Western countries should consider ''suspending, denouncing or renegotiating'' the 1975 Helsinki accords with the Soviet Union to protest the treatment of the Soviet physicist and dissident.    ''Since 1975, when the Helsinki accords were signed, the overall human rights situation in the Soviet Union has continued to deteriorate,'' the stepdaughter, Tatyana Yankelevich, said in a joint statement with her husband, Yefrem.   ''We believe that the prospect or possibility that the accords would be denounced or suspended by one or more of the signers,'' they went on in a statement read at a news conference, ''might be a sufficient reason for the Soviet Government to reconsider its position on the Sakharov case.''

headline: A.T.&T. Seeks Rule Changes
abstract: One day after the Government ordered a reduction in long-distance telephone rates, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company applied for depreciation rule changes that could lead to new rate increases. Although A.T.& T. officials expressed pleasure Thursday with Federal Communications Commission authorization to reduce long-distance rates 6.1 percent, the company acknowledged the possibility of a rate increase in connection with a formal petition it filed today with the agency.

headline: C.I.A. SAID TO OVERSPEND IN NICARAGUA
abstract: The House Select Committee on Intelligence said today that it had found that the Central Intelligence Agency had exceeded, by less than $1 million, Congressional spending limitations on covert operations in Nicaragua.    The committee finding came after an occasionally heated meeting with agency officials, including John H. Stein, director of operations, and Daniel A. Childs Jr., the controller.   A majority of the committee questioned the agency's accounting practices, including those used for some overhead and personnel costs that had not been charged against the $24 million statutory Congressional ceiling on covert operations in Nicaragua in the current fiscal year.   A key issue was the agency's financing of the mother ship in the mining of Nicaraguan harbors. The agency allocated $1 million of the $1.2 million cost to ''overhead.'' The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, initially raised questions about this accounting procedure.

headline: ;  Fujitsu Systems Fills Top Executive Post
abstract: Donald P. Moffat, after three years as president of Zenith Data Systems, a leading maker of desktop computer systems, has been named president and chief executive officer of Fujitsu Systems of America Inc. The company markets Fujitsu computer systems for the banking and retail industries.   ''I am very happy with what we have achieved here at Zenith,'' the 52 year-old Mr. Moffat said, ''but I got an offer that was exceedingly appealing.''    At Zenith Data, Mr. Moffat will be succeeded as president by Carl A. Michelotti. Mr. Michelotti, 52, will also hold the title of senior vice president in the Zenith Electronics Corporation - the parent company - in charge of Zenith Data and the Heath Company, the producer of electronic kit products.

headline: ; Rosenfeld, Sirowitz Gets Krystle Fragrance
abstract: Charles of the Ritz Group Ltd. named Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson to handle its new Forever Krystle fragrance line. The fragrance is named for the saintly character Krystle Carrington played by Linda Evans in the television show ''Dynasty.''

headline: 2 MAJORS USEFUL FOR TEACHERS
abstract: AT a recent meeting called to help college students chart their careers, a mother asked if a double major in music and science would help her son follow a teaching career. The answer was a resounding ''Yes, a great double major.''     Music and science. Schools across the nation have been short of science and mathematics teachers - partly because teachers with a science background found higher salaries in private industry than schools could pay. Meanwhile, many schools could use help with their music programs.

headline: REAGAN WILL USE EMERGENCY POWER FOR SALVADOR AID
abstract: President Reagan invoked emergency authority today to give El Salvador up to $32 million in new military aid after Congress recessed without approving the money, Administration officials said.   In a day marked by contradictory reports, the officials said the arrangements, worked out in a series of meetings into the evening, marked an attempt to avoid an all-out confrontation with House Democrats. The Democrats had offered a compromise of their own that the Administration appeared to accept only in part.   With Congress gone for 10 days on its Easter recess, and Salvadoran troops reported in need of emergency shipments of ammunition, the issue was: Should the President accept the offer of the House Democrats and use $32 million in funds already approved for other countries, so-called reprogrammed aid, or use his own authority and approve an unspecified amount of aid, known as invoking the ''draw-down authority.''

headline: GIVING WORKERS A PIECE OF THE ACTION
abstract: EMPLOYEES listen closely each   quarter when the president of   Electro Scientific Industries Inc. in Portland, Ore., reports sales and profits. And there are probably few who don't grasp the subtleties of pretax and aftertax profits.   It's no wonder. The employees collectively are paid 25 percent of the pretax profits each quarter, with a fourth of that going straight into their pockets and the rest into retirement or stock ownership accounts.

headline: BURMESE ARMY IS SAID TO FIGHT INDIA REBELS
abstract: At least 50 people have died in recent clashes in northern Burma involving guerrillas fighting for independence from India, the Burmese Army and villagers in the region, according to reports received today from the area.    In one incident that was said to have occurred at the end of March, the guerrillas attacked a village, killing 25 people, according to the reports. They were also said to have gunned down five Burmese soldiers who tried to repel the assault.

headline: Advertising; Belleek Pottery's Awakening
abstract: -PAGE four-color ads in the    May issues of House & Garden   and Architectural Digest magazines mark the awakening of Belleek Pottery Ltd., a 127-year-old porcelain manufacturer that has never had a sustained advertising campaign.    The selection of magazines indicates that the Northern Ireland company, through its agency, Silverman Mower Advertising of Syracuse and New York, intends to reach the affluent. The idea is to remind people of the tableware and giftware when they are in a buying mood and to introduce the products to newcomers.    Advertising will not run again until October, November and December with Town & Country, another posh print vehicle, added to the schedule.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Brazil Killings Spur Concern Over a Death Squad Revival    RIO DE JANEIRO, May 15 (Reuters) - Brazilian newspapers have expressed concern that the organization called the Death Squad had resumed its killings of criminals.   The newspapers reported that the police over the weekend found the bullet- riddled bodies of four men, their wrists showing signs of handcuffs and their necks with bullet holes, both characteristics of a death squad killing.

headline: 17 Held in British Rampage
abstract: The police made 17 arrests early today when 200 youths rampaged through the Yorkshire coal-mining town of Maltby, one of the areas supporting a three-month- old strike in the coal industry. The youths threw stones at the police station and smashed shop windows.

headline: HOME MEDICAL ALERT SYSTEM
abstract: The problem struck him while he was shaving one morning in 1973.    He was thinking about a frail individual, living alone, who had fallen and couldn't budge. ''How does someone who can't call for help call for help?'' he wondered.   It was the sort of puzzle that frequently piqued the interest of Andrew Dibner, a psychologist on leave from Boston University who was studying personality in advanced age.   ''When I was in my 20's,'' he said, ''I knew an elderly woman who lived alone and had a stroke and lay there for four days. She died within six months in a nursing home. Maybe that was on my mind.''

headline: Offer Made in Lloyd's Case
abstract: In an effort to avoid years of complex litigation, Minet Holdings P.L.C. and the New York-based Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. today proposed a $52 million settlement of claims growing out of a scandal that shook the Lloyd's of London insurance market two years ago.   The scandal involved premiums paid to PCW Underwriting, a Minet agency that has since been renamed Richard Beckett Underwriting Agencies Ltd., and WMD Underwriting Agencies Ltd., an associate firm.

headline: JAPANESE SUPPORT OF CAR QUOTAS
abstract: CLYDE HABERMAN      TOKYO, May 10 - Leaders of Japan's ruling party have told Vice President Bush that they want to continue restrictions on Japanese automobile exports to the United States.    Their position came as somewhat of a surprise, given both domestic unhappiness with the auto quotas and comments by some members of the Reagan Administration that the restrictions should not be renewed when they expire next March.   Their reason for speaking out now was unclear, but some analysts speculated that the aim was to deflect criticism from President Reagan should he decide to renew the quotas.

headline: Geers Gross Gets All Of Bass Shoe Business
abstract: Geers Gross Advertising, which about a month ago got a $1 million project from G. H. Bass & Company, a shoe manufacturer in Wilton, Me., has now acquired the rest of the company advertising, which totals about $5 million.

headline: New Bonds Guard Against Price Fall
abstract: A new kind of tax-exempt security, offering protection against the risk of declining bond prices if interest rates rise, is gaining wider acceptance among securities dealers and investors. Underwriters led by Matthews & Wright Capital are preparing this week a new $35 million offering of Top's, a trademarked term for the tender option bonds that the firm began offering in March.

headline: MOSCOW ASSAILS PEKING'S STANCE TOWARD REAGAN
abstract: A commentary distributed by Tass, the Soviet Government press agency, accused China today of taking only scant notice of the United States' ''militarist course'' while seeking improved relations with Washington.   The unsigned assessment of President Reagan's visit reiterated previous Soviet press reports that Mr. Reagan had given the visit a ''provocative anti- Soviet orientation'' and had sought ''to play the 'China card' '' against Moscow.   But diplomats noted that the commentary today was also critical of the Chinese leaders, charging them with having tacitly or even openly supported Mr. Reagan's policies.   Deng Said to Back U.S. Buildup    The commentary said Deng Xiaoping, the paramount Chinese leader, was supporting the United States arms buildup, and it said the Chinese either took no notice or issued only minimal criticism of American policies toward the Soviet Union, Asia, Latin America and even Taiwan and Communism.

headline: Shell Stockholders' Suit
abstract: A Delaware judge delayed a decision today on a lawsuit filed by Shell Oil Company stockholders who want to block the Royal Dutch/Shell Group from acquiring the 30 percent of Shell stock it does not already own.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: Accounts    * World Tennis magazine to Nadler & Larimer.

headline: ALLEN & CO. IN OFFER FOR CONRAIL
abstract: Allen & Company Inc., the Wall Street investment house, entered the bidding for Conrail yesterday, saying it would submit an offer of $1.1 billion plus an undisclosed amount in warrants.     The company said its bid to acquire the 85 percent of Conrail held by the Federal Government would be formally made before the Department of Transportation's deadline of next Monday. The remaining 15 percent of the stock is held by the railroad's employees.   Two other offers for the railroad have been made so far. The Alleghany Corporation, an investment company, has offered $1 billion in cash and, to make the bid more attractive to the Government, has said it would forgo $1.2 billion in tax credits due the railroad. In addition, the Railway Labor Executives' Association, representing Conrail's unions, has made a bid that it values at about $2 billion.

headline: Fire Reported to Ravage Huge Tract in Indonesia
abstract: A forest fire in Indonesia last year destroyed an area three times the size of Lebanon and represents one of the worst environmental disasters of the century, the International Union for Conservation of Nature said today.

headline: Dun & Bradstreet Buys Datastream
abstract: The Dunn & Bradstreet Corporation said it had agreed to acquire Datastream, a business information and services company based in London, for about $101 million. Datastream shareowners representing more than 50 percent of the common shares, have agreed.

headline: GEMAYEL TO VISIT SYRIAN FOR HELP
abstract: President Amin Gemayel will go to Damascus in the next few days for talks with President Hafez al-Assad on how to end the factional fighting here and on the formation of a government of national unity, a Lebanese official said today.    In the fighting, Moslem militiamen seized positions on the western side of the crossing point on the Green Line between East and West Beirut, and the police and security forces withdrew. Two hours later, a commission of representatives of the warring factions arranged for the militiamen to leave, and the police and security forces returned.

headline: Voznesensky, a Soviet Poet, Cancels Oberlin Appearance
abstract: Oberlin College said yesterday that Andrei A. Voznesensky, a Soviet poet, had canceled a visit to the Ohio campus, where he was to have received an honorary doctorate and given the commencement address on Sunday.   John Harvith, Oberlin's news director, said Mr. Voznesensky had given no reasons beyond ''serious circumstances'' in a telegram received Monday by the president of the college, S. Frederick Starr.

headline: U.S. RECEIVED 2 REPORTS OF PLOT TO MURDER ENVOY
abstract: United States intelligence sources received at least two reports last month providing details of a plot to kill the United States Ambassador to El Salvador by members of the National Republican Alliance party, an official in El Salvador said today.    The official, who has proved to have reliable knowledge of the plan to kill the Ambassador, said Roberto d'Aubuisson, the leader of the party, which is known as Arena, was among those with knowledge of the plot.   The reports convinced United States officials here and in Washington that the plan to kill Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering was well-advanced, the official said.   (In Washington, Administration officials said that top right-wing leaders were not directly involved in the plot. But the officials, who have access to intelligence data from El Salvador, said the plotters were known to be associates of Mr. d'Aubuisson. They said the intelligence reports did not establish a direct presence by Mr. d'Aubuisson.)

headline: Limited Begins Carter Hawley Bid
abstract: The Limited Inc. began its cash tender offer of $30 a share for 20.3 million shares of Carter Hawley Hale Stores, but directors of Carter Hawley, at a board meeting, did not formally comment on the offer. The directors, however, declared the regular quarterly dividend of 30 1/2 cents a share on the common stock.

headline: Sunday Novel Planned As Newspaper Insert
abstract: As if there were not enough to read in the Sunday newspapers, here comes Jack H. Gordun with The Sunday Novel, an insert that each month will contain a piece of pre-1970 fiction, as well as advertising.   His company - he is the president - is based in New York.

headline: Market Place; 'Power' Cited In Retailers
abstract: IT probably came as something as a blow to such    retailing battlewagons as the Dayton-Hudson   Corporation, Federated Department Stores and the May Department Stores Company. All three were recently removed from the ''recommended list'' by Bernard Sosnick and Susan C. Schmierer, analysts for L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin, the New York brokerage.    The reason was the three chains' failure to practice what the analysts call ''power retailing.'' Instead, the analysts are intrigued with R.H. Macy & Company and the Mercantile Stores Corporation, and are keeping them on the recommended list. In a recent report, the analysts said that those two companies ''have developed a competitive edge against their rivals.''

headline: FED CALLED ARGENTINE BANKER
abstract: To clinch the last-minute financial rescue package for Argentina at the end of March, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York assured the 11 American and foreign commercial banks that they would be repaid the $100 million that they were asked to lend the ailing Latin American nation, banking sources said yesterday.     This unwritten assurance not only persuaded the five American and six foreign banks to participate in the overall $400 million package but also convinced them to lend at an extraordinarily low interest rate, the sources said.    They added that there was little risk for the Fed itself because it had been authorized by Argentina's central bank to debit Argentina's dollar account at the Fed at the end of June, when the banks are scheduled to be repaid. Argentina is reported to have about $1 billion in readily available foreign-exchange reserves and about $2 billion in such longer-term assets as gold.

headline: FUJITSU TO EXPORT COMPUTER
abstract: Fujitsu Ltd., Japan's largest computer company, is planning to export supercomputers to the United States, mounting the first direct challenge to American manufacturers who make high-speed computers considered vital for national defense.    A Fujitsu spokesman said today that the computers would be sold by the Amdahl Corporation, a California computer company in which Fujitsu owns a 49 percent stake.   ''Fujitsu and Amdahl are discussing it now, but we haven't reached an agreement,'' said the spokesman, Yuri Momomoto.

headline: Soviet Press Agency Assails U.S. on Missile Interceptor
abstract: The Soviet Union said today that the successful testing by the United States of a ballistic missile interceptor was a step toward ''the militarization of outer space.''

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: * Ajinomoto Co. , a Japanese foodstuffs company, said it had increased the amount of its 15-year convertible Eurodollar bond offering a second time to $120 million. The lead manager is Nomura Securities Co.     * Chrysler Credit Canada Ltd.  said it had issued $2 million of 12 3/4 percent 5-year debentures and notes in a private placement with Credit Foncier.     * Del E. Webb Corp. , a diversified leisure company based in Phoenix, said its issue of $25 million of subordinated notes with warrants due April 15, 1988, had been offered and all sold by underwriters led by First Boston Corp.     * Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corp.  said it had priced at par for sale tomorrow a two-part, $1.37 billion bond package.

headline: New Ashton-Tate Data-Base System
abstract: Ashton-Tate, which markets one of the most popular data-base managers for the I.B.M. Personal Computer, said that it would introduce dBaseIII, a successor to its dBaseII program.

headline: An Unexplained Plan By Teledyne Official
abstract: After the years he has spent looking elsewhere for undervalued equities, recent actions taken by Henry E. Singleton, the chairman and founder of Teledyne Inc., seem to indicate that he sees real value in his own company's stock - even at $200 a share.     Over the last several years, Teledyne has occasionally offered to repurchase its shares from investors. But on Wednesday it made the biggest offer yet: a bid to buy back about 25 percent of the 20.4 million shares outstanding for $200 a share - a premium of almost 50 percent from the stock's trading price on Tuesday.

headline: Czech Press Says Russians Could Have Won War on Own
abstract: A weekly published by the Czech Communist Party says the Soviet Union could have defeated Nazi Germany alone, the official Czech press agency reported today. The agency reported on an article in the weekly Tribuna that suggests the final Western drive on the European front was launched only after it became clear Germany would lose World War II.

headline: TEXT OF STATEMENT ISSUED BY CATHOLIC THEOLOGIANS
abstract: Following is the text of a statement issued for publication today by Concilium, an unofficial group of Roman Catholic theologians:    Liberation theology is in the public eye. It has been the subject of comment by high ecclesiastical authorities, of articles in various newspapers and reviews, and of questions put to several individual theologians. We consider it our duty to take a position on this problem.   1.*Birth of basic Christian communities and of the theology of liberation:   Since Vatican II, we have witnessed a real renewal in the life of the churches in poor countries. This has shown itself in the flourishing of numerous basic ecclesial communities and of groups of biblical reflection, in a new vitality of faith among the people, and in the involvement of Christians (laity, priests and bishops) in the struggle for the defense of the right of the poorest to life.

headline: INTEREST RATES RISE MODESTLY
abstract: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday as weak investor demand and fear that the Federal Reserve might tighten monetary policy led to lower prices for short-term and long-term debt securities.    An increase in the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market was widely cited by dealers and economists as the main reason for the decline in prices and increase in rates. After opening at 10 percent, the closely watched overnight rate rose to 10 3/4 percent in the afternoon, with no actions by the Fed to put downward pressure on the rate.    By late in the day, rates for outstanding Treaury bills were up by about a tenth of a percentage point for issues due in six months or more, with the six-month bill bid at 9.89 percent. In the long-term bond market, the 12 percent Treasury issue due in 2013 was offered at 95 22/32, down 5/8 point, to yield 12.55 percent.

headline: Merger Policy Is Defended
abstract: Countering criticism from inside the Reagan Administration, the Federal antitrust chief, J. Paul McGrath, said today that considering world markets while evaluating mergers would produce as many Government challenges to such deals as approvals.   Mr. McGrath, the Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's antitrust division, said he hoped to revise the merger policy by June 14.

headline: NEW WAYS AT 2 G.M. PLANTS
abstract: Tall and silent, except for a faint beeping tone to warn the unwary, 22 unmanned forklift trucks roll heavily along the aisles of the General Motors Corporation's automobile plant here, bringing parts to workers along the assembly line.    The computer-controlled vehicles, which follow wires buried in the floor, are just one of the departures from old-fashioned car assembly incorporated in the plant, which began production late last year.    The Orion facility, about 30 miles north of Detroit, and a nearly identical one outside St. Louis, in Wentzville, Mo., represent a combined $1.2 billion investment in tools and buildings by G.M. to try to improve the quality of its products and to cut costs.   The vast new plants - Orion is half a mile long and a quarter of a mile wide - are now producing Cadillac DeVilles, Oldsmobile 98's and Buick Electras, the new generation of smaller front-wheel-drive luxury cars that were introduced last week.

headline: SOVIET TRADE EMPHASIS SHIFTED TO EUROPE IN '83
abstract: The Soviet Union, as part of an apparent reorientation of its trade among the leading industrial nations, strengthened its commercial ties with Western Europe last year.    While trade with Western Europe grew by 6.4 percent in 1983, Soviet exchanges with other industrial countries, notably Japan and the United States, declined by 16 percent.   This global shift in trading patterns is due in part to continued large Soviet sales of oil and natural gas, growing purchases of modern industrial technology and a decline in imports of grain.    Buyers and Suppliers    An analysis of trade figures released by Moscow shows that Soviet trade with the industrial democracies last year became increasingly focused on West Germany, Italy and France, the principal Western buyers of Soviet oil and natural gas as well as the largest Western suppliers of industrial machinery and equipment to the Russians.

headline: IN IRELAND,A HOST OF PROBLEMS
abstract: In a poster welcoming international travelers to Dublin Airport, the Republic of Ireland sells its youth. Pictured are four clean-cut students strolling across the cobblestone courtyard of Trinity College; the caption reads, ''We're the young Europeans.''   The advertisement, part of a new campaign by the country's Industrial Development Authority to attract foreign investment, reflects Ireland's attempt to cope with an awkward, urgent problem. For Ireland's greatest selling point - a growing population of well-educated young people - is also rapidly becoming its most critical national concern.

headline: SILVA: ARCHITECT OF DEBT PLAN
abstract: Argentina could be allowed as much as three months to reimburse the four Latin American countries that helped it through its interest-payment crisis last weekend, Jesus Silva Herzog, the Finance Minister of Mexico, said here today.    Mr. Silva, whom Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan cited as the architect of the $500 million loan agreement for Argentina, said he expected Argentina to meet the 30-day repayment deadline that the participants in the agreement reported Saturday. If not, however, the deadline can be stretched for 60 days, he said.    He also emphasized the significance of four debtor nations' contributing to assist a fifth.

headline: FOES OF MARCOS APPEAR TO MAKE BIG VOTE GAINS
abstract: The opposition to President Ferdinand E. Marcos appeared today to be on the way to winning a larger bloc of seats in the new National Assembly than had been expected before Monday's parliamentary elections.    But both the Government and the chairman of the independent National Citizens Movement for Free Elections predicted that the governing New Society Movement would have a majority when final official returns are in.   With about one-third of the votes counted, Jose Concepcion, the chairman of the citizens' group, said he estimated that the opposition would win 60 to 70 of the 183 seats at stake in the 200- member assembly, as against the 30 to 40 that many political experts had predicted before the election. In the previous National Assembly elections, held in 1978 while the Philippines was still under martial law, the opposition won 13.

headline: LINKED I.R.A.'S: NOTE OF CAUTION
abstract: SOME people have opened a type of Individual Retirement Account known as either linked, tandem or Super I.R.A.'s. But these accounts are now under scrutiny by the Internal Revenue Service and should be approached warily.     Among the places where the accounts have been offered by commercial banks and savings institutions to local and out-of-state customers are Illinois, Wisconsin, California and Ohio. Such accounts have been heavily advertised and promoted, particularly in the January-to-April period, when most retirement accounts are opened.    However, many thoughtful savers are not waiting until next January before starting their 1984 I.R.A.'s. They know that the sooner that funds are deposited in an I.R.A., the sooner they begin to accumulate tax-deferred interest or dividends.

headline: Air Florida Option
abstract: The General Electric Credit Corporation said its option to purchase up to 55 percent of the common stock of Air Florida System Inc. had been extended to Dec. 31, from Aug. 31.

headline: RALLY ELIMINATES EARLY LOSS
abstract: After sliding sharply in light early trading, prices in the credit markets rallied yesterday afternoon and ended the day relatively unchanged from the close on Friday.    Market participants attributed the improved performance to further evidence of a cooling economy and a successful auction of $12.8 billion of short-term Treasury bills.    ''The market did better after the factory utilization rate for May was released, and the report for April was revised downward,'' said David M. Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a Government securities house. ''You want the utilization rate to start to stabilize because it lessens the threat of future inflation.

headline: REAGAN REFUSES TO JOIN CRITICS OF FED
abstract: President Reagan refused today to endorse criticism of the Federal Reserve Board that was expressed last week by Larry Speakes, the chief White House spokesman, and by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan.   They had blamed the Fed for rises in interest rates, a view not shared by all Administration officials.    Mr. Reagan thus appeared to be attempting to dispel the growing impression that the White House and the Treasury were antagonists of the central bank, an impression that has subjected the White House to criticism by the financial community.

headline: WHOEVER WINS IN NOVEMBER, A TAX OVERHAUL IS COMING
abstract: WASHINGTON     AS the income tax season reaches its   climax - midnight tomorrow is the   deadline for filing 1983 returns - sentiment is building for a thorough overhaul of the nation's tax system. By this time next year, the newly inaugurated President, no matter who he is, will quite likely have sent Congress the most far-reaching restructuring plan in the 70-year history of the Federal income tax.    When legislation finally emerges later in the year, America's traditional income tax system is likely to be substantially altered and simplified as well.    And the tax bill paid by the nation's 95 million taxpayers will swell by some $100 billion a year, with the added burden inevitably falling mainly on middle-income citizens.   The key reason for the great tax initiative of 1985 is the Federal deficit - a budget shortfall so awesome that it will inevitably force the nation's next President, Democrat or Republican, into an urgent search for        Related story on the Democratic candidates and tax policy: Week in Review.    a major new sources of revenue. Even President Reagan has acknowledged that the deficit cannot be closed by economic growth alone and has been forced to give up his goal of relentless tax cutting.

headline: Johnson Expects Lower Earnings
abstract: Johnson & Johnson said it expects a new spending program and a slowdown in professional businesses to lead to lower earnings in the second quarter from a year earlier and to ''restrain earnings growth for the year.''

headline: People
abstract: *  Shirley M. Kaiden promoted to corporate executive vice president of Ruder Finn & Rotman.

headline: HAVE YOU EVER TRIED TO GIVE YOUR KIDS SOME MONEY SENSE?
abstract: I'VE given a good deal of thought to the issue of children and money. I'm not speaking of those depressing figures one encounters that say what it costs to   raise a child these days - figures that (if I'm to take them seriously) leave my husband and me, with three kids, about a million dollars short.    What I'm speaking of is the way a parent goes about teaching children the value of a dollar, and about money in general. You shouldn't love it, can't hate it, have to respect it, mustn't worship it. This money-explaining business makes communicating the facts about sex, religion, or the electoral college system, seem elementary.

headline: BRIEFS ;  Debt Issues
abstract: LTV Corp., Dallas, said it had completed a $675 million eight-year credit arrangement with a group of 21 banks led by Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company for use in the company's merger with Republic Steel Corp. Separately, Moody's Investors Service said it had raised to Ba-3 from B-1 the rating on the 6 3/4 percent subordinated debentures due in 1988 issued by Vought Corp., now known as LTV Aerospace and Defense Company, a subsidiary of LTV. The rating change affects about $17 million of debt.     *  Mohawk Data Sciences Corp., a Parsippany, N.J., supplier of computer communications systems and services, said it had completed a $115 million unsecured credit line with a group of 10 banks led by Bank of Boston.

headline: NEW-HOME SALES OFF BY 4.9%
abstract: Sales of new homes dropped by 4.9 percent in March from February as a sharp decline in home buying in the South more than offset a big jump in the Northeast, the Government reported today.   New single-family homes were sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 666,000 units in March, down from 700,000 in February, according to the report by the Commerce Department and the Housing and Urban Development Department.   The February rate represented a 3.4 percent improvement from the January level, when housing sales plummeted by 10.3 percent.

headline: Afghan, Rumored Held, Reported Leading Battle
abstract: An Afghan guerrilla chief, Ahmad Shah Masood, who was rumored to have been captured, has returned to the Panjshir Valley and is directing operations against Soviet forces who overran it, Western diplomatic sources said today.   The sources also reported a great deal of resistance activity in the Afghan capital of Kabul and nearby Paghman, and the continuing murder of Government supporters in Kabul, apparently the result of a feud among ruling Communist Party factions.   Afghan rebel sources said Mr. Masood had left the Panjshir Valley before Soviet forces mounted a big offensive there in April.

headline: TAX SHELTER PLANS GONE AWRY
abstract: A clutch of prominent people from business, entertainment and politics who invested in two intricate partnerships designed to generate tax losses may now have more losses than they bargained for.    The tax shelter partnerships have filed for bankruptcy, and the investors are facing real losses - they may be asked to come up with many times their original stake to help pay off the partnerships' creditors.    Among the individual investors are Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., the former Secretary of State, who invested $50,000, and Arthur B. Laffer, the supply-side economist, who put up $25,000. Harold B. Mayer, who retired three years ago as chairman of Oscar Mayer & Company, weighed in with $500,000. Avery Corman, who wrote the novel ''Kramer vs. Kramer,'' invested $175,000.

headline: Marcos Is Said to Seek An Expanded Assembly
abstract: Spokesmen for President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that a special session of Parliament that he has called would consider adding 18 appointed members to the body. But they later retracted the statement, saying the agenda had not been set.

headline: Japan G.N.P. Rises by 1.8%
abstract: Japan's gross national product rose an inflation-adjusted 1.8 percent in the January-March quarter from the previous quarter, the Economic Planning Agency said today.   The January-March figure reflects a 7.4 percent gain on an annualized basis, officials said.

headline: Weinberger Answers Queries Of Callers on BBC Talk Show
abstract: Some 400 callers from Europe, Africa, Asia and Australia jammed phone lines to the BBC World Service today to ask Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger about United States policies.   Mr. Weinberger was the first foreign official to appear on ''It's Your World,'' a program in which callers phone in questions to be answered by the guest.

headline: BACKERS RETHINK EFFORT TO SHIFT ISRAEL EMBASSY
abstract: Several backers of a bill to move the American Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem said privately today that they expected to avoid a direct confrontation with the Administration by making the legislation a ''sense of the Congress'' resolution. Such legislation is not sent to the President for his signature and is not binding.   President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz have said that the Administration would not move the embassy from Tel Aviv, and they have strongly suggested that Mr. Reagan would veto the current bill if it is adopted by Congress.   Supporters of the bill said their plan now was not to alter the wording, but rather to leave the legislation as it stands pending hearings starting next week by two subcommittees of the House Foreign Affairs Committee and at the end of the month by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: PAKISTAN TIE IMPERILS U.S.-CHINA NUCLEAR PACT
abstract: China, contrary to its public pledges, may be continuing to aid Pakistan's nuclear weapons program, according to Reagan Administration officials and Congressional sources.    The sources said there was some evidence that Peking seemed to be helping Pakistan in one particular area, the development of centrifuges used in enriching uranium for nuclear weapons.   Pakistan has been widely reported to be working on uranium enrichment at a plant in Kahuta. Pakistan asserts that the plant is for peaceful nuclear research, but it has not permitted inspection of the installation.

headline: NEW ROCHELLE MID-RISE BUILT OVER A RAILROAD CUT
abstract: Oldtimers in Westchester County remember with affection the Westchester & Boston Railroad. It started in 1912 with trains running northward from 180th Street and Morris Park Avenue in the Bronx.    The founders had grandiose ideas of service to Boston, said Thomas Hoctor, the city historian of New Rochelle, but they never got farther than Portchester on one branch and White Plains on another. The line went into bankruptcy in the 1930's and the administrators sold the right of way and the stations piece by piece.

headline: Bear, Stearns Appointment
abstract: Milton B. Rubin, president of the investment management firm of Bernstein-Macaulay Inc., will join Bear, Stearns & Company as a limited partner with responsibility for the firm's asset management services division, Alan C. Greenberg, general partner and chief executive officer at Bear, Stearns, said yesterday. Mr. Rubin, 47 years old, will work with Kenneth D. Malamed of the firm's Los Angeles office in supervising $900 million of assets currently under Bear, Stearns management.  In conjunction with Mr. Rubin's appointment, Bear, Stearns announced that another Bernstein-Macaulay employee, Peter N. Marron, 35, would join the firm as a limited partner in the asset management area. Mr. Marron had been a vice president and portfolio manager at Bernstein-   Macaulay.

headline: Letter Backs Enstar Offer
abstract: The Enstar Corporation said yesterday that it was sending a letter to shareholders in which it supported the offer for Enstar by the Unimar Company.   Unimar is a general partnership and consists of subsidiaries of the Allied Corporation and Ultramar P.L.C., a London-based oil concern.

headline: WEST'S LEADERS BRIEFED BY MITTERRAND ON SOVIET
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand today discussed his Soviet trip with the nine other leaders of the European Economic Community, reportedly saying that his talks with Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, were candid, open and marked by ''the obvious differences.''    Mr. Mitterrand's spokesman, Michel Vauzelle, offered no details. The description of Mr. Mitterrand's conversations in Moscow last week came from Italian and Belgian sources, who also quoted him as having said that Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko had emphasized an interest in reaching agreements on weapons in space as well as chemical and biological arms.

headline: PRIME LOAN RATE IS RAISED BY BANKS 1/2 POINT, TO 12 1/2%
abstract: The nation's leading banks raised their prime lending rate half a percentage point yesterday, to 12 1/2 percent, the third such increase in two months.     The rise in the key interest rate to its highest level in 18 months brought sharp criticism by the White House of the Federal Reserve Board, which is the nation's central bank.    Larry Speakes, chief White House spokesman, said the Federal Reserve had been unduly restricting the supply of money to the national economy, thus driving up the cost of money - interest rates - and threatening to choke off the economic recovery. (Page D6.)

headline: COMPUGRAPHIC MARKETER SHIFTS TO SCITEX AMERICA
abstract: Bryan E. Newman, who has been senior vice president for marketing at the Compugraphic Corporation, is the new president of the Scitex America Corporation, a unit of the Israeli- based Scitex Corporation.     Mr. Newman, 47, fills a post that has been vacant since Dec. 31, when Paul Rosenbaum left.

headline: Sonat Aide Is Promoted
abstract: Sonat Inc.'s directors yesterday elected Ronald L. Kuehn Jr. chief executive officer.  Mr. Kuehn, a 49-year-old lawyer who has been the company's president and chief operating officer since 1982, will assume his new post on June 1.

headline: Pakistan Banks Delete Interest
abstract: Banks in Pakistan will stop paying interest to depositors next year to conform with Islamic law, according to Finance Minister Ghulam Ishaq Khan. Foreign-owned banks that operate in Pakistan have promised to cooperate, he said at a news conference Friday. Interest payments are forbidden by the Koran, the sacred book of the Moslems.

headline: ON VERSE AND VERVE: 2 AMERICANS CHARM CHINESE
abstract: One recent afternoon, more than 200 Chinese students and teachers jammed a classroom at Hebei Normal University to spend a couple of hours listening to two American scholars read the poetry of Edgar Lee Masters and Ezra Pound, of Robert Frost and Archibald MacLeish.   Some clutched tape recorders. Other followed along with mimeographed copies of the poems. The rapt silence was interrupted by periodic applause and laughter as Charles C. Dickinson and his wife, Joanne W. Eaton, acted out the poems, employing a variety of voices, accents and body movements that most Chinese scholars would have considered beneath their dignity.

headline: BRANIFF'S BUSINESS PICKING UP
abstract: Patrick Foley, vice chairman of Braniff Inc., said yesterday that his airline's business, after a disappointing start, had picked up so strongly that Braniff might show a profit by September.     ''In the last six weeks, bookings have been phenomenal,'' he said at a news conference in the Grand Hyatt Hotel in New York. Braniff began flying again on March 1. It had been idle almost two years, since declaring bankruptcy in May 1982.

headline: OFFER BY THE U.S. TO GUARD TANKERS IN GULF REPORTED
abstract: The United States has reportedly offered to provide Arab countries on the Persian Gulf with air cover to deal with military threats such as the recent attacks on Kuwaiti and Saudi oil tankers.   But at the time of the proposal, with the Iran-Iraq war not as tense as it has since become, no country took advantage of the offer, Reagan Administration officials said.   In the latest attack today, a Saudi tanker was hit by unidentified planes, according to reports from Bahrain. The attack, the fifth in three weeks, caused sharp increases in insurance rates and in the spot and futures oil markets. (Pages A5 and A6.)

headline: Troop Exercise in Honduras
abstract: One thousand United States Army and Air Force troops will join about 1,800 Hondurans and 1,300 Salvadoran soldiers Wednesday in a monthlong series of counterinsurgency exercises in Honduras, the Defense Department said today. The Pentagon said, ''The U.S. decision to participate in Granadero I reflects U.S. resolve to reassure Central American nations of our continuing support and cooperation.''

headline: RCA Sues Esprit
abstract: Esprit Systems Inc. said the RCA Corporation had filed suit against Esprit in Federal District Court in Delaware charging patent infringement relating to the company's sale of video display terminals.

headline: Article 216171 -- No Title
abstract: The Charter Company reported yesterday that it lost $36.2 million in the first quarter in contrast to earnings of $952,000 in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.     Charter, an oil and insurance conglomerate that filed on April 20 for protection from its creditors under Federal bankruptcy law, added that it expected to report a ''substantial provision for losses'' in the second quarter that may result in ''a significant reduction or elimination of stockholders' equity.''    Charter executives also met yesterday with about 150 of the company's estimated 20,000 creditors in Jacksonville, Fla., Charter's headquarters.

headline: Holly-Internorth
abstract: The Holly Corporation said it had agreed in principle to sell the oil and gas properties of its Holly Energy Inc. subsidiary to an Internorth Inc. unit for $53 million. Holly, through its subsidiary, the Navajo Refining Company, will continue to be engaged in petroleum refining, its main business. Internorth is based in Omaha.

headline: OLYMPIC BOYCOTT IS CALLED FIRM
abstract: The Soviet Union appears unlikely to reverse its decision to boycott the Olympic Games in Los Angeles, United States and Soviet officials said today.   Afghanistan announced that it was also withdrawing from the Games.

headline: Volcker Hails Debt Move
abstract: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that a decision by bankers to give Mexico better terms for repaying its debts was the beginning of a ''new phase'' in the Latin American debt crisis. ''I think this approach that was taken here - the initiative taken toward Mexico - is a constructive change to a longer-term perspective within the same basic approach that's been followed,'' Mr. Volcker said at a news conference. It followed the closing session of the International Monetary Conference here. Mr. Volcker was referring to the bankers' agreement to negotiate a stretch-out of payments from Mexico, beginning with those falling due in 1985.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: GREEN PARTY BOUNCING BACK IN BONN
abstract: The days are over when the breezy conventional wisdom in Bonn had it that the Green Party was a flash in the pan, a minor disturbance on the tranquil surface of West Germany's orderly and predictable politics, soon to be swept into oblivion by the conservatism of the nation's voters.   Since Sunday, when the five-year-old party received an impressive 8.2 percent of the popular vote in elections to the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France, the conventional wisdom has been drastically revised. The assumption now is that the Greens, whose political success defies the notion that parties must be harmonious and well-organized, will be around for a long time.   A giddy, faintly cocky mood has infiltrated the parliamentary offices of the antinuclear, anti-NATO, pro-environmentalist coalition, which occupies a string of cubicles in the upper stories of an antiseptic high-rise overlooking a grassy, sun-dappled quadrangle not far from the Rhine.

headline: 1,500 in Bonn Protest South African's Visit
abstract: The police clashed today with some 1,500 demonstrators protesting the visit of Prime Minister P. W. Botha of South Africa. At least nine people were arrested in the scuffles.

headline: Beet Plant Won't Close
abstract: The Great Western Sugar Company, reversing an earlier decision, said it would keep its Billings, Mont., beet-processing plant open.

headline: MANAGEMENT MAY BUY BALDWIN'S MGIC UNIT
abstract: The management of the MGIC Investment Corporation is preparing an offer to acquire the unit of the troubled Baldwin-United Corporation, a commission of insurance regulators said yesterday.     The Special Masters Commission, a group appointed by the courts in Arkansas and Indiana, where Baldwin has six of its insurance operations, said it had requested MGIC management to present a formal proposal. MGIC is the leading mortgage insurer in the United States.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Technology Chief Retiring at I.B.M.
abstract: B. O. Evans, vice president for engineering, programming and technology at the International Business Machines Corporation, the company's research and development arm, will retire on July 1, the company said yesterday.     In addition, I.B.M. reported that it had reorganized the staff headed by Mr. Evans, who is 56 years old, into two groups, one for development and the other for programming.

headline: AN IMAGE PROBLEM FOR DETROIT
abstract: To some people, the decision of General Motors and Ford, the two largest automobile makers, to pay record bonuses to their executives while enjoying protection from Japanese competition is a symbol of management high-handedness that may cause political problems for all of corporate America.  The auto bonuses, in the two weeks since they were disclosed, have stirred a storm of protests that Detroit seems to be feathering its own nest.     Executives of the auto companies acknowledge that they expected a hostile reaction to the payments, which put the compensation of top officers of the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company well over $1 million each for 1983.   Matching Other Industries    But they say that high pay for key executives is standard in American business and that to leave auto executives' compensation below the levels of other manufacturing industries would risk seeing their most talented people go find better pay elsewhere.  Allan Gilmour, Ford's vice president for external affairs, said public reaction was considered before the bonuses were paid.
