headline: Kaiser Steel to Sell Its Fontana Works
abstract: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Fontana steel works to the Pacific Steel Corporation for more than $100 million.

headline: I.M.F. SEEN AS UNLIKELY TO ACCEPT PLAN
abstract: Despite widespread sympathy for Argentina's new democracy here and in other Western capitals, its latest proposal for economic retrenchment is unlikely to satisfy the International Monetary Fund's terms for fresh loans, monetary officials and commercial bankers said today.    They stressed, however, that the negotiations were continuing and would probably go down to the wire, as they often have in the long saga of Argentina and its foreign creditors.    Argentina's decision to send on to the fund an economic retrenchment plan that had not first won the approval of staff members in talks in Buenos Aires - and to take the unusual step of making it public - were seen as intensifying a war of nerves.    Double Standard Implied    Officials familiar with the fund's thinking said that, despite President Raul Alfonsin's pleas for help in consolidating support for Argentina's first nonmilitary Government in eight years, the fund could not accept the proposal.

headline: U.S. JOURNALIST APPEALS BAN BY COSTA RICA TO THE O.A.S.
abstract: A United States journalist appealed to a commission of the Organization of American States today for help in overturning the verdict of a court in Costa Rica that convicted him of illegally writing for publication there.   In a hearing before the organization's seven-member Inter-American Human Rights Commission, lawyers for the journalist, Stephen B. Schmidt, contended that the verdict against him had violated the Inter-American Human Rights Convention as well as Costa Rican legislation guaranteeing freedom of the press. Costa Rica is a party to the convention.

headline: Creusot-Loire Pact Doubted
abstract: Talks between the French Government and the engineering group Creusot-Loire aimed at finding a solution to the company's financial crisis were expected to continue through the weekend, although chances of an agreement were slim, official sources said today.   Creusot-Loire, a subsidiary of the Empain-Schneider group, failed to meet a court deadline on Wednesday for the presentation of a recovery plan and its chairman, Didier Pineau- Valencienne, said it would apply to go into receivership after failing to agree to the financing of a rescue package with the Government.

headline: EAST GERMANY JOINS SOVIET IN BOYCOTTING GAMES
abstract: East Germany, a nation of 17 million people that has become a world power in sports, announced today that it would not take part in the Olympic Games in Los Angeles this summer.   Using virtually the same arguments that the Soviet Union used two days ago, the East German National Olympic Committee said it had made its decision ''to protect the honor, dignity and life'' of its athletes, who it said might be the objects of ''political and criminal attacks by extremist groups'' in Los Angeles.   The East German statement alluded to ''harassment and defamation of the socialist countries'' in the United States - language that seemed to hint that, with the possible exception of independent-minded Rumania, the Warsaw Pact nations would be falling into line with the Soviet Union in the coming days.   On Wednesday Bulgaria, an unwavering Soviet ally, announced its athletes would stay away from Los Angeles.

headline: Puget Sound's Utility Bond Sale
abstract: The Puget Sound Power and Light Company yesterday offered $75 million worth of extendable first mortgage bonds due July 1, 1996.    The issue, which carries a 14 percent coupon and was co-managed by Salomon Brothers and Kidder, Peabody & Company, was priced at 99.40 to yield 14.25 percent.

headline: Genscher Said to Irk U.S.
abstract: The West German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, has irked the United States by seeking last-minute changes in a NATO declaration that is to be issued after a ministerial meeting here this week, senior NATO sources said today. The sources said Secretary of State George P. Shultz had written a stiff letter to Mr. Genscher saying that the ministers should not waste time drafting the declaration at the three-day session, which is to start Tuesday. The sources said Bonn had sought to make more positive references to the achievements of detente.

headline: Disk Innovation
abstract: The Control Data Corporation said the partnership formed by it and Philips N. V. had developed a high- capacity computer disk memory that uses laser beams to record and read information. It said the new memory, developed by the Optical Storage International partnership, can store up to one billion bytes, or characters, of information for as long as 10 years on one side of a densely packed 12-inch glass disk.

headline: Times Mirror Profit Up
abstract: The Times Mirror Company said today that with a robust economy generating more money for its newspapers, including The Los Angeles Times and Newsday on Long Island, first-quarter profits rose 47.3 percent.

headline: HONDURANS URGE TOP NICARAGUAN REBELS TO UNITE
abstract: High-ranking Honduran officers told Nicaraguan rebel leaders this week that they were eager to unite the three principal groups fighting the Government in Managua, the military authorities say.     ww The authorities said the Hondurans, at a meeting Thursday attended by a United States intelligence agent, told four leaders of the Honduran-based rebels that they would like to bring the military leader of the Costa Rican- based insurgents, Eden Pastora Gomez, to this country to form the alliance.   The third anti-Government group, is composed of Miskito Indian factions.    The insurgents based here, the Nicaraguan Democratic Force, depend heavily on the good will of the Honduran military, which allows them to move freely in the border area.

headline: STINGER SALE: MIDEAST BALANCING ACT
abstract: In recent years, American Administrations pondering policy decisions have repeatedly been faced with choosing between Israeli and Saudi concerns.    This time, the Reagan Administration took little time to decide to proceed with the urgent shipment of 400 Stinger antiaircraft missiles to Riyadh. It asserted that the Saudis needed the portable weapons immediately to help defend their shipping and oilfields against possible aerial attacks by Iran.   Israel quickly announced its opposition to the shipments, saying that the missiles could be readily shifted for use against them, and could possibly fall into the hands of terrorists.

headline: May Day Firebombing In Mexico Disclosed
abstract: The Mexican Government has disclosed that two unidentified men threw firebombs at the National Palace during a May Day parade and wounded three people.   Late Wednesday President Miguel de la Madrid attributed the attack to ''minuscule groups of agitators in which we recognize foreign interference.''

headline: U.S. TELLS HOW IT RETALIATES AGAINST ENVOYS
abstract: The State Department disclosed in detail today how it deliberately complicates the lives of foreign diplomats posted in the United States if their governments harass American envoys overseas.   The retaliation involves unplugging telephones, cutting off utilities, restricting travel, holding up shipments of goods from overseas and refusing certain countries the right to buy property in the United States, according to a report by the department's two-year- old Office of Foreign Missions.   The department also said it would soon require all of the 25,000 motor vehicles driven by diplomats in the United States to carry new and distinctive red, white and blue Federal license plates.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Jet Express, Chicago, a new no- frills airline, to Zechman & Associates, Chicago.     * The Weather Channel to J. Walter Thompson, Atlanta.     * Triangle Manufacturing Corp., Raleigh, N.C., an affiliate of the Campbell Soup Company, to Richardson, Myers, Donofrio in Philadelphia, for the Triangle line of health and fitness products.

headline: ACTING TO AVERT DEBTOR CARTEL
abstract: THE meeting of Latin American finance    ministers and foreign ministers in Cartagena, Colombia, which started yesterday, was preceded by some adroit maneuvering by Western countries and financial institutions to prevent the Latin Americans from ganging up on them.   First, Jacques de Larosi ere, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, let Mexico know that it would receive easier terms than other debtors as a reward for putting its economic house in order. Then Walter B. Wriston, chairman of Citicorp and a close adviser of President Reagan, let Brazil know that it, too, would receive favored treatment for its sacrifices.   At the London economic summit conference earlier this month, the leaders of the seven industrial countries endorsed these overtures to Mexico and Brazil by agreeing that ''in cases where debtor countries are themselves making successful efforts to improve their position,'' the summit countries would encourage ''more extended multiyear rescheduling of commercial debts.'' They also agreed to encourage the substitution of ''more stable long-term finance, both direct and portfolio, for short-term bank lending.''

headline: Former GCA Executive To Head Robotic Vision
abstract: Pat V. Costa, who is 40 years old, was named chairman, president and chief executive of Robotic Vision Systems Inc. yesterday.     He succeeds Paul Dimatteo, 56, who is leaving the small, Hauppage, L.I., electronics company to form a new concern to make automatic hospital beds.

headline: Texaco to Sell Japan Oil Interest
abstract: Texaco Inc. said it had reached agreement to sell the 50 percent interest in Japan's Mitsubishi Oil Company for $335 million in cash, continuing Texaco's efforts to unload unwanted assets acquired when it purchased the Getty Oil Company for $10.1 billion earlier this year.

headline: ANTI-POLLUTION EFFORTS LAG IN SMOGGY PRAGUE
abstract: When the sun breaks through, Prague is a crystalline gem of a city. But during the long winter, a noxious blanket of smog clings to its ancient buildings and churches. Children are sent to the mountains for ''schools in nature'' where they can breathe clean air.

headline: SEABROOK RESCUE BID APPROVED
abstract: Owners of the Seabrook nuclear power plant today unanimously approved a plan that they said should save Seabrook's first reactor and avert bankruptcy for the plant's main owner.   The 16 utility-owners of the New Hampshire plant announced the agreement following an eight-hour closed-door meeting.   Robert Hildreth of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets said the plan eliminates the main obstacle of earlier proposed solutions to the Seabrook crisis - making other owners responsible for the payments of the main owner, the Public Service Company of New Hampshire.

headline: NEW MATZOH MARKETS SOUGHT
abstract: Each autumn, Brooklyn's Satmar Hasidim begin making matzohs for the coming spring. A clamorous assembly line of 30 women, printed scarves hiding their hair and lace aprons cinching their waists, wrestle with plump wads of dough until the loaves are thin enough.   Now and then the rhythm slows for an exchange of gossip or a lesson in technique, but they know they must work quickly if they are to complete the enormous task ahead: producing 100,000 pounds of the crisp, unleavened bread by mid-April.   Not too far away, in Long Island City, Queens, the Horowitz Margareten factory is also at peak production. Here, claw-like mixing forks and half-ton rollers do the work, making 780,000 sheets of matzoh a day, or 1,250 a minute. Roughly 60,000 pounds of flour make the 18-minute trip through the works daily, and the factory uses more flour in a week than the Satmar bakery uses in a year.

headline: College Issue In Massachusetts
abstract: A $22.2 million Massachusetts College Student Loan Authority Education Loan revenue bond issue was tentatively priced yesterday by a selling group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: Venezuela Payment
abstract: Venezuela's largest private sector debtor, La Electricidad de Caracas, last week paid $40 million in overdue interest to foreign creditors, a company spokesman said today.

headline: Large Japanese Surplus
abstract: Japan's current account surplus for the 1983 fiscal year may total $24 billion, a top- ranking but unidentified Economic Planning Agency official was quoted as saying by the Kyodo News Service today. The official added that the balance for the 1983 fiscal year, which ended March 31, may have been $1 billion more than projected by the Government earlier this year.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: EXILES SAY LIBYANS HAVE SEIZED 3,000
abstract: A Libyan exile group says the Libyan security police have arrested as many as 3,000 people and executed 7 people this month.   The group, which made the assertion in a statement issued here Sunday, is the National Front for the Salvation of Libya. It was founded in 1980 by a former diplomat, Mohammed Yusef al- Maghariaf, and it took responsibility for an unsuccessful coup attempt on May 8 against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader.

headline: Imelda Marcos Set to Testify For Panel on Death of Aquino
abstract: Imelda R. Marcos, wife of the Philippine President, is scheduled to testify before an investigative commission Friday about why she warned the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. against returning to the country.

headline: World Shipbuilding
abstract: World shipbuilding orders fell in the first quarter to 31.45 million gross tons from 32.62 million tons in the previous quarter, but were up from 26.6 million tons a year earlier, Lloyd's Register of Shipbuilding Returns said today. The order books of most leading shipbuilding nations fell from the previous quarter. Japan remains the biggest builder, followed by South Korea, Brazil, China and Taiwan.

headline: 8 DIED IN GULF RAID, SHIPOWNER SAYS
abstract: Eight crewmen were killed and three seriously hurt in the Iraqi missile attack on a Swiss-owned supertanker Wednesday, the ship's owners said today.    It was second such fatal incident in the Persian Gulf war. The only previous reported loss of life occurred June 3 when Turkey said three Turkish seamen were killed in an Iraqi missile attack on a Turkish tanker, the Buyuk Hun. Iraq and Iran first extended their ground war, which began in September 1980, to attacks on gulf shipping earlier this year, beginning attacks on tankers taking on oil there.

headline: Market Place; Dow Dropped 23.35 in Week
abstract: THE specter of rising interest rates and concern over the possible failure of the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company, the nation's eighth-largest bank, undermined the already fragile confidence of investors last week. The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 23.35 points, to 1,133.79, as part of a broad market retreat.    At 3:30 P.M. Friday, the average hovered just below the year's closing low of 1,130.55, set on April 5. There was an unconfirmed report that, in the final minutes of trading on the New York Stock Exchange, a brokerage firm executed an order from an index fund to buy 155 stocks - an action that just might have prevented the Dow from finishing at its lowest level so far this year.

headline: IN DEFENSE OF COMMODITIES
abstract: To the Editor:      Mr. Train's cynical view of the commodity brokerage community is very troubling. He suggests that the purpose of establishing a commodity brokerage department is ''to fleece the customer, not to help him,'' a view that most brokerage firms would find offensive in the extreme.

headline: Advertising; Champion Employee Campaign
abstract: CHAMPION International, a major force in paper, plywood and packaging, is going to spend $7 million on advertising to convince its 32,000 domestic employees it's a swell place to work.     ''We believe that employees who feel good about their companies do a better job,'' said David R. Brown, vice president, communications, who was visiting his agency, Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson, at the time.    The two companies had been partners in corporate campaigns in 1979, 1980 and part of 1981 and then cut back entirely because of the economy. On July 9 the company returns, and for the first time will be on television in addition to magazines.

headline: Mexico Is Selling Stock Held by Seized Banks
abstract: Mexico today offered for sale nearly a half billion dollars of holdings in ''nonessential'' companies whose shares have been held by the Government since it seized the country's banks in 1982.   The sale includes majority interests in many of Mexico's best-known companies and hotels and minority interests in a number of international concerns, including the Mexican subsidiaries of John Deere, Bayer, Reynolds Aluminum, Fluor, Celanese, Hooker Chemical, Borden Chemical, Kimberly Clark and General Electric.   The move, which had been promised for several months, is intended in part to calm concerns among businessmen over the Government's increasing role in the private sector here.

headline: UTIILITES CHANGE NAMES IN BIDS FOR NEW IMAGES
abstract: Investors can no longer buy common stock in the Virginia Electric and Power Company, although the public utility still sells securities and serves 1.5 million customers. To investors, the 59-year-old company is now Dominion Resources and its familiar stock symbol, VEL, has been replaced by the letter D.    Nor can investors buy stock in the name of the Indianapolis Power and Light Company, the Florida Power and Light Company or the Tampa Electric Company. They are now, respectively, Ipalco Enterprises, the Florida Progress Corporation and the TECO Energy Corporation.   Those changes are part of a growing trend among electric utilities to set up holding companies with different names to manage their new, nonutility businesses. Underlying the name changes, utility experts say, is a wish to signal Wall Street that the companies are no longer just in the business of selling electricity, largely a no-growth enterprise.

headline: East River Stock Plan
abstract: The East River Savings Bank announced yesterday plans to become the first mutual savings bank chartered by New York State to convert to stock ownership under recently enacted state legislation.   The conversion would be accompanied by a $43 million capital infusion from Alvin Dworman, chairman of the ADCO Group, a real estate firm, and the Great Universal Capital Corporation, one of Mr. Dworman's affiliated companies.

headline: Czech Dissident Detained
abstract: A former spokesman for the Charter 77 Czechoslovak human rights movement, Ladislav Lis, has been in custody since Thursday for failing to report to the police, emigre sources said here today. Mr. Lis, released last March after serving a 14-month sentence on charges of incitement, told his family by telephone that he was being held for violating the ''protective supervision'' order imposed on him on his release from jail, the sources said.

headline: LABOR DEPT. STUDY ON CARTER HAWLEY
abstract: The handling of the profit-sharing plan for employees of Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. is being studied by the Labor Department for possible violations of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, it has been learned. The plan owns an 18.5 percent block of shares that may determine whether The Limited Inc. succeeds in acquiring Carter Hawley.     Gloria Della, a Labor Department spokesman in Washington, said, ''We are looking at Carter Hawley Hale to see if there are Erisa violations.''    She would not state what the possible violations might be. But according to financial sources in New York, they may involve a letter dated April 15 that was sent by the Bank of America to participants in the plan.

headline: INTEREST ON CHASE NOTES MAY BE PAID IN STOCK
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Corporation increased the size of its sale of floating-rate subordinated notes to $400 million from $300 million. It is offering the notes through a group of underwriters led by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb.

headline: TEXT OF STATEMENT BY C.I.A.
abstract: Following is a statement today by George Lauder, the Central Intelligence Agency spokesman, on behalf of the agency concerning its efforts to keep appropriate committees of Congress informed of C.I.A. covert operations:    During the 13 January 1981 Senate Select Committee on Intelligence hearing on the nomination of Mr. Casey to be Director, C.I.A., Mr. Casey said:   ''I intend to comply fully with the spirit and the letter of the Intelligence Oversight Act. I intend to provide this committee with the information it believes it needs for oversight purposes.''   Mr. Casey believes the record will reflect that he and his staff have kept that pledge. A chronology of briefings of the Congressional oversight committees in connection with events in Central America reveals that from December 1981 through March 1984, either the director or deputy director briefed the Congressional committees 30 times on Central America.

headline: Iran and Iraq Report Successes in Gulf War
abstract: Iraqi warplanes struck at Iranian positions today and fighting on the ground in the southern sector of the war front left 34 Iranian soldiers dead, a communique by the Iraqi military command said.   Iraqi patrols and border gunners killed another 15 Iranians in the central and northern sectors of the 700-mile border, the Iraqi communique said.

headline: Yamani View On British Oil
abstract: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's oil minister, was quoted today by the Middle East Economic Survey as saying he was disappointed by a recent increase in Britain's output of crude oil.   British production from the North Sea rose to more than 2.6 million barrels a day in the first quarter this year from 2.3 million barrels a day late last year.   Britain is one of the largest oil producers outside the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, while Saudi Arabia is the biggest within the 13-nation group.

headline: INDIANS REPORT DAYLONG BATTLE AT SIKH TEMPLE
abstract: Army troops sent to quell violence in Punjab continued to trade fire today with Sikh terrorists firing mortars and machine guns from inside a Sikh shrine in Amritsar after a daylong battle Tuesday, the Government said.   Two people outside the Golden Temple, the holiest of Sikh shrines, were reported killed in the fighting Tuesday. One of them was said to be a soldier.    A report this morning from Chandigarh, the state capital of Punjab, said that Harchand Singh Longowal, president of the Akali Dal political party and leader of the moderate wing of the Sikh protest, had surrendered to security forces at the Golden Temple.  Surrendering with him, according to the report, was G. S. Tohra, the chief administrator of all the Sikh temples in Punjab, who is another major figure in the moderate camp.

headline: Detroit Edison
abstract: The Michigan Public Service Commission said it had granted the Detroit Edison Company an interim rate increase of 8 percent, amounting to $182.9 million.

headline: MOTOROLA'S POWERFUL NEW CHIP
abstract: The Motorola Corporation yesterday introduced a powerful new microprocessor that analysts said would make it possible for the next generation of desktop computers to rival the power of giant mainframe machines.    The new chip is the long-anticipated successor to the Motorola 68000, the microprocessor that lies at the heart of Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh computer, among others. But the new device, called the 68020, can manipulate 32 bits of information at a time. It can also exchange data with outside devices at that pace, twice the rate of the older chip. A bit is the most basic unit of data handled by a computer.

headline: Stocks Mixed; Dow Slips 0.21 Point
abstract: Stock prices finished with minor changes yesterday in heavier trading after dropping sharply in recent sessions because of rising interest rates.     The Dow Jones industrial average closed off 0.21 point, to 1,150.86. The number of stocks that gained on the New York Stock Exchange was identical to the number that declined: 777.

headline: ROME PROSECUTOR REQUESTS TRIAL OF 3 BULGARIANS IN ATTACK ON POPE ROME, May 8 (AP) - A state prosecutor recommended today that three Bulgarians and four Turks be tried in connection with the attempted assassination of Pope John Paul II in 1981, Italian news agencies reported.
abstract: The agencies, Ansa and A.G.I., quoting unnamed sources, said the state prosecutor, Antonio Albano, had filed the request with the Court of Appeals in Rome asking trials for Sergei Ivanov Antonov, former Rome manager for the Bulgarian state airline, and two former Bulgarian Embassy employees, Todor Ayvazov and Vassiliev Kolev.   Mr. Antonov is in Italian custody, but Mr. Ayvazov and Mr. Kolev left Italy two years ago.   Giuseppe Consolo, Mr. Antonov's Italian laywer, confirmed in a telephone interview that he had been told of the prosecutor's action. He said that he had not seen the document but that the charges were ''probably for complicity'' in the shooting of the Pope on May 13, 1981. Mr. Albano could not be reached for confirmation of the report.

headline: BRITISH OFFICIAL CONFERS IN PEKING ON HONG KONG
abstract: The British Foreign Secretary met today with China's Foreign Minister to review the negotiations on the future of Hong Kong.   Britain's lease over most of the colony expires in 1997.   Sir Geoffrey Howe, the British Secretary, discussed the issue of Hong Kong in separate sessions this morning and this afternoon with his Chinese counterpart, Wu Xueqian.  A Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman, Qi Huaiyuan, said the talks were carried out in a ''warm, friendly and earnest atmosphere.''

headline: DOW SLIDES BY 10.78, TO 1,165.52
abstract: Stock prices dropped yesterday in much heavier trading after advancing moderately on Tuesday. The star performer was Teledyne, which soared 32 points, to 187 3/4.     The Dow Jones industrial average finished down 10.78 points, to 1,165.52. The day before the average rose almost 10 points although several major banks raised their prime lending rates to 12 1/2 percent from 12 percent.

headline: First Executive Offers Preferred
abstract: The First Executive Corporation, an insurance holding company based in Beverly Hills, Calif., is offering 5.4 million shares of adjustable rate preferred stock at $25 a share through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert. The preferred stock offering, which was rated A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, was increased from four million shares.    Initially, the stock will have a dividend rate of 13.5 percent, but after Sept. 30, the interest rate will change quarterly at 1/4 percentage point below the higher of the bond-equivalent yield for 3-month Treasury bills, the 10-year Treasury note yield or the 20-year Treasury bond yield.

headline: PATENTS
abstract: Stimulator Devised For Plant Growth     The Biochemical Research Corporation in Falls Church, Va., has received a patent for a plant growth stimulator that is being used experimentally.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: DNA Plant Technology Corp., Cinnaminson, N.J., an agricultural biotechnology concern, has elected to its board Edward L. Hennessy Jr., chairman and chief executive of the Allied Corp.     *  EAC Industries, Chicago, a manufacturer of hardware and electromechanical equipment, has elected to its board Paul E. Price, executive vice president-international grocery products for the Quaker Oats Co.     *  Fischbach Corp., a holding company whose principal subsidiaries are in the construction industry, has appointed Michael R. Appel treasurer.

headline: Four Latin American Nations Seek Easing of Debt Terms
abstract: Mexico, Argentina, Colombia and Brazil, which hold more than half of Latin America's $336 billion foreign debt, today called a meeting of Latin American nations to push for lighter repayment terms.   A statement by the presidents of the four nations, released simultaneously in the four capitals, said they would hold a meeting of their foreign ministers and top economic officials and would invite ministers of other Latin American nations.

headline: BRITISH ANTI-SPY AIDE GOESON TRIAL FOR SPYING
abstract: A middle-ranking British intelligence officer went on trial today for passing secret information to Soviet officials here.    The Government says that the officer, Michael Bettaney, 34 years old, wanted to become a Soviet spy but apparently had failed to convince the Soviet intelligence agency that he was credible.   Mr. Bettaney was accused at the Old Bailey, London's central criminal court, of 10 violations of the Official Secrets Act between Dec.  21, 1982, and last Sept.  16, including having collected at his home some material so sensitive that even the Attorney General, Sir Michael Havers, who is the chief prosecutor, has not been allowed to see it.   Mr. Bettaney was arrested three days before he intended to fly to Vienna in hope of gaining the acceptance of the Soviet intelligence agency, the K.G.B., that had eluded him here, Sir Michael said. Mr. Bettaney is said to be a nine- year veteran of MI5, a British organization whose existence has never been officially confirmed but which oversees domestic security in the same way as the Federal Bureau of Investigation does in the United States. Mr. Bettaney became a counterespionage officer in 1982.

headline: SOVIET SAID TO ADD NEW SUBS OFF U.S.
abstract: Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov said today that the Soviet Union had increased the number of missile-carrying submarines off United States coasts and that the missiles were within 10 minutes of American targets.    Marshal Ustinov also said the number of SS-20 medium-range missiles in the European part of the Soviet Union would be increased ''accordingly'' in the event that the United States proceeds with its plan to deploy additional Pershing 2 and cruise missiles in Western Europe.   By United States estimates, there are 243 SS-20's in Europe, many times the number of Pershing 2's and cruises so far deployed.   (At the State Department, a spokesman said the department would have no comment on Marshal Ustinov's remarks at this time.)

headline: High Justice Officials Are Shuffled in Soviet
abstract: The Soviet Union appointed a new Justice Minister and a new chairman of the Supreme Court in April in a little noticed shuffle of the judiciary.   The appointments were announced at the session of the Supreme Soviet, the nominal legislature, in which Konstantin U. Chernenko assumed the national presidency in addition to his leadership of the Communist Party.

headline: HANOI ACCUSES CHINESE OF INCURSION
abstract: Vietnam said today that up to 2,000 Chinese troops had crossed into its territory in two locations and were locked in combat with defending Vietnamese forces.   China said the Vietnamese report was not true, but said artillery duels had taken place.   It was the latest in a series of border incidents that began Monday, when China said it shelled Vietnamese border posts in retaliation for what it said were repeated border provocations by Vietnam. Monday's shelling was the first reported Chinese bombardment of Vietnam in a year.   Backed by Artillery and Rockets    According to Vietnamese diplomats here, the Chinese troops, backed by artillery and rockets but without air cover, crossed into Vietnamese territory on Friday at 9 A.M. (9 P.M. Thursday, New York time) several miles east of the Chinese city of Pingxiang.

headline: UAL, Delta Gain; Frontier Has Loss
abstract: The parent companies of United Airlines and Delta Air Lines yesterday posted record profits for the first three months of the year, as higher air fares helped reverse their losses of a year ago in the midst of fierce price-cutting. But losses at the parent of Frontier Airlines widened.    Most of the major carriers have recently reported either strong earnings for the quarter or a narrowing of their losses.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: * Metropolitan Savings and Loan Association of Dallas said its public offering of $25,185,000, 13 1/4 percent mortgage-backed bonds will be fully paid by May 1, 2011. The bonds, which are being underwritten by E. F. Hutton, are priced at 99.25 percent.      Debt Ratings    * Bally Manufacturing Corp.  was added to S.&P.'s Creditwatch list so its potentially negative developments could be evaluated.

headline: Austerity In Philippines
abstract: President Ferdinand Marcos announced a tough economic recovery package today that raises taxes, cuts the budget and effectively devalues the peso by allowing it to float against the dollar.   The measures are certain to anger labor groups demanding higher wages but appear to satisfy International Monetary Fund conditions for a $650 million loan to help the country out of its worst economic crisis since World War II.

headline: Japanese Leaders Affirm U.S. Ties in Visit to India
abstract: Japan's Foreign Minister, meeting his Indian counterpart, said today that his nation hinged its foreign policy on its relationship with the United States.   And the Japanese Prime Minister, Yasuhiro Nakasone, on a four-day tour of India with Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe, placed a wreath on the grave of Mohandas K. Gandhi, the leader of India's independence movement.   ''The U.S.-Japan defense relationship is the backbone and most important pillar of Japan's foreign policy,'' Mr. Abe told India's Minister for External Affairs, P. V. Narasimha Rao.

headline: PARIS OFFERS A BILL ON PRIVATE SCHOOLS
abstract: The Cabinet, acting on one of the most divisive and emotional issues in French political life,    approved a bill today that would increase Government control over the largely Roman Catholic private schools.   The Socialist-led Government's proposal now goes to the National Assembly for a vote.  A Socialist legislative majority usually guarantees the enactment of Government legislation. But the divisions on the private schools are so complex that it is not clear whether the bill will be approved in its present form.

headline: MERRILL'S NEW BANK CHALLENGE
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company will begin another attack on the traditional turf of banks late this spring when it test-markets a personal asset management account intended for the small investor.   With a $5,000 minimum in securities or cash and a $20 annual fee, the company's new Capital Builder Account is aimed at the young upscale professional, earning more than $35,000 a year. These people, the company reasons, are just beginning to accumulate assets and have little experience in investing.   Other brokers are watching this experiment with interest, but question the need for such a program for limited financial holdings, and prefer to remain with their higher-priced products. It is the banks, industry experts agree, that will feel this new challenge most directly.

headline: CONGRESS IS URGED TO DELAY FUNDS UNTIL POWER TRANSFER IN SALVADOR
abstract: -A key Congressional leader urged today that military funds for El Salvador be delayed until after the inauguration of a new president there, for fear that a newly elected leader could be overthrown by a military coup.    Administration officials said that they regarded the proposed delay as another obstacle to Congressional approval of President Reagan's Feb. 17 request for $93 million for the Salvadoran Government. They warned that further delays could encourage the Salvadoran rebels to intensify their attacks in an effort to topple a new Government in the post-election period.   But the legislator, Representative Clarence D. Long, the Maryland Democrat who is chairman of the Foreign Operations subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee, told a committee hearing that if Jose Napoleon Duarte won the May 6th runoff election, ''We don't know if the military would let him take over.'' The congressman noted that Mr. Duarte had previously been the victim of a military coup that prevented him from taking office after winning an election.

headline: Esmark Reportedly Accepts Bid;  Beatrice Is Said to Raise Offer To $2.9 Billion
abstract: The Beatrice Foods Company has reached an agreement to buy Esmark Inc., the huge Chicago conglomerate, for $60 a share, or about $2.9 billion, in cash, food industry sources disclosed last night.   The price -- believed, to be the least Esmark would take to guarantee acceptance -- would be $4 a share more than the $2.5 billion that Beatrice had offered only two days earlier.   In anticipation of a higher offer, Esmark's shares advanced $2.125, to $58.375, on the New York Stock Exchange, with nearly 1.9 million shares changing hands. Beatrice's shares fell 87 1/2 cents, to $28.375.

headline: President Adds a TitleAt Bank of New England
abstract: Peter J. McCormick, president of the Bank of New England Corporation in Boston, was named to the additional post of chief executive. He succeeds Roderick M. MacDougall, who remains chairman.     ''We have had a management succession in place for a long time,'' Mr. McCormick said. ''There was no race here. It was over long ago.''

headline: Upper Volta Said to Foil Plot to Stage Coup
abstract: A plot to overthrow the Government of Upper Volta was foiled by the arrest of a dozen soldiers, Agence France-Presse reported today.

headline: No Headline
abstract: 2 New Home Computers Planned      CHICAGO, June 3 - The downturn in the home-computer market has not stopped manufacturers from developing new products. Two of the leading manufacturers of home computers today announced plans to offer significantly more powerful computers by Christmas.    At the first day of the International Summer Consumer Electronics Show here, Commodore International Ltd., which has an estimated 50 percent to 60 percent of the home computer market, exhibited a machine that it called the Commodore Plus/4, a revised version of the Commodore 264 model introduced in January.

headline: Advertising Pages Up
abstract: The Publishers Information Bureau has reported that in February member magazines increased their advertising pages 5.4 percent, to 11,174, over the same month last year. Advertising revenues increased 12.1 percent, to $325 million. February marked the 14th consecutive month of revenue increases, the bureau said.

headline: PRELATE ASSAILS SANDINISTAS AS CONFLICT SHARPENS
abstract: In the last four weeks, the conflict between Nicaraguan bishops and the Government has become more strident than at any time since pro-Sandinista demonstrators disrupted a mass celebrated by Pope John Paul II in Managua 14 months ago.    On Sunday, Archbishop Miguel Obando y Bravo, a prominent critic of the Sandinista Government, offered a mass here that in some ways resembled an anti-Government political rally.   The Church of Santo Domingo de las Sierrietas began to overflow well before the mass, the Archbishop's first here since his meeting with the Pope in Rome three weeks ago, was scheduled to begin. Worshipers clapped wildly and chanted ''O-ban-do!'' as he made his way toward the altar.

headline: Poland Detains 15 In Raid on Printing Plant
abstract: The Polish police have detained 15 people in a raid on an underground printing center and seven others who put up anti- Communist placards in public places, the official press said today.

headline: C.D. Rates Still Climb
abstract: As New York's largest banks continued their rate war, annual effective yields on six-month certificates of deposit and money market deposit accounts climbed further in the week ended yesterday, the Bank Rate Monitor said. The increases come on the heels of the year's fourth increase in the prime rate.   Leading the latest round of gains were New York banks, which offered a yield of 11.66 percent, up from 11.57 percent, on six-month certificates, and 10.12 percent, up from 10.07 percent, on money market accounts.

headline: Staar Surgical
abstract: The Staar Surgical Company said the Food and Drug Administration had approved its application to start human implants of its elastic intro-ocular lenses under an investigational device exemption. The company said that, under the exemption, the implants could be sold on a limited basis for investigational use while their safety and effectiveness were being studied. In over-the-counter trading today, Staar was the second-biggest percentage gainer, rising $3, to $20.50 bid.

headline: RUSSIAN DISSIDENT IS REPORTED AILING
abstract: The Soviet physicist and human rights activist Yuri F. Orlov is in ''very poor health'' after serving a seven-year sentence in a labor camp in the Urals, according to officials of an international human rights organization.   Helsinki Watch, a group that monitors international compliance with the human rights provisions of the 1975 Helsinki accord, reported last week that Dr. Orlov, who is now in internal exile, ''performed exhausting forced labor, lived on a near-starvation diet and suffered beatings by criminal inmates at the instigation of prison officials'' while he was in prison.    Friends of the physicist in Moscow gave Helsinki Watch ''before and after'' photos that the organization said suggested that Dr. Orlov has aged considerably, that his hair has turned completely gray, and that he has lost most of his teeth and a good deal of weight. The Helsinki Watch report concluded that ''the new photos provide a striking testimony to the ravaging effects of life in a Soviet labor camp.''

headline: MOSCOW IN MAY: ICY TOWARD THE U.S.
abstract: A middle-aged Russian said recently that he had heard songs on the radio he had not heard since the 1950's. They were patriotic marches with titles like ''We're for Peace'' and ''Millions Are Headed for Happiness'' that children learned in summer camp.  What struck the man, however, was their evocation of the mood of those days, with the bravado of the marches marking the cold war.   It was unlikely that the music had been resurrected specially to recreate that mood. But the songs were one of several elements that blended with the shock of the Olympic boycott and Andrei D. Sakharov's hunger strike, the report of more Soviet missiles in East Germany, an offensive in Afghanistan and a surprise snub to China, to cast a pall over an otherwise unusually warm and sunny May in Moscow.

headline: U.N.'s Lebanon Force Is Extended 6 Months
abstract: The Security Council unanimously agreed today to extend the life of the United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon for six months more. The mandate of the 5,688-man force would have expired at midnight.

headline: Federal Express
abstract: The Federal Express Corporation said it had ordered six McDonnell Douglas DC-10 aircraft for the company's small-package air express service.

headline: NET MORE THAN DOUBLES AT UNION CARBIDE CORP.
abstract: The Union Carbide Corporation, helped by the general improvement in the nation's economy, reported yesterday that net income in the first quarter more than doubled, as revenues rose 9.1 percent.   Union Carbide, the nation's third- largest chemical producer after E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company and the Dow Chemical Company, said net income in the quarter climbed to $107 million, or $1.51 a share, from $48 million, or 69 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: A REALIGNMENT FOR INSURANCE
abstract: The word in the insurance industry these days is ''demutualize.'' For many of the nation's mutual life insurance companies - insurers owned by their policyholders rather than by stockholders - are thinking of converting to stockholder ownership, a move that could change the face of the industry.     A few smaller companies have already made the change. But experts say the momentum is growing and is likely to carry over to some of the large insurers, in particular those that sell life insurance.

headline: Hindu Editor Slain By Sikhs in Punjab
abstract: Sikh terrorists assassinated a leading Hindu newspaper editor in the northern state of Punjab today, touching off violence in which hundreds of Hindus attacked buses, stores and banks, reports from the area said.   The editor, 60-year-old Ramesh Chandra of the Hind Samachar newspaper group, was killed when terrorists sprayed gunfire at his car in Jullundur city, some 215 miles northwest of New Delhi.

headline: ; Management Shuffle At MCA Advertising
abstract: In a management reorganization at MCA Advertising Ltd., Morgan V. Hunter, president, was named chairman and William W. Bishop, executive vice president, was named president.    The title of chairman had been held by James McManus, chairman of the Marketing Corporation of America, the parent of the advertising agency.

headline: PITFALLS IN THE CAPITAL SPENDING BOOM
abstract: IT'S the way recoveries work. First,    consumer spending powers the nation out of the depths of recession. Then, a few months later, business spending for new plant and equipment kicks in like a booster rocket, pushing the economy higher and higher.    It happened that way last year. Capital spending picked up speed in the first half, when the recovery was about six months old. It's been booming every since and is expected to soar by 13.6 percent this year over last to a record $343.6 billion in outlays.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM ; CONFESSIONS OF A CHRONIC DISSENTER
abstract: MICHAEL PERTSCHUK    FOR three years now, I have enjoyed the distinction of being on   the losing end of every major merger decision that has come before the Federal Trade Commission. As Pete Seeger once said, after receiving prolonged applause for competently whistling a tune, ''that's not precisely what I'd like to be known for.''   Like any chronic dissenter, I choose to believe that the world has gone astray, not I. And I plead both law and history, for the fact that by some curious quirk, I find myself defending the best elements of the antitrust law that came to fruition under the Nixon and Ford F.T.C.'s.   Throughout the early and mid- 1970's, these sober Republican commissions steadfastly applied the Clayton Act which directs us to enjoin any merger that ''may'' substantially lessen competition. So vigorous was this enforcement tradition in challenging mergers of even marginal competitors that the joining of major competitors in the oil and auto industries as we have seen recently was unthinkable.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  American General Corp., Houston, a diversified financial company, has elected to its board Thomas D. Barrow, vice chairman of the Standard Oil Co. (Ohio).

headline: Brazil Hopes to Pay Interest Due in '84
abstract: Brazil will be able to meet interest payments due this year on its $93 billion in foreign debt, despite the recent rise in interest rates, Affonso Celso Pastore, president of the central bank of Brazil, said in an interview yesterday.   But Mr. Pastore, who was in New York for a visit after a two-day conference in Washington, was far from sanguine about 1985.   "Because of rising export sales, our reserve position is improving fast, much faste than we thought," he said. "Even with the rise in the prime rate, debt service this year will not be much of a problem, because interest rates get readjusted very six months, and most of that readjustment will occur in the second half of this year.

headline: 2,000 Filipinos March In an Economic Protest
abstract: About 2,000 protesters, led by members of the family of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the assassinated opposition leader, marched in the Makati business district today to denounce the economic policies of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

headline: ITT Wins Order
abstract: The Turkish Government said it would award the ITT Corporation a $300 million order for advanced telephone switching equipment, ending weeks of doubt about the transaction. Veysel Atasoy, Minister for Transportation and Communications, told a parliamentary committee that ITT's switch was less expensive and more technically advanced than those of two competitors for the contract.

headline: Reagan's Media BuyerAnd Other Sundries
abstract: Among the bits and pieces of news that floated to the surface over the weekend:    The Tuesday Team, put together as agency for the Reagan-Bush reelection effort, announced that it had completed a search for a media buying service, selecting Ed Libov Associates, which is especially well- known in toy circles. Five services gave formal presentations and there were two finalists, the other being Vitt Media International. Tuesday Team has also found office space, at 1270 Avenue of the Americas.

headline: Solidarity Fugitives Call For Rallies Next Month
abstract: The Solidarity underground called today for anti-Government marches next month, its first such action since the failure of nationwide demonstrations last December.   Meanwhile, the Government issued a ''white book'' that renews criticism of United States sanctions against Poland and says strained relations with Washington are not expected to improve soon.

headline: FAMILY RENTALS
abstract: PROVIDING housing for children away at school can be a costly expense for parents, or an investment opportunity.  Similarly, under present tax law it can be profitable to help other family members who cannot afford the homes they would like. But homeowners must make sure they charge family members ''arms-length rents'' to be eligible to deduct depreciation, utilities, maintenance and other household costs for tax purposes, according to M. Donald Wright, a tax partner in Arthur Andersen & Company. Also, the housing must be the renters' principal residence.

headline: Japanese Fighters Sent Aloft As 7 Soviet Planes Approach
abstract: Japanese fighters scrambled today when Soviet planes, including at least three Backfire bombers, appeared off the west coast of Hokkaido.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN'S ADDRESS IN GREAT HALL OF THE PEOPLE
abstract: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's address today in the Great Hall of the People:    Twelve years ago, former President Nixon arrived in Beijing, stepped down from Air Force One, and shook hands with former Premier Zhou Enlai. Premier Zhou would later tell him, ''Your handshake came over the vastest ocean in the world - 25 years of no communication.''   With one handshake, America and China each turned a new page in their histories. I believe history beckons again. We have begun to write a new chapter for peace and progress in our histories, with America and China going forward hand in hand.

headline: Who's to Blame?
abstract: To the Editor:      The subtle rewriting of economic history by George Champion (''Regulators and Bankers Are to Blame,'' Business Forum, June 10) cannot go unchallenged.    He stated that ''the (banking) system has proven to be the lifeblood for growth. . . . Commercial banking has been the catalyst for our economic growth . . . providing more jobs and the highest standard of living.''

headline: The U.N. Today; May 24, 1984
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Committee on Strategy for the Third Development Decade - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Plenary meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3:00 P.M.

headline: Binney & Smith Views Options
abstract: Binney & Smith Inc.   said yesterday that it had retained Morgan Stanley & Company as its financial adviser to examine corporate strategic alternatives, and the company's stock soared.

headline: Chrysler Bonus Plan Disclosed
abstract: The   bonuses to be paid to top executives of the Chrysler Corporation could be, on average, larger than those paid at the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, according to Chrysler's annual proxy statement. Chrysler's bonus plan lapsed when it was near bankruptcy, but the auto maker is now seeking shareholder approval for a new plan that would pay the 1,465 senior executives up to $51.6 million for 1983, or an average of $35,221.

headline: POPE OFFERS TO GO TO SOVIET IF ASKED
abstract: Pope John Paul II returned today from a 10-day, 25,000 mile journey to the Far East and said he would continue his world travels, even going to the Soviet Union and China if such trips could be arranged.    Shortly before landing on the last leg from Bangkok, Thailand, the Pope, looking fresh after a few hours of sleep, strolled among the reporters in the back of his plane.   The Pope declared his readiness to go to the Soviet Union or China, although no plans or invitations for such journeys are known to exist.   ''Of course,'' the Pope said when asked if he would go to the Soviet Union. ''The people of Russia are my brothers also, like Polish people.''

headline: ATTACK IN SOUTH PERSIAN GULF SAID TO THREATEN NEW PHASE IN WAR
abstract: The air attack Sunday on a Kuwaiti supertanker, widely presumed to have been launched by Iran, threatens to open a new phase in the Persian Gulf war, Arab and Western officials said today.    A week ago, Iran appeared to be stymied by Saudi Arabia's decision to protect shipping in its part of the gulf by air defense over its northern gulf territorial waters, which it claims 12 miles offshore.    Last Tuesday, Saudi Arabian F-15 jet fighters, guided by Awacs surveillance planes, shot down an Iranian F-4 Phantom and forced several other Iranian jets to turn back in an air clash almost in the middle of the gulf.   After the air attack Sunday on the Kuwaiti tanker Kazimah in the southern part of the gulf, however, it appears that Iran is intent on circumventing the Saudi Air Force and continuing its sporadic attacks on Arab tankers, Western diplomats said.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM; MONDALE: FIRST, CUT THE DEFICIT
abstract: MY top domestic priority is to make our free economy the strongest, most productive on earth - and to do it fairly. The overriding goal of economic policy must be to give all Americans the opportunity to work.  History teaches us that broader opportunity spurs private economic growth, but Reaganomics takes the opposite tack. It concentrates its tax cuts and incentives on the very wealthiest - bringing declines in savings and investment, record real interest rates, record trade deficits, record postwar unemployment and record budget deficits that restrain growth. Instead of building our future, Reaganomics mortgages it.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: THURSDAY, APRIL 12, 1984   The Economy    The House approved a $49.2 billion tax bill as the first concrete step by Congress to reduce Federal budget deficits. The bill is intended to close loopholes and raise taxes on liquor and diesel fuel. Debate on a similar bill continued in the Senate. Both bills differ from plans proposed by President Reagan. (Page A1.)

headline: Balcor in Film Accord
abstract: Balcor/American Express Inc., a subsidiary of Shearson Lehman/American Express Inc., said today that it had agreed to provide $160 million to finance all production and marketing costs for New World Pictures through 1987. New World is a privately held film maker and distributor based here. The financing will include a $12 million investment that gives Balcor a significant minority interest in New World.

headline: MOSCOW'S HOSTILE MOOD
abstract: In the four months since Konstantin U. Chernenko became the Soviet leader, the Kremlin has settled into a hostile mood of a kind that has rarely been seen since the height of the cold war 30 years ago.  Recent weeks have seen a sharp turning inward, a curtailment of ties with the West and a resort to something approaching rudeness in dealing with official visitors who have sought a return to compromise.    Little is known about the workings of the Kremlin under Mr. Chernenko, but one view among Western diplomats is that the mood owes at least something to the character of the new Soviet leader, a peasant's son from Siberia, who has shown over the years that he has strong instincts of the kind associated with conservative Russian leaders.   Apparently his views are reinforced in the current climate by those of Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, who has emerged as the most powerful figure around Mr. Chernenko. Those attitudes include suspicion of the West, a rigid pride in the Soviet Union and a quick hostility toward anything seen as denigrating or threatening.

headline: Coffee Quota Talks Begin
abstract: Coffee- producing countries plan preliminary discussions of new export quotas at a two-week meeting of the International Coffee Organization that began today, Colombia's top coffee official said here. Final decisions are not expected yet, according to the official, Jorge Cardenas.

headline: MUSIC TOWNS: PLAYING A COMPANY TUNE
abstract: THERE are probably few other   manufacturing towns in the Middle West that would make a hero out of a cornetist with a bad lip. But in Elkhart, Ind., population 41,305, Col. C.G. Conn is something of a legend.   According to local folklore, Colonel Conn - the military title was apparently more colorful than accurate - played cornet in the Elkhart town band in the late 19th century. ''Then he got his lip injured in a barroom brawl or fight of some kind,'' said Keith E. Meade, a vice president of the Elkhart Chamber of Commerce and a local history buff.

headline: Careers; Information Systems Get Focus
abstract: PROPOSAL writers at about 500 graduate schools of business will be scrambling in the next few months to formulate plans for submission to the International Business Machines Corporation.    The big computer maker wants to make sizable grants to graduate business schools interested in strengthening training programs and doing research in the field of management information systems. M.I.S., as it is known, has become one of the hottest subspecialties in management.    ''Our aim is to encourage business schools to develop more graduates who understand the role information systems will play in coming years,'' John R. Opel, I.B.M.'s chairman, said last week. Information systems, he said, are ''strategic tools'' for management.

headline: SENATE DEFEATS A PROPOSAL TO BAN SEA-BASED NUCLEAR CRUISE MISSILES
abstract: The Senate, moving toward approval of its $230 billion military authorization bill, rejected an attempt today to impose a moratorium on deployment of nuclear- armed cruise missiles at sea.    Still ahead, as the Senate moved through dozens of amendments, was a measure from Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, that would prod more military contributions from the Western European members of the North Atlantic Treaty organization.   Senator Nunn said Administration officials, including President Reagan, as well as foreign officials had kept in touch with him on his amendment.   On Monday, Senator Nunn said in a speech that the Atlantic alliance was not prepared to stop a conventional attack by the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact forces with conventional weapons.

headline: Suzuki Ships Cars to G.M.
abstract: The Suzuki Motor Company has shipped the first load of 1.0-liter subcompact cars for the General Motors Corporation, a Suzuki official said today.   The first shipload of 900 fuel- efficient, 60-horsepower cars, called the Cultus, left for the United States from central Japan on Sunday, he said.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Aegis Corp. , a tank cleaning and transport company in Coral Gables, Fla., said its board would consider a tender offer from Min Acquisitions Inc. as well as alternatives. It recommended that shareholders defer action until a special board meeting on Thursday.     * Allegheny Beverage Corp. , a Baltimore-based soft-drink company, said it had bought the assets and operations of Electromax Inc., a coin-operated laundry company in San Jose, Calif.

headline: E.E.C. Steel Output Off
abstract: Production of crude steel in the European Economic Community fell to 11.8 million tons in March, down a seasonally adjusted 2.8 percent from February, Eurostat, the trade bloc's statistical agency, said today. The March output was 10.5 percent higher than in March 1983, but 3.9 percent below production in March 1982, the agency added. Greek output was not included.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM ; KUDOS FOR MANAGEMENT, NOT DARTS
abstract: SINCE the Gulf Corporation  agreed last month to a $13.1 billion takeover by the Standard Oil Company of California, Wall Street denizens and the financial press have enjoyed labeling Gulf's management team as a failure. Specifically, Chairman James E. Lee has been called a loser - a chief executive who just did not have enough fight in him and refused to use all the defensive options in his arsenal.   I find this reaction distorted because it focuses on ''survival at all costs'' rather than on the proper responsibilities of managers in public corporations.   To understand the prevailing sentiment toward Gulf on Wall Street, a little background might help. Gulf incurred some disfavor among professional traders when it abandoned its 1982 attempt to buy Cities Service. In the midst of a takeover contest, government scrutiny of the deal for possible antitrust violations cooled Gulf's ardor and Mr. Lee was quoted as saying he ''had no stomach for this kind of thing.'' As a result, many Wall Street risk arbitragers who had bought Cities Service stock in anticipation of a successful takeover suffered losses as the stock plunged. Indeed, several ''arbs'' have been quoted as being pleased that Gulf is being taken over and supported T. Boone Pickens' takeover bid to make up for earlier losses.

headline: BATTLING BASQUES FIGHTING THE FRENCH OVER FISH
abstract: Late last year the small village of Lijar in southern Spain took a long look back to 1883 when, furious that ''French rabble'' had stoned a Spanish monarch in Paris, it single-handedly declared war on France.    The villagers decided it was time to let bygones be bygones. And so, after 100 years, they formally declared the war over. ''We've forgiven them now,'' said the Mayor, Diego Sanchez.

headline: U.S. VETOES U.N. BID TO CONDEMN MINING OF NICARAGUAN PORT
abstract: The United States today vetoed a proposed Security Council resolution that would have condemned the mining of Nicaraguan ports.   The veto came at the end of four days of debate on a complaint by Nicaragua against the United States for ''the escalation of acts of military aggression brought against it.''

headline: Soviet Atom Blast Detected
abstract: The Seismological Institution of Uppsala University said today that it had recorded a Soviet underground nuclear explosion at the Semipalatinsk test site in eastern Kazakhstan. It was the fourth recorded this year at a magnitude exceeding 6.5 on the open-ended Richter scale.

headline: HEAVY FIGHTING REPORTED AT SHRINE IN PUNJAB
abstract: Army troops and Sikh terrorists reportedly clashed in several areas of Punjab today, with casualties on both sides. Heavy fighting was reported between Sikh terrorists inside the holiest shrine of the Sikh religion and security forces outside.    The state, where Sikhs are campaigning for greater political autonomy, was virtually sealed off from the rest of the world.   An armed cordon has been put around the Sikh shrine, the Golden Temple in Amritsar. The temple has been both the headquarters of the Sikh rebellion and a sanctuary for terrorists.

headline: IN HORN OF AFRICA, THE DAY THE DRUGS CAME LATE
abstract: The biggest business in this tiny country is the khat trade.    Khat, a narcotic leaf that produces mild stimulation, is Djibouti's unofficial national plant, the much loved legal drug of inhabitants of the Horn of Africa.  Each day 8 to 10 tons of the stuff are flown from Ethiopia to Djibouti by Air Djibouti or Ethiopian Airlines in the cargo hold and economy sections of the planes.   No passenger is more eagerly awaited. At 1 P.M. some 300 drivers of green and black official taxis, known as the Sultans of Khat, assemble at the airport to carry the plane's precious cargo to customers throughout the country. The plant must be chewed while it is fresh or it loses potency.

headline: ETHIOPIA'S TOP DIPLOMAT IN U.S. ASKS ASYLUM AFTER HE IS RECALLED
abstract: The charge d'affaires at the Ethiopian Embassy here said today that he had decided to seek political asylum in the United States.   The charge, Tesfaye Demeke, 40 years old, has been the highest Ethiopian diplomat in the United States since 1980.   He said at a news conference that he decided to seek asylum because of what he called the increasingly hostile stand of Ethiopia's Marxist Government toward the United States and because of death threats made in Ethiopia against him and his family.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; A Zero-Coupon Issue Of Sears Eurobonds
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company became the second United States company to offer zero-coupon bonds in the Eurobond market this week. Through a subsidiary, Sears is selling $500 million face amount of zero-coupon bonds, which do not bear interest, through underwiters led by the Goldman Sachs International Corporation.

headline: 28 Poles Reported Charged In May Day Demonstrations
abstract: Prosecutors have filed criminal charges against at least 28 of 100 people detained in May Day disturbances in the Gdansk area, press reports said today.

headline: REAGAN CITES NICARAGUAN RALLY
abstract: President Reagan, in his speech tonight, took note of what he described as a ''demonstration of defiance'' staged by 100,000 Nicaraguan Catholics on Good Friday, April 20.   ''You may be hearing about that demonstration for the first time,'' Mr. Reagan said.

headline: The U.N. Today; April 19, 1984
abstract: SECURITY COUNCIL   Meets on the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon at 3:30 P.M.  GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Working Group of Experts on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights Covenant - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Commission on Transnational Corporations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  Abraham & Straus, a division of Federated Department Stores, has appointed Curtis Champlin senior vice president in charge of merchandising, Budget Store, and David Stern senior vice president, director of all stores except Brooklyn.     *  Allied Maintenance Corp., a diversified service company, has appointed Frank Rosenberg executive vice president.     *  Capital Holding Corp.  of Louisville, Ky., active in life insurance, has named Theodore S. Rosky chief financial officer, succeeding John Franco, who becomes president of the company's agency group.

headline: SHERPA
abstract: The word conjures up images of a rugged, agile Tibetan guide leading adventuresome British climbers up the face of Mount Everest. In the world of modern economics, however, the term has taken on a more genteel meaning.   Today's sherpas are the seven key government aides who lead their nation's chief executives in their ascent to the world's economic summit. There, the leaders of the world's seven largest non-Communist industrial nations, primed for both the obvious and the arcane questions of economic policy, work to narrow the gap on global disagreements. The sherpas and their backup teams try to assure that their nations' leaders are not embarrassed by surprises at the highly publicized meetings - and to see that issues most important to their chief executives are given sufficient airing.    This year, the 10th economic summit conference will be held in London, starting next Thursday and ending Saturday night with a state banquet at Buckingham Palace. In addition to President Reagan, the leaders of Britain, Canada, France, Italy, Japan and West Germany will attend. (The European Economic Community also sends a sherpa and its president.) For Mr. Reagan, it will be summit No. 4. And for his lead sherpa, W. Allen Wallis, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, it will be summit No. 2.

headline: WASHINGTON AIDES AFFIRM POLICY SHIFT ON U.S. TROOP ROLE
abstract: Senior Reagan Administration officials affirmed today that the Defense Department, in a significant shift in thinking, was now prepared to use American combat troops in Central America if leftist forces in the region cannot be defeated by other means.   Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger denied on Sunday that the Administration had prepared contingency plans for the use of American combat troops in Central America.

headline: IN LONDON, PAGEANTRY AND ANGER
abstract: Fortunately for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the opening of the economic summit conference today coincided with the House of Commons' first debate on Britain's coal strike, now three months old.   While Mrs. Thatcher and Britain's news media were preparing for the pageantry of summit delegations arriving at the Orangery beside Kensington Palace, 10,000 coal miners were marching angrily along Fleet Street toward the House of Commons to focus attention on their grievances.   The traffic-snarling march followed embarrassing disclosures about the Government's handling of the dispute. Memos leaked this week suggested that Mrs. Thatcher and the Government were far more involved than previously acknowledged in the handling of the strike by the state-owned National Coal Board.

headline: Chase Denies Loan Offer
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that it had made no offer of a loan to the Government of Colombia. ''We said we have had a long and positive history of supporting both the public and private sectors in Colombia, but talks are still continuing regarding financing needs,'' said a spokesman, who asked not to be identified. Yesterday, Colombia's Finance Minister, Edgardo Gutierrez, who said on Friday that Colombia had been offered a $700 million loan by Chase, said in London that Chase has only ''indicated'' to Colombia that it may attempt to arrange such a loan.

headline: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: MRS. THATCHER SHUNS A SIEGE
abstract: One of the oddest features of the siege at the Libyan Embassy in St. James's Square, which ended on Friday with the departure of 30 Libyan diplomats and others, was the distance Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher put between herself and the crisis.    No major political or diplomatic event that has occurred in London since Mrs. Thatcher took office five years ago has had so little overt involvement from the Prime Minister - a surprising circumstance, as one Western diplomat commented, for someone ''usually so fond of standing up to people who she thinks are trying to push Britain around.''   For the first 72 hours after the fatal shooting of Constable Yvonne Fletcher, the Prime Minister was in Lisbon on an official visit, an important trip but not one whose cancellation would have caused vast problems. When she returned, she went to Chequers, her country estate, for the weekend. And when the decision to sever diplomatic relations with Tripoli was announced last Sunday, it was explained to the press not by Mrs. Thatcher but by Richard Luce, a junior minister at the Foreign Office.

headline: NICARAGUA AND COSTA RICA SIGN BORDER PACT
abstract: The Foreign Ministers of Costa Rica and Nicaragua signed an agreement Tuesday night aimed at lessening tension and armed conflict on their common border.   The agreement, completed after a daylong meeting sponsored by the Contadora group of four Latin American nations, called for the formation of a joint ''Commission of Supervision and Prevention'' that would conduct border inspections and recommend solutions to problems between the two countries.

headline: SHULTZ ASKS MOVE AGAINST TERRORISM
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the Western countries had to consider pre-emptive action against ''known terrorist groups'' and face up ''to the need for active defense against terrorism.''   Identifying Iran, Syria, Libya and North Korea as countries involved in ''state-supported terrorism,'' Mr. Shultz said that ''we have no choice but to address ourselves boldly'' to ways of halting the rise in what he called ''a form of warfare.'' He said traditional methods of enhanced security and better intelligence were no longer adequate by themselves.   In a speech at a meeting of the Trilateral Commission, a group of prominent citizens of North America, Western Europe and Japan who meet to discuss world affairs, Mr. Shultz offered no specific plan, but his aides said there had been considerable discussion in the Administration on the need to take more forceful action against terrorist groups without waiting for them to strike.

headline: PATENTS ; Security Setup Detects Intruder, Fire or Smoke
abstract: Ronald E. Pyle of Austin, Tex., has patented a home security system intended to offer protection against intrusion, fire and smoke.

headline: Chemical Arms Offer Condemned by Soviet
abstract: The Soviet Union today called the United States proposal for a treaty banning chemical weapons absurd and unacceptable.

headline: Arco Field Bid
abstract: The Atlantic Richfield Company is seeking Federal permission to develop Prudhoe Bay's Lisburne formation, a field Arco estimates contains 3 billion barrels of oil.

headline: ; Food Industry Veteran To Lead Thriftimart
abstract: Robert J. Emmons, a food industry veteran and poet, has been named president and chief executive of Thriftimart Inc., a Los Angeles-based food retailer with a regional chain of supermarkets and cash-and-carry stores.    Mr. Emmons, 49, succeeds Roger M. Laverty Jr., who resigned.

headline: FUND DISCUSSED FOR BALDWINPOLICIES
abstract: The stock brokerage and life insurance industries, seeking to protect their reputations after the failure of the Baldwin-United Corporation, are considering a contribution of about $250 million to holders of Baldwin annuities, officials from the two industries said yesterday.    Executives from about two dozen national and regional brokerage firms that sold the annuities have been meeting frequently in New York for nearly three months to consider a contribution of approximately $200 million, according to attorneys from two of the firms, who asked not to be named.   In addition, the executive committee of the American Council of Life Insurance is scheduled to meet in Washington today to begin considering a contribution of ''upwards of $50 million'' from the life insurance industry, which also sold the policies, according to one executive committee member, who also asked not to be identified.   Two of the largest brokerage firms - Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. and Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. - had announced in late January that they would set aside $88 million and $25 million, respectively, for customers to whom they had sold Baldwin annuities. In addition, E. F. Hutton & Company had set up a $20 million Baldwin reserve without details on how it would be distributed.

headline: French Price Rise Slim
abstract: Wholesale prices in France rose three-tenths of 1 percent in February after a revised increase of 1.7 percent in January, the National Statistics Institute said today. The figures measure prices of raw materials and semifinished industrial products.

headline: Wilson Plant Sale
abstract: The Wilson Foods Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Cedar Rapids, Iowa, hog slaughtering and processing plant for about $16 million to Cedar Rapids Meats Inc., a new company headed by Keith Barnes, a Minnesota businessman.

headline: 'JUNK BOND' MARKET GROWING
abstract: Suddenly investment bankers are scrambling to get into a business they had traditionally shunned - the underwriting and trading of ''junk bonds.''     No fewer than half a dozen major firms, ranging from Dean Witter Reynolds and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette to Paine Webber and Morgan Stanley, are gearing up separate departments to cash in on the widening interest in these low-rated, high- yielding debt securities. And a host of other Wall Street houses that only dabbled in them in the past are scouting for more salesmen, traders and analysts for this area.   The business is dominated by Drexel Burnham Lambert. Its prowess in expanding the market for these bonds has placed it in the upper tier of managers in the total debt and equity underwriting ranking.

headline: ; Contraceptive Sponge Account to Key/Donna
abstract: Key/Donna/Pearlstein of Los Angeles has been selected by the VLI Corporation of Irvine, Calif., to do advertising for its Today brand vaginal contraceptive sponge.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD ; Angry Milk Producers Block French Roads
abstract: French milk producers blocked the main roads out of Arras in northeastern France this morning to protest plans to cut milk output, the police said.

headline: ;  Bates Branches Abroad
abstract: Ted Bates Worldwide has bought half of Entente Delacroix, a group of eight European agencies, which it describes as ''highly creative.'' The owner of the other half is Oliver Dassault International Communications, another European company. ''It is our intent to grow more rapidly throughout Europe,'' said Robert E. Jacoby, chairman and chief expansionist at Bates.

headline: German Trade Surplus
abstract: West Germany's merchandise trade surplus swelled in May to 4.83 billion marks, or $1.73 billion, from 2.56 billion marks in April and 3.64 billion marks a year earlier, the Federal Statistics Office said today. The current account swung in May to a surplus of 2.7 billion marks, or $972 million, from a deficit of 400 million marks in April, but was down slightly from a year-earlier surplus of $1.72 billion marks. The current account includes trade in merchandise as well as services like finance and shipping.

headline: ATOM PLANT MAY BE CANCELED
abstract: The Consumers Power Company said yesterday that its directors would probably cancel its two-unit nuclear project in Midland, Mich., on Friday unless there is ''substantial progress'' on how customers and stockholders would share the project's costs.     But the company and state officials said they were still far apart in negotiations about whether to cancel one or both of the plants, and about how the costs should be apportioned.    State sources and industry analysts said it was unlikely that an agreement could be reached.

headline: 200 GATHER IN PARIS TO RECALL DAYS BEHIND GERMAN LINES
abstract: Their names are Mike and Elmer and Nigel and Pierre. They are retired insurance salesmen and farmers and real estate salesmen. Forty years ago, some were in German-occupied France and others were parachuted in just after the Allied invasion of Normandy on June 6.    They were underground agents known as Jedburghs, whose strategy was ''surprise, kill, vanish.''

headline: ADMINISTRATION WEIGHS INSIDER BILL
abstract: Momentum appears to be gathering in the Administration to oppose legislation intended to toughen penalties for the illegal use of insider information in the trading of securities, according to Government and industry sources.   A key Administration official has urged Wall Street securities industry officials to join him in lobbying against the bill, according to industry sources.    Christopher C. DeMuth, the official in charge of regulatory affairs in the Official of Management and Budget,  confirmed that he recently spoke with several Wall Street officials.

headline: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CUBA EVER ALERT FOR 'ENEMY'
abstract: After 25 years of Communist rule, this city, which was once one of the liveliest capitals in the Caribbean, has become subdued, orderly and distinctly faded.   It is a strikingly quiet place. Although the people seem relaxed, there is almost none of the usual sidewalk chatter that is heard in the center of most cities. There are no blaring radios, no shouting street vendors.

headline: Manila Panel Is Urged To Check Aquino Body
