abstract: Two experts in forensic medicine urged the Philippine Investigative Commission today to recommend exhumation of the body of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., saying it might hold the key to a dispute about his slaying last Aug. 21.   The experts said that radiological examination of the body might show that the opposition leader was shot two times by two gunmen as he arrived at the Manila airport from the United States.

headline: DAMASCUS SAYS 3 CAPTIVE ISRAELIS WERE TAKEN TO SYRIA AS P.O.W.'S
abstract: Syria confirmed today that it captured three Israeli officials in Lebanon Tuesday and said they had been taken to Syria. Israel demanded their release.   Syria said the Israelis were seized as they were trying to infiltrate Syrian-controlled territory. But an Israeli spokesman said the three had strayed into the area while on a sightseeing tour.   An Israeli Government spokesman in Jerusalem said the three men were diplomats working out of the Israeli liaison office in Dbeiyeh, a village just north of Beirut controlled by the Christian Phalangist militia.  The office has served as Israel's unofficial embassy in Lebanon, although it has no diplomatic or legal status.

headline: BUILDING OUTLAYS UP SHARP 6.9%
abstract: Spending for new construction, driven by continuing strength in the housing industry, soared by 6.9 percent in February, the largest monthly increase in almost four decades, the Commerce Department reported today.   Officials said spending was at an annual rate of $295 billion, compared with $276 billion in January. The new rate reflected broad improvement throughout the construction industry, with particularly strong showings in residential and industrial building.

headline: RIOTS IN SANTO DOMINGO RENEW DEBATE ON I.M.F.
abstract: The warning from President Salvador Jorge Blanco of the Dominican Republic to President Reagan was blunt: If his country accepted the International Monetary Fund's terms for continued aid, he wrote in a letter, it ''could undoubtedly provoke social tensions so strong that it could alter the peace and the most important functional democratic process in the Caribbean.''   Mr. Reagan, replying nearly three months later, dismissed the warning. So did the I.M.F.   And even Mr. Jorge Blanco, writing that letter on Jan. 4, did not foresee how grave the public reaction would be. As the Dominican Republic began implementing its second round of I.M.F.-ordered adjustments, riots broke out around the country this week, leaving an estimated 55 Dominicans dead and hundreds injured, and shaking the social and political foundations of this normally tranquil island.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: *  Aid Auto Stores Inc. , a Brooklyn- based retail automotive franchiser and wholesaler, has signed an agreement to acquire Allied Accessories and Auto Parts Co., an automotive wholesaler with headquarters in Madison Heights, Mich.     *  American Plan Corp. , Plano, Tex., and American Guaranty Financial Corp., Portland, Ore., have agreed to terminate previously announced plans to merge. No explanation was given.

headline: BONN BARS ITS EAST BERLIN MISSION TO EAST GERMANS TRYING TO LEAVE
abstract: The West German Government effectively closed its diplomatic mission in East Berlin today to East Germans seeking refuge and emigration to the West.   The immediate purpose of the move was apparently to resolve the plight of 45 East Germans who have been living in the building for weeks.   In a broader context, West Germany fears that the process of detente with East Germany may be undermined by its embarrassment in having citizens seek refuge in Bonn's mission.   ''We have no choice,'' said Hans Otto Br"autigam, the West German envoy, in explaining the decision to admit East Germans only to an outer entryway.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN REMARKS ON SOVIET TIES
abstract: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Reagan today to the Conference on U.S.-Soviet Exchange, as recorded by the White House press office:    Certainly nothing is more worthy of our attention than finding ways to reach out and establish better communication with the people and the Government of the Soviet Union.   For many months, I have encouraged the Soviet Union to join with us in a major effort to see if we could make progress in these broad problem areas, reducing the threat and use of force in solving international disputes, reducing armaments in the world and establishing a better working relationship with each other.   Let me describe to you some of the many efforts that we're making to establish a better workng relationship with the Soviet Union.   We have informed the Soviet Government that we're prepared to initiate negotiations on a new exchanges agreement, and we've completed our preparations for these negotiations. We propose to resume preparations to open consulates in New York and Kiev. We've taken steps to remove our - or revive our agreements for cooperation in environmental protection, housing, health and agriculture. Activities under these agreements have waned in recent years, because there've been no meetings of their joint committees to plan projects.

headline: Data Bank; June 24, 1984
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: AMERICANS ON SHIP SAID TO SUPERVISE NICARAGUA MINING
abstract: Americans working for the Central Intelligence Agency on a ship off Nicaragua's Pacific coast have been supervising the mining of Nicaraguan harbors in recent months, according to Reagan Administration officials and members of Congress.    The sources say the mining operation marks the first time since the United States began supporting Nicaraguan rebels three years ago that Americans have become directly involved in military operations against Nicaragua.   The actual placement of the mines inside Nicaraguan territorial waters, they said, is handled by an elite group of Latin American commandos who use small, high-speed boats to penetrate shipping lanes close to shore.   'Closer to Direct Confrontation'    The officials said that unlike ground operations inside Nicaragua conducted by rebel forces, which American advisers monitor from Honduras but do not control, the planting of the mines in Nicaraguan waters directly involves Americans and is under their immediate control.

headline: CONTINENTAL DISCLOSES TERMS OF LOAN
abstract: The directors of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company and its holding company, the Continental Illinois Corporation, agreed to resign if the F.D.I.C. asked them to.  The conecssion, disclosed by the holding company in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commision, was part of the agreement under which the bank received an emergency loan of $2 billion from the F.D.I.C.  The Chicago bank and its parent corporation also agreed not to resume dividend payments and not to give senior officers long-term employment contracts or large termination bonuses without F.D.I.C. approval, according to the filing, which was made Friday.  Alan J. Whitney, a spokesman for the F.D.I.C., said today that the agency had imposed similar restrictions in the past in the rare instances that it has made loans to shaky banks. The most analogous case, Mr. Whitney said, was the agency's arrangement with the First Pennsylvania Bank of Philadelphia, which borrowed $325 million in 1980. The money was repaid last year.

headline: No Headline
abstract: SATURDAY, MAY 12, 1984   The Economy    Retail sales surged 2.9 percent in April, but reaction was mixed: the Administration welcomed the apparent continued strength in the economy, but some economists worried that this strength could contribute to higher interest rates. Treasury Secretary Regan renewed his criticism of the Federal Reserve. (Page 1.)    Producer prices were unchanged in April, lessening fears of a resurgence in inflation. Food prices fell 0.6 percent, the sharpest drop since June, offsetting in large part a sudden 2.9 percent jump in gasoline prices. (38.)

headline: Kinney Shoe Deal
abstract: The F. W. Woolworth Company said its Kinney Shoe Corporation subsidiary had agreed in principle to acquire all of the shares of the Menlo Trading Company, a California- based retailer. Menlo Trading, operating under the name Athletic Shoe Factory, operates 62 stores in California, Arizona, Nevada and Texas that sell brand-name athletic footwear and apparel at discount prices.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: AAR Corp., Elk Grove Village, Ill., a marketer of aviation parts and services, announced that Ira Eichner, chairman and chief executive officer, was assuming the additional title of chief operating officer.     *  Advanced Semiconductor Materials International N.V., Bilthoven, the Netherlands, has appointed Franc R. J. De Weeger as president of its subsidiary, ASM America Inc. in Phoenix.     *  Alpine Geophysical Corp., whose principal business is oceanography, oil and gas, has named Steven S. Elbaum chairman and chief executive officer.

headline: 20 ISRAELIS ARRESTED IN A PLOT TO BOMB ARAB BUSES
abstract: Israeli security forces rounded up 20 Jewish suspects today after foiling a plot to blow up Arab- owned buses in the Jerusalem area, officials announced.    An authority in the security establishment said officials believed they had cracked an anti-Arab underground organization more dangerous and better trained than the three groups whose members were recently arrested for ambushing a bus and planting bombs at Christian and Moslem targets.   Josef Burg, the Minister of Interior, said, however, that the number of arrests should not be taken as an indication that an organization rather than just an individual was responsible for the bombing plot.

headline: ACCOUNTS
abstract: * Quaker Oats Co., Chicago, to Backer & Spielvogel for an unnamed cereal.     * Rainbow Programming Services, Woodbury, L.I., to Fearon O'Leary Kaprielian.     * Andrew Geller Industries to Margeotes/Fertitta & Weiss.

headline: TOOL ORDERS INCREASED 27% IN MAY
abstract: Orders for machine tools jumped 27 percent in May from April as the industry continued its month-by-month strengthening, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported yesterday. The gain followed a 23 percent rise in April.    ''It's encouraging that the industry is starting to build a backlog,'' said Christine Chien, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ''We're seeing a sequential improvement on a monthly basis.''

headline: 5,000 Sikhs Visit Reopened Temple
abstract: More than 5,000 Sikh pilgrims poured into the reopened Golden Temple complex today, one day after it was closed abruptly. Many wept as they viewed damage caused by the Indian Army's raid on the shrine.

headline: No Accord On Copper
abstract: The International Trade Commission, which has recommended that American copper producers be given relief from imports, failed today to reach a consensus on how that relief should be accomplished. On June 14, the commission recommended to President Reagan that copper imports to the United States be restricted because the American industry was being harmed.

headline: PROXMIRE CITES CHARGES ON GENERAL DYNAMICS
abstract: A former top official of the General Dynamics Corporation who is now a fugitive in Greece has told Senate investigators that he has evidence that top officials of his former company defrauded the Navy and then covered up the fraud, according to Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin.   The information, which Mr. Proxmire described in an advance text of a speech he said he would make Monday, involves submarine contracts during the 1970's between General Dynamics, the nation's largest defense contractor, and the Navy. Although General Dynamics won the contracts with the lowest bid, it subsequently filed claims to cover hundreds of millions of dollars in cost overuns.

headline: AQUINO'S WIDOW MAKES FIRST OF 17 ENDORSEMENTS IN ELECTION
abstract: The widow of the slain opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. today endorsed the first of 17 opposition candidates she plans to support in the parliamentary election next month.    The election May 14 will choose 183 candidates nationwide to serve in a parliament that will share law-making powers with President Ferdinand E. Marcos, whose term expires in 1987. Mr. Marcos is to appoint 17 members to make a parliament of 200.   Corazon Aquino, whose husband was slain last Aug. 21, proclaimed former Representative Neptali Gonzales as the opposition candidate for the suburban districts of Mandaluyong and San Juan.

headline: DHOWS IN GULF SLIP BY IRAQIS IN IRAN TRADE
abstract: While Iranian and Iraqi jets have concentrated their fire on big oil tankers in the Persian Gulf, creaking wooden vessels have been plying the waters of the gulf daily, delivering Texas rice, American tires and Japanese appliances to Iran.   The little dhows, many equipped with small engines as well as sails, provide Iran with needed foreign goods and this Arab emirate with a major source of revenue.   Dubai customs officials say that last year the legal dhow trade with Iran amounted to about $225 million, most of it in products imported to Dubai and then re-exported to the economically depressed Iranians. The real figure is probably much higher, shipping and trading sources say, because of smuggling trade, some believed to involve heroin from Pakistan.

headline: RUSSIANS, AT LAST MINUTE, CANCEL A VISIT TO CHINA
abstract: The Soviet Union today indefinitely postponed a visit to China by a First Deputy Prime Minister the day before he was expected to arrive, the Chinese Government announced.   The First Deputy Prime Minister, Ivan V. Arkhipov, would have been the highest-ranking Soviet official to visit China in 15 years, and the last-minute cancellation took Chinese officials and foreign diplomats by surprise.   The official explanation from Moscow, which Chinese officials said was conveyed this morning, was that the Soviet side was not fully prepared for the visit. Mr. Arkhipov was expected to discuss increasing trade and economic cooperation between the Soviet Union and China.   The Chinese Government officially accepted the explanation. ''Since they say they need more time to prepare, let them have more time to prepare,'' a Chinese official said.

headline: INSURERS OFFER HYBRID POLICY
abstract: A little-known type of life insurance called excess-interest whole life has been drawing increasing attention within the insurance industry since its creation about four years ago. And now, with more than 30 companies selling this policy, the public is becoming more aware of its existence as an insurance alternative.     ''It seems to be growing now,'' said Daniel F. Case, an actuary for the American Council of Life Insurance, the trade association for the nation's life insurers, about this interest-sensitive product. ''In my mind, it's a cross between a universal life policy and an adjustable-premium policy.''

headline: UTILITY WANTS TO FINISH MARBLE HILL
abstract: The Wabash Valley Power Association said today that it wanted to complete the Marble Hill power plant, either as a nuclear-fueled plant from the original designs or as a coal-fired plant, but would need a hefty rate increase to do so.    Construction of the Marble Hill plant, at Madison, Ind., was halted in January by the Public Service Company of Indiana, which owns an 83 percent stake in the plant. Wabash Valley holds the rest.

headline: A POCKET MONITOR FOR STOCK QUOTES
abstract: It resembles a pocket calculator with an antenna attached, and it monitors the prices of more than 7,000 stocks and commodities as they are traded. The new Quotrek, featuring a programmable memory and weighing less than a pound, is the first instant financial quotation monitor that is portable.    The cordless device, developed by Dataspeed Inc. of Burlingame, Calif., was introduced in New York last Monday after four months of test- marketing. It works on rechargeable batteries and picks up its data from local FM radio side-channels - parts of the frequency band not used for conventional radio programs.

headline: Biblical Review
abstract: Has New Idea      hardly seems a likely place to   spawn a new idea in publishing.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Cadillac Dealers Association of Southern California to Sawden & Bess.

headline: CREUSOT FACES STIFF CUTBACKS
abstract: By refusing a plea for emergency aid, the French Government has decided to let Creusot-Loire, the big steel and heavy engineering group, slip into bankruptcy as a way of forcing the privately owned company to restructure its loss-making activities. The decision, at a time when unemployment is rising rapidly, is expected to cost thousands of jobs.    Analysts said the Government's move last week would increase the pressure on the company to get rid of its deficit-ridden United States subsidary, the Phoenix Steel Corporation, which has already filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection under American law. Last year, Creusot-Loire made provisions totaling $25 million in its accounts to cover losses by Phoenix Steel, which is based in Claymont, Del.

headline: TEXT OF SOVIET STATEMENT ON OLYMPIC GAMES
abstract: Following is the text of a statement by the Soviet National Olympic Committee today saying it would not send a team to the Olympic Games in Los Angeles, as distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:    The National Olympic Committee of the U.S.S.R. made an all-round analysis of the situation around the games of the XXIII Olympiad in Los Angeles and studied the question of participation of the Soviet sports delegation in them.   As is known, in its statement of April 10, 1984, the National Olympic Committee of the U.S.S.R. voiced serious concern over the rude violations by the organizers of the Games of the rules of the Olympic Charter and the anti-Soviet campaign launched by reactionary circles in the United States with the connivance of the official authorities, and asked the International Olympic Committee (I.O.C.) to study the obtaining situation.   At its meeting on April 24 this year the I.O.C. found the stand of the U.S.S.R. National Olympic Committee to be just and substantiated.

headline: Washington Watch; Emergency Oil Planning
abstract: WASHINGTON  T HE Reagan Administration has become more   ''interventionist'' in planning to deal with an   emergency threat to the nation's oil supplies, such as a war in the Middle East. The shift, which dates from Iraq's receipt of new jet planes and missiles last summer, reflects the improving status of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, the emergency storehouse of oil located in caverns in Texas and Louisiana.    For several years, officials have debated the appropriate moment in an emergency to begin tapping the reserve - whether, for example, to regard it as a last resort or whether to use it promptly and with immediate price effect. The reserve now contains 390 million barrels, or about four months of crude imports at current rates of consumption.

headline: Cocaine Cache in Colombia
abstract: Three tons of cocaine have been found near the place where troops discovered a large laboratory producing the illegal drug, officials said. The cocaine, which was found Thursday hidden in a tunnel, escaped the investigators' initial search last week, officials said Friday.

headline: Helene Curtis May Narrow Loss
abstract: Helene Curtis Industries' president, Ronald Gidwitz, said at the annual meeting that the company may report a narrower loss for the fiscal first quarter, ended May 31.

headline: A FIRST IN PEKING: DINNER AT A KEY LEADER'S HOME
abstract: Hu Yaobang, a diminutive man, sat on the edge of his dinner chair running over a list of some Americans he has met. Most of them, as it turned out, have been American Presidents.   Mr. Hu, at age 68, is the General Secretary of the Communist Party of China, and last Thursday evening he was adding four new names to his short list of Americans and entertaining them in a new fashion of informality in the most exclusive quarter of Peking - the living-and-working compound of China's leaders, Zhong Nan Hai, which adjoins the Forbidden City.   It was a dinner not without deliberate symbolism. The style was what the party leader called ''informal American.'' His message was one of cheery optimism in a troubled world. He urged Americans to recall their country's history and take heart from it. Any nation, he said, which could move from a ''barren and desolate place'' in 200 years to become the world's No. 1 power, need not look to the future with pessimism.

headline: Unocal Oil Find
abstract: The Unocal Corporation said its Union Oil subsidiary had made a ''significant'' oil and gas discovery in the Santa Barbara Channel off Ventura, Calif.

headline: Business Digest; THURSDAY, MAY 24, 1984
abstract: Companies  Beatrice raised its bid for Esmark to $2.9 billion, or $60 a share, after Kohlberg, Kravis withdrew its own offer of $2.4 billion, food industry sources said. Esmark's chairman is understood to have accepted the offer and granted Beatrice an option to buy its food operations. The two boards are to vote on the deal today. (Page D1.)  Continental Illinois Bank said its situation had ''stabilized'' since a multibillion-dollar rescue package was assembled last week. Although the run on the bank had about ended, the bank added, it was still drawing on its credit line. And it said it was less interested in being taken over than officials had indicated. (D1.)

headline: MARRIOTT MAY JOIN IN DISNEY BID
abstract: The big Marriott hotel organization is considering joining an investor group headed by Saul P. Steinberg, the New York financier, to make a nearly $900 million bid for a 49 percent interest in Walt Disney Productions, Wall Street sources disclosed yesterday.     In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday, Mr. Steinberg said that he might seek control of Disney because recent Disney actions ruled out his being ''merely a passive investor'' in the big entertainment company.    The Wall Street sources said that a formal announcement of the Steinberg group's plans is expected to come after the long holiday weekend. Stockholders would be offered between $70 and $73 a share, they said.

headline: TRADE HELPS U.S. JOBS, STUDY FINDS
abstract: Despite deep import penetration of the steel, automobile and other industries in the 1970's, foreign trade produced an increase over all in manufacturing jobs in the United States, according to a new Brookings Institution study entitled ''Can America Compete?''    Robert Z. Lawrence, the economist who wrote the 156-page report, said that foreign trade between 1973 and 1980 created an additional 280,000 jobs in manufacturing.

headline: CHASE PLANS FOR INTERSTATE DEPOSIT-TAKING
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Corporation plans to ask Federal regulators soon to allow it to accept deposits in bank offices in eight states, according to company and Government officials.    The request, if approved, would mark another step toward dismantling barriers to interstate banking that date back a half-century. Other banking companies have filed similar applications recently or said they would.

headline: ADVERTISING;
abstract: 3 Agencies Receive Additional Business      Doyle Dane Bernbach; Chiat/Day, and Ogilvy & Mather have all got additional business from existing clients, but Silverman Mower Advertising of Syracuse and New York is splitting with a client after a seven- year relationship.    DDB, an International Business Machines Corporation agency since 1979, has been additionally assigned its I.B.M. Credit Corporation, which had no previous agency.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: MONEY FUND PAYOUTS: TAX POLICIES CONFLICT
abstract: Across the country, investors in money market mutual funds face conflicting patterns of state taxation on interest paid by the funds, and a decision this week by New York State has further complicated the question.     The issue is whether interest payments by money market funds, which are technically dividend payments, are exempt from state tax.   Interest from Treasury securities is exempt if the securities are held directly by an individual, and some mutual funds would like to extend that exemption to investors in their funds. Treasury securities held by money market mutual funds on April 4 totaled about $24 billion, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Reports in Holliston, Mass.

headline: Morgan Forms A Venture Unit
abstract: Fred A. Middleton has been named president of Morgan Stanley Ventures Inc., a newly formed venture-capital subsidiary of Morgan Stanley Inc. Mr. Middleton, 34 years old, had been vice president, finance and corporate development, of Genentech Inc., a biotechnology concern based in South San Francisco.

headline: Technology; A Coal-Water Fuel Is Tested
abstract: IT looks like black latex paint and can be handled    or burned like oil. It is, however, a mixture of   coal particles, water and additives to maintain the suspension. And a growing number of researchers and executives are viewing coal-water fuels as a way to replace billions of barrels of imported oil while providing major new sales for the ailing United States coal industry.    ''The technology holds tremendous promise,'' says Gary Voelker, director of the alternate fossil fuels program at the Energy Department, which manages a variety of research programs on the mixtures.

headline: U.S. Industries Backs Hanson Bid
abstract: U.S. Industries said its directors had recommended that holders tender their shares to a unit of Hanson Trust P.L.C. of London. Hanson is offering $23 a share, or a total of $511 million, for the maker of industrial products, apparel, furniture and furnishings and lighting products.

headline: LTV-Republic
abstract: The LTV Corporation said it had completed its $770 million acquisition of the Republic Steel Corporation, a merger that creates the nation's second-largest steelmaker. Final closing and merger documents were filed with the secretaries of state in New Jersey and Delaware, making the merger official, said an LTV spokesman, Julie Price. The new company, LTV Steel, will be based in Cleveland and employ 46,000.

headline: PHIBRO SPLIT-UP CONSIDERED
abstract: Phibro-Salomon Inc., one of the nation's most prominent investment banking and commodity trading organizations, said yesterday - less than three years after the merger that formed it - that it was considering breaking up the company.     In a brief statement about this surprising development, Phibro-Salomon said it was ''studying the possibility'' of selling all of its Philipp Brothers commodity trading operations, except oil, to a group of executives and employees.    Phibro-Salomon emphasized that it had not yet decided whether to go ahead with the idea. It has retained Lazard Fr eres, the Wall Street investment banking firm, to study the plan.

headline: Citicorp Offering
abstract: A $250 million offering of Citicorp extendable notes with a final maturity in 1999 is offered at a price of 100 with an initial coupon of 13.60 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. After two years investors have the option of redeeming their notes at par. At that time, Citicorp will announce a new interest rate and a new maturity of from one to five years.

headline: Top Officers At Ladenburg
abstract: Ronald B. Koenig, 50 years old, has been named chairman of Ladenburg, Thalman & Company, the 150-year-old investment banking house.

headline: May 1-10 Auto Sales Jumped 25.5%
abstract: New-car sales in the first 10 days of May jumped 25.5 percent from the period a year earlier, the nation's major manufacturers reported today.   The increase was on a daily rate basis, with nine selling days in the period this year and eight a year ago.    The companies, G.M., Ford, Chrysler, A.M.C., Honda and VW, sold 238,240 automobiles in the May 1-10 period, or 26,471 a day. That was the highest daily rate for the period since 1979. Last year the six car makers delivered 168,785 units, or 21,098 a day.

headline: CONDOMINIUMS GOING UP ON OLD RHINEBECK ESTATE
abstract: In 1968, Victor Weingarten and Roy R. Neuberger began a program of land investment. Thinking for the long term, they bought 14 parcels, a total of 6,000 acres, in Westchester, Putnam and Dutchess Counties, all of it in what they believed would be the path of growth.    They have since resold about half the total. But the largest holding - 1,658 acres in the town and village of Rhinebeck in Dutchess County - they kept to develop themselves. The property is well known in the region as the ''hinterland'' tract of the old Astor estate, separated by River Road from land the Astors owned along the Hudson River. The gradual breakup of the estate began after W. Vincent Astor's death in 1959. The Weingarten-Neuberger partnership acquired the hinterland tract from another development group.

headline: DESIGNERS TURN TO BOUTIQUES
abstract: Some of the best-known fashion designers, including Georgio Armani, Ralph Lauren, Norma Kamali and Hanae Mori, increasingly are emphasizing their own boutiques. They see this form of retailing as the best way to showcase their talents and bypass the vagaries of department store distribution and merchandising. Moreover, profits at boutiques can be more than twice as high as those from supplying goods to other retailers.     ''This is truly the way to get out there in your own personal way,'' said Betsey Johnson, a designer of women's clothing. Her company, which grosses about $7 million annually, opened its third boutique three weeks ago about a half-block from Bloomingdale's, one of the more than 500 stores that carry her fashions.

headline: INVESTING FOR CHANGING STEPS OF LIFE
abstract: INVESTING money so that it grows steadily and significantly is not a mysterious art known only to the wizened few with doctorates in finance. Even middle-income people can accumulate respectable wealth if they invest part of every paycheck. ''Time and money are analogous,'' said Donald J. Ercole, a tax partner at the Arthur Young accounting firm. ''We let time slip away, and we also let money slip away.''    Although investing strategies change with the various stages of life, there are some basic guidelines that everyone should heed:     - Set aside an hour or so every month to review your investing program. ''I realize I could have made a lot more money,'' said a book editor who is over 60 and was recently told she could not afford to retire. ''I inherited a little bit of money when my parents died, but I just didn't manage it.''

headline: 3 Telephone Companies On Target for Quarter
abstract: The Nynex Corporation, the Pacific Telesis Group and the Bell Atlantic Corporation, three of the eight telephone companies spun off from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company last January, reported their first quarterly earnings yesterday.     Charles Schelke, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company said that, generally speaking, the newly created telephone companies that have reported so far showed surprisingly strong earnings. The Southwestern Bell Corporation and American Information Technologies Inc. reported results last week.

headline: Federated Stores
abstract: Shareholders of Federated Department Stores Inc., the nation's largest department store operator, approved several antitakeover moves at the annual meeting in Cincinnati. Among them was an increase in the number of authorized common shares to 100 million, from 70 million, and staggered terms for board members.

headline: BRITISH M.P.'S ASSAIL MRS. THATCHER OVER GRENADA
abstract: A bipartisan committee of the House of Commons issued a report today that criticized the performance of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government during the Grenada crisis. It also said that the United States deliberately kept Britain in the dark about Washington's invasion plans.    In the report written after a fact-finding trip to the Caribbean by Members of Parliament, the committee suggested that British officials were too slow to respond to the danger signals in the area and too insensitive to the attitudes of Commonwealth countries there, such as the desire of Barbados that Britain take part in any intervention.

headline: NEW DELHI AND TOKYO PUSH TIES
abstract: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan today began the first visit to India by a Japanese head of government in 23 years. The trip indicates the nations' new interest in a relationship that has been somewhat distant.    Mr. Nakasone, who met with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, described his visit as a turning point in Indo-Japanese relations. He offered to help India expand its abilities in science and technology.

headline: ECONOMISTS WORRIED BY INFLATION
abstract: WINSTON WILLIAMS    CHICAGO, April 8 - A year ago, the problem of rising prices had ceased to worry economists. The severe recession and persistent glut of energy supplies had halted the advance of inflation, a relief that continued even after the recovery began. Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan boasted that a stake had been ''driven into the heart of inflation.''   Now, as the economy moves into a surprisingly strong boom, rising prices are once again a major concern. The numbers of the past few months show that inflation has been reborn, economists say. And many predict a worsening of the trend as the economy continues to grow.

headline: Several Bids For Orange-Co
abstract: S. Robert Davis, chairman of Orange-Co Inc., said the company had been approached by several large corporations regarding its possible acquisition. Mr. Davis, stating that the discussions have been ''preliminary,'' declined to identify the potential suitors.

headline: RATES RISE DESPITE FED ACTION
abstract: Interest rates rose yesterday, despite a generous provision of credit to the banking system resulting from loans to the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.     The Continental Illinois crisis and the large loans made to the bank by the Fed have added to confusion in the credit markets, where interest rates have surgd in recent weeks. But the Chicago bank's problems have alleviated fears that the Federal Reserve might soon tighten monetary policy. In the past, the central bank has often made credit more plentiful ''during periods of major financial dislocations or during periods of disorderly market conditions,'' according to analysts at Money Market Services Inc., an economic analysis firm.

headline: Cameroon Says Rebels Are Being 'Mopped Up'
abstract: The Government of President Paul Biya of Cameroon said today that remnants of a palace guard revolt were being ''mopped up'' and urged citizens to remain vigilant against mutineers.

headline: BEIRUT PLAN ALTERS POLITICAL STRUCTURE
abstract: Prime Minister Rashid Karami submitted to Parliament today his month-old Government's program for modifying Lebanon's political structure and ending the civil war.    Mr. Karami asked special powers for his Government of national unity to rule by decree for the next nine months.   ''This is an exceptional Government for an exceptional situation,'' Mr. Karami said of his Cabinet, which consists both of feuding warlords and of men who have spent many years in political office.   ''The structure of the new Government reflects the Lebanese determination to silence the guns and begin a dialogue for peace,'' the Prime Minister said.

headline: No Headline
abstract: The Israeli Army said today that four Arab guerrillas had been captured in the southern part of the Golan Heights after having broken through the fence on the Syrian border.   It was the first reported infiltration from Syria in many years, and it was considered significant in view of Syria's past restrictions on the use of its territory by guerrillas for assaults against Israel.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Chief Fund-Raisers Winding Up Efforts
abstract: As the race for today's New York State Democratic primary election reached a climax yesterday, the volunteer fund-raisers in the state for the three candidates were winding up their campaign efforts as well.    Each of the three men running for the Presidential nomination - former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, Senator Gary Hart and the Rev. Jesse Jackson - has undertaken a major fund-raising effort in New York.   Heading the Mondale fund raising in New York is Robert E. Rubin, 45 years old, a general partner and a member of the policy-making management committee of Goldman, Sachs & Company. Mr. Rubin, whose campaign title is finance chairman for New York, and his associates raised $1.9 million for Mr. Mondale last year, which he said represented more than 20 percent of the total amount contributed throughout the country.   ''I've spent most of my time trying to recruit people who, in turn, would give fund-raising events,'' he said yesterday. His approach, he added, was ''based on the appeal of the guy plus his prospects.'' Mr. Rubin, a lawyer, joined Goldman, Sachs in 1966, became a partner in 1971 and was elected to the 11- member management committee 10 years later. He has been responsible for the firm's arbitrage activities since 1975.

headline: U.S. CALLS SOVIET PULLOUT 'BLATANT POLITICAL ACTION'
abstract: The Reagan Administration said today that the Soviet decision not to take part in this summer's Olympic Games in Los Angeles was ''a blatant political action for which there was no real justification.''   Although the Soviet authorities had been hinting for more than a month that they might keep their team away from Los Angeles, most Government experts on the Soviet Union were surprised by today's announcement by the Soviet press agency Tass.   White House and State Department officials, as well as several members of Congress, heatedly denied charges the Russians made in justifying their decision.   The Soviet National Olympic Committee, in announcing that the American authorities had made it ''impossible'' for it to participate in the Games, accused the United States of inadequate security arrangements and of encouraging ''extremist organizations'' to create ''unbearable conditions'' for the Soviet athletes.

headline: IT'S CAVEAT EMPTOR WITH I.R.A. ADS
abstract: ADS promoting Individual Retirement Accounts are everywhere these days, but pity   the poor consumer trying to figure out who pays the highest rate. There is little basis for comparison, and the return you think you are getting may not be the one you actually receive.   It is not that there is a dearth of rate information, as financial institutions battle each other for a share of the multibillion-dollar I.R.A. market. The problem, with the deadline for making 1983 I.R.A. contributions drawing near, is the form in which that information is presented.

headline: PATENTS ; DETECTORS FOR USE ON SHUTTLE
abstract: WASHINGTON   Several infrared imaging detectors planned for use on the space shuttle within the next three years were patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Patent 4,443,701 was obtained by Gary C. Bailey, a staff member at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, which is maintained for NASA in Pasadena, Calif., by the California Institute of Technology.

headline: UNION PLANTERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TRANSCRIPT OF NEWS CONFERENCE BY PRESIDENT ON MONEY FOR THE MX
abstract: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference today, as recorded by The New York Times:      OPENING STATEMENT    Not a single rhinestone.   Our defense policy is based on a simple premise - I stated it the other night - that we do not start wars. We maintain our strength to deter aggression and preserve peace.   Since the dawn of the nuclear age, we've sought to reduce the risk of war by maintaining a strong deterrent and by seeking genuine arms controls.   And after close bipartisan coordination with the Congress, the Scowcroft Commission on Strategic Forces last year reaffirmed that we must continue the Peacekeeper program as part of an overall strategic modernization program that includes ambitious arms control negotiations.

headline: 3 Sikh Activists Killed In Factional Fighting
abstract: At least three Sikh activists were killed today in fighting between moderate and extremist factions within an anti-Government Sikh movement in Punjab state.   State officials reported the arrest of 160 members of the banned All India Sikh Students Federation, a militant organization.

headline: TALKS END ON SPLIT OF PHIBRO
abstract: Phibro-Salomon Inc., the big New York commodity trading and investment banking house, said yesterday that it was no longer considering splitting up the company.     Only 10 days ago, Phibro said that it was studying whether to sell its commodity trading operations, except oil, to a group of executives and employees. Yesterday, in a one-sentence statement, Phibro said only that the study had been ''terminated.''    Top executives would not elaborate, but insiders said that while no price had ever been proposed officially, the two main factions within the company could not agree on one.    One insider, who asked not to be identified, said that he thought the commodity trading operations being sought were worth at least $750 million.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Allegheny International Inc., the Pittsburgh-based manufacturer of consumer and industrial products, has named F. George Scott senior vice president, human resources.     *  Bristol-Myers Co.  has named Bruce R. Ross general manager of its new U.S. oncology division, to be based in Syracuse, which will consolidate anti- cancer pharmaceutical sales and marketing groups from the Mead Johnson and Bristol Laboratories divisions.

headline: BETTER DAYS FOR OIL AND GAS SHELTERS
abstract: HOSTILITIES in the Persian Gulf and the looming threat that the conflict poses to world oil prices may lead some investors to take a new look at oil and gas tax shelters, which have been out of favor since 1981.     That year, nearly $2 billion poured into drilling partnerships, but in the last couple of years, sagging oil prices, generally disappointing returns of drilling partnerships and the well-publicized financial problems of a few oil and gas tax shelter program sponsors have slaked investors' oil fever. Interest has declined so sharply that in the first three months of this year, sales of publicly registered drilling partnerships were down 43 percent from a year earlier, to a paltry $65 million, according to Robert A. Stanger & Company, a tax shelter research firm based in Shrewsbury, N.J.    But a number of investment advisers believe oil and gas drilling ventures hold more favorable opportunities than the sales figures suggest, mainly because the economics of the business has sharply improved.    ''For a lot of reasons, it's the best of times,'' said Martin Helpern, a tax partner at Laventhol & Horwath, an accounting firm.

headline: Rath Ouster Countered
abstract: Directors of the Rath Packing Company voted to create a new position to keep Lyle Taylor as president after stockholders had removed him from the board.

headline: ;  A New Consultant
abstract: Add to the ever-growing roster of consultants the name of Samuel Ferber, who will be doing his thing for the magazine or agency business from 10A, 200 West 58th Street. Mr. Ferber, now 64, was publisher of Esquire from 1974 to 1976 - the job that capped almost 25 years with the magazine. From there he went to Altman, Stoller & Weiss, where he was executive vice president. When that agency was acquired by Nadler & Larimer, a Mickleberry Company, he was named vice president there.

headline: PIDGIN IS THE FASTEST GROWING OF CAMEROON'S 285 LANGUAGES
abstract: More than a thousand languages are spoken between Cairo and the Cape of Good Hope. Some 285 of them are spoken in Cameroon, including French and English, the ''official'' languages here.    But the fastest growing language in this West African nation - and one already widely spoken in many of its cities and provinces - is not any of these but is rather a singsong tongue known as Cameroonian pidgin.   ''I consider myself well-educated,'' said Emmanuel Kome Epule, deputy director of Cameroon's Ministry of Information. ''But among my friends I speak pidgin. It's the language you use when you socialize, when you tell jokes, when you want to enjoy yourself. It's the language of fun.''

headline: U.S. AIDES SAY U-2'S HAVE FLOWN OVER NICARAGUA
abstract: Government officials say United States Air Force U-2 reconnaissance planes have flown over Nicaragua and photographed military installations and at least one port from high altitudes.   These officials said that such U-2 missions have not been flown over Nicaragua for at least several weeks and that they are infrequent.   The officials, speaking Friday, refused to say where the U-2 flights originated.

headline: Norcen Purchase
abstract: Norcen Energy Ltd. said it had agreements that allow it to increase its stake in the Hanna Mining Company to 28 percent, from 20 percent.

headline: Data Bank; May 13, 1984
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: FED PROPOSAL CRITICIZED
abstract: A proposal by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to impose stricter capital requirements on government securities dealers was criticized by some firms yesterday in testimony to a House subcommittee.   The dealers agreed, however, that the Fed should increase its surveillance of the market.   Edward J. Geng, senior vice president at the New York Fed, said in written testimony to the House Subcommittee on Domestic Monetary Affairs that ''a wide range of opinion'' among government securities dealers had delayed the implementation of the capital standards, which were proposed several months ago.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;
abstract: A Founder Rejoins Franklin Computer      Joel Shusterman, a founder and former president of the Franklin Computer Corporation, has rejoined the company as its executive vice president and acting president, the Pennsauken, N.J., company announced yesterday. He will temporarily perform the duties of R. Barry Borden, another founder and Franklin's chairman and chief executive, who has resigned, the company said.    It is Franklin's second top management change in a month. On April 6, Avram C. Miller resigned as president, saying the company was unable to become the ''large, broadly based'' microcomputer concern he wished to develop. Mr. Borden assumed Mr. Miller's duties.

headline: VAGUE FRUSTRATIONS OF A RETAILING CAREER
abstract: THOMAS M. Macioce, head of    Allied Stores and dean among   retailing industry leaders, wears a rueful smile and gestures occasionally with his favorite Jamaican cigar as he looks back on the frustrations of a rewarding but sometimes difficult career.   ''It's incomprehensible to me that we don't have the recognition of the analysts, the industry and Wall Street for what we have accomplished,'' said the president and chief executive of the big chain - which includes Jordan Marsh of Boston and Miami, Bonwit Teller, Julius Garfinckel of Washington and Maas Brothers of Tampa, Fla.   ''Perhaps it's because we don't have the visibility of having a big New York store, or that we don't give parties as some of the other retailers do or have their glamour,'' he said. ''But we think that our results would speak louder than any of those things.''    Mr. Macioce, who at 65 has held the post of C.E.O. longer than anyone else among the major department store chains and who has built Allied into an industry giant ranking among the nation's top seven or eight retail chains, is nearing the end of his long assignment. But he gives the impression that he still hopes that by the time he relinquishes that post in two and a half years, he may gain the recognition that has eluded him.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., an insurance brokerage firm, has elected to its board Kenneth Black Jr., dean of the college of business administration at Georgia State University.     *  Burlington Northern Inc., Seattle, has appointed Charles J. Berling senior vice president-development for its Glacier Park Company subsidiary.

headline: Debt Issues ;  Debt Ratings
abstract: Security Pacific International Leasing (Europe) Inc. , a wholly owned subsidiary of Security Pacific Corp., a Los Angeles-based financial services company, offered and sold through Commerzbank A.G., 60 million West German marks of its 7 5/8 percent notes due 1988.   Elizabethtown Water Co. , Elizabeth, N.J., had the rating of its debenture and secured pollution control revenue bonds raised by Moody's Investors Service to A-One from A-Three. Some $57 million of long- term debt is affected by the rating change.

headline: Sweden's G.N.P. Rises
abstract: Sweden's gross national product rose 5 percent in the first quarter from the period a year ago, and was up a seasonally adjusted 2 percent from the preceding quarter, Statistics Sweden said today. The agency said an 11 percent rise in exports from a year earlier was the primary cause of the first quarter gain, but added that domestic demand also picked up by 1.5 percent.

headline: China Plans to Restore Ranks in the Military
abstract: China disclosed a new military service law today that will reduce the size of its army and restore ranks, which were abolished during the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS ; TREASURY BILL RATES PLUNGE
abstract: Treasury bill rates fell sharply yesterday, as investors scrambled to put funds in the safest securities while waiting for signs that Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust will be able to finance itself without reliance on the Federal Reserve.     By late in the day, the rate for three-month bills had fallen to a bid rate of 9.75 percent, down from 10.10 percent, while the six-month issue was at 10.21 percent, down from 10.42 percent. Earlier in the day, the three- month rate was as low as 9.6 percent.    For shorter-dated Treasury bills, rates were even lower, as investors avidly sought the safe haven provided by Treasury bills, which are backed by the full faith and credit of the United States, and which are the most readily salable of all securities.

headline: Dunlop Loss Widens
abstract: Dunlop Ltd., the British tire manufacturer, reported a loss of $236 million for 1983, reflecting the troubles in its European tire operations.

headline: ITT Declines by 42.3%; Goodyear and 3M Gain
abstract: The ITT Corporation, citing severe insurance underwriting losses and unfavorable foreign-currency exchange comparisons, reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter of 1984 fell 42.3 percent although revenues increased 18.8 percent.   ITT said that net income in the latest three months fell to $79 million, or 52 cents a share, from $137 million, or 92 cents a share, as restated for accounting changes, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues rose to $5.7 billion in the latest three months, from a restated $4.8 billion in the first quarter of 1983.

headline: Stocks Gain; Dow Up 4.40, to 1,138.30
abstract: Stock prices rose moderately in more-active trading yesterday, as declining interest rates and bargain- hunting helped buoy the list.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which has tumbled almost 150 points since Jan. 6 because of rising interest rates, rose 4.40 points, to 1,138.30.    In the overall market, gainers on the New York Stock Exchange outscored losers, 847 to 710. Turnover on the Big Board expanded to 79 million shares, from 71.6 million Monday.

headline: THE VALUE OF FILM LIBRARIES
abstract: How much is Snow White worth?     Such ungenteel speculation arose earlier this month amid rumors that Walt Disney Productions might be a takeover target. The rumors got a boost last week with the announcement that the Reliance Group has bought 6.3 percent of Disney.    When any company is a possible takeover target, its assets are naturally a matter of keen interest. In the case of the movie studios, that means film libraries. Thus, when Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher, last year began his unsuccessful attempt to acquire Warner Communications, some analysts suggested that one of Warner's selling points was its film library.

headline: Striking Coal Miners March in Edinburgh
abstract: Tens of thousands of striking coal miners and their families marched through Edinburgh today, bringing the center of the Scottish capital to a standstill.   A 13-week-old coal dispute has left three-quarters of Britain's 175 mines idle as coal miners in Scotland and northern England protest plans by the state-run National Coal Board to close 20 to 25 mines by March 31, 1985.

headline: Airbus Picked By Air India
abstract: The European Airbus consortium bested the Boeing Company for an Air India order of six airliners valued at $530 million, including spare parts and training.

headline: PATENTS;
abstract: Preparation Intended To Save Lives of Calves    A preparation intended to save the lives of calves has been patented for Molecular Genetics of Minnetonka, Minn.

headline: 2 Top Economic Aides Are Dismissed in Chile
abstract: President Augusto Pinochet dismissed his two top economic ministers today in a Cabinet shake-up that was seen as a response to nationwide protests against his military regime.

headline: Iraq Says It Destroyed 3 More Ships in Gulf
abstract: Iraq said its navy destroyed three more ships in the Persian Gulf today between Iran's Kharg Island oil terminal and the Iranian port of Bandar Khomeini.   A military spokesman in the Iraqi capital said all three ''enemy naval targets'' were afire in an area Baghdad has declared closed to shipping because of its war with Iran.

headline: STEADY PRICE DROP BREEDS PESSIMISM
abstract: Pessimism reigns in the bond markets as each week of falling bond prices discourages potential investors whose absence helps depress prices still further.     With only a few brief interruptions, prices of long-term Treasury bonds have fallen steadily since mid-January, raising the yield on the bellwether 12 percent issue due in 2013 to 12.76 percent from 11.60 percent. The rising trend has shattered forecasts that called for rates to be declining about now.    With few exceptions, predictions that bond yields would decline this spring to the 10 3/8 percent level of a year ago have been discarded. Today an optimist in the bond market is someone who expects to see Treasury bond prices rise enough in the next few months to reduce yields back to the 12 percent level.

headline: TAKEOVERS AND INSIDER TRADES
abstract: A PATTERN of what seems to be insider trading is emerging in the securities markets. Stocks of companies have been climbing, often on a sharp increase in volume, just before the announcement of some takeover or management buyout.     This comes at a time when takeover mania has become what some professionals call ''the only game in town.'' Most equity prices have been sinking ever since a spectacular bull market ended - temporarily, at least - a year ago.

headline: ISRAELI LATIN ROLE IS DENIED BY U.S.
abstract: The State Department says the United States has no intention of providing money to third countries such as Israel for covert military activities in Central America on behalf of American interests.   But it is not clear whether Israeli and American officials are considering other forms of cooperation in Central America.   The denial, issued Friday, came after Haaretz, an Israeli newspaper, reported that Israel and the United States would discuss plans to finance Israeli aid to Africa and Central America, including military aid to El Salvador. Haaretz said in a dispatch from Washington that American officials had confirmed Israel would increase its economic and military aid to El Salvador.

headline: ISRAEL EXPECTING A CLOSE ELECTION
abstract: Israel's election campaign is about to get under way amid expectations that the two main parties will run a close race in their fight for voters in the center of the political spectrum.    Although public-opinion polls show the opposition Labor Party led by Shimon Peres with a significant lead now, the gap has been shrinking. Many pollsters, politicians and Israeli journalists expect the governing Likud bloc of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to pull even with Labor before the July 23 election.   There are 120 seats in Israel's Parliament. One poll in March said voters would have given 55 seats to Labor and 37 to Likud, but by May this had shifted to 52 for Labor and 39 for Likud. In another survey, published in the newspaper Hadashot, Likud's share of the electorate went from 20.2 percent at the end of April to 27.7 percent at the end of May, with Labor's share staying at about 41 percent.

headline: Warsaw Pact Plans Meeting
abstract: Warsaw Pact Foreign Ministers will meet in Budapest late this month, the official press agency said Friday. The officials, from the Soviet Union, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Hungary, Poland and Rumania, last met in Sofia, Bulgaria, in October.

headline: Toyota-ASC Deal
abstract: Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. Inc. said it had agreed to jointly produce Toyota Celica GT-S convertible models with ASC Inc. of Southgate, Mich.

headline: SYRIAN ASSERTS 3 CAPTURED ISRAELIS CONFESSED TO SPYING
abstract: A senior Syrian official said today that three Israelis captured by Syrian troops in Lebanon on Tuesday had confessed that they had been on a ''spying mission.''   There was no independent confirmation of the Syrian's statement. Israeli officials have said repeatedly that the three captured men were diplomats working in the Israeli liaison office north of Beirut and accidentally strayed into Syrian-controlled northern Lebanon while on a May Day sightseeing trip.   The Syrian official confirmed Lebanese Army reports that the three Israelis engaged in a shootout with Syrian troops before they were finally taken into custody.

headline: MZilitary Contracts
abstract: The Hughes Aircraft Company received a $77.1 million contract from the Navy for sonar display equipment, the Defense Department said. In addition, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation received a $26.5 million Navy contract for channel finder systems, the department said.

headline: Market Place; Japanese Stock Volatility
abstract: THE volatility of Japanese stocks, which have    produced some of the biggest price gains in   recent years among securities markets worldwide, was demonstrated yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Substantial losses in Japanese issues of American depository receipts, representing ownership of shares held abroad, directly reflected the latest day's trading on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.    Matsushita Electric Industrial, Japan's largest manufacturer of consumer and electronic products, fell 5 5/8, to 72 1/2, on the Big Board. The company's brand-name products familiar to American households include Panasonic and Quasar. The Kyocera Corporation, a leading Japanese maker of ceramic products for the electronics industry, dropped 3 1/8, to 45 1/4. Between early 1982 and late 1983, this issue rose 250 percent.

headline: EXXON NET RISES 39.6% IN QUARTER
abstract: The Exxon Corporation, benefiting from improved conditions in the oil industry, yesterday announced a 39.6 percent increase in earnings in the first quarter of 1984 on a rise in revenues of 5.1 percent.    The Standard Oil Company of California reported a 21.9 percent increase in earnings and the Phillips Petroleum Company an advance of 49.6 percent.    ''If anything, Exxon was toward the higher end of our expectations and Socal was toward the lower end,'' said William L. Randol, vice president and senior petroleum analyst at the First Boston Corporation.

headline: 6 Bombs Go Off in Marseilles
abstract: Corsican separatists demanding political status for nationalist prisoners detonated six bombs early today at banks and public buildings, causing damage but no injuries, the police said. The bombs went off in succession at about 1 A.M. in this southern port city. The Corsican National Liberation Front took responsibility for the attacks.

headline: Sargent Acquired
abstract: Sargent Industries said it had reached a definitive agreement to be acquired by the Dover Corporation for $8.90 a share, or about $68 million.

headline: TEMPERS RISE AS SHOPS FALL IN DAMASCUS RESTORATION
abstract: For more than 30 years a family here owned three shops next to the walls of the majestic Umayyad Mosque in the heart of old Damascus.    Recently they became the owners of half a shop. Two and a half of their stores disappeared virtually overnight. The shops were razed by the Syrian Government as part of an ambitious restoration project now under way in the Syrian capital.

headline: Market Place; Cosmetics Issues Out Of Favor
abstract: MUCH of the glamour has rubbed off cosmetics stocks in recent years, and a current example of this phenomenon can be seen in Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. The stock closed yesterday at 32 5/8, down 1/2, on the New York Stock Exchange, after trading as low as 32 1/4. That marked the stock's lowest price since Aug. 11, 1982, two days before the start of the great bull market, when it traded at 30 7/8.    The stock later rebounded to a high of 47 1/4 in December 1982, but began to lose ground soon thereafter.   ''The most recent price decline in Chesebrough reflects not only the prospect of disappointing earnings for the first three months of this year, but also a pattern of volatility in quarterly profits,'' said Joseph H. Kozloff, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ''Actually, this is a highly diversified consumer-packaging company that derives 40 percent of its revenues from the personal care, or cosmetics, business.''

headline: E.E.C. and I.B.M. In Antitrust Talks
abstract: The commission of the European Economic Community said it is in the ''final stages'' of negotiations with the International Business Machines Corporation to end one of the longest antitrust inquiries in the Common Market's history. The commission said last month that it planned to charge I.B.M. in June with abusing its dominant market position in Europe.   I.B.M. has continued negotiating with the commission, contending its practices are not illegal or anticompetitive.

headline: Technology Company President
abstract: John E. Donalds has been named president and chief executive officer of Collaborative Research Inc., Orrie M. Friedman, chairman, announced yesterday.     Mr. Donalds, 59, comes to the Lexington, Massachusetts-based biotechnology company after spending all of his professional life - 34 years - with the Dow Chemical Company. He succeeds James A. Wimbush, who resigned as president and chief executive officer last March.

headline: Canberra Eases Quotas
abstract: The Australian Government announced increases today in most textile, clothing and footwear import quotas for 1985. John Button, Minister for Industry and Commerce, said the increases reflected expected market growth, improved production and sales of textile, clothing and footwear products this year.

headline: SALVADOR REBELS STILL SAID TO GET NICARAGUAN AID
abstract: Western European and Latin American diplomats here say the Nicaraguan Government is continuing to send military equipment to the Salvadoran insurgents and to operate training camps for them inside Nicaragua.    The United States has been making such charges since 1980. Nicaragua, while not explicitly denying all of the charges, say its support is ''moral and political.''   The diplomats, including some from countries that have criticized United States policies in Central America, said military support to the Salvadoran rebels had dropped over the last year, but remained substantial.

headline: Body of Club Med Man Is Found Off Corfu
abstract: The body of a French employee of Club Mediterranee who disappeared on a fishing trip last week was found today in the sea off this resort island, Greek and French authorities said.   The man's brother charged that he had been shot dead by border guards on the nearby Albanian coast.

headline: NORFOLK SOUTHERN TO GET PEPSICO UNIT
abstract: Pepsico Inc. announced yesterday that it had reached a preliminary agreement to sell its North American Van Lines Inc. subsidiary to the Norfolk Southern Corporation for $315 million.     Donald M. Kendall, Pepsico's chairman, said in a statement that the sale did not reflect any dissatisfaction with the performance or prospects of North American Van Lines, which is the nation's largest mover of household goods. Rather, he said, ''transportation is not a long-term strategic complement to our major businesses.''

headline: TALKING BUSINESS/WITH JOHN PAULUS OF MORGAN STANLEY ; HOW TO CALM CREDIT MARKETS
abstract: Inflation and interest rates tend to move in tandom; the higher the inflation, the larger the return demanded by investors. But recently, while inflation has remained relatively low, interest rates have skyrocketed, creating new costs for businesses, consumers and debt-burdened developing countries as well as depressing bond prices.     Indeed, before recovering somewhat in the last three days of trading, the Government's 30-year bond fell so far in price that it was yielding 14 percent, disturbingly close to its record 15.3 percent level in the fall of 1981.    John D. Paulus, who is 40 years old, has been the chief economist at the Wall Street firm of Morgan Stanley & Company since August 1982, just when interest rates began to decline from record levels. In an interview, Mr. Paulus discussed the unsettled credit markets and what might again soothe them.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: Foote, Cone Adding     Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, which already has direct marketing operations in Chicago, San Francisco and London, announced yesterday its intention to acquire Smith-Hemmings-Gosden of Los Angeles, the largest agency in that specialty on the West Coast. It had billings of $38 million last year. Plans call for current management of the agency to remain in place.

headline: SALVADOR TRIAL IN KILLING OF 4 IS DUE NEXT WEEK
abstract: A Salvadoran criminal court judge said today that the five former national guardsmen accused of murdering four American churchwomen would go on trial next week.    The judge, Bernardo Rauda Murcia, said in a telephone interview that the ''evidence looks good'' and that he would begin jury selection Thursday.   At the same time, a trial date will be chosen from one of three days, May 22, 23 or 25, he said. The trial will be postponed if too few jurors show up on the day of the trial, according to Judge Rauda and United States officials.

headline: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ANGOLA REBEL STAKES CLAIM
abstract: The dancers gyrate on the parade ground at this remote spot in southern Angola, singing, ''Savimbi is our guide.''    His aides, in public speeches, call him ''the most able strategist of our days.'' Around Jamba, his portrait adorns huts and buildings. The usual titles affixed to him are president and general.   He is Jonas Savimbi, leader of the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, a South African- backed insurgent movement fighting the Cuban-backed Marxist Government in Luanda, 850 miles away. Mr. Savimbi is currently trying to stake out a place for himself in negotiations affecting neighboring South-West Africa, also known as Namibia, and Angola itself.

headline: MEXICO AID SAID TO GET BACKING
abstract: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, gave his support today to a plea by the head of the International Monetary Fund that the world's leading banks lower the interest rates they charge on loans to Mexico and give that country more time to repay its debts, according to banking sources.   The recommendation came at a closed meeting of the heads of some of the world's largest banks, who are among those attending the annual International Monetary Conference here.   Mr. Volcker's position as head of the Federal Reserve system generally goes a long way toward assuring a positive response by bankers to suggestions he might make. In addition, Mexico is well regarded by bankers because it has substantially improved its financial condition,    Wriston Cites 'Linkage'    In fact, just before the closed meeting was held, Walter B. Wriston, chairman of Citicorp - who has generally opposed concessions to the third-world debtor nations, said at a news conference that ''I believe there is linkage between the spreads and actual performance.'' In other words, if a country performs well, it deserves lower interest rates.

headline: Brazil Seizes 11 Companies
abstract: The Government summarily liquidated, or took over, 11 companies associated with two large private savings and loan institutions today on the ground that they had far overextended their financial obligations.

headline: World Bank Aid Plan
abstract: The governing board of the World Bank approved plans today to raise $9 billion for aid to the poorest nations, as well as plans for an $8.4 billion capital increase. The action had been expected, and the bank's 21 executive directors recommended that its more than 140 member nations approve both increases.

headline: CONFEREES BREAK 3-DAY DEADLOCK
abstract: House and Senate tax conferees reached agreement on health care and public assistance spending cuts tonight, opening the way for approval of a $50 billion tax increase and a package of spending cuts totaling about $11.2 billion through 1987.    The Senate conferees, for their part of this key compromise, also dropped just under $5 billion of tax cuts, including the President's proposed expansion of tax-exempt Individual Retirement Accounts for nonworking spouses. The Senate conferees also killed the extension of several energy tax credits beyond 1985, including the residential credit for installing solar or other alternative energy systems.   However, the Senate conferees did not drop the President's proposal for so-called Enterprise Zones, which are intended to attract companies to economically depressed areas with tax breaks.

headline: HOUSE VOTES OF TRISTATE AREA
abstract: Following are the House roll-call votes today by Representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on a measure to give $61.75 million in emergency military aid to El Salvador, which was approved by 267 to 154, and on a measure to deny more money for Nicaraguan rebels, which was approved by 241 to 177. An ''xxx'' denotes not voting.       WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) - Following are the House roll-call votes today by Representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on a measure to give $61.75 million in emergency military aid to El Salvador, which was approved by 267 to 154, and on a measure to deny more money for Nicaraguan rebels, which was approved by 241 to 177. An ''xxx'' denotes not voting.    Aid to El Salvador

headline: Occidental Stock
abstract: The shares of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation jumped $2.125, to $35.625, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday on a volume of nearly 2.6 million shares. Analysts said the activity stemmed from unconfirmed reports that the Olayan Group, controlled by Suliman S. Olayan, the Saudi Arabian businessman, had increased its stake in the company to at least 5 percent from about 4 percent. Wall Street analysts discounted the significance of the reports - even if true - arguing that Mr. Olayan had been a supporter of Occidental's chairman, Armand Hammer.

headline: I.B.M. TURNS UP THE HEAT IN EUROPE
abstract: BONN     ON the second floor of a Karstadt Department Store - next to the kitchen appliances - I.B.M. has a new booth, and it is crowded with shoppers. A few form a respectful circle around a young salesman who is demonstrating how a personal computer can be used to prepare an income tax return. Later, the salesman brags that he and his booth-mates are selling two or three PC's a day.    ''Normally, we don't go into department stores,'' says Kaspar V. Cassani, the 55-year-old, Swiss-born president of I.B.M.'s huge European operation. Until recently, I.B.M. Europe hadn't gone into furniture outlets or discount stores or cash-and-carry emporiums, either. But times have changed. Sales of tabletop computers for homes and offices are entering a rapid growth stage in Europe, two years behind their surge in the United States, and I.B.M. is struggling for domination of the market.   The competition is stiff - stiffer perhaps than in the States - and the International Business Machines Corporation has yet to emerge as Europe's leading vendor of personal computers, which it decidedly is in the States. In part the company's sales team is fighting against European reluctance to buy American computers when European computer makers are struggling to grow and trying to resist I.B.M. dominance.

headline: Arbitrage Trading Examined
abstract: Miller Tabak Hirsch & Company, a New York securities firm that has been questioned about the possibility of manipulation of stock-index options, said yesterday that it was engaged in ''bona fide arbitrage activities'' when it purchased large blocks of stock and traded options on April 19.    Heavy last-minute trading on the Chicago Board Options Exchange and the New York Stock Exchange on that day has led to informal investigations by the exchanges and by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Miller Tabak is one of several firms being investigated.   The heavy purchases of stock pushed up the Standard & Poor's 100 index so rapidly that large sums of money were made and lost in trading on S.& P. 100 index options in Chicago.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * American Fuel Technologies Inc.  of Federalsburg, Md., said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire Quality Oil Inc. of Kansas for 1 million common shares.     * Arveron Investments Inc. , of Sommerset, N.J., and its chairman, Arthur N. Goldberg, said in a S.E.C. filing that they had increased their stake in G.C. Murphy Co., an operator of variety stores, to 8.13 percent.

headline: Kemper Charge
abstract: The Kemper Corporation said it expects to report an after-tax charge of 30 cents a share for the first quarter.

headline: ABC PROFIT UP BY 71.9%
abstract: The American Broadcasting Companies said yesterday that earnings rose 71.9 percent in the first quarter, to $23.9 million, or 81 cents a share, from $13.9 million, or 48 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues climbed 26.2 percent, to $836.7 million, from $663.1 million.    Despite a disappointingly low audience for ABC's coverage of the Winter Olympics in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, broadcasting group profits rose  39 percent in the first quarter, to a record $56.6 million, on sales of $746.9 million. ABC provided exclusive coverage of the Olympics, and the five ABC-owned television stations ''had significant incremental profits'' as a result of Olympics revenues and improved sales, the company said. The company's radio stations reported a loss before including the sale of station KGO-FM in San Francisco for a $4.8 million pretax gain.

headline: Cutback at Merrill
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company has trimmed 621 support personnel since the beginning of the year, William A. Schreyer, president of the brokerage, said at its annual meeting in Houston.

headline: Kenya Jails Founder Of Human Rights Group
abstract: The founder of a Nairobi-based Movement for Human Rights in Africa has been jailed for two and a half years for managing an unlawful society, court officials said.   They said Edward Zade, a Uganda refugee living in Kenya, was sentenced here Thursday for running the human rights organization after the authorities rejected registration applications.   Mr. Zade was arrested in February after the authorities warned him that they would not tolerate hostile activities against neighboring states from Kenyan soil.

headline: Conrac Chief Adds Title And President Is Named
abstract: The Conrac Corporation, a technology company that has refocused its interests in recent years, has named Donald H. Putnam to the new post of chairman, and Paul E. Graf to succeed him as president. Mr. Putnam, 59, remains chief executive, a position he has held since 1958.     Mr. Graf, 40, joined the Stamford, Conn., company in 1979 from Texas Instruments Inc. He has been a vice president with responsibility for the company's information group and, since 1980, has been executive vice president. He will be chief operating officer and a director, as well as president.

headline: SOVIET WIDENING DRIVE, AFGHAN SAYS
abstract: An Afghan rebel spokesman said yesterday that the Soviet Union's spring offensive in Afghanistan, although most intense in a key valley north of the capital, had expanded into heavy attacks against insurgents around the country.    The spokesman, Abdul Rahim, a political officer for the Islamic Society rebel organization, said at a news conference in Manhattan that the Soviet objective appeared to be to wipe out resistance in the Panjshir Valley, 50 miles north of Kabul, and in other areas of north-central Afghanistan.   ''This is the time for the American people to press Congress for more aid for our cause,'' Mr. Rahim said at Freedom House, 20 West 40th Street. He said the rebels did not have the heavy weapons needed to shift from the defensive to the offensive.

headline: No Headline
abstract: The U.N. Today June 22, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: SEVERAL BEIRUT LEADERS RESIST JOINING UNITY CABINET
abstract: Lebanon's Prime Minister-designate tried today to persuade the main leaders of the country's warring militia groups to join his Cabinet of national unity, but he continued to meet serious resistance from several key men.   After deliberating overnight, two Christian leaders, Camille Chamoun and Pierre Gemayel, indicated they would take part in the 10-member Government announced Monday by the Prime Minister-designate, Rashid Karami.   But the Shiite militia leader, Nabih Berri, issued a statement reiterating his refusal to join the Karami Cabinet as it was now constituted, and Walid Jumblat, the Druse leader, also appeared to be hesitant about participating.   In addition, the Greek Catholic Community Council announced that it was ''suspending'' participation by its representative, Joseph Skaf, in the proposed Cabinet until the Greek Catholics were given additional seats, beyond the Ministry of Information portfolio assigned to them by Mr. Karami.

headline: Fuel Contracts
abstract: The Hess Oil Virgin Islands Corporation received a $208 million contract for naval and jet fuel, the Defense Department said. In addition, a unit of the Exxon Corporation got a jet-fuel order of $126.6 million and the Steuart Petroleum Company received an order of $101.8 million.

headline: 7 SUMMIT LEADERS PLEDGE TO ASSIST DEBTOR COUNTRIES
abstract: The leaders of the seven major industrial democracies pledged today to make it easier for some of the hard-pressed third world countries to repay their debts, promised to continue their own vigorous policies against inflation and voiced their support for ''precise commitments'' to the ''nonuse of force'' by both East and West.    In a long economic communique and three shorter political statements issued at the end of the 10th economic summit meeting here, President Reagan and six other government leaders touched on most of the issues they had discussed, but there were signs that in several important cases they had been unable to agree on specifics.
