As the leaders concluded their deliberations at Lancaster House, tens of thousands of antinuclear demonstrators marched through the streets of central London, carrying banners and placards denouncing American policy. The organizers said more than 150,000 people took part. They were kept well away from the conference sites by the police, but traffic was paralyzed and more than 170 people were arrested for obstruction during the march and two smaller protests. (Page 13.)

headline: Rebels in Mozambique Said to Kill 10 on Bus
abstract: Rebels in Mozambique killed 10 people and wounded 19 when they fired on a civilian bus near the border with Swaziland Wednesday, the official Mozambique News Agency reported today.

headline: Acid Rain Protesters Are Active in Europe
abstract: Three ecologists spent a second night perched on a gasoline refinery chimney here to protest acid rain, but demonstrations in several other Western European countries were ruined by the weather.

headline: LESSONS FROM CONTINENTAL; CONFIDENCE: THE MOST PRECIOUS ASSET
abstract: IF there is any lesson for both bankers and the public in the sad story   of the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company, it is that the most important asset that any bank has is the confidence of its depositors. Bankers should remember that once confidence is lost, whether through bad loans, bad management or just bad publicity, there soon is very little left of a bank.   What is a bank? One wonders about this looking at Continental, the largest bank in the heartland of the United States and long considered a pillar of strength. Yet, it survives now only because of the extremely generous assistance provided by the regulatory agencies and by fellow bankers who feared that Continental's demise could lead to major problems of their own.

headline: British Air Profits Triple
abstract: British Airways P.L.C., the Government- owned airline that is to sell stock to the public next spring, reported today that its profits more than tripled in the fiscal year ended March 31.   The company reported a profit before extraordinary credits of $:181 million, or about $251.6 million, compared with $:51 million, or $70.9 million, a year ago.

headline: 3 Other Ad Agencies Win New Assignments
abstract: In other account news Korey, Kay & Partners in New York, Griswold Inc. in Columbus, Ohio, and Wunderman West in Los Angeles are all welcoming incoming traffic.     K.K.P. becomes the ad agency for the new, low-fare Virgin Atlantic Airways, whose United States destination will be Newark Airport.

headline: Careers; New Stress On Liberal Arts Study
abstract: IN seminars all over the country    the Association of American   Colleges and the National Endowment for the Humanities have been beating a drum for liberal arts. They have drawn important speakers from corporate management and universities who have echoed the need for broadly trained managers and increased recruitment of college graduates with a liberal arts background.    Ralph Z. Sorenson, who combines a business and academic background, sounded an alarm of sorts at a recent seminar for the Boston region. Mr. Sorenson is chairman of the Barry Wright Corporation of Watertown, Mass., a diversified maker of computer accessory equipment, and former president of Babson, a business- oriented college in the Boston area that also offers the master of business administration degree.    One problem, he said, lies with corporate officials who do the interviewing or hiring. They ''are typically placing a much higher value on practical and professional skills, such as accounting, finance, marketing, engineering and computer science than they are on the candidate's grasp of history, politics, philosophy, literature, science or ability to think analytically,'' Mr. Sorenson said.

headline: A DEMAND FOR GOODS FROM ASIA
abstract: Uwajimaya, a block-long food, gift and furniture business with a pagoda-style roof, is a mainstay of this city's international district, where streets are lined with Japanese and Chinese restaurants, small shops and curio stores.    In a second-story office, above the store's fish market, Tomio Moriguchi, a 47-year-old United States citizen who is Uwajimaya's president, puffs on a pipe as he presides over the $20 million-a-year operation, the largest such Japanese retail and wholesale business with American ownership in the nation.    Mr. Moriguchi says the company's philosophy - developed by his father, Fujimatsu, who founded Uwajimaya as a fish market in 1928 - has been ''to take care of the home front first, our Asian customers, and then expand to the general market.''    Stores in Other Cities    Similar stores are springing up in other cities, largely to accommodate the influx of Japanese executives moving to this country to open branches of Japanese corporations. For example, there is Katagiri & Company in New York, Yaohan in suburban Los Angeles and Toguri in Chicago. But they are all smaller and owned by Japan-based companies.

headline: Energy Ventures
abstract: The Appalachian Company said it wants to remove the board of Energy Ventures Inc. and liquidate the company.

headline: TEMPLE RAID PUTS SIKHS 'IN A VERY FOUL MOOD'
abstract: A light rain today, harbinger of the coming monsoon, soaked the woven jute carpets leading to the golden-domed Bangla Sahib gurdwara, or Sikh temple, here.   But the rain did not cool the tempers of the knots of turbaned Sikh men, who in agitated tones discussed the assault on their holiest shrine, the Golden Temple in Amritsar, last week.   ''If Christ's temple were destroyed, what would Christians say?'' asked Jagjit Singh, a doctor, as a crowd of Sikhs nodded in angry assent.   ''What has happened is not tolerable to the Sikh community,'' he added.   'This is Hindu Democracy'    A younger Sikh with intense brown eyes interjected bitterly: ''This is not democracy. This is Hindu democracy.''

headline: Rainbow Programming
abstract: Rainbow Programming Services of Woodbury, L.I., has switched its account to Fearon O'Leary Kaprielian from Slater, Hanft, Martin. Rainbow, which is expected to spend almost $2 million a year for advertising, is made up of the Bravo, Sportschannel and Playboy cable TV channels and has a subscriber base of more than 1.5 million. The assignment is for both trade and consumer advertising in print, radio and TV.

headline: G.E. CREDIT: A BUYOUT PIONEER
abstract: As one of the biggest purveyors of financing for leveraged buyouts and an aggressive proponent of ''creative financing'' for American companies, the General Electric Credit Corporation is growing rapidly in the turbulent financial services industry.    The credit subsidiary of the General Electric Company has been expanding on its business beyond consumer financing for more than 20 years. Beginning in 1965, long before leveraged buyouts became a fad on Wall Street, the company began financing such transactions, and has been active in more than five such transactions each year.    The company has, nonetheless, remained outside the increasing controversy that has surrounded L.B.O's in recent months by adhering to a long- standing policy of financing the buyouts of relatively small companies in transactions negotiated in relatively friendly terms.    For example, two groups that have received G.E. credit financing for these transactions in the last 12 months included the senior management of Microdot Inc., a subsidiary of Northwest Industries, which was taken private for $125 million, and Farley Industries, which bought out the shares of the N.L. Metal Products Group for $118 million,    Some Warnings Sounded    Leveraged buyouts are transactions in which public companies are taken private by management or others who borrow to purchase the shares. As a lender, G.E. Credit has typically assumed that future earnings of the companies would be used to pay off the buyout debt.

headline: A CROISSANT BOOM IN U.S. MARKETS
abstract: In 1981, when sales of the traditional desserts, coffee cakes and sweet breads produced by the Kitchens of Sara Lee were faltering, the company's parent, Consolidated Foods, brought in new management. The new management took decisive action: It brought in the croissant.    Today, Sara Lee's frozen croissants are outselling its celebrated pound cake. Indeed, while its traditional fare is doing about the same, the company says, the croissant has become the most successful new product Sara Lee has ever introduced.

headline: U.S. BACKS ARAB BID IN U.N. TO CONDEMN SHIP ATTACKS BY IRAN
abstract: The United States today backed efforts by a group of Arab nations for the Security Council to condemn Iran for attacks on commercial shipping in the Persian Gulf.   Speaking in the Council, the United States representative, Jose S. Sorzano, said: ''The acceleration of attacks against shipping in the Gulf, particularly attacks against shipping going into or out of the ports of nonbelligerent states, threatens not only those states but indirectly poses a potential threat to world price levels, and inflation.''

headline: Data Bank; April 29, 1984
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: Mobile-Phone Lotteries Set
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission, changing its rules, voted today to begin using lotteries to award licenses for advanced mobile phone systems across the country.   The commission decided it could cut years off the licensing process for so-called cellular phone systems by using lotteries, which would replace complicated hearings before administrative law judges during which the qualifications of competing applicants are compared.

headline: BUILDING OUTLAYS UP BY 1.2%
abstract: Spending for new construction rose 1.2 percent in March from February, with a small gain in private building offsetting a decline in Government projects, the Commerce Department reported today. The gain put the spending at $295.6 billion on a seasonally adjusted annual rate.   The modest improvement compared with a strong 5.9 percent gain in February and a 3.9 percent rise in January, but building activity was still running 22 percent above the level of a year ago, when the construction industry was pulling out of the 1981-82 recession.

headline: IRELAND'S PREMIER CHIDES PRESIDENT
abstract: Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald of Ireland implicitly rebuked the United States for its policy in Central America tonight in a speech at a gala state banquet at Dublin Castle in honor of President and Mrs. Reagan.    Mr. FitzGerald, who has been under strong pressure from his political allies to try to modify Mr. Reagan's views on the region, said the Irish people wanted Central American problems to ''be resolved peacefully, by the people of the region themselves.''   Visit to Ancestral Village    Earlier today, in a visit to the tiny village of Ballyporeen in County Tipperary, an elated Mr. Reagan walked the narrow streets and prayed in the old stone church of his Irish forebears. He said the experience ''has given my soul a new contentment.'' (Page A8.)

headline: ANTI-SANDINISTA AID IS IN DOUBT
abstract: The White House is considering dropping its insistence on $21 million in emergency aid for Nicaraguan rebels to end a House-Senate deadlock and speed action on $100 million for summer youth jobs, an aide to the Senate Republican leadership said today.   The $21 million, approved by the Senate but opposed by the House, is included in the same omnibus supplemental spending bill as the summer jobs money.  The new option would allow Congress to avoid addressing for now the issue of further support for the rebels seeking the overthrow of Nicaragua's Sandinista Government.

headline: Arch to Buy Mine
abstract: The Pennsylvania Power and Light Company said it had signed a letter of intent to sell the Pennsylvania Mines Corporation, a subsidiary, to the Arch Mineral Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. The company said it would agree to purchase 4 million to 4.5 million short tons of coal annually from Arch, which would also lease undeveloped coal reserves in Greene County, Pa., from Pennsylvania Power.

headline: Republic Air Pay Cuts End
abstract: Republic Airlines has failed to reach an agreement with three of its six unions that would have extended 15 percent wage concessions. The concessions expired yesterday.

headline: Manville's Legal Fees
abstract: United States Bankruptcy Judge Burton Lifland has approved more than $3 million in Manville Corporation lawyers' fees and expenses associated with the Denver-based company's Chapter 11 proceedings. The building materials company has now spent nearly $11 million in such fees since it sought court protection from creditors in 1982. In New York on Wednesday, Judge Lifland approved $3,272,404 in lawyers' fees and expenses covering the four months from October through January, according to a Manville spokesman, Mary Tomenko.

headline: A NEGOTIATED PEACE IN LONG UNC FIGHT
abstract: UNC Resources Inc., a small manufacturing and natural resources concern that filed suit eight and a half years ago to break up what it called an international uranium cartel, said yesterday that it had agreed to accept about $300 million to settle out of court.    UNC said the bitterly fought case, which reached the United States Supreme Court on appeal, was settled in two days of nearly continuous bargaining in San Francisco last weekend with lawyers representing the former General Atomic Company, the Gulf Corporation and the Standard Oil Company of California.   UNC had brought suit against General Atomic in December, 1975, seeking some $3 billion in antitrust damages. General Atomic was acquired by Gulf in 1982 and Gulf, in turn, has agreed to be acquired by Socal for $13.2 billion.

headline: ATARI VIDEO GAME UNIT INTRODUCED
abstract: Atari Inc., attempting to rekindle enthusiasm for its video game and computer products, introduced a sophisticated video game machine yesterday that it said was the first of a flurry of new products.     ''I believe that over the next 12 months this beleaguered company is going to surprise a lot of people,'' said James J. Morgan, the chairman and chief executive of the Warner Communications unit, who was brought in last year to save Atari. The company, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., lost more than $500 million in the price war that devastated the home computer and video game businesses last year.

headline: Riblet Gets Offer
abstract: The Riblet Products Corporation said it had received a $20-a-share offer from Jupiter Industries.

headline: Cinzano Assignments To MacNamara, Clapp
abstract: MacNamara, Clapp & Klein has been assigned the Cinzano U.S.A. business by Julius Wile Sons & Company, a subsidiary of Nabisco Brands.

headline: Indian Parliament Approves Security Law
abstract: The lower house of Parliament approved a security law today that allows the Government to detain suspected extremists in the north Indian state of Punjab for up to two years without trial.

headline: Economic Scene; London Talks: Getting Ready
abstract: THE next economic summit conference among    the leaders of the major industrial democracies will take place in London June 7-9, with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher as host.   The London conference is intended, as a principal purpose, to follow through on the program of trade liberalization mapped out last May at the summit conference in Williamsburg, Va. Despite its high rhetoric, however, Williamsburg was followed by a wave of protectionism.   Ambassador Robert Morris, deputy to the Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, is representing the United States in preparations for the London conference. In an interview yesterday, he conceded, ''For a variety of reasons, some of us - and not just the United States - took protectionist actions after Williamsburg.''

headline: SALVADOR TO RESTUCTURE SECURITY FORCES
abstract: El Salvador's three security forces, long linked with the worst human rights abuses, are being streamlined and restructured, according to military and Government officials.    In the most dramatic demonstration of these changes, the Government has disbanded the 100-man intelligence unit of the treasury police, which American officials said earlier this year had been providing information to right-wing death squads.   ''The idea is to improve the image that the security forces have, especially in relation to civilians,'' said Lieut. Col. Rinaldo Golcher, the director of the treasury police. ''Instead of being afraid to go to an agent, civilians will feel confident in going to them.''

headline: Violence in India Continues
abstract: One person was killed and four were wounded today in a two-hour gun battle between Sikh militants and paramilitary troops in this Sikh holy city. The authorities here said the slain man was watching the gun battle, which came after a grenade attack by Sikhs on a police patrol.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  L.W. Biegler Inc. , a Chicago-based managing general agency specializing in unusual and high- risk insurance coverages, announced that Richard E. Stone is joining the firm as vice chairman.     *  W. P. Carey & Co., an investment banking firm, has elected to its board of directors and chairman of its Economic Policy Committee, Dr. Lawrence Klein, the Benjamin Franklin Professor of Economics and Finance of the University of Pennsylvania and creator of the Wharton Econometric Model.     *  Ceco Corp., an Oak Brook, Ill.- based company that provides forming services for concrete construction, has elected Erwin E. Schulze as chief executive officer.

headline: PLAY PUBLISHER RELOCATES AFTER MIDTOWN RENT RISE
abstract: Sixty years ago the Samuel French Company moved uptown from West 38th Street, following the northerly movement of the legitimate theaters on which the concern had based its business of representing writers, publishing plays, collecting royalties and selling books on the theater.    The company settled at 25 West 45th Street, where its second-story book store and reading room served thousands of actors, directors and lovers of the theater for 60 years. Now, however, the venerable publishing house has had to move again,    Rent was quadrupling at the end of a 10-year lease, forcing Samuel French to leave the Broadway area in search of more reasonably priced space back in its old neighborhood.    So on Monday the company opened its doors at the newest address in its 154-year existence - 45 West 25th Street, a 10-story loft building in the rapidly growing section of midtown south where publishers, advertising agencies and other companies have sought refuge from rising rents farther uptown.

headline: McCormick Deal
abstract: McCormick & Company said a subsidiary had agreed to acquire Paterson Jenks, a publicly held British corporation, for about $53.5 million. Paterson Jenks is involved in the grocery business, distributing and marketing a variety of products, including the Schwartz brand of herbs, spices and seasonings. McCormick, based in Baltimore, produces seasonings, flavorings and specialty foods.

headline: Phone-Mate Deal
abstract: Phone-Mate Inc. said it had entered into a letter of intent with the Asahi Corporation under which Asahi intends to supply substantial additional financial assistance to Phone-Mate and to acquire a majority interest in the company. Asahi, a maker of telecommunications products, is Phone- Mate's principal supplier. The intended financial assistance includes a $4 million subordinated term note, up to $5 million of trade financing and up to $1.5 million of cost reductions associated with Phone-Mate's purchase of Asahi products.

headline: Plan Rejected For Marble Hill
abstract: The Public Service Company of Indiana today turned down a proposal from a consortium of three companies to complete the Marble Hill nuclear power plant. Hugh Barker, chairman of P.S.I., said the plan had been rejected because it would have required the utility to continue to find financing for the $7.1 billion project, which was canceled in January at the urging of a study group appointed by Indiana's Governor, Robert D. Orr.

headline: PLAYING THE HORSES ON WALL ST.
abstract: As recently as 1980, the owners of thoroughbred horses were mostly small syndicates and wealthy individuals. There were no public companies that offered investors the chance to play the horses on the stock market.   In the last four years, however, the price of buying, keeping and training thoroughbreds has skyrocketed. And the need for fresh money has led to the creation of six companies that offer investors a stock market play.

headline: S. Carolina's Mazda Bid
abstract: Gov. Dick Riley said he would visit Hiroshima, Japan, in mid-July to try to persuade the Mazda Motor Corporation to build an auto assembly plant in South Carolina. Mazda is considering Greenville as a possible site for a United States assembly plant, along with a mothballed Ford Motor Company plant in Flat Rock, Mich., and an undetermined site in Nebraska. Governor Riley said this week that he would present Mazda officials with a gift from local businessmen and artwork by local students promoting life in South Carolina.

headline: WHITE HOUSE AIDES UNSURE CHINA ACCEPTS AMERICAN VIEW OF SOVIET
abstract: White House officials said Saturday that they might not know for months whether President Reagan had convinced China's leaders that his policy toward the Soviet Union is effective.   The assessment, voiced by the officials in interviews after the President's talks here, contrasted with the upbeat tone of earlier American suggestions that the talks had brought Peking and Washington closer together.   The White House officials voiced disappointment that China had censored Mr. Reagan's anti-Soviet comments from news accounts and videotaped television broadcasts. The officials said a bigger problem was whether the comments got through in private.

headline: JEWEL RUMORS DYING DOWN?
abstract: After more than a month of rumors and gyrating stock prices accompanied by heavy volume, the interest in the Jewel Companies may be evaporating.   The supermarket and drugstore operator, based in Chicago, has been the subject of takeover speculation, especially since the company said earlier this month that its chairman, Weston R. Christopherson, had met with L. S. Skaggs, the head of American Stores Inc. Both companies say no merger is planned.   In addition, one report last week mentioned interest from an unidentified foreign concern. But Jewel's stock price declined throughout the week, closing at $52.50 on Friday, down $2.75 for the week, and analysts are beginning to suggest that the recent stock fluctuations may simply have been the result of speculation in an otherwise dull market.

headline: SATELLITES OUTPACE CUSTOMERS It is not easy owning a communications satellite these days.
abstract: Cable television, long-distance telephone service, video teleconferencing and other forms of sophisticated electronic communications have not produced the bonanza of customers that was predicted by the satellite industry.   After several years of intense demand and relatively tight capacity, there is now too little demand for too much satellite transmission capacity. Welcome to ''transponder glut'' as the industry calls it.   This oversupply, analysts say, is likely to continue for the next two or three years because demand is expected to continue to lag as more satellites are fired into space.

headline: NATO CUTS SOVIET-BLOC ESTIMATE
abstract: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization today published a revised comparison of its troop strength and that of the Soviet-bloc Warsaw Pact, and tacitly acknowledged that it had been exaggerating the numerical superiority of Soviet-bloc armies available for combat in Europe.   Joseph M. A. H. Luns, Secretary General of NATO, presented the study at a news conference, his last before stepping down. He said procedures to estimate the number of troops available for any East-West war had been changed to give ''a more complete picture of those land forces which could actually be brought to bear.''

headline: Sale of Stations Aids Dun's Net By The Associated Press The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation said yesterday that,
abstract: aided by the sale of six television stations for $606 million,   its first-quarter net income   soared to $310.7 million, from  $37.1 million a year before. Without the nonrecurring   gains from selling assets not   related to its business services   and information operations,   Dun & Bradstreet's operating   income was $45 million, up 21.3   percent from $37.1 million a   year earlier.

headline: Piedmont Planes
abstract: Piedmont Aviation Inc. of Winston-Salem, N.C., has exercised its option to buy eight more F-28 MK- 1000 Fanjet aircraft, according to Fokker, the private Dutch aircraft maker.

headline: Houston Offers $70 Million Bonds A $70 million issue of Houston general obligation bonds was offered yesterday, with yields ranging from 6 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 8.8 in 1994 and 9.9 percent in 1990, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. About $27.2 million of the issue was unsold as of late yesterday, underwriters said.
abstract: The bonds were rated AAA by Standard & Poor's, but Moody's Investors Service recently reduced its rating to Aa-1. Analysts at Moody's said Houston's financial condition is still very strong, but added that the city is faced with large capital spending projects. The two-year term for elected officials makes financial planning more difficult, the rating agency added.

headline: C.D. Yields Rise Further
abstract: Annual effective yields on six- month certificates of deposit rose nationwide to 10.38 percent, up from last week's 10.24 percent, in the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.    The increase marked the 16th consecutive gain for The Monitor's national index of annual effective yields.

headline: Shultz to Visit Asia in July
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz is to leave July 5 on a two-week tour of East Asia and the Pacific that will take him to Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia, Australia and New Zealand, the State Department said today.

headline: BRZEZINSKI SEES U.S. AND SOVIET AT 'END OF THE ROAD' ON ARMS CUTS
abstract: Zbigniew Brzezinski, national security adviser to President Carter, said today that the Soviet Union and the United States appeared to have come ''to the end of the road'' on reaching major strategic arms control agreements.   Mr. Brzezinski cautioned against a playing into Soviet hands in the Persian Gulf by United States military involvement without the collaboration of British and French forces and a clear invitation from Arab governments.   Even if these conditions are met, he said, there are risks that American involvement in the Gulf conflict could drive Iran toward Moscow.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: FRIDAY, MAY 25, 1984   Markets    An unfounded rumor about Manufacturers Hanover rattled the nervous and volatile stock, bond and currency markets. The rumor, apparently started in Europe, said the bank was having trouble raising funds, but it was strenuously denied. (Page D1.)    Stock prices plummeted in heavy trading.  The Dow Jones industrial average fell 10.37, to 1,103.43, its lowest level in 15 months, after flitting all day around 1,100. Banks stock were particularly depressed. Volume rose to 99 million shares. (D4.)

headline: Republic Air Loss Narrows
abstract: Republic Airlines Inc. said   today that its net loss narrowed   to $4.1 million in the first quarter, from $59 million a year   earlier, aided by employee   wage concessions and other   economies. Republic also reported operating earnings of $18.5 million   from the airline, compared   with an operating loss of $38.7   million in the first quarter of   1983.

headline: PATENTS
abstract: Internal Combustion Engine Starter     A new starter for internal combustion engines has been patented for the Ford Motor Company.

headline: LEHMAN, SHEARSON PACT SEEN
abstract: Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., one of the oldest investment banking firms in the country, is negotiating the sale of the company to Shearson/ American Express Inc. for between $300 million and $400 million, Wall Street executives said yesterday.     Shearson officials said the company would have no comment yet, and Lehman executives did not return calls.    But sources familiar with the talks said that the Lehman board had approved offering itself for sale yesterday, and that the Shearson board would meet this morning and promptly approve an agreement to pay the price Lehman is seeking.   One Wall Street executive said that by approving a takeover, Shearson would be ''betting a lot of money on the personal element - keeping the people and keeping the relationship with clients.''

headline: No Headline
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.   Tuesday    Productivity1st Qtr. Wednesday    Merchandise Trade BalanceApril    New-Home SalesApril Thursday    Leading IndicatorsApril    Factory OrdersApril    Farm PricesMay Friday    UnemploymentMay    Construction SpendingApril

headline: NEW IN CONDOMINIUM SALES: STOREFRONTS ON MADISON
abstract: Wherever rents have risen sharply in New York City, condominiums have followed. It began in New York's residential market, then spread to offices and industrial space, although the movement there was slow to start and is only now gathering momentum.    The latest form of condominium ownership here is the retail condominium - the small drugstore or pastry shop that is part of a much larger structure and that is sold individually, most often to the merchant himself.       So far, only a few retail condominiums have been sold in New York. Among the first were the five shops that make up the ground floor of Carnegie Hill Tower, a new 233-unit residential condominium on Madison Avenue between 93d and 94th Streets.

headline: DOMINICA, ON THE MAP NOW, HOPES FOR BETTER DAYS
abstract: The invasion of nearby Grenada last October brought unaccustomed international exposure to this impoverished Caribbean island nation.    As chairman of the Organization of Eastern Caribbean States, Prime Minister Mary Eugenia Charles was in the forefront in the deliberations surrounding the invasion, which she and the heads of five other island member-nations urged the United States to lead.   ''Some people, they even began to say our name right,'' one resident said of the invasion. ''It put us on the map.''   Dominica - the name is pronounced Dom-in-EE-ka - is an English speaking nation that gained its independence from Britain in 1978. It is not to be confused with the Spanish-speaking Dominican Republic.

headline: Market Place; Cautious View On Fast Food
abstract: -food industry's recovery is continuing nicely, thanks to an improved domestic    economy as well as new products, effective advertising and only modest cost pressures. Moreover, average earnings growth of 20 percent appears in the picture for this year. Ordinarily, the combination of these factors might sound like a ''buy'' signal for the stocks.   However, a current appraisal by Prudential- Bache Securities is sending out a warning signal instead.

headline: DOMINICANS HALT TALKS WITH I.M.F. OVER ITS DEMANDS
abstract: The Dominican Republic suspended negotiations with the International Monetary Fund on Thursday after rejecting demands that gasoline prices be raised 50 percent, Dominican officials said today.   A spokesman for President Salvador Jorge Blanco said the Government made the moves because it feared that a gasoline price increase would set off more violence in the country. Increases of up to 200 percent in the prices of some foods and most imported goods in late April resulted in three days of street riots that left about 60 people dead and hundreds injured.   Some Latin American leaders said the violence was evidence that tough austerity conditions being demanded by the monetary fund in return for financial help had gone beyond the point of social tolerance.

headline: GOVERNORS TO STUDY SEABROOK UNITS
abstract: The governors of the six New England states met privately today to discuss how to cancel the No. 2 unit at the Seabrook, N.H., nuclear plant, but resolved instead to study whether both units should be canceled.    Gov. J. Joseph Garrahy of Rhode Island, chairman of the New England Governors Conference, and others at the meeting, which was held at the Providence, R.I., airport, said they feared that Seabrook 2 would drag Seabrook 1 down with it.   In an interview with reporters after the meeting, the governors said they have asked a consultant to prepare, within three weeks, a study on the Seabrook project. Governor Garrahy said the study would ''examine the whole liability of Seabrook.''

headline: F.C.C. Backs Cable Rule
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission, after more than three years of controversy, rejected Friday, by a 5-0 vote, a petition filed by Ted Turner, the Atlanta entrepreneur, challenging the so-called ''must-carry rule.''    Broadcasters have long considered the must-carry rule among the most important of the agency's regulations, particularly now that cable TV is serving roughly 40 percent of the nation's TV households.

headline: Eagle Loss in Quarter
abstract: Eagle Computer Inc., the Los Gatos, Calif., maker of computers that are compatible with the International Business Machines Corporation's computers, said yesterday that it lost nearly $9.9 million in its fiscal third quarter on revenues of $10 million. In the quarter a year earlier, Eagle posted profits of $767,000, and sales also totaled $10 million. The company, which had previously predicted a more modest loss for the period ended March 31, also said that it expects a loss in the current quarter, although not as large.

headline: MOYNIHAN RESIGNS SENATE PANEL JOB
abstract: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan officially resigned as vice chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence today to protest what he called the failure of the Central Intelligence Agency to inform the panel fully on American involvement in the mining of Nicaraguan harbors.    The New York Democrat said he would remain on the committee until his term expired at the end of the year.   Concerning his continuing dispute with the C.I.A., Mr. Moynihan said he had met with William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, on Tuesday. He described the 45-minute meeting as ''civil.''

headline: A.T.&T. REQUESTS RESTRAINTS BE EASED
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, citing its new competitive position, asked the Federal Communications Commission today to lift business restraints imposed in 1980 when it still owned and controlled local telephone companies.   ''A.T.& T. files this petition because the monumental changes in circumstances since 1980 dictate the removal of the structural separation requirements now applicable to it,'' the company told the F.C.C.   Since 1980, A.T.& T. has been required to maintain a separate subsidiary, held at arm's length from other parts of the organization, to provide equipment to customers on their premises.

headline: PROTECTION URGED FOR COOPER IN U.S.
abstract: The International Trade Commission unanimously found today that imports were causing serious injury to American copper producers and that the Government should impose new trade barriers to help the industry.    Protection for the domestic copper producers, which operate in the West, could raise the cost of copper and products made with copper, especially electrical equipment.   For that reason, President Reagan is expected to come under pressure from copper-consuming states in the Middle West and East to give the producers little or no protection from imports. How he will resolve this regional conflict was unclear tonight. In 1978, trade specialists recalled, when the commission made a similar finding, President Carter refused to grant protection.

headline: Chairman to Buy More GAF Stock
abstract: Samuel Heyman, chairman and chief executive officer of the GAF Corporation, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he intends to acquire up to 15 percent of GAF's voting stock outstanding.

headline: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
abstract: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.19     An index of yields for long-term   A-rated general obligation bonds   compiled weekly by The Bond   Buyer.   Aa Utility Bonds*14.50     Salomon Brothers' estimate for   new long-term issues.

headline: Markets Closed
abstract: Stock and commodity markets, banks and Government offices in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Memorial Day.

headline: The U.N. Today May 4, 1984
abstract: SECURITY COUNCIL   Meets on Cyprus at 10:30 A.M.  GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Committee on New and Renewable Sources of Energy - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Working Group of Experts on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Meets at 3 P.M.   Social Committee - 3 P.M.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: *  Boise Cascade Corp. , a forest products company based in Boise, Idaho, said it plans a $9 million expansion of its office-products distribution network in Charlotte, N.C., and Jacksonville, Fla. The upgrading will add about 7,000 items to the company's basic 8,000-item catalogue.

headline: DESPITE THE ODDS, CZECH REBEL PRESSES CASE
abstract: Vaclav Benda pressed two fingers against his forehead and horn-rimmed glasses and told a bitter joke about political isolation in Czechoslovakia. A Czech, it goes, has only three friends: his car, his weekend cottage and himself.   From prison in 1979, the philosopher portrayed the citizen in Czechoslovakia as facing an ''inert, grim and all-devouring'' Communist system. ''Power has set itself up against truth,'' he wrote, ''nothingness against reality, and the monotony of the endless cycle of anniversaries against history.''

headline: ;  Chrysler Arranges Line of Credit
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation has worked out a deal to obtain a billion-dollar line of credit, another in a series of breakthroughs the No. 3 auto maker has made since its brush with bankruptcy less than five years ago.   Financial and industry sources say the amount of credit lined up approaches $1 billion and could go as high as $1.2 billion - the amount Chrysler received in federally guaranteed loans from 1980 to 1982 to avoid bankruptcy.

headline: ISRAELIS BID U.S. READMIT BLACKS
abstract: Israel has asked the United States to take back stateless black Americans who renounced their citizenship as part of their membership in a cult calling itself the Black Hebrews.   The Black Hebrews are a group of roughly 1,000 American blacks who say they are descended from the original Jews and have settled - most without official consent - in southern Israel.   As far as the Israeli Government is concerned, most of the Black Hebrews have no legal status in Israel, since they came in on three-month tourist visas and simply stayed on, and they have no rabbinically recognized connection to Judaism.   An Israeli Interior Ministry official said that to make them citizens would contradict both the letter and the spirit of Israeli law; to expel them, he said, would be awkward and perhaps logistically impossible because the United States could put noncitizens right back onto a plane to Israel.

headline: BRITISH CHANGING ON CERAMICS
abstract: -ON-TRENT, England - Britain's venerable ceramics industry, chastened by the impact of recession and the loss of export markets when the pound shot up along with oil prices in 1979, is now working on several fronts to stimulate its recovery.    The companies here in North Staffordshire are keeping a closer watch on overseas competitors, paying more attention to the tastes of trend- setting American consumers, stepping up marketing and increasing their investments in automation.   The last element is depressing news here in The Potteries, as this city of 250,000 and the neighboring towns are known. The region, which produces everything from fine china to toilet bowls, accounts for more than 80 percent of the British ceramics industry's $700 million output, and it bore the brunt of job losses that cut the industry's employment to 35,000 from 55,000 and brought the region's current unemployment rate to 12.2 percent.

headline: Teacher Freed in Italy
abstract: A teacher kidnapped seven months ago was released unharmed today after her parents paid a $480,000 ransom, the police said. The kidnappers originally demanded a ransom of $2.4 million, which the teacher's father, head of a wine-exporting business, said he could not pay. The teacher, Anna Maria Fusco, was kidnapped in November as she was driving from her home to the village school.

headline: Insider Accord In Atari Case
abstract: A second senior officer of Atari Inc. has decided not to fight insider-trading charges and has agreed to give up $154,184 and 2,925 common shares in Warner Communications Inc., the Securities and Exchange Commission said today. Without admitting or denying guilt, Dennis D. Groth, now president of Atari's international division, also agreed to surrender to Warner stock option rights on 13,333 Warner shares.

headline: BRAZIL'S ARMY REGIME RULES OUT DIRECT ELECTION OF PRESIDENT IN '85
abstract: The head of Brazil's military Government has ruled out direct election of the country's next president, but has promised that the successor of that president will be chosen freely.    ''Direct elections are inopportune at the moment,'' President Joao Baptista Figueiredo said, ''even though the Government recognizes the advisability of restoring them for the future.''    The President, the fifth successive general to rule Brazil since 1964, made the announcement in a nationwide address Saturday night.   He said he would sponsor a constitutional amendment permitting direct presidential elections that would come into force only after his successor is chosen by a 686-member Government- dominated Electoral College in January 1985.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: TUESDAY, APRIL 24, 1984   Companies    Partners in the Seabrook nuclear project moved to take over financial management of the plant after its lead utility, Public Service of New Hampshire, defaulted Friday on its 35.5 percent share of expenses, according to executives of two of the partners. (Page D1.)    Standard Oil of California neared agreement with the F.T.C.  on what assets it would sell in order to gain antitrust clearance to take over Gulf. The approval is expected on Thursday. (D1.)

headline: Debt vs. Cash
abstract: To the Editor:      There is an interesting irony between two of your May 27 articles.   In ''Risky Trend in Business Borrowing,'' you note that since January, ''new debt has been rising at a 31 percent annual rate'' and that much of this debt is short-term and at variable rates.

headline: HAITIANS SAY POLICE CRUELTY TOUCHED OF 4 DAYS OF RIOTS
abstract: Residents in this northwestern city said today that the immediate cause of rioting last week was the beating by policemen of a pregnant woman, who later died of her injuries. They said it was the latest in a series of such incidents of brutality against civilians.   But they also said the disturbances grew out of unhappiness over rising food prices and a general sense of hostility toward the Government. The disturbances were an unusual event in the 13-year rule of Jean-Claude Duvalier, who succeeded his late father, Francois, as President in 1971.

headline: Penn Traffic
abstract: The Penn Traffic Company, a supermarket and dairy operator, said certain company officers were invited to meet with an investment company last February to discuss a possible leveraged buyout, but they decided there was no basis for pursuing the matter.

headline: Chesebrough Posts Big Stock Gain
abstract: Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. said that the sharp rise in its stock on the New York Stock Exchange was not the result of any corporate action. Responding to a rumor linking it with Revlon Inc., the company said it had had ''no contact'' with Revlon.

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: Atlas Accepts Bid From Wesray Unit    EVANSVILLE, Ind., June 22 (AP) - Atlas Van Lines Inc., which had been fighting a takeover from a group that included its former president, agreed today to a $71.1 million merger offer from another company.   Atlas, the nation's sixth-largest mover, said its board had approved a merger with Wesray Transportation Inc., a newly created affiliate of the Wesray Corporation, whose principal stockholders include former Treasury Secretary William E. Simon.

headline: U.S. GROUP STUDIES PHILIPPINES' PRESS
abstract: An investigating team representing United States press and human rights organizations has concluded that the future of a free press in the Philippines remains uncertain despite a recent easing of Government restraints.    The group's conclusion followed a 10- day survey of news reporting in the Philippines under the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.   The group, noting that the mechanism for press control used under martial law still exists, said it saw ''danger signals'' in recent criticisms of the press by Mr. Marcos and his aides.

headline: Ally & Gargano to Get Resorts Casino Account
abstract: Mark van Hartesvelt, who in January became senior vice president- casino marketing for Resorts International, Atlantic City, has announced that Ally & Gargano will be his new agency.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: ACF Prefers Bid By Warburg Firm
abstract: ACF Industries said it did not consider a takeover bid by an investor group headed by Carl C. Icahn as good as a competing bid from a private investment firm. Under a ''standstill agreement'' ACF has with Mr. Icahn, it agreed to allow him to present a counteroffer to any bid.

headline: Lilco Turns Down Gas Company Bid
abstract: The Long Island Lighting Company announced that its board had unanimously rejected an unsolicited bid to purchase its gas operations.

headline: INTEREST RATES MOVE LOWER
abstract: Interest rates fell yesterday, with the biggest decline coming in the Treasury bill market, where rates for outstanding issues fell by a tenth of a percentage point or more as prices for the securities rose.     Prospects for a steadily diminishing supply of outstanding Treasury bills during for the coming month helped raise prices in that sector.    At the same time, the lack of any Treasury note or bond financings this week or next helped support prices. Except for a two-year Treasury note auction expected April 25, Government securities dealers do not expect any note or bond auctions until the week of May 7, when three new issues totaling $16 billion are likely.

headline: FLORIDA NATIONAL SETS DEBT ISSUE JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 30 (Reuters) - Florida National Banks of Florida Inc. said it had registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a $50 million offering of 12-year floating rate subordinated debentures.
abstract: Net proceeds will be used in part to repay borrowings incurred mainly in connection with the company's recent acquisition of the Royal Trust Bank Corporation. The balance will go toward general corporate purposes. Salomon Brothers will manage the underwriting group.

headline: LEADERSHIP OF D.D.B. REALIGNED
abstract: LAST year Doyle Dane Bernbach    moved to a four-creative director operation without a single creative head from a two-creative director setup. This year's special will be five creative directors with a creative overseer.

headline: ISRAELI REPORTS POLICY IS NOT TO AID SANDINISTA FOES
abstract: A senior Israeli official said today that Israel had made an unequivocal decision some time ago against supporting the United States-backed insurgents in Nicaragua.   At a breakfast meeting with reporters, David Kimche, the Director General of the Israeli Foreign Ministry, said, referring to the Nicaraguan rebels, ''We have not, we are not, and, I presume, we will not be supplying arms or military equipment to the contras.''   With the Reagan Administration's money for the so-called covert operation in Nicaragua said to be nearly gone and House Democratic leaders saying they will not approve any more Central Intelligence Agency money for the insurgents, some Administration officials in recent weeks have talked privately about the possibility of persuading friendly governments, such as Israel, to help.

headline: FRENCH UNION PARADES SHOW DISUNITY AND DISMAY OF LEFT
abstract: France's three main labor unions had separate and poorly attended May Day demonstrations today, illustrating the divisions and disenchantment in the French left.    ''Is this what we wanted?'' asked Henri Krasucki, the secretary general of the Communist-led Confederation Generale du Travail, speaking of the Socialist Government's policies of job cutbacks in heavy industry.   ''Do we give up a historic opportunity and such great hopes without having brought our real weight into the game?'' he asked. Mr. Krasucki asserted that the Government was responsible for diminished buying power, growing unemployment and the closing of factories. ''We're not modernizing,'' he said. ''We're giving up.''

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: POLISH AUTHORITIES CLAIM VICTORY IN VOTER TURNOUT
abstract: The Polish Government said today that the turnout in nationwide elections Sunday represented a vote of confidence in its policies. But preliminary figures it released indicated that in the most urban areas, the election boycott called for by Solidarity sympathizers received significant support.   The Government's full response to the election is expected to come at a news conference scheduled for Tuesday, when Jerzy Urban, the Government spokesman, is expected to expand upon the view carried today in the Government press - that a turnout of more than 75 percent of the electorate was a rebuff to those who urged a boycott. Fuller vote totals or percentages will presumably also be made public.

headline: Dow Edges Up 1.67 In Heavy Trading
abstract: Stock prices registered only minor changes yesterday in heavy trading. The biggest movers were issues responding to specific news.    The Dow Jones industrial average ended up 1.67, to 1,167.19, after dropping almost 11 points Wednesday. In the general market, 790 stocks fell on the New York Stock Exchange, while 739 gained.

headline: OPTIONS INQUIRY CONTINUES
abstract: The chief executive of Bear, Stearns & Company, Alan C. Greenberg, said yesterday that his firm was ''not involved in any way, shape or form'' in options trading on the Chicago Board Options Exchange on April 19.     An unusually large volume of last- minute stock purchases on that date drove up the price of the Standard & Poor's 100 index options. This has led to an informal investigations by the Chicago Board Options Exchange, the New York Stock Exchange and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: TAKEOVER RUMORS SPUR MILTON BRADLEY STOCK
abstract: The price of the stock of the Milton Bradley Company, a major manufacturer of games based in Springfield, Mass., climbed sharply yesterday on rumors the company might be the target of an acquisition bid.    Milton Bradley, which is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, closed yesterday up $3.625, to $30.875, on a volume of 266,300 shares.   ''The two biggest speculations are that the company might be contemplating a leveraged buyout or that there is a new major shareholder out there who has not yet filed his 13-D with the Securities and Exchange Commission,'' said David S. Leibowitz, special situations analyst at the American Securities Corporation, a New York brokerage firm.

headline: 2 JEWISH SETTLERS HELD IN BUS PLOT SAID TO CONFESS IN A HEBRON RAID
abstract: Israeli newspapers and the army radio reported today that two of the Jewish settlers arrested last week for planting bombs on Arab buses also confessed to the attack last summer on an Islamic college in which 3 Arabs were killed and 33 wounded.    The two were highly trained members of elite army units, the army radio said.    The Israeli television reported that several of the settlers under arrest had given oral confessions of their involvement in a car-bombing attack in 1980 that maimed two Arab Mayors in the West Bank. The television quoted unidentified security officials as saying the attacks were carried out by 10 Jews who had originally planned to bomb more Arab political figures.

headline: Thatcher Foes Assail Agreement
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is facing sharp criticism from political opponents and misgivings among her supporters after today's compromise settlement of the five-year dispute over Britain's contribution to the Common Market budget.   Most British politicians, business executives and observers expressed relief that the dispute had been settled, at least for the time being, but fundamental British skepticism about the benefits of belonging to the European Economic Community is expected to persist.    ''It's not much of a deal,'' said Neil Kinnock, leader of the Labor Party, in reaction to the news from a conference in Fontainebleau, France, that Britain will be refunded 66 percent of its net budget contribution for the forseeable future. ''She's failed completely to get any of the reforms necessary.''

headline: A & W'S ROOT BEER CAMPAIGN
abstract: -second    spot from HBM/Creamer the   viewer will be convinced that this it is another heady communique from Budweiser, Miller or some other free-spending brewer.   The setting is the usual beer advertising cliche: two lumberjacks sitting at a bar in a rustic tavern and one talking about his desires for ''a big, tall, cold, frosty one.''    The viewer will be as surprised as the other lumberjack to find out the big man's craving is for an A & W root beer.

headline: PATENTS; Way to Split Water Into Hydrogen, Oxygen
abstract: A method of splitting water into hydrogen and oxygen, using the tiny plants called green algae with the sun's rays as the energy source, has been patented for the Department of Energy.

headline: FOR WAGES: NO BIG TAKEOFF IN SIGHT
abstract: WITH profits rising strongly, prices climbing faster than a year ago and the unemployment rate falling, the stage seems set for wages to take off once again. This year's heavy bargaining calendar includes some powerhouse unions - the auto workers, miners and postal workers - and their leaders are making tough statements about hefty wage increases ahead. Washington fears that a few heavyweight wage pacts could push consumer prices skyward and endanger the recovery. ''The economic outlook,'' said Robert Ortner, chief economist for the Department of Commerce, ''is to a great extent in the hands of labor and management. But despite the springtime rumblings from labor and worried words from the Administration, the dam is not likely to burst on wages this year - or the next. Double-digit wage raises appear to be a fading memory, not a realistic fear for the immediate future. Though wages are expected to rise this year by slightly more than last year's 5 percent, organized labor is also expected to be less aggressive during the recovery under way than in any recent postwar recovery. Nevertheless, many labor analysts say 1984 may produce major innovations for some industries, such as lifetime job security and more flexible compensation packages. Labor's new moderation reflects sweeping changes in the environment in which labor operates - and in labor's attitudes resulting from those changes. The nation's unemployment rate, though down to 7.8 percent from 10.7 percent at the end of 1982, is still high by historical standards.

headline: FUTURES/OPTIONS ; Profitable Spread Cited In Value Line-S.&P. 500
abstract: Bargain hunting among the blue- chip stocks by institutional investors yesterday further enriched holders of 1984's most profitable stock index futures spread: the selling short of Value Line index futures and the buying of Standard & Poor's 500 contracts.     While the Dow Jones industrial average rose 4.40 points, to 1,138.30, yesterday, the spot June Value Line futures closed down 25 points, at 177.95, and the June S.& P. 500 contract was up 20 points, at 157.80.   With the movement of each point representing $5 per contract, holders of the spread made $225 because, in this rare instance, both legs of the spread produced gains. The best that futures spreaders normally hope for is that one leg will make more money than the other loses.

headline: LIBYANS LEAVE EMBASSY IN BRITAIN AND FLY HOME, ENDING SIEGE
abstract: The 11-day siege of the Libyan Embassy ended peacefully today as 30 diplomats and other occupants of the building in central London filed silently out, hands at their sides, eyes fixed straight ahead, and clambered into police vans.    Scotland Yard took the Libyans to a ''safe house'' in the London suburbs, where they were closely questioned, before putting them aboard a Libyan Arab Airlines flight to Tripoli.   The group was believed almost certainly to have included the gunman who, according to witnesses, killed a policewoman, Yvonne Fletcher, and wounded 10 opponents of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, who were demonstrating outside the embassy on April 17.   Tonight, the Libyans were reported to have received a vociferous welcome in Tripoli, the Libyan capital.  In a carefully synchronized move, the remaining British officials in Libya hauled down the Union Jack over their embassy, and all but two of them then left for home. (Page 3.)

headline: U.S. PLANS TO LEASE MISSILES TO SAUDIS
abstract: The Reagan Administration, which last month canceled plans to sell Saudi Arabia 1,400 Stinger antiaircraft missiles, has agreed to lease the Saudis four of the weapons to protect King Fahd's new yacht, Administration officials said today.    The leasing project is regarded as very delicate by the Administration, which does not want to hurt relations with the Saudis, already strained over the abrupt suspension of the Stinger sale to Saudi Arabia and Jordan in the face of overwhelming Congressional criticism. The missile can be fired by one soldier from a shoulder-held launcher.

headline: LEBANESE CABINET AGAIN DISAGREES ON PEACE PLAN
abstract: Lebanon's new national unity Cabinet failed again today, because of bickering over foreign policy questions and the future role of the army, to draw up a plan for restoring peace in the country.   Government sources said that for the second time since the Cabinet came to office April 30, a compromise could not be worked out between Moslem ministers, who want the army returned to its barracks and put under the control of a six-member Cabinet committee representing the country's various religious factions, and Christian leaders, who want the army to continue to carry out day-to-day security tasks under a Christian-dominated command.   The nine Moslem and Christian ministers, who met for two hours, were also understood to disagree on the question of how to deal with Israeli and Syrian occupying forces.

headline: White House Blames the Fed's Monetary Rein
abstract: The White House, concerned that the latest rise in the prime rate could hamper the economy as the election approaches, today attributed the half- point increase to what it said was an overly tight grip on the money supply by the Federal Reserve Board.   ''We are disappointed that the prime interest rate has increased to 12 1/2 percent,'' said Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, in a statement. He added that, ''although the economy has been growing at a healthy pace and inflation remains at a low level, it appears the money supply is not accommodating real economic growth.''   The Chase Manhattan Bank was the first bank to announce its rate rise today and its action was quickly followed by other major banks across the country.

headline: FRIDAY, JUNE 22, 1984
abstract: The Economy    House and Senate conferees agreed on spending cuts in health care and public assistance. The agreement, which was reached after three days of deadlock, opens the way for approval of a $50 billion tax increase and spending cuts totaling about $11.2 billion through 1987. (Page A1.)    A bill to keep banks from diversifying into other financial services passed a House subcommittee. The vote was the first test for legislators who want to keep banks from engaging in stock brokerage, direct operation of mutual funds and other areas. (D16.)

headline: U.S. SAID TO SEEK COSTA RICA SHIFT
abstract: Government officials here say the Reagan Administration is privately putting pressure on Costa Rica to abandon its public stand of neutrality and openly support United States action against Nicaragua's Sandinista Government.   The effort, the officials said, has thus far been unsuccessful. But the United States has been promoting all indications that it is gaining, they assert, thus deepening existing conflicts within the Government of President Luis Alberto Monge, who is firmly committed to the nation's neutrality, and strengthening the hand of his opponents in the country who are more supportive of Washington's position.   Some officials expressed concern that the United States was preparing an invasion of Nicaragua, and that clashes between the Sandinista forces and Costa Rica - which has no standing army - would be used as the political justification for the action.

headline: Starving Panda Saved By a Chinese Peasant
abstract: A starving giant panda ''staggered'' into a peasant's house and was rescued from the bamboo famine affecting its mountain habitat, the New China News Agency reported today.   The report said the panda, a male 5 or 6 years old, entered the home of Qin Yiling in Pingwu county, Sichuan Province, on March 25.

headline: G.M.-Toyota Deal Approved WASHINGTON, April 11
abstract: The General Motors   Corporation and the Toyota   Motor Corporation got the Government's approval today to   proceed with a plan to jointly   build small cars at a former   G.M. assembly plant in Fremont, Calif. The Federal Trade   Commission, on a 3-to-2 vote,   made permanent the provisional approval it had granted   the project last December.

headline: LIBYAN ASSERTS TRIPOLI WARNED BRITAIN
abstract: Libya's Foreign Minister said today that his Government had warned British officials well before Tuesday's shooting incident at the Libyan Embassy in London that ''anti-revolution forces'' would try to disrupt relations between the two countries.   ''But, in fact, we did not receive any positive responses,'' the Foreign Minister, Ali Abdel Salam Turayki, said. ''What we had expected has taken place. We told them that this demonstration was a hostile act.''

headline: MAKING PARTNER IN AMERICA'S LAW FIRMS
abstract: ONE of the things that most concerns young lawyers just entering the law firm world is their likelihood of making partner, especially since gossip has it that the major New York law firms are getting increasingly stingy with their partnership offers.    That seems true at some firms. At Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood, according to the ''National Law Journal Directory,'' only 1 percent of the young lawyers that joined the firm in 1973 and 1974 became partners. Of the New York firms listed, the second-hardest place to make partner seems to be Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, where 9 percent of the first-year associates hired in 1973 became partners.

headline: Navy Contracts
abstract: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation received a total of $126.6 million in three Navy contracts, the Defense Department said. It said the contracts were $88.4 million for 80 F/ A-18 aircraft and four TF/A-18 aircraft, $29.4 million for engineering and technical maintenance manuals for F/A-18 aircraft and $8.8 million for 32 AV-BB aircraft.

headline: GERMAN PLANT BUILDERS SLUMP
abstract: A slowdown in orders from heavily indebted developing countries is putting severe pressure on West Germany's plant- construction companies. They build turnkey plants for making chemicals, steel, plastics and almost any other product from Mexico to Malaysia.     This industry's orders fell to $5.5 billion last year, nearly 30 percent less than in 1982 and roughly half of 1981's $11.1 billion.    Reasons for the poor prospects range from increasing overseas competition to the slowdown in oil producers' industrialization plans and reduced investment in countries of the Eastern bloc and the third world. Many developing nations are investing less in their economies so they can meet payments on their huge foreign debt.

headline: CITY SEEKS CON ED CHANGES
abstract: New York City officials yesterday asked the Consolidated Edison Company to change its financial structure in a way that city officials asserted would reduce electricity bills for all customers by about 2 percent.    They said they hoped the company would take the action voluntarily, adding that lower energy costs were necessary to make New York more attractive to businesses. However, city officials warned they would initiate legal action if they did not get an ''affirmative response'' from the company by May 23.   A Con Edison spokesman said the company would discuss the issue with the city before making a formal response. But the spokesman, Laurence Kleinman, said the company believed its current structure had ''a lot of merit,'' and any change could cause problems for shareholders and customers. Mr. Kleinman said one reason the utility was not requesting a rate increase this year was because of its strong ratio of equity to debt, which city officials want reduced.

headline: NEW CANADA CHIEF SETS SWEARING IN
abstract: John N. Turner, the new leader of Canada's Liberal Party, said Friday that he would be sworn in as Prime Minister next Saturday.    The announcement came as Brian Mulroney, leader of the opposition Progressive Conservative Party, ended a three-day visit to Washington to confer with President Reagan and other top officials.  Earlier this week, President Reagan also invited Mr. Turner to visit Washington.     Mr. Turner, who was elected head of the Liberal Party last Saturday, will automatically replace Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, who is resigning. Mr. Turner will then call an election later this year.

headline: CHICAGO'S FAST BUSINESS PULSE
abstract: The Talk  of  LaSalle Street      CHICAGO, June 10 - The business scene here has suddenly witnessed an explosion of unusual activity. In between the arrival of Rupert Murdoch at The Chicago Sun-Times in January and the continuing saga of the shaky Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, a series of mergers, stock deals and extraordinary exchange trades have helped change the way Chicago thinks of itself.   During the recession its status as the nation's ''second city'' was lost to Los Angeles as the Sun Belt and the suburbs continued to drain away population and resources. LaSalle Street, the Chicago equivalent of Wall Street, fell into the doldrums. Chicago's chief distinction - insular capital of the nation's industrial and agricultural heartland - became a dubious honor.   'Rust Bowl' and Commodities Regional companies, such as International Harvester, wobbled on the edge of insolvency. More plants were abandoned. The term ''rust bowl,'' meaning areas of industrial blight, entered the language. And Middle Western farmers, never having fully recovered since the 1980 limitation of grain shipments to the Russians, continued to cry about low commodity prices.

headline: Martin Marietta
abstract: The Martin Marietta Corporation, an aerospace and defense-system company based in Bethesda, Md., said its Data Systems division had received a 10-year contract from the Navy valued at $225.6 million for an automated personnel/payroll data system. The contract, which is annually renewable at a fixed price, calls for the installation of hardware, software and data communications equipment; management of equipment maintenance, and training.

headline: CHINA'S RACE TO KEEP PUMPING OIL
abstract: FOR the last 20 years, the Chinese   Government has held up Daqing,   the nation's largest oilfield, as a shining example of the sort of all-out productivity that every enterprise should emulate.   Developed on the windswept Manchurian plain without foreign assistance or technology, Daqing has been producing 1 million barrels of oil a day - about half of China's daily total output. Now, the overworked wells of the aging field are being squeezed to produce a new burst of oil. In effect, the Chinese are trying to keep Daqing and their handful of other onshore fields going strong until the vast effort to find petroleum offshore finally pays off.    That might take eight or 10 years, according to the Western oil companies that are spending millions to explore for oil along China's long coastline. So far, their exploratory wells have come up dry, or with only traces of oil. Even if the ocean yields major oil fields, the Western companies doubt that China could begin offshore production before 1992.

headline: India Gets Oilfield Loan
abstract: The World Bank said today that it would lend India $242.5 million to increase oilfield output. The projects have a total cost of $954 million and will increase the number of drilled wells, improve maintenance and test new technology for increasing recoverable oil reserves.

headline: 6,500 TRY TO STORM NEW FRANKFURT RUNWAY BUT ARE REPULSED
abstract: About 6,500 Weste German environmental protesters tried to storm a new runway at Frankfurt International Airport today but were turned back by riot policemen with water cannons and a crowd-control chemical.    At least six policemen and three protesters were reported seriously injured and 52 people were arrested.    The demonstrators, most of them young and many wearing helmets and masks, hurled firecrackers, stones and tree branches onto the runway, and dozens tried to ram through a security wall with fallen tree trunks.

headline: Disney Investor Can Raise Stake
abstract: Saul Steinberg, the New York financier, has a green light from the Government to increase his stake in Walt Disney Productions to 25 percent, Federal officials said today. Neither the Federal Trade Commission nor the Justice Department has raised objections to Mr. Steinberg's plan to more than double his holdings in the entertainment company.

headline: PROTEST OF TURKISH PRISON CONDITIONS GOES ON
abstract: When she was 20 years old, Nigar Gulsat Aygen was a medical student and an active member of the Turkish Folklore Association.    But like so many Turkish young people, Miss Aygen got caught up in the political turmoil of 1980, was arrested after the army seized power and now four years later, is a defendant in a mass trial of young leftists before an Istanbul military tribunal.   The military prosecutor has charged that she was involved in terrorist activities, a charge that she and her relatives deny. She, in turn, has asserted that she is being tortured in prison. She is on a hunger strike to back demands for improved prison conditions.

headline: U.S. TAKES OPTIMISTIC VIEW OF DUTCH MISSILE DECISION
abstract: Reagan Administration officials said today that they were only mildly disappointed by the Dutch Cabinet's decision to delay final action on the deployment of new United States missiles.   They said that overall, the Dutch move seemed to be a step toward eventual installation of the 48 cruise missiles assigned to the Netherlands.   There had been fear in the highest levels of the Administration that the Dutch Government, which had been divided on the question of deploying the missiles, might resign in disagreement, forcing new elections that could lead to a new government more inclined to reject deployment altogether.

headline: RETAINING VALUED ATTORNEYS
abstract: Paul Koepff joined Davis, Polk & Wardwell in 1973 fresh out of Duke Law School, expecting, like most of the other first-year associates, to work hard and ultimately become a partner in the firm.    But three years ago, Mr. Koepff was told he would not be invited to join the partnership.    ''When you come to a large Wall Street firm, you know not everyone makes it, not even everyone who's good,'' he said. ''But I thought I had a good shot at it. I thought that right up until I didn't make it.''

headline: U.S. OFFERS EXPLANATIONS FOR DEFICIT, BUT THE SKEPTICS SEEM UNCONVINCED
abstract: Like an unwelcome guest, the subject of the American budget deficit keeps appearing at the economic summit conference here despite the best efforts by President Reagan and his entourage.    By now, Mr. Reagan has practiced perhaps a dozen explanations of why - after years of complaints by other world leaders - the deficit has refused to disappear, and why it may not matter that it hasn't.    Listeners who plead skepticism about one explanation are quickly provided with another. But some are apparently still unpersuaded. For example, Nigel Lawson, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, told reporters the American position was ''simple-minded.''

headline: LEBANESE SEEM WEARY OF THE ISRAELIS
abstract: The only road in and out of south Lebanon was closed today for a Jewish holiday.    But the lines of more than 40 heavy trucks parked on the dusty mountain road, the battered Mercedes taxis with piles of baggage roped to the roof and the families squatting in the shade are regular sights even when the road is open.   Since Feb. 29, when Israel blocked the coastal highway running through the major cities of Sidon and Tyre about 10 miles south of Beirut, the only way to get between the fertile coastline and rolling hills of the southern part of the country and the capital has been through this checkpoint. Rival Christian and Druse militias had been fighting near Damur, but both have since issued statements saying they wanted the coastal road reopened.

headline: REPORT SAYS ISRAEL DIVERTS AID FOR ARABS
abstract: An independent study has concluded that millions of dollars in United States Government aid intended for Palestinians under Israeli occupation are being redirected by Israel away from programs that would strengthen the Arabs' economic base on the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.    The study asserts the money is instead going into projects that free Israeli funds to be used for Jewish settlements.   (In Washington, a State Department official said the report was ''misleading.'' The official said: ''It is true that the Israelis can halt implementation of programs. But we have never discerned any pattern. Besides, the majority of programs that have been proposed have been implemented.'')

headline: DUTCH UNREADY TO FULFILL MISSILE PLAN
abstract: The Dutch Government, buffeted by conflicting pressures on the issue, has concluded that it will be unable to go through with the deployment in 1986 of all 48 cruise missiles allotted to it by NATO, senior political officials said this week.    ''It is simply impossible, in domestic political terms, for us to deploy in full on time,'' said a ranking Dutch diplomat who backs the cruise program.  ''To put 48 missiles in here on schedule, just like that, another job done, is a hopelessly unrealistic proposition.''   United States officials in Europe and in Washington fear that a Dutch failure to carry out their 1979 commitment in full could lead to a breakdown in the NATO plan for deployment of 572 medium-range missiles in five countries. Opinion in Belgium and West Germany could change. And, the officials say, pressure on the Soviet Union to resume arms talks would evaporate.

headline: PAPANDREOU CALLS THE U.S. A-ARMS IN GREECE 'A PROVOCATION'
abstract: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou today denounced American nuclear warheads stockpiled in Greece as ''a provocation'' and ''a true threat to the welfare of the Greek people.''    He said the weapons were in Greece without an official agreement between the two Governments. ''These weapons have no place on Greek sovereign territory,'' Mr. Papandreou said.

headline: Busch Volume And Profit Rise ST. LOUIS, April 25 (AP) -
abstract: August A. Busch 3d, president   and chairman of the Anheuser-   Busch Companies, today announced record earnings for   the first quarter.

headline: Soviet and Poland in Economic Pact
abstract: The Soviet Union and Poland have signed a 15-year accord calling for greater economic independence from the West, but at the same time calling for broader trade with Western countries that will ''not try to use economic relations for political pressure.''    The pact, which also provides for unusual ''direct links'' between Soviet and Polish factories and for broader coordination of five-year plans, is an apparent effort to integrate the two economies.   These and other details emerge from the text of the agreement, which was signed on May 4 in Moscow by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the visiting Polish leader, and by Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader. The text was made public three days later.

headline: Elected King's Reign Ending in Malaysia
abstract: Officials said farewell today to King Ahmad Shah, Sultan of Pahang, at the end of his five-year reign and prepared for a new constitutional monarch.   Sultan Mahmood Iskandar of Johore, 52 years old, will take the oath on Thursday as the country's eighth King.

headline: NICARAGUAN RADIO IS REPORTED TO AID SALVADOR GUERRILLAS
abstract: Government officials say the Reagan Administration's assertions that Nicaragua is aiding Salvadoran rebels are based on a secret United States radio monitoring operation that has intercepted several thousand messages between the two Central American countries since 1981.   The message transmission system between Nicaragua and the insurgents was set up soon after President Reagan took office and is so advanced that it could have been assembled only with Soviet and Cuban help, the officials assert.   The operation is said to involve a complex coding system that is changed daily to maintain secrecy. Officials said American monitors are having difficulty cracking the codes.

headline: ABOUT REAL ESTATE ; MOVE BY A BANK TO DOWNTOWN ALBANY
abstract: Many a mayor of an aging city has watched in frustration as major companies abandoned downtown offices to move to the suburbs.   But earlier this spring, public officials in Albany heard the comforting news that Norstar Bancorp, a 13- year-old bank holding company in an Albany suburb and one of the region's fastest-growing commercial organizations, would move from its office building in Guilderland to a location in downtown Albany.   Norstar, which is the 11th-largest banking concern in New York State, announced in April that it would purchase Albany's Union Station, which has been vacant since 1968, and convert the turn-of-the-century landmark into its headquarters.       In the mid-1960's, the State Department of Transportation took over the station as part of a highway expansion project. Although the train tracks and sheds were demolished, the building was left intact.

headline: HUGE BLAST SAID TO HIT A MAJOR SOVIET ARMS DEPOT
abstract: A huge explosion apparently ripped through a major navy ammunition storage depot in the Soviet Union last month, and many people are believed to have died in the blast, United States intelligence sources said today.   The explosion, reportedly detected on the Kola Peninsula by United States reconnaissance satellites and other intelligence means, was said to have been so great that American authorities believed for a while that it had been a nuclear blast.
