Intelligence analysts, however, say they are convinced that the mid-May explosion at Severomorsk, 900 miles north of Moscow, involved conventional ammunition. The ammunition depot is near the northern port city of Murmansk, site of a major Soviet naval base.

headline: Air Florida Seen Close to Key Loan
abstract: Air Florida is close to receiving a crucial $5 million loan from the General Electric Credit Corporation to help it meet urgent debts and keep flying, according to the airline and reports published today. Robin Cohn, a spokesman for Air Florida, said late today that the company expects to complete the loan Tuesday.

headline: ELECTION CHANGES LOSE IN SALVADOR
abstract: The Provisional President of El Salvador announced today that he had vetoed legislation designed to eliminate the use of voter-registration lists in the country's May 6 presidential election.    The veto of the legislation, which was passed by the National Assembly and backed by the country's conservative parties, means that Salvadorans will have to vote at assigned booths, as they did in the first round of presidential voting March 25, and will not be able to vote anywhere in the country in the May 6 runoff.   A statement issued by the office of the Provisional President, Alvaro Magana, said the use of national registration lists gave Salvadorans greater confidence in the election results.

headline: CONGRESS PLEA ON SAKHAROV
abstract: The House of Representatives today approved, on a 399-to-0 vote, a nonbinding resolution asking the Soviet Union for specific information about the health and legal status of the dissident scientist Andrei D. Sakharov and his wife, Yelena G. Bonner. The resolution was introduced by Rep. Timonthy E. Wirth, Democrat of Colorado. The House approved it by a 399-0vote, and the Senate then approved it on a voice vote.

headline: Daewoo Case Pleas Entered
abstract: Seven people and two South Korean companies accused of violating Federal laws on importing steel entered not guilty pleas here today in United States District Court.   The defendants are accused of conspiring to file false statements that said they sold South Korean steel in the United States at higher prices than they actually charged.

headline: Warner Severs Tie With Ladd Warner Communications
abstract: Inc. said the Ladd Company,   which has produced pictures   exclusively under Warner   Brothers' aegis for nearly five   years, will become a nonexclusive production organization.  There has been speculation   that Warner, which has been   under considerable financial   pressures from its Atari video   game divison, might seek to   sever its arrangement with   Ladd, which has had several   box-office failures recently.

headline: General Dynamics
abstract: The Pomona division of the General Dynamics Corporation received a $68.5 million Navy contract for missile guidance, control and autopilot- battery sections, the Defense Department said. It said the contract combines purchases for the Navy and for Japan, Australia and Italy under the foreign military sales program.

headline: Latin Debt
abstract: To the Editor:      The author of ''The New Crisis for Latin Debt'' (March 11) had access to the precise information which allowed him to analyze the situation in a way that seems accurate to me and that gives a clear vision of the subject.   However, the following quotation: ''While Venezuela's refusal to devalue the bolivar during last year's    More letters, Page 21.

headline: MILWAUKEE ROAD BIDS WEIGHED
abstract: The trustee of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad, which is in bankruptcy proceedings, said today that the Soo Line Railroad Company's $168.5 million cash proposal to purchase the Milwaukee Road's assets appeared to be ''marginally better'' than a competing offer by the Chicago, North Western Transportation Company valued by that company at in excess of $170 million.   Richard B. Ogilvie, the trustee, said he based his conclusion on a preliminary analysis conducted over the weekend after both carriers substantially upgraded their purchase offers last Friday. Mr. Ogilvie said he would submit a detailed analysis of the offers to the Interstate Commerce Commission next Friday.   In its amended proposal, the Soo Line agreed to pay $148 million in cash for substantially all of the railroads assets, give an additional $20.5 million in cash directly to Milwaukee Road employes for deferred wages and assume about $250 million in liabilities. Previously, the Soo Line, controlled by the Canadian Pacific Ltd., agreed to pay $40 million in cash and assume the liabilities.

headline: GREEK EDITOR SAYS THE U.S. IS TRYING TO INTIMIDATE HIS PAPER
abstract: The editor of Greece's largest daily newspaper, Ethnos, told a court here today that the United States was seeking to intimidate the newspaper and undermine the interests of the Greek people.    The editor, Alexander Filipopoulos, appeared as a witness in the hearing of an appeal by a Cypriot reporter, Paul Anastasiades, who was sentenced in December to two years in prison on charges of having defamed and libeled the publisher of Ethnos.   The journalist, who writes under the name Paul Anastasi, is appealing the sentence.

headline: Bull Unit Gets Interest
abstract: The French state-controlled computer company, Bull, said today that its Bull Sems subsidiary had acquired an interest of about 10 percent in Ridge Computers of Sunnyvale, Calif.

headline: 33,000 Metalworkers Join West German Strike
abstract: About 33,000 West German metalworkers joined a strike in support of a 35-hour work week today, and labor and management agreed to meet to see whether there was a basis for reopening talks.   The strike is in its second week, and about 100,000 workers are on strike or have been laid off because of a lack of car parts made of metal. The walkout today shut down the Opel auto plant near Frankfurt.

headline: BELL SPINOFFS REPORT
abstract: The GTE Corporation, bolstered by strong demand for basic telephone and other communications services, reported yesterday that its earnings in the first quarter of 1984 rose 16.7 percent on a 16.6 percent increase in revenues.    The communications company, based in Stamford, Conn., said net income rose to $256.7 million, or $1.30 a share, from $220 million, or $1.17 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier; the 1983 figures included $17 million of tax refunds applicable to prior years. Revenues increased to $3.45 billion, from $2.96 billion.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;
abstract: Morrison-Knudsen Appoints President As a boy, William J. Deasy took his first ride on the New York City subway from his home in the Bronx to the Museum of Natural History in Manhattan. ''I can still remember when the ride was 10 and 15 cents,'' he said.    On Friday, Mr. Deasy, 46 years old, was named president and chief operating officer of the Morrison-Knudsen Company, which has been rebuilding subway cars for the same system Mr. Deasy once rode. ''I'm delighted we're able to perform work'' in his native state, he said.

headline: Bolivian General Strike Ends
abstract: A three-day general strike ended today, but the Workers Federation gave the Government until next Monday to revise an austerity plan or face an indefinite work stoppage. The plan includes a 75 percent devaluation of the peso and price increases of 110 percent to 600 percent on basic foodstuffs, fuel and transport.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: Brock Hotels Corp., an independent operator of Holiday Inn Hotels, has filed an issue of $10 million convertible subordinated debentures due 1991 through Offerman & Co.     *  Citicorp's $150 million of AA/Aa rated 13 1/8 percent notes due in 1989 were offered at a price of $100 through underwriters led by First Boston Corp. The size of the issue was reduced from $250 million.     *  Illinois Central Gulf Railroad Co., a unit of IC Industries, a diversified holding company, has filed a proposed public offering of $150 million of first mortgage bonds, series K, due 2004 through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: MORGAN STANLEY FIGHTS FOR NO. 1
abstract: THE ties between Exxon and Morgan Stanley, premier names in oil    and investment banking, date back at least half a century. For decades, whenever Exxon turned to Wall Street to issue new stocks or bonds, Morgan Stanley was by its side, usually as the lead underwriter for the money-raising effort under way. Even today, the two companies occupy the same gleaming skyscraper in midtown Manhattan.   But when Exxon set its financing for 1983 - a modest $77.7 million in tax-exempt bonds - it did not turn to its traditional investment banker. The oil giant opted, instead, for E. F. Hutton and its ''lower floaters,'' a new kind of long-term bond with a floating interest rate. Explained W. Allen Harrison, Exxon's assistant treasurer: ''Morgan Stanley does not have a product here.''

headline: SALVADOR ELECTION COUNCIL FIXES MAY 6 FOR RUNOFF
abstract: The Salvadoran Elections Council said today that the runoff election to choose a new president will be held May 6.    The second phase of the campaign has begun amid a flurry of political bargaining sessions to resolve such issues as coalitions, the voting procedure for the runoff, and even whether the party slates should be changed.   Few of the issues have been resolved. However, it appears that the two parties will not change slates.

headline: Safeco Stock Split
abstract: The Safeco Corporation plans a 2-for-1 stock split and a 15 percent rise in its quarterly dividend, the Seattle company said over the weekend. The new shares will be distributed June 1 to shareholders of record on April 20.

headline: LONG-PLANNED COMECON TALKS DUE
abstract: The leaders of the 10-nation Communist trade bloc are scheduled to convene in Moscow on Tuesday for their first economic summit meeting in 15 years.     The long-planned meeting, beginning three days after the end of the London summit talks of the non-Communist industrial nations, will likely serve to underscore Soviet pre-eminence in the bloc, after a period of frequent leadership changes in Moscow, and document the East bloc's unity at a time of strained East-West ties, according to Western diplomats and economists.    If Western summit meetings are faulted for failing to keep promises, the Moscow gathering may prove a clone of its Western model.    Though the last economic summit meeting of the leaders of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance, or Comecon, in April 1969, laid the groundwork for the widened East-West industrial and financial ties of the 1970's, the Moscow meeting is thought likely to offer little in the way of major policy shifts or long-term remedies for the East bloc's pressing economic problems, such as its towering debt and cumbersome trade system.

headline: ;  Addenda
abstract: * Gentlemen's Quarterly magazine increasing its circulation to 500,000 from 450,000 and its advertising rates 11.1 percent, with the September issue.     * National Geographic Traveler magazine increasing its circulation rate base 67 percent, to 1 million, from 600,000, and its advertising rates 71.9 percent with the September issue.

headline: Two Accused Libyans Agree to Extradition
abstract: Two Libyan students who were called a ''grave danger to the community'' by a United States magistrate waived a hearing today and agreed to extradition to New York to face charges of buying three pistols equipped with silencers.   The magistrate, Edwin Naythons, refused to reduce the $10 million bail set for Mehdi Hitewesh, 37 years old, of Glenolden, Pa., and Bashir A. Baesho, 36, of Lanham, Md.

headline: Fiber Optic Cable Plans Set
abstract: Plans to link North America to both Asia and Europe with fiber optic cables capable of carrying telephone messages at the speed of light were disclosed today.   Organizations from 20 European countries and the United States and Canada have signed a major deal to lay the first fiber optic cable under the Atlantic, sources close to this week's talks here said.

headline: Economic Scene; T.V.A. at 50: New Criticism
abstract: WASHINGTON DESPITE the heated debate that has erupted periodically over the Tennessee Valley Authority, most Americans have come to regard this grand experiment in planned economic growth as a big, nearly unqualified success.     A poll would no doubt show that far more people would agree with President Kennedy - ''In the minds of men the world over, the initials T.V.A. stand for progress'' - than with President Eisenhower, who disliked it so much he sought to ''sell the whole thing'' off to private enterprise. Just try to find an encyclopedia, for example, that fails to portray the T.V.A. as having brought unprecedented growth to an almost hopelessly backward region.        But some analysis of the T.V.A.'s first half century seems to show such praise, now elevated to national mythology, to be almost entirely unjustified. According to two current critics, approaching the issue from different perspectives, the ideas on which the T.V.A. was built are fundamentally flawed and will lead to similarly bad results when applied elsewhere in this country or in underdeveloped countries of the third world.

headline: Continental Bank Denies Rumors
abstract: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company denied rumors that it was considering filing for protection under the Federal bankruptcy laws. In response to a question from a reporter from the Reuters news service, Robert McKnew, senior vice president and treasurer, described the rumors as ''totally preposterous.''

headline: PICKING LOSERS WHO COME OUT ON TOP
abstract: WHEN a prospective investor in the Mutual Shares Corporation checks out the fund's roster of holdings, a first glance can be troubling. One finds bonds of at least half a dozen companies that are in bankruptcy proceedings, shares in more than a dozen corporations that are being liquidated and dozens of stocks that are selling well below their book value.    But what may seem at first to be a junkyard of mistakes is actually a treasure-trove of hidden values, says Max Heine, the 73-year-old president and co-founder of the fund. For 35 years now, he and his associates have been searching out stocks and bonds whose beaten down prices are a scant reflection of their true worth.    By sticking doggedly to that belief, the $343 million fund has racked up one of the best records in the mutual fund fraternity. It currently is ranked sixth out of more than 600 funds for its most recent 12-month improvement in price per share, and it is first out of 92 funds in the growth and income category, according to Lipper Analytical Securities. Over the past 10 years, it ranks eighth with a 712 percent overall gain in share value.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: * Credithrift Financial Corp.  of Evansville, Ind., a subsidiary of American General Corp., filed a shelf offering of $400 million in senior and/ or subordinated debt securities.     *  Financial Corp. of America, a Los Angeles-based holding company, plans to offer to acquire up to 10,460,000 of its common shares in exchange for $21.50 a share of reverse adjustable rate subordinated debentures due 1994.     *  Pogo Producing Co., an oil and gas exploration company based in Houston, announced the completion of the private placement of $40 million of convertible subordinated notes with two groups of institutional investors.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation yesterday announced plans to sell $750 million of collateralized mortgage obligations, a kind of security backed by home mortgages. Interest rates and prices for the mortgage obligations will be announced next week when they are offered to investors through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

headline: No Headline
abstract: A.T.&T. Files Rate-Cut Plan    The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has filed new tariffs with Federal regulators that provide for a 6.1 percent reduction in rates for interstate long-distance, WATS and international telephone calls this Friday.   The company submitted the new rate schedules last Friday to comply with the terms of a May 10 decision by the Federal Communications Commission. At the same time, A.T.& T. suggested that the commission consider delaying the 6.1 percent reduction in international rates until this fall because of the need to negotiate new settlement rates with foreign governments.

headline: Essex County Sues on Tax
abstract: An Essex County, N.J., official yesterday filed a lawsuit in the Federal District Court in Newark to overturn a Federal law that could indirectly tax interest paid on municipal bonds held by Social Security recipients.    The suit, by Peter Shapiro, County Executive, seeks to overturn a law passed by Congress last year that includes interest payments from municipal bonds when computing the ''combined income'' of Social Security recipients.   As of Jan. 1, 1984, if an individual recipient's combined income is $25,000 or more, tax is owed on the lesser of one-half of the Social Security income or half of the combined income above $25,000.

headline: WANG TEAMS UP IN PBX'S
abstract: Wang Laboratories said yesterday that it had agreed to buy as much as 30 percent of Intecom, a maker of communications and switching equipment, in an effort to increase Wang's telecommunications offerings for the office market.    Analysts said the transaction, which includes joint research and development efforts, was likely to hasten a shakeout under way among the more than 50 companies that make private branch exchange, or PBX, equipment. Last June, the International Business Machines Corporation made a similar investment in the Rolm Corporation, a major PBX manufacturer in Santa Clara, Calif.

headline: National Medical
abstract: National Medical Enterprises said it had acquired Lutheran Medical Center of St. Louis.

headline: China Reports 40 Casualties From Shelling by Vietnamese
abstract: China accused Vietnam today of shelling densely populated border villages, killing or wounding more than 40 Chinese frontier guards and civilians this month.   Vietnam said it killed two Chinese and wounded many in attacks along the border in response to Chinese attacks from April 21 to April 26 that killed one Vietnamese and injured seven others. Vietnam made its charges today in reports monitored in Bangkok, Thailand.

headline: SALVADOR OUSTS AIDE OVER TERRORISM REPORTS
abstract: El Salvador has dismissed a New Orleans- based diplomat who it said implicated Salvadoran military and civilian leaders in acts of terrorism.   An official at the Salvadoran Embassy in Washington said Saturday that Roberto Santivanez, who served in the army's military intelligence operations until 1979, was discharged earlier this week at the order of Provisional President Alvaro Magana.

headline: Costa Rican Denies the U.S. Pressed Him Over Neutrality
abstract: President Luis Alberto Monge says he has ''never been coerced'' to change Costa Rica's policy of neutrality.   The Reagan Administration has been reported to have put pressure on Costa Rica to abandon its public stand of neutrality and openly support United States action against the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua.

headline: TAX BENEFITS LIMITED BY CONFEREES
abstract: House and Senate tax conferees set new restrictions today that will limit tax benefits for many items, such as personal computers that are utilized for business and personal use.     They also approved sharp reductions in business tax deductions for luxury automobiles selling for more than $16,000.    A business tax deduction for home computers used in connection with work will no longer be allowed unless the computer is required by the employer. And the business tax deductions allowed for a home computer used to manage personal investments will be sharply reduced.

headline: Israel Denies Latin Arms Tie
abstract: The Foreign Ministry today denied that Israel had provided Soviet-made arms to the Nicaraguan rebels. According to reports in the United States, a rebel commander said his group had weapons that had been captured by Israel from Palestinian guerrillas in 1982.

headline: NIGERIAN MILITARY IS SEEN AS LOSING SUPPORT
abstract: Four months after seizing power, Nigeria's military leaders appear to be suffering an erosion of popular support.    Last Dec. 31, Maj. Gen. Mohammed Buhari led a group of young officers in a coup against the civilian Government of President Shehu Shagari, saying the takeover was necessary to save Nigeria, Africa's richest and most populous nation, from economic collapse.   The military intervention appeared at the time to enjoy enthusiastic support from a broad range of Nigeria's population.   Many intellectuals argued that the corruption and incompetence of the Shagari administration had made drastic action both necessary and inevitable. Traders, merchants and people in the streets welcomed the soldiers and looked forward to a quick improvement in their standard of living.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  Advanced Genetic Sciences, Greenwich, Conn., an agricultural genetic- engineering company, has appointed Anthony G. Markert chief financial officer.     *  Bank of America, San Francisco, has appointed Edward J. Blackburn to the new post of executive officer, retail insurance, and also president of its BA Insurance Co. and BA Insurance Agency Inc. subsidiaries.     *  Canadair, Montreal, a manufacturer of aircraft and aircraft components and surveillance vehicles, has appointed Carl Dean Perry executive vice president.

headline: SIKH GUNMEN KILL HINDU IN PUNJAB
abstract: Sikh gunmen shot and killed a Hindu opposition leader today in Amritsar, the holy Sikh city in the northern state of Punjab, and crowds of Hindus attacked buses and stores in retaliation.    Witnesses said the gunmen opened fire on Mr. Khanna, the president of the Amritsar branch of the Bharatiya Janata Party, killing him, his bodyguard and another person before escaping in a waiting jeep.    Authorities responded by imposing a two-day curfew on Amritsar, 250 miles northwest of New Delhi. District officials also announced the closure of all schools in Amritsar after violence flared in the streets after the slaying of the Hindu leader, Harbans Lal Khanna.

headline: Ally & Gargano Prevails At Clio Awards Again
abstract: The annual Clio Awards, an always showy event in adland, reached new heights last night in celebrating its 25th anniversary at an expensively mounted extravaganza in Radio City Music Hall.     The big agency winner for the fourth year in a row was Ally & Gargano, with six Clio statuettes. The big individual commercial winner was ''Fluffy Bun,'' better known as Wendy's ''Where's the beef?'' The major production house victor was Sedelmaier Film Productions, which did the Wendy's spot. It won four altogether and also had one of its early Federal Express spots entered in the Clio Classic Hall of Fame.

headline: WEEK IN BUSINESS
abstract: RCA yielded to indifferent consumers and a $575 million loss and announced it would stop making its videodisk players. The players, introduced three years ago amid hoopla suggesting that videodisk libraries would soon be as extensive as record libraries, were soon overtaken by video cassette recorders, which were more versatile and offered recording as well as playback capabilities. RCA had continued to produce the players long after anemic sales figures convinced analysts and other manufacturers that the players would never catch on. But RCA's chairman, Thornton F. Bradshaw, said that he came to that unpleasant conclusion only recently. RCA will take a $94.5 million after-tax write-off in the first quarter to reflect the decision.     The Fed raised the discount rate to 9 percent on Friday. Investors had been expecting, but fearing, the move since the Federal Open Market Committee meeting two weeks ago. The half-point increase, coming one day after major banks raised their prime rates by half a point, to 12 percent, was interpreted by some as reflecting a tighter monetary policy by the Fed in an attempt to turn the economic boom into steady expansion. But others said the higher discount rate, which is the interest rate charged to institutions that borrow from the Fed, was simply a reflection of the current upward pressure on short-term rates. It was the first increase in the discount rate in three years.

headline: IN HOMETOWN, GUY LOMBARDO WON'T BE FORGOT
abstract: It had been a day of warm breezes and spring blossoms. But Saturday night at Wonderland Gardens, where thousands of colored lights twinkled and three shimmering silver balls hung from the ceiling, it was New Year's Eve.    ''I want you to imagine it's winter out there and the snow is blowing and it's Dec. 31,'' the master of ceremonies said. Then, precisely at midnight, the dance band struck up ''Auld Lang Syne,'' couples kissed and everyone said happy new year.

headline: GUINEA'S MILITARY VOWS TO PROMOTE FREE ENTERPRISE
abstract: The military junta that seized power in this West African nation on Tuesday vowed in a communique issued today to encourage free enterprise and uphold human rights.    As the military made its announcement, life appeared to return to normal in this city of once-graceful colonial buildings ravaged by years of harsh weather and neglect.   Groups of people waited patiently in the wilting heat for delapidated, overcrowded buses or shopped at the metal- roofed stalls in the city's marketplace. At times people cheered or waved to cars and trucks carrying soldiers, but the majority of the residents showed little interest.    'Too Soon to Say'    ''This is perhaps a good thing that has happened,'' said a man who identified himself only as Mr. Camara, a common name here. ''But it is too soon to say.''

headline: Rio Grande Talks
abstract: Rio Grande Industries said talks had been terminated with other railroad companies regarding its acquisition or merger. The company, on Feb. 27, had referred to preliminary talks with companies that it did not identify. On the New York Stock Exchange today, Rio Grande was the biggest percentage loser, plunging $7, to $39.25.

headline: JUNE 6TH '84: NORMANDY AWAITS ARMY OF AGELESS G.I.'S
abstract: A New York City homicide detective who worked on the Son of Sam case will be there. So will an Episcopal minister from Alabama.    A woman who never knew her father, who died there, will make the trip. Another, whose husband was killed on the first day, will be there. Their son will not be there.  He died in Vietnam.

headline: Bush Starts Asia Trip
abstract: Vice President Bush started a two-week trip to Asia today. He will discuss trade and economic issues with Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone and other Japanese officials in Tokyo before going to Indonesia, India, Pakistan and Oman.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Analog Devices Inc.  of Norwood, Mass., said that Analog Devices Enterprises, a division that invests in emerging high-technology companies, paid $4,576,000 for additional shares in International Imaging Systems Inc.     * Crane Co. , a New York valves and pumps company, said it planned to occasionally buy up to $40 million in its common stock on the open market and in private transactions.     * Domtar Inc., a paper and newsprint company in Montreal, said it had completed the purchase of the Upson Co., a Lockport, N.Y., specialty papers concern, for an undisclosed sum.     * Exidyne Inc. , a hospital supplies company in Colorado Springs, said it had acquired Western Advanced Technology Inc.'s assets and assumed certain liabilities for 750,000 common shares. The company said it may issue an additional 1,420,000 shares, depending on future earnings contributed by Western Advanced, which develops medical electronic devices.

headline: Mission Insurance
abstract: The American Financial Corporation said it is buying more common stock in Mission Insurance Group Inc., increasing its ownership to 49.9 percent, from 20.7 percent.

headline: PHILIPPINE GENERAL TELLS OF PLAN TO ARREST AQUINO
abstract: The country's top military officer told a civilian board of inquiry today that he ordered Benigno S. Aquino Jr. arrested on his return to the Philippines last summer because the opposition leader was under a death sentence imposed by a military court. Mr. Aquino was slain as he was being escorted from an airliner by military officers.    At the same time, the officer, Gen. Fabian Ver, denied that elements of the military or civilian Government had been involved in the Aug. 21 assassination.   General Ver, who is head of Philippine intelligence, also told the five-member panel that Philippine intelligence agents had learned of a Communist plot against Mr. Aquino's life seven months before the shooting. He added that agents had also ''extrapolated threats to Senator Aquino's life'' from personal enemies and from his rivals in the opposition coalition.

headline: Polish U.N. Employee To Work in Warsaw
abstract: A United Nations employee who was released after spending more than four years in a Polish prison on spying charges will start work for a United Nations agency in Warsaw on June 1, a United Nations spokesman said today.   The United Nations employee, Alicja Wesolowska, a 40-year-old Polish citizen, was released from a Polish prison in February after negotiations between the Polish Government and the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar.

headline: No Headline
abstract: The U.N. Today June 5, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Subcommittee on Small Territories - 3 P.M.   Committee on Science and Technology - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Working Group on Drafting a Convention on the Rights of Migrant Workers - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Stauffer Chemical Fills 2 New Posts
abstract: Kenneth E. Davis and Milton Stern have been appointed to newly created posts as vice chairmen at the Stauffer Chemical Company, H.B. Morley, chairman and chief executive officer announced yesterday.    In a release, the company said the new vice chairmen would advise and share in decision-making with Mr. Morely. Together, the three executives will make up the office of the chairman at Stauffer Chemical, which is based in Westport, Conn.

headline: A MEASURE OF HOLIDAY STABILITY
abstract: IF any one factor stabilized the    financial futures market last   week, it was the traditional pre- holiday warning that upstairs trading strategists send to their often groggy pit traders on the Chicago exchanges: ''Attention, spreaders day!''   Normally, these warnings are issued on Fridays to remind the pit traders to cover exposed positions for the weekend. Last week, the warnings began Thursday because it was assumed, correctly as it turned out, that most traders would not wait until Friday to cover their positions.   Those who sell futures short are usually in a more vulnerable position than those who have bought contracts because most shorts do not have the underlying instruments to deliver. Last week, the shorts were particularly nervous because many had huge paper profits and wanted to protect themselves against any adverse developments over the long weekend.

headline: QUARTERLY BANK RESULTS MIXED
abstract: There were distinct winners and losers among the nation's largest banks during the first quarter as at least one reported record profits, while others did quite poorly.     On the plus side, most banks benefited from higher fee income, especially on consumer business, and from higher volume of earning assets. On the negative side, the banks continued to struggle with mountains of problem loans, both international and domestic.    But some analysts saw reasons for optimism because the banks seemed finally to be emerging from the depths of the recession. Although their provisions for loan losses remained fairly high, actual loan charge-offs were dropping at most banks.

headline: IN POST-COUP GUINEA, A JAIL IS THROWN OPEN
abstract: Cell 72 was typical: a concrete room about five feet wide and eight feet long, illuminated only by the narrow shafts of light that filtered through small holes near the ceiling.    The door was steel. There were no windows but on one wall ?former occupant had drawn himself one, complete with bars.   Other occupants had scratched their names into the walls or etched off the days. And there was one inscription, in letters about two inches high, written in blood. It read, in French, ''God save me.''

headline: SALVADORAN DENIES ROLE IN PLOT AGAINST ENVOY
abstract: Roberto d'Aubuisson, the Salvadoran rightist, said today that he believed there had been a plot to assassinate the United States Ambassador to El Salvador but that he was not involved. He told reporters he had ''helped to avoid such a terrible thing'' by denouncing it in public.    In a closed meeting with about a dozen senators, Mr. d'Aubuisson, who lost the presidential runoff election on May 5 to Jose Napoleon Duarte, reportedly charged that the election was ''fraudulent'' but promised nonetheless to accept the results.   When reporters later asked him if this meant he would support President Duarte, he replied: ''Yes, always, if he is within the Constitution. This decision was made by our party. This way we make good things for our country.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: THURSDAY, MAY 10, 1984   The Economy    Martin S. Feldstein resigned as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, effective July 10. The departure of Mr. Feldstein, who frequently differed with the White House on economic policy, had been expected. But he used the occasion to again support the Fed in the face of White House criticism. (Page A1.)

headline: Group Withdraws Offer for Standex
abstract: The Standex International Corporation said an acquisition offer for the company had been withdrawn.

headline: ALL WORK HALTED AT SEABROOK SITE BY COST PRESSURE
abstract: The utility that is building the Seabrook nuclear power plant in New Hampshire laid off 5,200 workers yesterday and stopped all work on both reactors at the site, citing ''financial pressures on the company.''   Analysts and utility regulators said the move could be a prelude to bankruptcy, a possibility that the utility, the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, and its auditors have raised in recent weeks. Others said the layoffs could be the first step in canceling the entire project in a last-minute effort to keep the utility solvent.    Public Service of New Hampshire said the move would save the company and its partners in the project $750,000 a day in construction costs. But analysts said that overhead, primarily interest costs on the $2.5 billion already spent, would continue to run about $1 million a day.

headline: Reuters Shares
abstract: The Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, a Government agency, has told Reuters Holdings that it has bought 36.5 million, or 12.5 percent, of the ''B'' limited voting shares in the news organization, Reuters said.

headline: Market Place; Earning Profits From Weather
abstract: WALL STREET security analysts ponder two time horizons in assessing company prospects - the short term, a period of months, and the long term, perhaps several years. Whenever the market outlook is misty, for example, analysts usually allow that they are ''cautious for the short term, but bullish for the long term.''    In the current ''investment strategy'' notes of Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins Inc., one article upstages the analysts' fraternity by taking a genuinely long-term look at events. Its author, Iben Browning, a 66-year-old climatologist of Albuquerque, N.M., is executive director of the Thomas Bede Foundation, a nonprofit research organization. He also serves as a consultant to Paine Webber and, on occasion, has addressed investment seminars.

headline: New Seiko Color TV Is Flat, Pocket-Sized
abstract: The Hattori Seiko Company introduced a flat pocket-sized color television set today, apparently the world's first.   Company officials also announced that Seiko would cease manufacturing its black and white wristwatch television set, which captured the public fancy but not many sales.   The new color television set uses a color liquid crystal display instead of the conventional cathode ray tube. Liquid crystal displays, normally used in calculators and digital watches, have been used in black and white television sets, including Seiko's wristwatch model, but not in color sets.

headline: Radice Contracts
abstract: The Radice Corporation said it had signed contracts to sell the initial three office buildings in office parks in Fort Lauderdale and Clearwater, Fla., and in Pittsburgh.

headline: MAGAZINE'S WINNING FORMULA
abstract: Hot tubs, kiwi fruit and Napa Valley chablis. By now they might be called the cliches of California, but not by Sunset magazine. For the magazine that was promoting the West before the West was won, they come with the territory.     ''We're provincial, and proud of it,'' said John F. Henning Jr., associate pubisher of Sunset and president of the Lane Publishing Company, the family business that owns the magazine.

headline: FACTORY USE RISES TO 81.9%
abstract: Industry operated at 81.9 percent of capacity in April, nine-tenths of a percentage point above the March level and the biggest gain since a one-point increase in January, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.    April marked the 17th straight month that the operating rate did not decline and the third month that the figure was above 80 percent.   Some economists are beginning to warn that the operating rate has reached the point, particularly in some industries, where capacity is strained, bottlenecks begin appearing and prices start rising.

headline: Algeria Reports Clash With Moroccan Troops
abstract: Algeria said that its troops intercepted a 60-man Moroccan contingent inside Algerian territory early today and killed two Moroccan soldiers, wounded two and captured 31 in the fight that ensued.   A Defense Ministry communique said the rest of the Moroccans fled to their side of the border.

headline: SEEKER OF RECONCILIATION
abstract: If official returns confirm his own party's estimates, Jose Napoleon Duarte has achieved a dream he has harbored for more than two decades: governing El Salvador as its elected President.  ''Some 23 years to get to this moment,'' said Mr. Duarte, 57 years old, ''and this moment is just the beginning of a much longer road.''   A confirmed victory in the runoff election Sunday would mark the third time Mr. Duarte has been chosen as the country's top civilian official - twice through election, and once by appointment.   His first apparent victory in a presidential election came in 1972. His running mate was Guillermo Manuel Ungo, now a leader of the exile opposition political forces. The military responded to the victory by jailing Mr. Duarte, beating him severely and throwing him out of the country. His right cheek still shows an odd indentation, which he attributes to a the butt of a gun.

headline: 5 Libyans Said to Die In Ethiopian Explosion
abstract: Diplomats said today that at least five Libyans and an Ethiopian were killed in an explosion at a house here Tuesday night.   The total death toll is not known.

headline: State Banks as Underwriters
abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation today proposed revised regulations that would let subsidiaries of about 9,000 state-chartered banks underwrite corporate securities.   Today's action by the agency modifies an earlier rule proposed last May that would allow subsidiaries of state- chartered banks that are not members of the Federal Reserve System to underwrite some forms of corporate securities.

headline: Bid on Basic Four
abstract: Management Assistance Inc. said it had received a proposal from a private investor group to acquire the company's worldwide Basic Four Information Systems operations, including international maintenance activities.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Belzberg Bank Unit Names a President
abstract: Stephen Shulman was named president and chief operating officer yesterday of the First City Capital Corporation, the New York-based merchant banking subsidiary of the Belzberg family's First City Financial Corporation of Vancouver, British Columbia.    Mr. Shulman, who is 43 years old, has been a vice president of the Signal Companies. The new appointment is effective July 1.

headline: DELEGATE GROUPS CONTINUE DESPITE MONDALE'S PLEDGE
abstract: Walter F. Mondale promised last month to shut down the delegate committees formed to support his candidacy and return all the money they had collected from labor union sources. But so far he has not fulfilled that promise.     Officials of Mr. Mondale's campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination said $400,000 had been put into an escrow account at the D.C. National Bank here for repayments, but the money will not be returned until the Federal Election Commission gives its approval.   A senior campaign official said the process was proving to be a ''logistical nightmare'' and could take months.   'We Have to Request'      David Ifshin, general counsel of the Mondale campaign, said: ''We have had difficulty persuading the delegates, who were acting perfectly legally, to cease and desist. We have to request, we cannot tell the delegate committees to shut down.''

headline: SAYS HE RAISED MONEY FOR REBELS
abstract: The State Department said today that it had revoked the entry visa of Guillermo Ungo, a Salvadoran Social Democratic exile allied with the insurgents, on the ground that he collected money for the guerrillas on previous visits.    An associate of Mr. Ungo, Hector Oqueli, said by telephone from Mexico City, when told of the stated reason for the revocation, that Mr. Ungo had never engaged in fund-raising of any kind in the United States.   Richard Weeks, the State Department spokesman who said Mr. Ungo had raised money, declined to provide details.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Automatix Inc., manufacturers of robots and artificial vision systems, named Michael J. Cronin president and chief executive officer. Mr. Cronin, a founder of the company, was also elected a director.     * Carson Pirie Scott & Co., Chicago, appointed Richard H. Gundy to the new position of senior vice president- merchandising for County Seat Stores, Minneapolis.

headline: Household Notes
abstract: The Household Finance Corporation said it planned to sell $100 million of medium-term notes as part of a $400 million shelf registration it filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission earlier this month. The company said that the maturities would range from nine months to 10 years and would be offered on a continuous basis though Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: Tiffany Rejects $16 Million Bid
abstract: A family-owned New Jersey mail-order company that built its business on selling inexepnsive clothes offered to buy Tiffany & Company for $16 million in cash, but the jewelry company's parent promptly rejected the offer. Max Habernickel, owner of the Haband Company, said he thought his ''family personal touch'' and ''excellent service'' could help turn around Tiffany, a subsidiary of Avon Products Inc. But he said he was not interested in buying the company's building on New York City's Fifth Avenue. Avon previously said its expects the sale of the eight-store Tiffany chain to bring more than $160 million.

headline: SILICONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FOSTER MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GILLETTE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: TEXAS PACIFIC LAND TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: ILLINOIS TOOL WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: LYPHOMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: THOMAS & BETTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: JERRICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: STOCKHOLDER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REGO GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: Corroon & Black Gets Ingram Bid
abstract: The Corroon & Black Company said it had received an unsolicited letter from Ingram Industries offering to buy all of Corroon's shares for $31 each.

headline: ICI Net Rises Sharply
abstract: Imperial Chemical Industries, Britain's largest industrial company, reported sharply higher earnings today for the first quarter on the strength of its cyclical business in plastics and petrochemicals. The company's net income in the quarter nearly doubled, to $207 million, or 34 cents a share, from $105 million, or 17 cents a share. Revenues climbed 15 percent, to $3.4 billion, from $2.9 billion in 1983.

headline: 200 Students Return To Polish School
abstract: About 200 students returned to classrooms bare of crucifixes today, and there were signs that Poland's monthlong ''war of the crosses'' was easing.   Both sides - the Roman Catholic Church and the Communist Government - appeared to have softened their stances in the dispute over an official ban on crucifixes in state-run schools and other public buildings.

headline: MOZAMBICAN UNITS BATTLE GUERRILLAS
abstract: Mozambican Government forces were said today to have begun a major operation in the south of the country after an incursion by up to 1,000 guerrillas from South Africa.    Mozambican officials said the insurgents entered Mozambique in the weeks before the signing of a nonaggression pact between the two ideologically opposed neighbors on March 16.   The Government officials in Maputo, Mozambique's capital, said they believed that unrest caused by the insurgents would worsen, despite the nonaggression pact, as the guerrillas, now theoretically deprived of South African backing, made a final attempt to unseat President Samora M. Machel before their supplies ran out.   The officials, along with foreign diplomats in Maputo and Western travelers from the area, said evidence of the insurgent presence was provided Thursday when a truck on the highway leading from Maputo to the South African border was attacked.

headline: B.I.S. Chief To Leave
abstract: Fritz Leutwiler, president of the Swiss central bank and the Basel-based Bank for International Settlements, will step down from both positions at year's end, the Swiss Finance Ministry said today.    Mr. Leutwiler has headed the central bank since 1974.

headline: Whittaker Pact
abstract: The Whittaker Corporation said it expects to stop operating a Saudi Arabian health-care program when its contract expires May 31.

headline: FINALLY, EGYPT GETS A BREAK FROM LEISURE
abstract: Egypt loves holidays.    For example, Egyptians are given a day off on Syrian Revolution Day even though the two countries are barely on speaking terms. Egypt commemorated Libya's Revolution Day until two years ago, when their common border was closed.   But this last week has been a banner one for holidays, even by Egyptian standards. There were six, almost consecutively, touching every religious and political base.

headline: Reynolds Stock Up;Pickens Role Seen
abstract: R. J. Reynolds Industries, which has huge oil and gas holdings, rose $3.75 in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to end the day at $63.375.   Reynolds said that it did not know of any corporate developments to account for the rise. However, T. Boone Pickens, the Amarillo, Tex., oilman who touched off the Standard Oil Company of California's takeover of the Gulf Corporation, was rumored to be buying stock in Reynolds.

headline: INDIA CALLED KEY STAGING AREA FOR HEROIN SENT TO U.S.
abstract: Delhi and Bombay are rapidly becoming the main staging, shipping and trafficking centers for heroin smuggled to the United States and Western Europe from the Khyber Pass area of Pakistan and Afghanistan, authorities here and in Pakistan say.   The United States, particularly the East Coast, is now said to get most of its heroin from the Khyber area, which since 1980 has supplanted the ''golden triangle'' in Southeast Asia as the world's biggest heroin-producing region.   At the same time, the rapidly swelling flow of Khyber heroin and opium across the Indian-Pakistani border has reportedly stimulated drug use at several levels of Indian society, from the farm workers of Punjab, who have opium in their morning tea, to the literati of Bombay, who have begun taking it in cold milk as a party drink.   India has found itself in the middle of the world of hard drugs, the authorities say, because previous conduits out of Pakistan are being increasingly blocked by enforcement efforts there as well as at European and American airports. Customs officers at those airports in recent months have become more attentive to Pakistanis and to passengers getting off direct flights originating in Karachi, the authorities say.

headline: Gaines Pet Foods
abstract: Anderson, Clayton & Company said it had agreed in principle with the General Foods Corporation to acquire General Foods' Gaines Pet Foods business.

headline: REVLON: COSMETICS SHOW THEIR AGE
abstract: The company is still known for its Charlie scent and its Flex shampoo, but the bulk of the dollars these days comes from such things as plasma derivatives and lens grinders.    Revlon Inc., under the stewardship of Michel C. Bergerac, has rapidly diversified into health care products during a period when its mighty cosmetics line has come on hard times.    ''This isn't a cosmetics company with health care,'' said Jack Salzman, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. ''This is a health care company with cosmetics.''

headline: Reuters Raises $309.8 Million
abstract: The initial public offering of Reuters Holding P.L.C. - the first in memory occurring simultaneously in New York and London - raised $309.8 million yesterday from investors around the world.     Reuters is a financial information and news service. It has been owned principally by British newspaper groups.

headline: Impostor Is a Suspect In Nicaragua Bombing
abstract: A man posing as a Danish journalist when a bomb explosion wounded Ed en Pastora Gomez, the Nicaraguan rebel leader, and killed eight others carried a false passport and is a prime suspect in the assassination attempt, Denmark's Foreign Ministry said today.   A rebel spokesman said last week that a journalist or an impostor may have set the bomb that exploded Wednesday at Mr. Pastora's news conference on the Nicaraguan side of the border with Costa Rica, killing two reporters and six rebels.

headline: Hindu Priest Killed in Punjab
abstract: A Hindu priest was shot and killed in Punjab today as militant Sikhs and Hindus set their terms for resuming talks with the Government on the crisis in the northern Indian state, the Press Trust of India reported. The news agency said gunmen riding on a scooter fired at the priest of a Hindu temple in Jogiana, wounding him, his wife and two others. The priest later died in a hospital and the others were reported in serious condition, it said.

headline: HOUSE PANEL APPROVES NEW LIMITS ON BANKING
abstract: The House Banking Committee approved a comprehensive bill tonight to halt recent bank moves across state lines and to force banks out of certain nonbanking businesses. The vote puts the committee at odds with the Senate and the Administration.   The measure, approved on a 32-to-16 vote after 10 hours of debate, is also vigorously opposed by much of the banking community, which views it as a step backward in efforts under way in the Senate to further deregulate the rapidly changing financial services industry.   The bill, sponsored by Fernand J. St Germain, a Rhode Island Democrat and chairman of the panel, would also close a provision in banking law that has allowed several dozen nonbanking companies to push into commercial banking and the savings and loan business. Such firms include Merrill Lynch & Company and Sears, Roebuck & Company. In this important aspect, the House bill is similar to the one in the Senate.

headline: SANDINISTAS' FOES AND EL SALVADOR WIN A SENATE VOTE
abstract: The Senate approved $61.75 million today in new emergency military aid for El Salvador and $21 million in funds for Nicaraguan rebels.    The vote was 76 to 19, with 53 Republicans and 23 Democrats supporting the Administration-backed compromise bill.   Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut was the only Republican to join 18 Democrats in opposing the aid package, among them Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut.   All four senators from New York and New Jersey voted for the bill. Strong Opposition Predicted    The passage of the legislation was regarded by many Administration supporters as an important, although anticipated, victory for President Reagan after his recent defeat on efforts to have a school prayer amendment to the Constitution passed in the Senate and after delays on his nomination of Edwin Meese 3d, his White House counselor, to become Attorney General.

headline: Basques Bomb Spanish Boat
abstract: A bomb planted below the waterline blew up a Spanish Navy launch today, killing a seaman, naval officials said. Telephone callers to newspapers said the bomb was planted by a previously unknown Basque guerrilla group, which called itself Ataska.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM; A NAIVE SOLUTION RIFE WITH PROBLEMS
abstract: THE proposed dollarization of Israel's economy has given rise to great interest - and even greater confusion - on the part of the Israeli public. In view of an annual inflation rate currently exceeding 300 percent, and a huge balance-of-payments deficit, dollarization was initially presented as a universal cure for the country's economic ills - a way to avoid the hardships that normally accompany recovery.  The dollarization plan met energetic resistance and vehement opposition from people in both the Government and the universities. The reaction was the final factor in the Finance Minister's resignation.

headline: CREDIT CARDS - THE KEY TO EXPANDING SERVICES
abstract: FOR better or worse, depending on your luck in getting credit, the 600 million cards floating around in American wallets are becoming electronic keys, capable of unlocking a dizzying array of services. Indeed, for consumers, the rush by American Express, Diners' Club, MasterCard and Visa, among others, to expand the utility of their cards is somewhat bewildering. It is no longer a simple task to determine what kinds of services and limitations each card carries, much less what types of cards most people need.    ''Services are definitely getting better,'' said H. David Meyers, chairman of the board of Timesaver Inc., one of the largest marketers of the Visa and MasterCard credit cards. ''But they are also getting more confusing.''

headline: France Seeks Forest Parley
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand said today that France would propose a world conference to save forests, particularly those threatened by acid rain. Mr. Mitterrand made his proposal in a message to the European Associations for the Defense of Nature, saying, ''The most urgent question for Europe is to safeguard the forest devasted by acid rains.''

headline: D-Day Joins the Lexicon
abstract: -day is the day on which a military attack or other important operation is to take place, and especially refers to June 6, 1944, when the Allied invasion of Western Europe started during World War II. After an operation begins, subsequent days are termed, for example, D plus 2, D plus 3. The expression was not widely used until World War II.

headline: 3 Killed and 40 Hurt As Quake Hits Italy
abstract: A strong earthquake followed by more than 20 lesser shocks rocked central and southern Italy today, killing at least three people, interrupting telephone and train service and causing tall buildings to sway.   At least 40 people were injured by falling debris, mainly in remote towns in the Abruzzi Mountains south of Rome where the quake was centered. More casualties were expected once contact was made with other mountain villages, officials said.

headline: TOP AIDE QUITS U.S. FUEL PANEL: INQUIRY PRESSED
abstract: Victor M. Thompson Jr. resigned today from the board of the Synthetic Fuels Corporation, amid widening charges of improprieties.   His departure leaves the embattled Government-sponsored company without a quorum to conduct business.    At least two critics of the corporation on the Senate Energy Committee, Bill Bradley of New Jersey and Howard M. Metzenbaum of Ohio, both Democrats, quickly seized on the existence of a crippled board to try to force a review of the company's mission to spur development of synthetic fuels, or even to shut it down.     The corporation, created under a law signed by President Carter with great fanfare in mid-1980, was designed to be the catalyst for private-sector development of a major new American industry. It was envisioned that the Government would provide up to $88 billion in aid but, largely because of the decline in world oil prices, interest in the development of synthetic fuels has waned.

headline: D'Arcy Sets Restructuring
abstract: Hal Bay, chairman and chief executive of D'Arcy MacManus Masius Worldwide, announced with relief yesterday that he had completed his financial restructuring with the naming of John B. Balson, 42 years old, to be chief operating officer, North America, of the worldwide agency.  Mr. Balson, who began his business career at Grey Advertising, was until this week president of K & E Holdings, parent company of Kenyon & Eckhardt. A Chicago native, he is a graduate in hotel management of Cornell University and has an M.B.A. from Harvard.

headline: TAX CONFEREES SEEK END TO IMPASSE
abstract: In an effort to break a deadlock on this year's tax legislation, Senate conferees tonight offered to drop their major special tax cuts - including President Reagan's proposal to expand individual retirement accounts - if the House conferees would accept all the Senate's $12 billion in spending cuts, including $8 billion in Medicare.    The Senate tax cuts total about $6.1 billion.   The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, said immediately that the offer ''is the first indication that this conference can come to a successful conclusion.''   While Mr. Rostenkowski said he would reply when the conferees meet again Wednesday morning, he said, ''I think we are ready to do as much as we possible can,'' adding that the House response would be ''quite palatable.''

headline: WORLD COURT, A PART OF U.N., WAS SET UP IN '45
abstract: The interim decision handed down in The Hague yesterday in Nicaragua's case against the United States was rendered by a 15-member court headed by a Nigerian and including judges from the United States, Britain, France, West Germany and the Soviet Union.    The judicial body, the International Court of Justice, whose decisions are nonbinding recommendations, was created in 1945 under a statute that is part of the United Nations Charter.   The statute says those on the Court should be ''independent judges elected regardless of their nationality from among persons of high moral character, who possess the qualifications required in their respective countries for appointment to the highest judicial offices.''   9-Year Terms for Judges    Only one national from a country is allowed. The judges are elected by the General Assembly and the Security Council for nine-year terms and may be re-elected.

headline: U.S. IS COOL TO GULF INQUIRIES ON ARMS
abstract: The Reagan Administration today discouraged allies of Saudi Arabia in the Persian Gulf region from seeking to buy new weapons from the United States and suggested that they look instead to Britain, France and other suppliers.   The chief spokesman for the Defense Department, Michael I. Burch, said at a news briefing that the needs of Gulf nations ''might be better met elsewhere'' because they had bought arms and received military training from West Europeans.   Mr. Burch said the United States had no plans to sell Stinger antiaircraft missiles to Kuwait, which is nearest to the war zone between Iran and Iraq. Kuwaiti officials have said they might be interested in buying such missiles.

headline: ;  Gearhart Reports Debenture Sale
abstract: Gearhart Industries., which is being sought by Smith International Inc., sold $98.7 million of 10-year senior subordinated debentures and five- year warrants to purchase 2,961,000 common shares at $33 each to several financial institutions, through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.   The company, which provides services to the oil and gas industries, said it would receive proceeds of $73 million.

headline: ECONOMY DOMINATES VOTE IN ECUADOR TODAY
abstract: Voters in Ecuador's elections on Sunday will choose between a Social Democratic legislator and a conservative businessman who offer sharply contrasting solutions to the country's economic crisis.    The election is a runoff between the two front-runners of the nine candidates who sought the presidency in the first round of voting Jan. 29. The winner will begin a four-year term as successor to President Osvaldo Hurtado on Aug. 10.

headline: Jobless Rate Dips in E.E.C.
abstract: Unemployment in nine of the ten countries in the European Economic Community fell to 10.8 percent in May from 11 percent in April, the community's statistical agency, Eurostat, said today.    Eurostat's nonseasonally adjusted figures do not include Greece because that country uses a different method to assess the jobless rate and comparisons are difficult.

headline: VOLCKER PLAYS DOWN ARGENTINA'S DEADLINE
abstract: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, and Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan today played down the importance of a deadline Friday for Argentina to qualify for a special $300 million Government loan to ease it through its immediate interest payment difficulties.    Mr. Regan said in New York that the Treasury might extend the deadline, already extended twice, into the weekend and perhaps until Monday. A Treasury Department spokesman, Robert D. Levine, said here that, even if the extension were denied, the offer could be reactivated later. Mr. Volcker said the deadline was not significant.   Argentina's difficulties in making timely interest payments on its $45 billion in foreign debt have raised the developing country debt issue to a new level of international concern. The new Government of Raul Alfonsin has refused to accept customary procedures for solving its payments difficulties, arousing fears in the financial community of a new crisis of confidence in the health of American banks, which have lent heavily to Argentina.

headline: China Cancels Wheat Orders
abstract: China has canceled orders for 340,000 metric tons of wheat scheduled to be delivered in the coming crop year, the Agriculture Department said today.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: I.M.F. Names Official
abstract: The International Monetary Fund today announced the appointment of Richard Erb as its deputy managing director. Mr. Erb, 43 years old, succeeds William Dale, who is retiring on May 31, the I.M.F. said in a statement. His five-year term at the I.M.F. will begin on June 1.

headline: Mortgage Rates Rise;  Mortgage Rates Rose in May
abstract: Mortgage rates continued to climb last month, with conventional fixed- rate loans for a new home rising to 14.34 percent from 14.12 percent in April, the Government said today.

headline: PANEL SETS $30 BILLION TAX RISES
abstract: House and Senate tax conferees agreed today on about $30 billion in tax increases over four years - more than half of their goal of $50 billion in additional revenues.     The increases, which are intended to shrink Federal budget deficits, include restrictions on tax breaks in leasing deals by such tax-exempt entities as colleges and municipalities, extension of the 3 percent telephone excise tax through 1987, curtailment of income averaging for individuals and repeal of an interest income exclusion that was scheduled to become effective in 1985.   But even as the conference committee moved ahead with its business of reconciling tax bills passed by the House and the Senate, there were new signs that final passage of a tax measure as part of an overall deficit-reduction package of $140 billion to $180 billion through 1987 could get hung up over spending reductions.

headline: Japan's New Ceramics Drive
abstract: Here in the heart of Japan's ceramics industry, the Noritake Company produces th china for which it is known throughout the world. But near the dishes in a company showroom are some newer Noritake ceramic products -- pump components, digital displays for electronic devices and parts usd in the molding of engine blades for the American F-15 fighter.   Across town, another leading ceramics concern, the NGK Spark Plug Company, is working on ceramic automobile engines, which use far less fuel than existing engines.   Throughout Japan, an entirely new ceramics industry is taking shape. The industry is developing high-technology ceramic materials that are super-hard, super-strong and super-resistant to heat for use in industries as diverse as electronics, aerospace, energy and medicine.

headline: Otasco Buyout Accord Signed
abstract: The Rapid-American Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent with its Otasco Inc. subsidiary for a leveraged buyout plan under which a group led by the management of Otasco would acquire the company for more than $125 million. Otasco, which is based in Tulsa, Okla., markets home, auto and outdoor seasonal merchandise through a chain of stores, primarily in the Southern states.

headline: Quake in the Indian Ocean
abstract: There was a strong earthquake about 2,050 miles southeast of the Cape of Good Hope in the southwest Indian Ocean today, Hong Kong's Royal Observatory reported. There were no reports of damage or casualties.

headline: Culbro Names New President Edgar M. Cullman Jr. has
abstract: been elected president and   chief operating officer of the   Culbro Corporation. His father,   Edgar M. Cullman, who is   chairman, made the announcement at the annual meeting   yesterday.

headline: DETAILS OF TREASURY PLANS DUE
abstract: The only Treasury financings scheduled this week are today's regular sale of bills due in three and six months, but market particpants are looking ahead to a heavy schedule of note and bond financings next week.    Details of next week's financings, as well as the outlook for Treasury borrowing needs this quarter and next, are expected at a Treasury news conference on Wednesday. Government securities dealers expect that, in the week of May 7, the Treasury will sell more than $6 billion of three-year notes, $5 billion or more of 10-year notes, and about $4.5 billion of 30-year bonds.

headline: STARTS SOAR BY 19.3% IN HOUSING
abstract: Construction of new housing, rebounding from its sharpest monthly downturn in history, soared by 19.3 percent in April, the Commerce Department reported today. Although the figure seemed to signal a strong beginning for the second quarter, analysts cautioned that rising interest rates could soon dampen activity.   The Commerce Department said construction starts for new homes and apartments surged to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.96 million units last month, up from 1.65 million in March, marking the strongest improvement since a 26 percent rise in January 1983. The February rate was 2.26 million and the April 1983 rate was 1.55 million.

headline: Data Bank; June 10, 1984
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: RUSSIANS STUDY NEW CLUES TO PILOT LOST IN '37
abstract: Nearly half a century ago, on Aug. 13, 1937, a crowd gathered at the airport of Fairbanks, Alaska, awaiting a Soviet four-engine transport that was overdue on a 30-hour, 4,000-mile transpolar pioneering flight from Moscow. It never arrived.    The disappearance of the plane, piloted by Sigismund Levanevsky, at 35 one of the best known Soviet polar fliers, was front-page news around the world and set off one of the most intensive international searches in aviation history. No trace of the occupants or the plane, an improved ANT-6 with N-209 painted on its blue fuselage and red wings, was ever found.

headline: LATE RALLY PUSHES DOW UP BY 8.95
abstract: A late rally, fueled by some of the blue-chip issues, enabled stock prices to close moderately higher yesterday in slower trading.    At the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was up 8.95 points, to 1,133.84, after being ahead less than a point at 2 P.M. Analysts attributed the late upsurge in part to reassuring comments made by Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, on the economy and interest rates.    In the overall market, advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered those that declined by 914 to 571. Volume on the Big Board shrank to 83.4 million shares, from 84.8 million shares Tuesday.

headline: CANADA AIR RULES ARE EASED
abstract: Canada took a first step today toward airline deregulation, but stopped well short of the sweeping measures adopted in the United States in 1978.    Uner a plan announced by Transport Minister Lloyd Axworthy, Canadian carriers will be permitted to set their own domestic fares and to fly anywhere in southern Canada that they wish. But controls will remain on maximum prices, and there will be some restrictions on routes, kinds of aircraft and other considerations.

headline: COLUMBIA STARTS MAJOR CRACKDOWN ON DRUG TRADE
abstract: The Government has begun its biggest crackdown against Colombia's multi- billion dollar narcotics industry.    The action follows the murder two weeks ago of the country's Justice Minister, who the Government says was killed by men working for cocaine dealers.   Since the killing, more than 100 suspects have been arrested, including four well-known traffickers. Dozens of raids have been carried out against homes and farms thought to be used by drug traders and several properties acquired with cocaine profits have been seized by the authorities.

headline: Thayer Case Denials Made
abstract: Paul Thayer, the former Deputy Secretary of Defense, and eight codefendants have filed documents denying allegations that they used inside corporate information to reap $1.9 million in illegal stock profits.   The responses were the first to the case initiated by the Securities and Exchange Commission on Jan. 5.

headline: FIGHTING CLOSES SALE CROSSING POINT BETWEEN EAST AND WEST BEIRUT
abstract: The only crossing point between East and West Beirut was closed today after shells landed there near motorists and pedestrians heading for work.   Scores of people scrambled for cover, leaving their cars and packages in the street, as the shells came sailing in around the Museum crossing, so named because it goes past the gutted National Museum.   Although the shelling and sniper fire died down by late morning, the rival Christian and Moslem militiamen who control the two ends of the crossing could not agree on when and how to open it. Negotiations between them continued late into the night.

headline: RCA RECORDS PLANS BERTELSMANN LINK
abstract: RCA Records and Bertelsmann, the big West German publisher, announced preliminary plans yesterday to merge their worldwide record, music publishing and music video businesses.     The merger proposal follows a similar one in the record industry by Warner Communications Inc. and Polygram Records.    The Warner-Polygram proposed merger is waiting the outcome of a court case brought in Los Angeles by the Federal Trade Commission, which opposes the merger on antitrust grounds, and approval of the West German authorities.

headline: Bankruptcy Forestalled
abstract: A major creditor of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, Prulease Inc., agreed yesterday to the renegotiation of a $50 million credit agreement, forestalling bankruptcy for the utility.

headline: GUITARS ARE DOWN, BUT THIS ONE'S A STAR
abstract: THE world has not yet beaten a   path to Ned Steinberger's factory door in a converted warehouse 75 miles northeast of New York City. In fact, Mr. Steinberger had a hard time even keeping his parking lot plowed this winter. But the 35- year-old former cabinet maker, who founded the Steinberger Sound Corporation three years ago in a Brooklyn loft with about $36,000 in capital, still believes he has built a better bass guitar, and many of the nation's top rock musicians and critics seem to agree.    Very expensive and visually distinctive, Steinberger guitars - made of reinforced molded plastic, instead of the usual wood - have attained remarkable visibility, considering that only about 2,000 of them have been sold. The suggested retail price for one of the company's instruments is $1,900, compared with about $200 for the average imported guitar and about $550 for the average guitar made in the United States.

headline: 40,000 FROM SUDAN CROSS INTO ETHIOPIA TO ESCAPE FIGHTING
abstract: About 40,000 Sudanese have fled across the border to a refugee camp here in the last six months, United Nations and Ethiopian officials said today.    The Sudanese have fled to escape hunger and fighting between the army and rebels in the southern Sudan, the United Nations officials said. They say there may be as many as 70,000 refugees in western Ethiopia.   Last year, the officials said, there were 10,000 refugees at the camp here, 300 miles west of Addis Ababa and 35 miles from the border. This year, the number has risen to 40,000, an average of 800 are said to arrive daily, compared with 100 in 1983.

headline: POPE STARTS TRIP TODAY TO ASIA AND THE PACIFIC
abstract: Pope John Paul II will leave Wednesday on one of his most far-flung journeys, a trip to Alaska, Asia and islands of the Pacific involving 25,000 air miles over 11 days.    On his first stop in Alaska, the Pope will meet Wednesday with President Reagan. Before he returns here on May 12, he will have canonized 103 Korean martyrs and visited a leper colony in South Korea, celebrated mass in pidgin English in Papua New Guinea and on Guadalcanal, been greeted by King Phumiphol Aduldet of Thailand and commiserated with Indochinese refugees in a camp near Bangkok.   South Korea is the principal goal of the papal voyage; Papua New Guinea, the Solomon Islands and Thailand were added to the schedule because, a Vatican priest said, John Paul likes to show the reach of his church.

headline: LLOYD'S MORE THAN DOUBLES SHIP PREMIUMS FOR TRIPS TO IRAN PORTS
abstract: Lloyd's of London announced today that it had more than doubled war risk insurance premiums for ships traveling to two Iranian oil ports, following reports of increased violence in the Persian Gulf area.   Lloyd's said it had raised war risk premiums to 7.5 percent, from 3 percent, for vessels going to Kharg Island and Bushire, which are considered the areas of highest risk for ships. Before the recent intensification of attacks by Iran and Iraq on shipping in the area, tankers traveling to the Iranian ports were insured at a rate of 0.375 percent. (According to Reuters, these premiums are calculated on the value of both cargo and ship).

headline: U.S. RIGHTS GROUP SEES SOME GAINS IN NICARAGUA
abstract: A New York-based human rights organization says in a report that rights abuses against Nicaragua's Miskito Indian population have ended.   But the group, in a report on the overall human rights situation in Nicaragua issued last week, said that press censorship continued and that abuses at detention centers had increased.   The 51-page report by the group, Americas Watch, its third such review concerning Nicaragua, praised steps the Government had taken to eliminate abuses against Miskito Indians, but also criticized it for failing to account for Indians who disappeared in 1982.

headline: graph of Shoney's net income since 1974; AT SHONEY'S, DETAILS COUNT
abstract: When Gary P. Spoleta, the president of Shoney's Inc., visited one of his company's restaurants in Kansas City, Mo., three years ago, he was upset by what he saw. A flood of conventiongoers at lunchtime overwhelmed the coffee shop's staff, and a line of customers waiting for tables extended out the door.   To help out, Mr. Spoleta started washing dishes and had the two regular dishwashers clear tables. A local Shoney's executive took over as host, and the hostess waited on customers. Three hours later, the operation was back to normal.

headline: INDUSTRY STAKES A NEW CLAIM IN SPACE
abstract: TOMORROW, when the space shuttle Discovery makes its scheduled    liftoff from Cape Canaveral, Charles Walker will be on board, a pioneer among astronauts. The McDonnell Douglas engineer will be the first person from private industry to voyage into space, and with him a new era for business will be launched, one that could extend forever the frontiers of corporate America.    ''It's a new area, an area that is providing a great service to mankind in general, and it's one of the most exciting technologies for our future corporate activity,'' said an exuberant John Yardley, president of McDonnell Douglas, of the experiment that his engineer will conduct on board. In fact, he said, ''we're a little nervous we won't be able to expand fast enough, once demand for the products builds.''    The journey to space by Mr. Walker, a 35-year-old ''commercial payload specialist,'' could lead to the development of the first product made in space by a private company, a new drug that scientists and analysts say could be a major advance in the treatment of diabetes. In tests during four previous shuttle flights, the hormone that Mr. Walker will work with proved to be up to 700 times larger and four times purer than any produced on earth.

headline: CHERNENKO SAYS CAPITALISM IS STILL VIGOROUS
abstract: Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, told party ideologists today not to underestimate the ''far from exhausted'' reserves of capitalism although the system itself, he said, was ultimately doomed.    Addressing a meeting of Communist officials charged with drawing up a new party program, he said that it should eliminate the prediction of an impending triumph of Communism over capitalism that was included in the last program, drawn up in 1961 under Nikita S. Khrushchev.   Instead of predicting the future course of development, Mr. Chernenko said, the new document should deal with specific domestic and foreign policy issues and what he called ''peace efforts,'' since it is on the success of these policies that the triumph of the Soviet system will depend.

headline: Conrail's Board Asserts Right to Approve Sale
abstract: The directors of Conrail have told Elizabeth H. Dole, the Secretary of Transportation, that they would reserve the right to make or support other offers for the railroad if they felt that none of those submitted by Monday were in the best interests of the corporation.    The board made its intentions known in a letter sent to Mrs. Dole Thursday, just four days before the deadline she had set for all interested parties to submit their bids.
