It is unclear what effect the resolution of the board will have. The Northeast Rail Service Act of 1981 does not require that the Conrail board approve of any sale. The act provides only some guidelines for disposing of the railroad.

headline: TEXTS OF STATEMENTS ON EAST-WEST RELATIONS, TERRORISM AND THE GULF WAR
abstract: Following are the texts of the Declaration on East- West Relations and Arms Control and of the Declaration on International Terrorism that were adopted by the leaders at the economic summit conference and the text of a statement on the Iraq-Iran war by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the chairman, all made public today:    On East-West Relations      We had a substantial discussion of East-West relations. We stressed that the first need is for solidarity and resolve among us all.     At the same time, we are determined to pursue the search for extended political dialogue and long- term cooperation with the Soviet Union and her allies. Contacts exist and are being developed in a number of fields. Each of us will pursue all useful opportunities for dialogue.

headline: Vienna Bomb Kills Man In Turkish Aide's Car
abstract: A bomb exploded in a Turkish diplomat's car as it pulled up to his embassy today, killing the driver and wounding five other people. Telephone calls to news offices in Stockholm and Paris said the Armenian Revolutionary Army was responsible for the bombing.

headline: 5 OF LONDON PAPER'S DIRECTORS SUPPORT EDITOR
abstract: The independent directors of The Observer, whose task is to uphold editorial independence, accused the paper's owner today of actions that constituted ''improper proprietorial interference in the accurate presentation of news and free expression of opinion.''   Lonrho Ltd., the congolomerate that owns the paper, Britain's oldest Sunday newspaper, rejected the criticism and said it had ''never inhibited or prevented the editor from publishing whatsoever he saw fit to publish.'' The editor, Donald Trelford, was attacked last week by R. W. Rowland, the chairman of Lonrho, for an article about Zimbabwe that Mr. Rowland described as ''sensational'' and ''wrong.''   Mr. Rowland, who has renewed earlier threats to sell the paper, which is reportedly losing more than $1 million a year, met this morning with Robert Maxwell, a Czech-born printing and publishing millionaire, to discuss a sale. But no deal was agreed upon.

headline: ADVERTISING;
abstract: Foote, Cone Earnings Up Sharply in Quarter      Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, like other public agencies that have reported first-quarter earnings, had a healthy gain. With the help of results from the NCK Organization, merged on Jan. 1, the company reported a nearly sixfold increase in earnings.

headline: Vietnam Brings Home 3,000 From Cambodia
abstract: About 3,000 Vietnamese soldiers returned home today as Hanoi began a partial withdrawal of its estimated 180,000 troops in Cambodia.   A convoy of nearly 150 military vehicles, most of them carrying Vietnamese soldiers but also including five 105- millimeter howitzers and five armored personnel carriers, left for a 112-mile trip to the Vietnamese border.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Lou Scharf Inc., Fort Lee, N.J., to Beber Silverstein & Partners for Old Tyme Ginger Beer.     * Italian Trade Commission to Muller Jordan Weiss.

headline: DOW OFF 8.06
abstract: Stock prices retreated yesterday in slower trading as profit taking, interest rate concerns and unsubstantiated rumors that the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Paul A. Volcker, would resign snuffed out a two-day market advance.     Analysts said declines in the bond market pulled stock prices steadily lower throughout the day and traders cautiously cashed in their gains from the recent run-up in blue-chip issues ahead of the long Easter holiday weekend. The Volcker rumor, later denied by the Federal Reserve, added to the selling.

headline: No Decision Yet On Jewel Proposal
abstract: The chairman of the Jewel Companies, Weston Christopherson, said at the annual meeting that the company's board had not yet met to consider a proposal by American Stores Inc. to acquire the company. He said no other statements on the offer would be made until then.

headline: Military Contracts
abstract: The Electromagnetic Systems division of the Raytheon Company received a $55 million Air Force contract for tactical jamming system spares for the EF-111A aircraft, the Defense Department said. In addition, the department said the McDonnell Douglas Corporation had received a $46.7 million contract from the Navy for aircraft weapons systems.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: *  Automatic Data Processing Inc.  of Clifton, N.J., said it had signed final contracts to acquire the payroll services business of Security Pacific National Bank; terms were not announced.     * Florida Gulf Realty Trust , an equity real estate development company in South Daytona, Fla., said an investment group holding 30.4 percent of its shares planned to propose its own slate of nominees for Florida Gulf's board of directors.

headline: Sargent Considers $66 Million Bid
abstract: Sargent Industries Inc. said its board will meet later this week to vote on a proposed acquisition of the company, valued at about $66 million, by a ''major public company'' that it did not identify.

headline: V.A. Mortgage Rate Limit Up
abstract: The interest rate ceiling on basic home loans insured by the Veterans Administration will rise one-half percentage point on Tuesday, to 14 percent, the highest level since 1982, the agency announced today.

headline: Consumers Power Is Downgraded
abstract: Moody's Investors Service yesterday announced lowered ratings on $2.2 billion of the Consumers Power Company's debt and $781 million of the company's preferred and preference stock.    The rating agency said the utility, based in Jackson, Mich., faced severe problems in recovering its investment in two nuclear power plants known as the Midland project.

headline: Financial Units In Michigan Deal
abstract: First Federal of Michigan said it had agreed in principle to sell 16 metropolitan Detroit branch offices to First Federal Savings Bank and Trust of Pontiac, Mich., in a deal expected to add $58 million to First Federal of Michigan's capital.

headline: City's New Bond Offer Carries Rise in Yield
abstract: Rising interest rates in the Treasury securities market have spilled over into the tax-exempt bond market, leading to higher yields at this week's $250 million offering of New York City bonds compared with a similar sale three months ago.    The city's new bonds are tentatively offered with a maximum yield of nearly 11.03 percent for 11 percent bonds due in 2013 and priced at 99 1/2 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: Market Place; Uncertainty And Earnings
abstract: T HE stock market kicked up its heels last   Thursday with a stirring rally, demonstrating anew that hope springs eternal in Wall Street.    International Business Machines got part of the credit for touching off the sharp, one-day rebound, thanks to its announcement of a 23 percent increase in first-quarter profits. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 26.17 points, its strongest session since late February.   But, just to show that earnings announcements can cut both ways, G. D. Searle sank 5 3/4 points, to 40 1/2, on Friday after its profit increase for the latest three months - 51 cents a share against 34 cents a year earlier - disappointed some analysts. Meanwhile, the industrial average slipped 7 points in the final session.

headline: WEST GERMAN FINDS MOSCOW ADAMANT ON U.S. ARMS TALKS
abstract: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany concluded two days of meetings here today without any indication that the Soviet Union was prepared to return to the Geneva arms talks.   Mr. Genscher, who said he had come to impress on Konstantin U. Chernenko the ''complete seriousness'' of the United States Government in seeking talks, was asked at a news conference whether he thought that renewed talks were possible before the Presidential elections in the United States.   ''I have seen no indication of that,'' he replied.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; N.Y.U. Backing Bonds With Endowment Fund
abstract: New York University, the largest private university in the country, is using some of its $350 million endowment fund to back a $150 million issue of tax-exempt bonds and thereby reduce the interest paid on the bonds.   The university's bonds were sold through the New York State Dormitory Authority, and were offered with yields ranging from 7.25 percent for bonds due in 1989, to 9.8 percent in 2000 and 10 percent in 2004.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
abstract: Agencies Issue Caution On Texas Utility's Debt    Two bond-rating agencies warned yesterday that securities of the Texas Utilities Electric Company were in danger of being downgraded.    The announcements followed a recommendation by the staff of the Texas Public Utility Commission on Wednesday that the company's rates be reduced by $65 million a year rather than increased $304 million as the company has requested.

headline: BRAZILIANS REJECT PROPOSAL ON VOTE
abstract: Brazil's Congress today narrowly rejected an opposition-backed constitutional amendment calling for direct presidential elections this year to bring an end to two decades of military rule.    The amendment had been strongly supported in street demonstrations throughout Brazil over the last three months, but it fell 22 votes short of the required two-thirds majority in the 479- seat Chamber of Deputies.   As soon as the amendment's defeat was announced at 2 A.M., disappointed supporters of the measure in the public gallery began chanting, ''The people won't pardon you!''

headline: Socal to Acquire A Stake in Amax
abstract: Amax Inc. said that the Standard Oil Company of California would acquire 2.2 million of the 4.3 million shares in Amax held by the British Petroleum Company. The purchase raises Socal's stake in the company to 22.4 percent, from 19.5 percent.

headline: New Space-Buying Aid Starts at Doyle Dayne
abstract: Yesterday marked the introduction of Doyle Dane Bernbach's new computer-based newspaper buying and planning process.

headline: INDIA COMMANDER IS KILLED AS SIKHS DESERT THE ARMY
abstract: A top Indian Army commander was shot dead today by an unidentified assailant in the northeastern state of Bihar and Sikh troops deserted the unit, the Government said.    According to a report from United News of India, 600 Sikh troops deserted the unit and wounded 600 people, including 25 officers, in a fierce battle. The report said the commander was killed by the mutineers.   The mutineers, the report said, were fully armed and ''on the way to Delhi with arms.''

headline: Despite Dip in Citicorp Net, Plaudits for Wriston
abstract: Citicorp's earnings dropped a bit in the first quarter, and some shareholders were complaining that their dividends were not big enough. Despite that, the annual meeting broke into warm applause yesterday after the company's chairman, Walter B. Wriston, reported the quarterly results.     Indeed, the fact that net income dropped 2.2 percent from the first quarter of 1983, and that per-share net income dropped 5.7 percent, seemed unimportant. Even those who generally dote on quarterly returns seemed a lot more willing than usual to take a longer-range view of Citicorp's progress.

headline: Midland Nuclear Plants
abstract: The Consumers Power Company will probably abandon its uncompleted Midland nuclear plants within a few weeks, unless state utility officials in Michigan agree on a plan for completion, John B. Selby, president of the company, said today.   ''If we don't get an agreement on how we are going to finish it, then we are not going to finish it,'' Mr. Selby said in a meeting with reporters. ''We are not going to try to finance in the present market with the uncertainty that exists on licensing and the uncertainties that exist in other jurisdictions. There is no way that we at Consumers Power alone, and with opposition of the Attorney General and others, can finance at reasonable cost and we won't try.''

headline: AROUND THE WORLD ; Dominican Union Chiefs Are Reported Arrested
abstract: Union officials said that the police arrested eight labor leaders on Tuesday, moments after they called for a general strike to protest increases in food prices ordered by the government.

headline: Market Place; Analysts Like G.E. Prospects
abstract: IN the midst of an uncertain stock market, the    General Electric Company has been the recipient of several purchase recommendations lately by brokerage houses and bank trust departments.    Earlier this month, Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins Inc., a firm that is not particularly optimistic about equity prospects in general, upgraded G.E. shares to a ''buy'' from a ''hold.''   Merrill Lynch rates the stock as a ''buy'' for the long term and as ''O.K. to buy'' within the time span of one year.    In Chicago, the Harris Trust and Savings Bank said in its investment advisory newsletter for April: ''We are reinstating our buy recommendation on General Electric.''

headline: COPPER DROPS SHARPLY DESPITE POSITIVE SIGNS
abstract: A late barrage of selling swamped the New York copper futures market yesterday.     Brokers said the weakness in copper began with the reopening of the London market after the Easter Monday holiday there. But, they emphasized, the selling on the Commodity Exchange in New York did not become pronounced until long after the London Metal Exchange had closed.

headline: STEINBERG SELLS STAKE TO DISNEY
abstract: Paying what analysts consider a lofty price, and substantially weakening its balance sheet at the same time, Walt Disney Productions today bought back Saul P. Steinberg's stake in the entertainment company for $325.5 million in cash.   A report with sketchy details of the deal moved on the Reuters financial news wire more than two hours before Disney's official announcement, sparking a huge selloff in Disney shares prior to the company's announcement at 5:23 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time. The stock closed with a loss of $10.87 1/2, at $54.25, in less than an hour of trading on the New York Stock Exchange.   Disney agreed to pay $297.5 million for Mr. Steinberg's 4.2 million shares, plus $28 million to reimburse Mr. Steinberg for ''expenses.'' The combined total amounted to $77.50 a share. Mr. Steinberg paid $265.6 million, or $63.25 a share, for his stake.

headline: REGAN SAYS LOAN TO THEARGENTINES IS TO AVERT CRISIS
abstract: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that the United States had agreed to lend Argentina $300 million to help the new democratic administration there avert ''a crisis of government.''    He said such a crisis could develop if Argentina failed to catch up on overdue interest payments to banks.   An accord on a plan to help Argentina pay its huge international debt was announced Friday by the Treasury.   Mr. Regan added that, in helping the Government of President Raul Alfonsin, the United States was also seeking to avoid an international banking crisis.   ''If you want to look over the cliff and see the chasm down below, that is the sort of thing that might happen,'' he said. He rejected suggestions that the main motive was to protect the profits of American banks.

headline: MILITARY PAST OF CHERNENKO EMBROIDERED
abstract: Apparently trying to enhance Konstantin U. Chernenko's public image, the Defense Ministry newspaper today printed a photograph of him as a 20-year-old border guard and spoke glowingly of his courage and marksmanship.   The picture appeared in conjunction with an article in the newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda that took the form of a letter to the concerned parents of a recruit by Lieut. Gen. Vasily L. Donskov, commander of the Eastern Border District. This is a command of the Border Guard Troops, which come under the K.G.B., the State Security Committee.   Most of the letter was about Mr. Chernenko's service from 1930 to 1933 as a volunteer on the Chinese border of Kazakhstan. That was a time, General Donskov wrote, when the border commonly being violated by anti-Soviet rebels and by smugglers, and hundreds of border guards fell in battle.

headline: CHILLING SPECTER AT CONTINENTAL
abstract: A    CHILL ran through the banking world last   week. An event that had haunted millions of   Americans old enough to know about the bank failures of the Depression years nearly happened in Chicago - a major American bank, the nation's eighth largest, almost failed.    Only the Government's unprecedented decision last Thursday to pay out billions of dollars to keep the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company afloat saved the venerable institution. Washington's dramatic action - a guarantee to fully repay all Continental's creditors and depositors - seemed at week's end to have stopped a run on deposits that had sucked billions of dollars from the Midwest's dominant bank.    The fear throughout the financial community, and at the White House itself, was that if the run on Continental were not stopped, and stopped cold, the contagion would have spread to other banks as well, threatening the entire financial system and perhaps plunging the world into another deep economic depression.

headline: Public Workers in Peru Vow to Stay on Strike
abstract: Striking civil servants and teachers said today that they would continue a week-old strike in defiance of a state of emergency declared by the Government of President Fernando Belaunde Terry.   Union leaders announced they would stage sit-ins and hold mass hunger strikes to press for higher pay and to protest the state of emergency.

headline: Israeli Foreign Debt Up
abstract: Israel's foreign debt rose 8 percent, to $22.5 billion, at the end of 1983, from $20.8 billion at the end of 1982, Israel radio said today. Bank of Israel officials could not be reached for comment, but Israel television said the increase was mainly in Government debt.

headline: O.A.S. TO STUDY DISCLOSURES ABOUT EX-CHIEF'S EXTRA PAY
abstract: The Organization of American States agreed today to investigate whether its former Secretary General acted improperly in going to work for a public relations company three months before he stepped down from the O.A.S.   The decision came five days after The Washington Post disclosed that Alejandro Orfila of Argentina, whose resignation from his O.A.S. post became effective last Saturday, had joined Gray & Company on Jan. 1 with a $300,000-a-year contract.   Mr. Orfila has tried to soften the impact of The Post disclosure by apologizing to the organization's permanent council and by agreeing to return almost $22,000, the amount he received in his last three months in office at the O.A.S.   But at the meeting today no one defended the Argentine diplomat and all agreed The Post disclosures should be investigated. The permanent council, made up of the organization's 32 representatives, will carry out the investigation, acting as a general committee.

headline: NESTLE IN TALKS ON A PURCHASE
abstract: Coopervision Inc., which last week introduced a new extended-wear contact lens, said yesterday that it was having talks with Nestle S.A. and Nestle's Alcon Laboratories about the possible acquisition of Coopervision for about $500 million.     The Menlo Park, Calif., producer of drugs, devices and diagnostics used in ophthalmology and optometry, said Nestle had proposed to acquire all of Coopervision's more than 20 million shares at $25 each.   Coopervision announced its discussions with Nestle after rumors of Nestle's ''price talk'' apparently reached the market last week, said Robert D. Mahoney Jr., vice president and treasurer. Coopervision stock, traded on the New York Stock Exchange, rose from $15.75 a share on April 16 to $17.375 last Thursday, and then rose another $5 yesterday, to $22.375. Markets were closed Friday.

headline: RATES UP ON TREASURY ISSUES
abstract: Interest rates for Treasury securities rose yesterday, reflecting weak investor demand for notes and bonds as well as concern among traders that short-term rates might come under upward pressure in the near future.     Prices were stable to slightly higher at the opening, but dealers said there was not enough investor buying to sustain any sizable advances. With few buyers, an increase in the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market to a high of 11 1/4 percent was the catalyst for a quick decline in note and bond prices.    By late in the day, the 13 1/4 percent bonds due in 2014 were offered at 97 1/2, to yield 13.60 percent, down 7/8 point on the day. The new 12 5/8 percent two- year Treasury notes, which were auctioned at an average yield of 12.68 percent, declined in price enough to raise the offered yield to 12.74 percent in late trading.

headline: European Steel Output
abstract: Orders are picking up in the European Community's steel industry, but output is still low and job losses continue unabated, according to new figures from Eurostat, the community's statistical organization.

headline: WEST GERMANY'S FEARFUL TOOLMAKERS
abstract: Efforts in the United States to limit imports of machine tools have created a mood of anxiety in West Germany's powerful machine-tool industry, and that mood has been exacerbated by recent American moves toward protectionism in steel and copper.    Last year, the United States was the West German industry's third- biggest customer, after the Soviet Union and France, despite a collapsing market that caused sales there to plummet nearly 28 percent.   Industry experts say an American curb on machine-tool imports could seriously jolt the European industry and cut off any recovery before it takes hold. Moreover, some believe that import limits could cause a further deterioration in Atlantic economic relations, already strained over steel, farm products and the exchange of industrial technology.

headline: REAGAN PROPOSAL IS CALLED POLITICS
abstract: Administration officials characterized President Reagan's proposal today to discuss a pledge against using force in Europe with the Soviet Union as a serious exercise in public diplomacy and politics.    They said the audiences for the proposal were Western Europeans and Americans who have grown skeptical about Mr. Reagan's desire for real give-and-take negotiations.   The officials said that convincing Western audiences and getting their backing was the best way to convince Soviet leaders to return to the nuclear bargaining tables they abandoned late last year.   They noted that the proposal was Moscow's own, made early this year at the 35-nation East-West conference in Stockholm. They said Soviet diplomats had been saying privately that the proposal was important and that the Soviet-American relationship would be seen in a different light if Washington responded favorably.

headline: Margeotes/Fertitta Names a Chairman
abstract: The principals of Margeotes/Fertitta & Weiss Inc., an agency with more than $20 million in billings, have moved up a notch to make room for three new vice presidents.    John Margeotes, the 59-year-old president of the agency, was named chairman and chief executive officer.

headline: Envoy From Nicaragua Expelled by Honduras
abstract: Honduras today declared the Nicaraguan Ambassador persona non grata and gave him 48 hours to leave the country in a further deterioration of relations between the neighboring Central American nations.   The Honduran Foreign Minister, Edgardo Paz Barnica, said the expulsion of Ambassador Edwin Zablah was in retaliation for Nicaragua's shooting down of a Honduran helicopter on Tuesday over Nicaraguan territory.

headline: U.S. SALES LIGHT THIS WEEK
abstract: No Treasury auctions are scheduled this week, except for the regular Monday auction of three- and six- month bills. Elsewhere in the credit markets, the supply of tax-exempt issues is modest, and investment bankers said the supply of corporate issues might increase.    Late Friday, the outstanding three- month Treasury bill was bid at 9.76 percent, while the six-month issue was at 9.82 percent. Securities dealers said the size of Treasury bill auctions might be briefly reduced to less than $12 billion in future weeks, because the Treasury is flush with cash from tax payments and because a cut in borrowings could provide breathing room for future borrowings until Congress raises the debt ceiling.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: SATURDAY, JUNE 16, 1984   The Economy    Industrial production rose only 0.4 percent in May, the slimmest advance since November. Economists and the White House said the figure indicated a welcome slowing of the economy to levels that can be sustained. (Page 1.)   The Producer Price Index was unchanged in May . Overall prices actually declined very slightly, but the change was too small to register in the rounded-off official figures. Food prices fell at the steepest rate in nearly two years, but energy costs rose. (29.)

headline: Marble Hill's Effect on Net;  Marble Hill's Effect on Net
abstract: The Public Service Company of Indiana Inc. indicated yesterday that this year's earnings would drop to about $1 a share, from $4.46 in 1983. The decline would reflect the company's decision, still unofficial, to halt construction on the Marble Hill nuclear power plant.

headline: DUTCH MISSILE STAND TROUBLING U.S.
abstract: Although top officials are saying the opposite in private, the Reagan Administration has adopted a public stand of insisting that the NATO alliance will suffer no damage if the Netherlands declines to allow deployment of new American medium-range missiles.   Senior State Department and Defense Department officials have conceded in private talks in recent weeks that if the Dutch rejected NATO plans for deploying 48 nuclear-armed cruise missiles by 1986 - the Dutch share of a NATO total of 572 Pershing 2 and cruise missiles - the result could be serious problems for the alliance as a whole.   A high State Department official said Monday in private that Dutch refusal to accept deployment, although of minor signficance by itself, could stimulate antinuclear movements in Britain, Italy and West Germany - where deployment has begun - to curb or limit future deployments.   Pressure on Belgium Foreseen    Such a move could throw into doubt the alliance's ability to carry out plans for installation of all 572 missiles. In addition, the official said, pressure might grow in Belgium to persuade the Government to block deployment of 48 cruise missiles allotted to that country.

headline: 14 Salvadoran Sailors Are Killed in Ambush
abstract: Leftist rebels killed 14 Government sailors in an ambush in the swampy lowlands of southeastern El Salvador, a military spokesman said today.

headline: A KOREAN 'FIRES' TOY PISTOL AT THE POPE
abstract: A young man ''fired'' a toy pistol at the car of Pope John Paul II this morning near Seoul Cathedral and was immediately overpowered by the police.    The Pope saw the incident but appeared to be unperturbed by it.   The Rev. Roberto Tucci, head of the Vatican radio and the official who arranges papal travel, said the man had stepped out from the crowd a few paces to the right of the car, brandishing a toy gun.   Father Tucci said he heard a pop or two and then saw the man throw the toy gun to the ground, breaking it. He made a threatening gesture at the shocked crowd and was then seized by the police and thrown into a van.

headline: U.S. STEEL POSTS PROFIT IN QUARTER
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, yesterday reported a profit of $171 million in the first quarter, but the Bethelehem Steel Corporation, No. 2, said it had a loss of $54.6 million.     U.S. Steel turned in ''a very good performance and dramatic turnaround from last year,'' said James N. Rudolph, an analyst at Wertheim & Company, while Bethlehem's report was ''disappointing but not discouraging.''   The results put steel at a ''takeoff point,'' said another analyst, Edward F. Carroll of Gintel & Company. Major cost factors are behind the industry, Mr. Carroll said, and leaders of the two big steel companies cited the success of their moves to modernize and cut costs.

headline: The U.N. Today May 10, 1984
abstract: SECURITY COUNCIL   Meets on Cyrpus at 10:30 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on Strategy for the Third Development Decade - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL   Social Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: ISRAEL SAID TO NAME PANEL ON 4 HIJACKERS
abstract: Defense Minister Moshe Arens was said today to have appointed a commission to investigate the deaths of the four Palestinians who hijacked an Israeli bus two weeks ago. The report came amid accumulating evidence that at least one of the hijackers was captured alive and killed later.    There was no formal announcement of the panel's creation. An official here in a position to know said the members included experienced military and intelligence people. The official said the panel was to be headed by a former army general, Meir Zorea, who was on the commission that investigated Israel's unpreparedness for the 1973 war. He recently retired as Comptroller of the Defense Ministry.

headline: POTENTIAL BUYERS CITE POOR CONTINENTAL LOANS
abstract: Potential purchasers of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company who have begun poring over its books said yesterday that the condition of the giant Chicago bank was much worse than they had expected.     The most likely buyers, mainly other banks, have received three volumes of material from Goldman, Sachs & Company, Continental's investment banker, which has been charged with seeking a buyer.    David G. Taylor, chairman and chief executive officer of both the bank and its corporate parent, the Continental Illinois Corporation, said in a letter to his staff yesterday that the bank's primary objective is to find a long-term solution to its problems that would allow it to continue as an independent organization.   ''The search for a solution that will avoid our merging with another institution is our No. 1 priority,'' he said.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Western Default
abstract: The Western Preferred Corporation said that it is in default on an $82.5 million bank loan and that its 1983 financial statement has been qualified by its accountants, Peat Marwick.

headline: U.S. NEWS IS SOLD TO ZUCKERMAN
abstract: U.S. News & World Report Inc. and Mortimer Zuckerman announced today that the 47-year-old Boston real estate developer, who is also the publisher and owner of The Atlantic, had bought the weekly news magazine and the company's other properties for $168.5 million, or about $2,800 a share.    Mr. Zuckerman, appearing with U.S. News executives at a news conference at the magazine's headquarters here, said the sale was subject to approval by the company's 300 employees, who are stockholders through a profit-sharing plan.    However, the vote, probably to be held in the fall, is unlikely to block the sale because most of the company's shares are controlled by top editors and managers. That group, acting as directors of the company, has already approved Mr. Zuckerman's bid.

headline: Tax Fraud Conviction
abstract: A Federal jury yesterday found four top executives of two Wall Street securities firms guilty of conspiring to provide more than $130 million in fraudulent income tax write-offs for show business celebrities, bankers and business executives. It was unable to reach a verdict on charges against a fifth defendant.    The jury had heard the testimony of 22 Government witnesses against Sentinel Government Securities and Sentinel Financial Instruments during the five-week trial. The companies are no longer trading.

headline: DISCREPANCIES SEEN IN INDIA'S REPORT ON SIKH RAID
abstract: The body of Jarnail Singh Bhindranwale, the militant Sikh leader killed last week during an army assault on the Golden Temple, contained 14 bullet wounds, including six in the head, according to autopsy reports from Punjab quoted today in the newspaper Indian Express.   The paper's dispatch from Chandigarh, capital of Punjab and the neighboring state of Harayana, appeared to contradict an account given to foreign reporters Thursday by generals in Amritsar, site of the battle.   One of the generals said the radical Sikh leader had suffered a severe head wound but appeared to have no other injuries. The general added, however, that the final definitive word would come from the autopsy.

headline: Couple Held In Fraud Case
abstract: A husband and wife who leased a seat on the New York Futures Exchange and operated a commodity trading pool were charged yesterday with engaging in fraudulent securities operations.   The couple, Michael Edward and Trudy Monica Charrier, both 38 years old, were charged with conducting a so-called boiler room operation that, according to State Attorney General Robert Abrams, resulted in losses of more than $300,000 to an undisclosed number of investors around the country.

headline: Careers; Computer's Importance In Auditing
abstract: THE accountant of tomorrow will    have to be a computer expert.   And ''tomorrow'' is already here, in the view of Peter R. Scanlon, chairman of Coopers & Lybrand, one of the Big Eight accounting firms.   ''This need presents a challenge that the profession and academia must repond to quickly and imaginatively,'' he said at a special meeting yesterday with accounting professors and the press.

headline: PUNJAB SOLUTION NOW SEEN AS FAR OFF
abstract: A solution to the issues at the heart of the crisis in Punjab appears far off, according to politicians and political scientists.   Negotiations over the demands of the Akali Dal, the Sikh political party that started the agitation for greater autonomy in Punjab in 1982, seem to be in limbo.   Some say they believe the raid on the Golden Temple in Amritsar, the holiest shrine of the Sikh religion, has transformed the situation, leaving the Akali demands and the negotiations all but irrelevant for the time being.   Questions have been raised about both the future influence and personal status of Harchand Singh Longowal, the Akali leader who was arrested in the Indian Army raid on the temple on June 5-6. The Government says nearly 600 people were killed in the action, but other reports put the figure at 1,000 or more.

headline: Pope Assails Pornography
abstract: Pope John Paul II denounced what he called an increase in pornography today and warned against sex in movies.

headline: 2 White South Africans Killed by Bomb in Angola
abstract: A South African white woman who opposed the country's racial policies was killed Thursday by a parcel bomb that exploded after being delivered to her home in Angola, the woman's father said today. Her 6-year-old daughter was also killed.   Jack Curtis, father of the woman, Janette Schoon, said in a telephone interview from his home near here that Mrs. Schoon, 35, and her daughter, Katryn, died in the blast in Lubango in southwestern Angola.

headline: Kodak to Cut Jobs
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company said it planned to eliminate 80 jobs by June 29, mostly in communications and publications groups in Rochester. The company said that most of the reduction would be in the marketing area, and that employees would be offered voluntary separation or retirement options. It said it would notify affected employees starting June 25.

headline: THE SHIFT TO SMALLER INVENTORIES; LESS STOCKPILING, MORE STABILITY
abstract: ALTHOUGH the current recovery  has been normal in most respects, the behavior of business inventories represents a radical departure from prior postwar business cycles. Such a change may not be bad for the economy. In fact, it could eventually lead to slower, more stable economic growth.   While recessions are characterized by business selling off its inventories, recoveries are normally led by business restocking the shelves. This leads to an inventory buildup at the bottom of a recession that propels the initial surge of economic growth. But this time, consumer spending generated most of the growth during the first year of the recovery, while inventories declined to record lows relative to sales.

headline: Elephant Kills Its Handler
abstract: A circus elephant killed one of its handlers during a training exercise and was put to death, the Austria Press Agency reported today. The Austrian National Circus was rehearsing in the resort of Badgastein on Tuesday when a 20-year-old Indian elephant charged Mohammed Harmzi and fatally injured him, the report said.

headline: The Outlook After Trudeau
abstract: A sense is emerging here that many of the bitter disputes between government and business that characterized the past decade are over. And that is likely to affect the business relationships between Canada and the United States as well.    Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau has announced his resignation, and when he leaves many of his economic nationalist and social interventionist policies are expected to go with him. An election is expected this year.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Standardizing Of Computers    Government and industry officials agreed today to   help set international standards to allow computers made   by different companies to communicate with each other.

headline: Internorth Files For Debt Offering
abstract: Internorth Inc. said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the possible offering of up to $300 million of debt securities.

headline: CHERNENKO AFFIRMS SOVIET STAND ON REVIVING THE U.S. ARMS TALKS
abstract: Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, said in a statement today that the United States had yet to make a concrete gesture to back up its professed yearning for a discussion with the Soviet Union.   In a reply to an appeal from the Socialist International, a grouping of Western parties, urging a resumption of arms talks, Mr. Chernenko restated the position that the United States was seeking military superiority and had to demonstrate its readiness for talks.   ''We share the viewpoint, expressed in your appeal, that it is necessary to work for a change in a better direction,'' he said in his statement, which was published by the Soviet press agency Tass. ''Yes, a dialogue is necessary, including, of course, one between the Soviet Union and the United States.

headline: 'Irreversible Coma' Reported For Italy's Communist Chief
abstract: The condition of the Communist Party leader, Enrico Berlinguer, who had a cerebral hemorrhage on Thursday, worsened today and doctors gave him no chance of recovery.

headline: Epson Introduces 2d Lap Computer
abstract: Epson America Inc. introduced a $995 notebook-sized computer, called the Geneva PX-8, that weighs four pounds and includes several programs etched on chips that can be plugged into the machine.

headline: EXPANSION IN U.S. CITED BY EUROPEAN FINANCIER
abstract: Sir James Goldsmith, the peripatetic financier who owns, among other things, Grand Union Stores and the Diamond International Corporation in the United States and L'Express, a weekly news magazine in France, wants more.    After accumulating shares for three months, Sir James announced last week that he intended to acquire the Continental Group for $2.4 billion. Meanwhile, Continental - formerly Continental Can - indicated it would oppose a takeover, especially if it involved selling off assets, something Sir James has done in past acquisitions.

headline: Riggs-AP Bank
abstract: Riggs National Bank has completed its acquisition of AP Bank Ltd. of London from Norwich Union Life Insurance Society of Norwich, England, for $34.6 million, officials announced.

headline: Washington Watch; Continental Deal Expected
abstract: WASHINGTON    A LTHOUGH two big bank holding companies have renounced any interest in buying the ailing Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, Federal banking officials insist that a rescue deal will be worked out by the end of July.   Either the bank will have a new owner, presumably another bank, or it will be broken up and sold to several other banks, the officials said.    A Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation official said that the agency has two dozen examiners in Chicago preparing for the moment when it will ''have to structure a transaction.'' They have been appraising the bank's loans and other assets.

headline: BROAD S.E.C. INQUIRY ON JOURNAL WRITER REPORTED
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission appears to be conducting a wide-ranging investigation into illicit profits from securities trading based on information improperly provided by a reporter at The Wall Street Journal.     The inquiry was disclosed last week by The Journal and was the subject of a remarkable page 1 account in yesterday's issue of the newspaper, detailing what apparently was the most extensive breach of ethics in recent financial journalism.    The article described dealings between the reporter, R. Foster Winans, who was dismissed last Wednesday, and stockbrokers that may have affected trading in the shares of 21 companies.    It also described at length a homosexual relationship between Mr. Winans, 35 years old, and a former Wall Street Journal news clerk who was characterized as a key figure in the episode. The Journal said that both men had been interviewed by the S.E.C.  last week.

headline: Dow Rises by 1.25; Trading Slow
abstract: Stock prices ended with minor changes yesterday in much slower trading following their sharp losses on Friday when fears of rising interest rates depressed the list.    The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 1.25 points, to 1,166.56, after moving in a narrow trading range throughout the session. In the general market, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored those that rose by 812 to 758.

headline: Call for Alliance Splits an Anti-Sandinista Group
abstract: The leaders of a Nicaraguan insurgent group here are split over demands reportedly made indirectly by the United States that they form an alliance with rebels based in Honduras.   An advertisement published in Costa Rican newspapers this week denounced pressure "by dark forces" as hysterical. It was signed by three of the six directors of the anti-Sandinista Revolutionary Democratic Alliiance, among them Eden Pastora Gomez, its military chief.

headline: I.B.M.'S PROBLEMS WITH JUNIOR
abstract: So how did I.B.M.'s Peanut go wrong?     In the computer industry, explanations abound for why sales of I.B.M.'s smallest computer, the PCjr, are off to a disappointing start. But one theory gaining particular currency holds that the International Business Machines Corporation, the master of marketing, may have made a serious mistake by designing the Peanut for the $800-to-$1,600 price range.    At that price, some analysts say, the machine is too expensive for casual home users, but, at the same time, is not nearly powerful enough for serious computer users who can afford a more capable machine. Thus, they say, the machine is betwixt and between, at once too much and not enough.

headline: DAUNTING JOB FOR DUARTE
abstract: As President of El Salvador, Jose Napoleon Duarte will have to balance his own ideas of democracy and increasing the power of the civilian Government with the task of calming suspicions held by some private citizens and the armed forces that his efforts will rob them of wealth and power.    To many Americans, Mr. Duarte is known as a moderate political leader. In the context of American politics he would be considered centrist.   However, in El Salvador, Mr. Duarte has been an iconoclastic political leader who for decades has fought against the traditional power of the armed forces and the landed class.

headline: BRITAIN TELLS UNESCO IT MIGHT FOLLOW U.S. AND DECIDE TO QUIT
abstract: Britain has presented the Unesco Director General, Amadhou-Mahtar M'Bow of Senegal, with proposals for changing the body, warning that it may follow the example of the United States, which is threatening to leave the organization.   In a letter delivered to the Director General Thursday and made public later, the British Overseas Development Minister, Timothy Raison, said the British Government considered withdrawing from Unesco last year when it reviewed its policy toward the world body.

headline: Revised Offer Made For Scott & Fetzer
abstract: A group led by Ivan Boesky, the Wall Street arbitrager, said today that it had modified its offer to acquire the Scott & Fetzer Company, dropping two conditions objected to by the company.   The Boesky group said the offer would be for $60 a share, or about $420 million, the same amount as an earlier offer.

headline: ;  Son Succeeds Father As Best Products' Head
abstract: Andrew M. Lewis, 38, has been named to succeed his father, Sydney Lewis, as chairman and chief executive officer of the Best Products Company.    Sydney Lewis will remain chairman of the board's executive committee.

headline: People
abstract: *  Joseph P. Mack and  Allen Banks, executive vice presidents of Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, named to the newly created positions of director of account management and director of marketing services, respectively.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Woody Allen Files Suit Over a Look-Alile Ad
abstract: The comedian and fim maker Woody Allen filed a $10 million dollar suit against a look-alike actor and the company that hired him for its advertising campaign.

headline: PENSION BILL SPLIT HOUSE COMMITTEE
abstract: Representative Matthew J. Rinaldo says that when he had to choose between gender-free insurance tables and what he saw as a way to continue lower car insurance premiums for women, he voted for the latter.     His choice put him at odds with some women's groups, but it is what the women in his northern New Jersey district wanted, said Mr. Rinaldo, a six-term Republican.   That difficult political decision was one of several made in the House Energy and Commerce Committee last week when it drafted Congress's first ''unisex'' insurance bill to apply a Supreme Court decision. The Court ruled in 1983 that paying women smaller monthly pensions than men was illegal.

headline: 2 Freed Soviet Soldiers To Stay in Switzerland
abstract: Two Soviet soldiers who were captured by guerrillas in Afghanistan were freed after two years of internment in Switzerland today, but they decided not to return to the Soviet Union, the Swiss Foreign Ministry said.   A third Soviet soldier, who was also freed today, left Zurich on a flight to Moscow.

headline: Military Contracts
abstract: The Newport News Shipbuilidng and Drydock Company, a unit of Tenneco Inc., received a $104.2 million Navy contract to overhaul the submarine Tecumseh, the Defense Department said. In addition, it said the Army gave the Brunswick Corporation's Defense division a $43.8 million contract for 762 shelters.

headline: Texaco Eurobond
abstract: Texaco Inc. issued $500 million of 11 3/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 1994 at par in the Eurobond market, the company announced yesterday. Last month the company issued $1 billion of a convertible Eurobond. Guaranteed by Texaco, the bonds are issued through the company's subsidiary in the Netherlands Antilles, Texaco Capital N.V. The bonds will be convertible into 20 shares of Texaco common stock for each $1,000 par value, or $50 a share.

headline: U.S. Couple Kidnapped By Sri Lanka Rebels
abstract: Eight armed insurgents kidnapped an American couple in northern Sri Lanka today and reportedly threatened to kill them unless the Government here paid a ransom of $2 million and freed 20 imprisoned rebels.   ''You have only 72 hours to comply with our demands,'' a ransome note said, according to the National Security Minister, Lalith Athulathmudali.

headline: Military Contracts
abstract: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation won a total of $227.9 million in seven Navy contracts, all for support of F-18 aircraft, the Defense Department said. The department also said General Dynamics won $107.9 million from the Navy for ship missile production.

headline: IMPERIAL OIL'S NEW STRATEGY
abstract: Imperial Oil Ltd., the biggest energy company in Canada, seems to be trying to take most of the chance out of one of the chanciest businesses in the world.     ''I hope I haven't left you with the impression that our sporting blood has turned to water,'' Donald K. McIvor, Imperial's chairman, said almost apologetically toward the end of a recent interview.   Imperial, a unit of the Exxon Corporation, does appear to have adopted a decidedly unglamorous strategy. Still, it is a strategy that analysts consider certain to increase the company's oil production by about half over the next four years, to some 220,000 barrels a day, while the industry's drops by a fifth.

headline: PROFITS UP SHARPLY IN FIRST QUARTER
abstract: SUSAN CHIRA    Corporate profits increased dramatically in the first quarter, with steel one of the few industries clouding the picture.   The gains occurred in almost every sector of the economy. Of 286 companies surveyed by The New York Times, 223 reported an increase in earnings from a year earlier, with the strongest showings posted by automobiles, chemicals, forest products and energy.

headline: Smaller Wheeling Loss
abstract: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation today reported that it had narrowed its loss in the first quarter to $4.9 million, from $23.9 million a year earlier. Wheeling-Pittsburgh, the nation's eighth-largest steel producer, said sales increased 49.9 percent, to $258.9 million, from $172.7 million, as shipments jumped 76.9 percent, to 594,282 tons, from 335,975 tons.

headline: EXILED HONDURAN CHIEF ASKS TO RETURN HOME
abstract: The ousted chief of the Honduran armed forces asked permission today to return home, asserting that he was removed unconstitutionally from the country in handcuffs, according to a congressional official.   The official said Gen. Gustavo Alvarez Martinez had made the request in a letter sent to the Congress.

headline: THE TRIP TO PEKING: BENEFITS ALL AROUND
abstract: For President Reagan, the journey to Peking this week offers an opportunity to serve the nation's interests by strengthening American ties with China as well as a chance to enhance his own bid for re- election by casting himself as a negotiator for peace.  As the Reagan entourage crosses the Pacific Ocean, Administration officials are conveying an air of restrained but expectant optimism. There is ebullient talk about ''a new era'' of Chinese-American relations, reminiscent not so much of the uncharted opening that President Nixon created in China 12 years ago as it is of Mr. Nixon's effort later in 1972 to draw the Soviet Union into a less menacing relationship with the lure of mutually profitable economic partnership and political parity.    Since the Chinese no longer favor open military cooperation nor drop hints about a link to the Atlantic alliance, as some Chinese did five years ago, the Americans are not pressing this time for a strategic partnership with China.

headline: South Africa's Ruling Party Loses to Right in Rural Vote
abstract: The governing National Party lost a key provincial by-election today to a right-wing coalition but strengthened its majority in another.   The Conservative Party won Potgietersrus, an Afrikaner rural district, in an alliance with the far-rightist Herstigte Nasionale party and the neo-fascist Afrikaner Weerstandbeweging.

headline: Libyan Demonstrators Back Qaddafi's Regime
abstract: A Government spokesman said tens of thousands of demonstrators turned out in support of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi today, two days after an attack aimed at the Libyan leader failed.

headline: Coleco in Private Debt Placement
abstract: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., May 9 (Reuters) Coleco Industries said it had placed privately $29 million of 10 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 1989, and said its board had authorized the issuance of an additional $21 million in similar debentures.   Proceeds will be used for working capital purposes, the company said.

headline: Some Immunity in Navy Case
abstract: P. Takis Veliotis, a Greek-American accused of defrauding the United States Navy while a vice president of the General Dynamics Corporation, has been granted immunity from prosecution in connection with statements he made to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, a lawyer said today.   Mr. Veliotis still faces fraud charges, according to Peter Makris, an associate of Mr. Veliotis's Greek lawyer, Alexandros Lykourezos.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Schrafft Ice Cream Co. to Romann & Tannenholz.     * Karabelas Furs to AC&R Advertising.

headline: Avon Stock Plan
abstract: Avon Products Inc. said it might use proceeds from the planned sale of Tiffany & Company to purchase up to 10 million shares of its common stock, make acquisitions, reduce debt or support existing business.

headline: Texas Federal Acquisition Talks
abstract: The Texas Federal Financial Corporation said it is involved in talks with several companies regarding its possible acquisition.

headline: CALMLY, THE CANADIENS, TOO, ARE CHOOSING A CHIEF
abstract: The campaign to choose a new leader of the Liberal Party to succeed Pierre Elliott Trudeau is more than two-thirds over, and compared with the fight for the Democratic Presidential nomination in the United States it has been a quiet and decorous affair.   The Canadian contest officially opened on Feb. 29, when Prime Minister Trudeau announced his intention to resign after more than 15 years as national leader and head of the party.   It will end at a three-day convention in Ottawa starting June 14 when party delegates, most of them chosen by local organizations, gather to choose one of the seven men in the race. The victor will then take over as Prime Minister, at least until he leads the party into national elections that are expected later this year.

headline: Leading Sikh Cleric Is Slain; Killing Is Linked to Militants
abstract: Three gunmen today killed the former head priest of the Sikh religion.

headline: Iran Says It Repulsed Effort By Iraq to Retake Marsh Area
abstract: Iraqi forces in boats and helicopters attacked the Majnoon Islands on Sunday but were driven back, Iran's official press agency reported today.   The agency, monitored here, gave no further details of the attempt to recapture the marshland islands, which Iran seized in February.   Iraq issued a communique today saying its helicopters and combat patrols attacked Iranians along the southern and central sections of the border, killing 25 of the defenders.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
abstract: Occidental Petroleum In 2d April Financing    The Occidental Petroleum Corporation, in its second major financing of the month, is offering 700,000 units consisting of notes, stock and warrants at a price of $1,000 a unit through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert. The financing will further reduce the debt incurred by Occidental when it bought the Cities Service Company in 1982.

headline: QADDAFI OFFERS INQUIRY TEAM TO LONDON
abstract: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, said today that he was willing to send an inquiry team to question the occupants of the besieged Libyan Embassy here about the incident Tuesday that resulted in the death of a policewoman and the wounding of 10 protesters, the BBC reported tonight.    Colonel Qaddafi was quoted as having said at a news conference in Tripoli that any Libyans involved could be taken back to Libya and tried there before international observers, the BBC said. But he insisted that no Libyans in the embassy were armed and said the British Government should investigate the activities of the police and of the demonstrators outside the embassy.

headline: PRESIDENT ASSERTS HE WOULD DISCUSS NONUSE OF FORCE
abstract: President Reagan told the Irish Parliament today that he would be willing to discuss with the Soviet Union the possibility of a NATO renunciation of the use of force if Moscow would agree to a specific set of measures to limit the risk of military confrontation in Europe.   The Soviet Union has been calling for a declaration on the nonuse of force at the East-West conference in Stockholm.    The United States, Mr. Reagan said, wanted to ''reach out'' to the Soviet Union to reduce world tensions. He also said the United States backed the forces ''struggling for freedom'' in Central America.   Leaves Ireland for London    ''If discussions on reaffirming the principle not to use force, a principle in which we believe so deeply, will bring the Soviet Union to negotiate agreements which will give concrete new meaning to that principle, we will gladly enter into such discussions,'' Mr. Reagan said.

headline: A SHIFT IN POWER AT HUGHES
abstract: Six years of intense and often bitter litigation for control of the Hughes Aircraft Company ended yesterday when a Delaware court named eight people as trustees of the Howard Hughes Medical Institute, the sole shareholder of the giant company.    The most significant issue facing the trustees is what to do with Hughes Aircraft, one of the nation's largest aerospace and military contractors, with sales last year of $4.9 billion and an orders backlog of more than twice that much, or $10.9 billion.    Parts or all of the company could be sold to another company or to the public with a stock offering. It could also be retained by the medical institute, but that seems unlikely in view of questions that the Internal Revenue Service has raised about the relationship between Hughes Aircraft and the institute.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: MONDAY, MAY 14, 1984   The Economy    Third world debt problems are provoking more serious concern. One reason for the new urgency is that the mounting debt, particularly in Latin America, is compounded by rising U.S. interest rates. Among the solutions under study are a cap on interest rates and a move to more multiyear loan agreements. (Page A1.)

headline: TAX-REPEAL PLAN IGNITES INTERNATIONAL DISPUTE
abstract: An international spat is taking place on Capitol Hill among investment bankers from both sides of the Atlantic, the Treasury Department and the Netherlands Antilles as Congressional tax writers consider repeal of a 30 percent withholding tax on foreign investors. The jostling is not just across oceans but among factions on Wall Street as well.     If the tax writers include the repeal in the larger tax bill now being shaped in a House-Senate conference, much of the business of issuing and selling American bonds to foreign investors could be done directly from New York. The business is now largely conducted through the Antilles and Europe, the circuitous route that American corporations use to nullify the impact of the tax for the foreign investors.

headline: PRIVATE BANKS RESUME ALL BUT LATIN LENDING
abstract: Private Western banks have resumed voluntary lending to many nations in the developing world, with the notable exception of those in Latin America, the Bank for International Settlements reported today.     This selective resumption of lending suggests that the international debt crisis is no longer the major threat to world economic recovery that it appeared to be a year or so ago, according to Western economic officials familiar with the new study made by the bank.    A year ago the settlements bank and other economic authorities feared that Latin America's inability to repay debt might lead to a general cutoff of private bank lending to the developing world. Such action, they warned, would produce a sharp contraction in international trade that could undermine the general recovery getting under way.

headline: POPE ENDORSES A PROPOSAL FOR NUCLEAR ARMS FREEZE
abstract: Pope John Paul II today endorsed a six-nation initiative for arms control that calls for a freeze on production of nuclear weapons. The Pope said he hoped the proposal would ''receive wide acceptance and be generously supported by those who have the responsibility for promoting the cause of peace.''   The initiative, sponsored by the leaders of India, Mexico, Tanzania, Sweden, Greece and Argentina, urged the United States, the Soviet Union and other powers to stop producing nuclear weapons and start negotiations for complete disarmament.

headline: Article 226744 -- No Title
abstract: Teledyne Inc., the electronics and manufacturing conglomerate, said yesterday that it would buy back all 8.7 million shares tendered under a $200-a-share offer for its own stock that expired last Friday.    The total cost to the company for the repurchase will be $1.74 billion, making it one of the largest corporate buybacks on record. Earlier this month, the company said it would buy back about 5 million shares for $1 billion.

headline: SEARCHING THE ECONOMY FOR GUIDANCE
abstract: IT was mid-1982 and many analysts thought the economy was on the verge of pulling out of the worst postwar recession. But Bernard Schoenfeld, an economist at the Irving Trust Company, wasn't taken in, not when he saw what was happening to the Government's count of how many people were making first-time applications for unemployment insurance.    ''The claims just shot straight up'' that summer, he recalls, evincing some satisfaction at how well he was served by one of his favorite economic indicators. ''This was the first solid evidence that the recovery wasn't in sight.'' Sure enough, the economy didn't stop sliding until November.    Federal statistics mills grind out such data - on output, employment, prices and a host of other macroeconomic indicators - almost every working day. But while there's never a shortage of professionals to venture opinions of what the figures mean, ordinary consumers and investors often remain confused. They find it hard to convert the torrent of information - and it seems that the more one studies, the more overwhelming the job becomes - to personal financial strategy.

headline: STRICT U.S. RULING TO SLASH PROFITS OF BANKS THAT LENT TO ARGENTINA
abstract: A number of the nation's major banks with loans to Argentina will be required to report substantially lower earnings because of a hotly disputed interpretation of accounting rules by Federal bank regulators.   Although the ruling does not officially become effective until the third quarter, most banks are expected to report their earnings for the second quarter on the basis of it.    The statement in which the strict interpretation of accounting rules is detailed was mailed last Saturday by the Federal Reserve System and the Comptroller of the Currency to chief executive officers of commercial banks across the country.    Some analysts cheered the decision, saying it would help clear the air of doubts about the banking system although the immediate effect would be lower bank earnings.

headline: THE PRISONERS TO BE RELEASED
abstract: Following are lists, provided today by the State Department, of the 22 American inmates and the 26 Cuban political prisoners being freed from Cuban jails, with ages and places of birth. An official said it was not possible to say with certainty if the list of Cubans was accurate.       WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) - Following are lists, provided today by the State Department, of the 22 American inmates and the 26 Cuban political prisoners being freed from Cuban jails, with ages and places of birth. An official said it was not possible to say with certainty if the list of Cubans was accurate.

headline: Debt Ratings
abstract: * Houston Natural Gas debentures, long-term notes and industrial revenue bonds were lowered to A-2 from A-1 by Moody's.     * Pogo Producing Co.'s $60 million convertible subordinated debentures were lowered to B- from BB- by S.&P.     * Texas Oil and Gas Co.  said its first mortgage bonds had been raised to Aa-2 from Aa-3 by Moody's, which also upgraded its single debenture issue to Aa-3 from A-1.      Common Stocks    * Fire Safety Corp.  said it had filed for an initial offering of 600,000 units, each consisting of four common shares and four common stock purchase warrants, through Hickey- Kober Inc.     * Home Centers of America , a retail discount stores business in San Antonio, said it may redeem 2.4 million warrants to buy common stock as early as next Monday, depending on S.E.C. approval and market conditions.

headline: PROVIDENT BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: VENEZUELA'S RULING PARTY SWEEPS LOCAL VOTE
abstract: President Jaime Lusinchi's Democratic Action Party has assured itself of undisputed political control in Venezuela for the next four years with a resounding victory in municipal elections.   Preliminary results today from the Supreme Electoral Council showed the Government party with 46.3 percent of the vote and the opposition Christian Democrats in distant second place with 20.6 percent. Some estimates indicated that Democratic Action's final tally could reach 60 percent.

headline: CGA Accepts Bid
abstract: CGA Computer Inc. said it had agreed in principle to be acquired for $13 a share by Bernard M. Goldsmith 3d, who is its chairman; the General Atlantic Corporation, a private investment company based in New York, and other management investors. Based on CGA's approximately 3.4 million shares, the deal would be valued at $44.2 million. CGA jumped $2, to $11.50 bid, in over-the-counter trading yesterday.

headline: Paris, London Stocks Surge
abstract: The Paris and London stock exchanges hit record highs today, buoyed by strong corporate earnings and optimism that economic recovery was gathering pace.   The Paris Bourse all-share index soared to its fourth record in as many trading days, closing at 181.7.

headline: WEINBERGER DENIES REPORT OF U.S. LATIN COMBAT PLAN
abstract: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the United States had no plans of any kind for the use of United States combat troops in Central America should the current strategy to defeat the leftists fail.    Mr. Weinberger's statement came in response to a television interviewer's question about a report today in The New York Times that top Reagan Administration officials had been drawing up such plans.   The report said the Administration officials involved in the planning included Fred C. Ikle, the Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, and two senior staff officers of the National Security Council.   The Secretary of Defense, speaking on the ABC News program ''This Week,'' denied that plans to use combat troops in Central America were either being drawn up or had already been developed.

headline: Sun Repurchase
abstract: The Sun Company plans to spend about $100 million to repurchase its common shares on the open market or in privately negotiated transactions, it said in its annual report. Over the last three years, Sun said, it has repurchased 9.5 million shares under separate repurchase programs for $358 million.

headline: Metal Strike In Germany
abstract: West German metalworkers began walkouts today called by unions to back demands for a gradual introduction of a 35-hour workweek, five hours shorter than the current workweek.   Hours after the union, IG Metall, called out about 13,000 workers at 14 factories in southern Germany, the Bavarian auto maker BMW announced it would be forced to close four assembly plants beginning Thursday for lack of parts if the strike continued.

headline: The Macintosh In Japan Debut
abstract: The Canon Sales Company introduced Apple Computer's Macintosh at its computer fair in Tokyo today.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: *  Cadbury-Schweppes, the British candy and beverage company, plans to raise at least $75 million in a United States offering of American depository receipts.     * Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corp.  will market a $1,368,000,000 two-part bond issue Wednesday.     * Hartford Steam Boiler Inspection and Insurance Co.  will exchange $43,616,000 of its senior notes and $21,808,000 in cash for 1,090,400 of its outstanding common shares - 556,000 held by Aetna Casualty and Surety and 534,400 by Hartford Insurance Group.

headline: STOCK GROUPS FOR LEADERSHIP
abstract: FOR months now, the stock market has    searched in vain for what Wall Street professionals call group leadership. Instead, investors have been whipsawed by rational favorites - various sectors rising briefly, only to fall again - that have produced profits chiefly for nimble traders with the good fortune to time these movements correctly.   Even in the period between mid-1978 and late 1980, when most stock prices were locked in a trading range, there existed three broad areas of sustained market leadership: energy, precious metals and high technology. Issues in these industries performed handsomely on the inflation-hedge thesis.

headline: Continental Executive In Conticommodity Post
abstract: Walter Goldschmidt yesterday was named president and chief executive officer of Conticommodity Services Inc., the trading arm of the giant Continental Grain Company, which is privately owned.    Mr. Goldschmidt had been president of Conticommodity from 1972 through 1980, before moving into other roles at Continental.

headline: FRANCE AWAITS CONFIDENCE VOTE TODAY
abstract: The Socialist-led Government, trying to force its Communist partners into line on a policy that includes large cuts in the work force, announced today that it had scheduled a vote of confidence in the National Assembly for Thursday.    The vote could lead to the rupture of the Socialist-Communist alliance.   With a clear Socialist majority in the National Assembly, President Francois Mitterrand's control over the legislature cannot be threatened by a Communist vote against Government policy. But rejection or abstention would mean, according to Socialist sources, that Mr. Mitterrand is likely to drop the four Communist ministers from the Cabinet. That would end the cooperation that has functioned since the left came to power in 1981.

headline: Inflation in Sweden
abstract: Swedish industrial executives think the inflation rate in 1985 will reach 7 percent, far exceeding the Government's goal of 3 percent, Dagens Industri, a Swedish business daily, said today. In a survey commissioned by the newspaper, most of 101 executives polled also said they saw an increase in wage costs of 7.8 percent in 1985, well above the 5 percent voluntary cap that the Government is urging unions to accept.

headline: Comecon Talks Begin
abstract: Ten Communist nations today began their first economic summit conference since 1971, with energy supplies believed to be a crucial issue.

headline: EUROPE'S WORRIED REFINERS
abstract: Plagued by overcapacity, uncertain demand and the prospect of new competition from the Middle East, Europe's oil refinery industry is going through a time of profound change.     Some major players, like Gulf Oil, have abandoned the game. Others, like Exxon and Shell, are struggling to cling to market shares by closing unprofitable refineries and spending heavily to build new ones that squeeze more high-value products from every barrel of oil at lower cost.    ''From an industry standpoint, clearly Europe has 30 to 40 percent overcapacity,'' Robert Wilhelm, Exxon's head of refining and marketing, said in London.

headline: ;  Service Merchandising Loses Its President
abstract: James E. Poole, president and chief operating officer of the Service Merchandising Company has announced his resignation from the company after less than a year on the job.     In a statement, Mr. Poole said he would continue to serve as a director of the Nashville-based catalogue showroom company.

headline: MONEY DATA BACKED AS GUAGE
abstract: Weekly announcements of changes in the nation's money supply are still closely watched in the financial markets, but recently traders and investors have been paying more attention to the impetus for higher interest rates that is coming from a rapidly expanding economy, growing credit demands, and increasing scarcity of bank reserves.    Recent increases in interest rates, accompanied by more stingy monetary policy by the Federal Reserve, have come at a time when money supply growth was within target and served to remind investors that the Fed is guided by developments in the real economy, not just money supply.    But money supply is still important enough that many investors look to it for indications of future economic growth and inflation. They also note that the Fed may some day put more empahsis on money supply change than it has recently.

headline: Panel Reaches Accord on Unitary Tax System
abstract: A panel of American business executives and state officials, including three governors, agreed today in principle that much of the income that multinational corporations earn outside the United States should not be subject to state taxes.    The state officials said, however, that such a retreat by state governments must be contingent upon a substantial increase in the number of Internal Revenue Service agents assigned to audit multinational corporations, thereby providing the states with more corporate data.    While the consensus is tentative and subject to entirely voluntary actions by state legislatures in modifying their tax laws, it represents the Administration's best hope for easing what has become an embarrassing issue between the United States and its major trading partners.

headline: Angola Rebels Report Capture of Americans
abstract: Forces of the Angolan rebel movement Unita captured 11 Americans, Portuguese and Colombians during attacks on Angolan Government troops, a spokesman for the rebel group said today.   The rebels also said they killed 210 Angolan soldiers and 30 Cuban troops in battles in four provinces Wednesday, the same day the 11 foreigners were seized.

headline: Steel Import Curb Fought
abstract: Two senior members of the Administration today criticized proposed legislation that would place quotas on steel imports.

headline: Careers; The Early Retirement Programs
abstract: A FEW days ago, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company offered early retirement to most of the 60,000 employees in its information services division,     The company had found that the division was overstaffed, even after eliminating 10,000 jobs last fall through attrition and another early retirement offer. The scope of the offer can be ascertained by relating it to the total current roster of 373,000 workers employed by the new A.T.& T.    Many companies have offered such programs in recent years - Eastman Kodak, Polaroid, Exxon, Xerox, Du Pont, the 3M Company, Alcoa and R. J. Reynolds. In fact, one study found that about 40 percent of the Fortune 500 companies have had early retirement campaigns.        Such campaigns, called ''cordial compulsion'' by one expert, involve people-recycling through the economy on a vast scale.

headline: JAPAN WILL USE FOREIGN VESSELS TO GET GULF OIL
abstract: Japanese petroleum officials said today that because of self-imposed restrictions on Japanese tanker movements in the Persian Gulf, they would begin chartering foreign-manned tankers to carry crude oil to Japan from the Persian Gulf.    Earlier, Japan announced that its ships would stay out of the northern third of the gulf, where commercial ships have been attacked by Iranian and Iraqi forces. The move is expected to reduce oil imports to Japan by about 5 percent. But Government officials here insisted that the effects of today's action would be slight.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. , a company engaged in insurance, has named Robert H. Moore to the new position of vice president of corporate relations.     *  Altex Oil Corp., Denver, has named Jerome C. Martinets Jr. president and chief executive officer, succeeding Cecil C. Wall, who remains chairman.

headline: VAST NETWORK OF AID CALMING DEPOSITORS, CHICAGO BANK SAYS
abstract: The unprecedented $7.5 billion emergency aid package extended by Government agencies and private banks to insure the survival of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company has apparently halted the run on the giant Chicago bank and calmed world financial markets.     ''It's been quiet today and the action seemed to stem the outflow,'' a Continental spokesman said yesterday.   The spokesman also said the rescue package, the largest such package ever assembled by the Government, was used yesterday by the bank, but he declined to elaborate on the amounts.    The package included $2 billion in new capital for the bank and a $5.5 billion line of credit from 28 banks. In addition, the Federal Reserve, the nation's central bank, said it would provide funds to meet daily cash requirements beyond the $7.5 billion commitment.

headline: DOW DROPS 6.07 AMID RATE WORRIES
abstract: Stock prices fell broadly yesterday for the second consecutive session in sluggish trading. Apprehension over rising interest rates continued to depress the list.    In the overall market, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered those that rose by a ratio of more than 2 to 1. On Friday, losers exceeded winners by more than 3 to 1.

headline: EFFECTS OF CUT IN STEEL IMPORTS
abstract: One major steel exporter after the other is curbing its shipments to the United States in response to an intensifying campaign for protection by the domestic industry.  First it was Japan.  Then the 10-nation European Economic Community. Now it is Brazil and Mexico, with South Africa, South Korea and Taiwan in the wings.    The results, analysts said, will be higher profits and more jobs in the domestic steel industry and higher prices for American steel users. Indeed, with the steel industry already operating at more than 80 percent of capacity, many analysts believe prices could begin rising rapidly as the exporters' new self-imposed quotas begin to be felt.

headline: U.N. Says Flow of Refugees From Vietnam Tripled in May
abstract: The number of boat people fleeing Vietnam by sea more than tripled in May from previous months this year, a United Nations spokesman said today.

headline: 4 Nations Hold Votes For Europe Parliament
abstract: Voters in Britain, Ireland, Denmark and the Netherlands cast ballots today in the first of two elections for representatives to the European Parliament.   The elections are seen more as a referendum on the performance of national governments than as statements on issues affecting the whole of Europe.

headline: Dow Slips 1.19 Points; Volume Sharply Lower
abstract: The stock market finished mixed yesterday for the second consecutive session in much slower trading. While most price changes were minor, Teledyne soared 10 points, to 212 1/4, in heavy trading.    The Dow Jones industrial average ended the session off 1.19 points, to 1,131.25, after moving in a narrow range throughout the day. In the general market, advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered those that fell by 759 to 691.

headline: Visicorp Loses Its President
abstract: Daniel H. Fylstra, cofounder and chairman of Visicorp, also assumed the duties of president and chief operating officer yesterday, following the resignation of Terry L. Opdendyk. Mr. Opdendyk, who joined the computer software concern in December 1980, resigned to pursue another business opportunity, Mr. Fylstra said.
