Visicorp, which in 1978 developed Visicalc, a popular business program, has been having difficulties since it was sued last year by its marketer, Software Arts, over ownership of the program.  Mr. Fylstra, 33, said Visicorp, based in San Jose, Calif., is trying to market new products such as a $99 spreadsheet aimed at the casual business user.

headline: MERRILL LYNCH NET OFF 85.3%
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company, following the general downtrend of earnings reported by the leading brokerage houses, announced yesterday that net income in the first quarter plunged 85.3 percent as revenues slipped 2.8 percent.    Last week, the American Express Company, which operates Shearson/ American Express, and three major securities firms, the E.F. Hutton Group Inc., First Boston Inc. and Paine Webber Inc., all reported sharply lower earnings for the quarter ended March 31.   Merrill Lynch, parent of the nation's largest brokerage company, said net income in the period plummeted to $18.6 million, or 21 cents a share, from $126.9 million, or $1.54 a share, a year earlier. Revenues fell to $1.39 billion, from $1.43 billion.

headline: ARGENTINE PARTIES SIGN A PEACE ACCORD
abstract: President Raul Alfonsin and former President Isabel Martinez de Peron signed an accord today that officials called a triumph in Mr. Alfonsin's drive for national unity.   The accord, signed also in a nationally televised ceremony by the leaders of a dozen other parties smaller than the Peronists, sets principles for dealing with a host of issues that have been threatening the country's six-month- old democracy.   Among the principles are that the country should repay its foreign debt, undertake limited economic austerity and use its advancing nuclear technology only for peaceful ends.   The signing came as presidential aides reported that agreement with the International Monetary Fund was expected soon on an austerity plan that would open the way for refinancing Argentina's $45 billion foreign debt.

headline: Finding the Right Buyer For Binney & Smith
abstract: A skilled marketer, Jack F. Kofoed has chalked up a big sale, totaling $203.5 million to be exact.   As chairman and chief executive officer of Binney & Smith Inc., which makes about 1.8 billion Crayola crayons a year, he has negotiated the company's sale to Hallmark Cards.

headline: CARGO LIABILITY RULING HELPS AIRLINE INDUSTRY
abstract: The Supreme Court, in a decision greeted with relief by the airline industry, ruled today that the limits on liability for commercial air cargo established by the major international aviation treaty will remain enforceable in American courts.   The 8-to-1 decision overturned a ruling by the Federal appeals court in New York that the liability limit was no longer enforceable because there is no longer an official price for gold in the United States.   While the case before the Supreme Court involved cargo, the decision was also expected to remove legal questions about the enforceability of existing limits on airlines' financial liability for passengers' lives.

headline: U.N. Panel Meets On Protecting Airliners
abstract: A special assembly of the International Civial Aviation Organization began work today on proposals to try to eliminate the possibility of such incidents as the downing of a South Korean jetliner by the Soviet Union.   ''The purpose of the different proposals presented to this assembly is to embody in the convention a specific provision that states must refrain from resorting to the use of force against civil aircraft,'' said Assad Kotaite of Jordan, who is president of the governing council of the United Nations organization.

headline: TURNOUT LOW, POLES WILL RERUN 85 LOCAL ELECTIONS
abstract: The Polish Government said today that about 75 percent of the 26 million enrolled voters participated in local elections Sunday and that a low turnout required new elections in some areas.   A Government spokesman, Jerzy Urban, said the results of elections to provincial, urban and rural councils had been invalidated in 85 of 23,214 voting districts because less then half the electorate turned out.   In a statement that was later broadcast and televised, Mr. Urban expressed the Government's desire to gain the confidence of many of those who did not vote.   ''For the most part,'' he said, ''these are citizens who maintain their skepticism of our actions, who waver in their appraisals of our policies and remain distrustful or undecided. We want their trust of our policies to grow as fast as possible. The Government knows that we still have to work for that trust and we declare the policy of the extended hand.''

headline: ASSESSING THE SYNFUELS PROGRAM; A CALL FOR LARGE COMMERCIAL PROJECTS
abstract: WHEN synfuels legislation was enacted in 1980, Congress authorized $20 billion (with the potential for another $68 billion) for a crash national program to produce substantial amounts of synthetic oil and gas. Production goals of 500,000 barrels a day of oil equivalent by 1987 and 2.2 million barrels a day by 1992 (more than 25 percent of our current production) were written into the law.   These goals were unrealistic then and are now clearly impossible. With the slack oil market making the large-scale commercial production of synthetic fuels increasingly uneconomical and unnecessary, some people are now calling for an end to the synfuels program. Others suggest it be scaled back to a research program within the Department of Energy.

headline: U.N. CHIEF REBUFFS ISRAEL ON BUFFER FORCE IN LEBANON
abstract: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar today rejected an Israeli proposal that United Nations peacekeeping troops serve as a buffer between Israel and Syrian forces in eastern Lebanon.   ''The U.N. is against anything which would signify directly or indirectly the division of Lebanon,'' he said. ''We want to have Lebanon in the hands of the Lebanese.''

headline: PROTECTING CORPORATE AMERICA AGAINST TERRORISM
abstract: CONTROL Risks Ltd. has a warning for big Los Angeles corporations: Beware of the potential for terrorism during this summer's Olympic Games there.   ''We would not like to exaggerate the threat,'' said Karl D. Ackerman, a director of the London-based company, ''but if anybody is going to seize an event to launch an attack on the U.S., then the Olympics will be a damn good site.''  Mr. Ackerman, a former director of security at the State Department, makes this statement with what sounds like the detachment of a diplomat analyzing a volatile political situation. But that was a former life. These days Mr. Ackerman, a rugged- looking six-footer, is selling hard for Control Risks, a security consulting firm seeking new revenue.

headline: Beirut Factions Ignore A New Truce in Beirut
abstract: Artillery duels and gun battles flared across the Green Line dividing the Moslem and Christian sectors of Beirut tonight and a call for a cease-fire was ignored.

headline: Director Picked in BidTo Complete Seabrook
abstract: Edward A. Brown is moving to New Hampshire soon, but he probably won't have much time for his favorite hobby, skiing.    Instead, Mr. Brown, 54, will be directing the renewed construction of the Seabrook nuclear power plant as chairman and chief executive of New Hampshire Yankee, an organization formed over the weekend to supervise completion of the project.

headline: U.S.-CHINA NUCLEAR PACT HITS SNAGS
abstract: Efforts to reach a nuclear cooperation agreement with China, the centerpiece of President Reagan's trip to Peking, have faltered and a pact is unlikely to be completed this year, Administration and Congressional officials said today.    The officials said that while many issues were unresolved, the basic question was whether China would agree to safeguards intended to accomplish two objectives. One, they said, is to prevent American nuclear technology and fuel produced in American-made reactors from being diverted to Chinese military use, either as warheads or propulsion for warships.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: A $150 million issue of Commonwealth of Massachusetts general obligation bonds was offered yesterday with serial bond yields ranging from 6.50 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 9.50 percent in 1994 and 10.60 percent in 1999, while term bonds due in 2004 were offered with a yield of 10 3/4 percent.    Underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation said the issue had been well received, with only $29 million of bonds remaining unsold late in the day. The bonds are rated A-1 by Moody's and AA by S.& P.    Analysts at Thomson McKinnon Securities said in a recent research report that rapid growth of high-technology and service sectors had brought new vitality to the state's economy and contributed to a general fund surplus of $64.4 million at mid- 1983.

headline: SOUTHERN YEMEN JOINS THE OLYMPIC BOYCOTT ADEN, Southern Yemen, May 26 (Reuters) - Southern Yemen said today that it was joining the Soviet Union and other nations in withdrawing from the Olympic Games in Los Angeles. It was the first Arab nation to join the Soviet-initiated move.
abstract: The Olympic Committee here said in a statement it was boycotting the Games because of ''Olympic violations by the American side and the wild hostility campaign against Soviet athletes and those of socialist states and some developing nations.'' It said such actions endangered the safety of athletes.

headline: MOSCOW HONORS PSYCHIATRIST
abstract: The Soviet Union today honored the nation's leading psychiatrist, who has been accused by the World Psychiatry Association of abusing his science to punish political dissidents.   The psychiatrist, Dr. Andrei V. Snezhnevsky, was given the Order of the October Revolution on his 80th birthday in recognition of his work in medical science and in public health.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: A Surge in Inventories    Manufacturers and merchants are restocking their warehouses and store shelves at a fast pace. Their willingness to increase inventories despite current high financing costs means they are confident they can sell these goods quickly and profitably.    The buildup has been such that when the Government issues its report this Friday on February inventories, it will show a rise of at least eight-tenths of 1 percent, or double the January increase, said Edward E.  Yardeni, chief economist at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.  Equally important, Mr.  Yardeni noted, the inventory-sales ratio for February could rise to 1.33, from 1.30 in January. ''This means,'' he said, ''that many businesses are now more concerned about losing sales because of bare shelves than being caught with expensively financed goods, which was their costly experience during the recent recession.''

headline: BRITAIN'S CO-OP MOVEMENT IN SEARCH OF ITS IDENTITY
abstract: MANCHESTER, ENGLAND     AT the turn of the century, with 56   years behind it, Britain's Co-   operative Movement had every reason to be pleased with its prospects.    With more than 1,400 locally controlled cooperatives offering members food and household goods at reasonable prices - plus a share of the profits based on how much they bought - the loose-knit movement with headquarters here had become a major presence in working-class life. Indeed, from the first successful retail society founded eight miles north of here, Co-operative groups had branched out into manufacturing, farming, banking, insurance, education, and had even formed a political party that was soon to elect representatives to the House of Commons.   But the 20th century has not been easy on the Co-operative Movement. Today, the 1,400 societies have shrunk to 120 - and those that survive are plagued by the desertion of their working-class constituents, lack of central planning and tough new price competition from chain stores.   Indeed, the movement's close association with the Labor Party and the working class has become a mixed blessing at best. As the life style of many workers has improved, their feelings of class solidarity have waned.

headline: Turk Shot in Teheran; Armenians Claim Attack
abstract: A Turkish businessman was shot and critically wounded today in Teheran, Iran, and Armenian militants said they had carried out the attack, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said here.   The attack took place shortly before the Turkish Prime Minister, Turgut Ozal, arrived in the Iranian capital on an official visit.

headline: PANAMA LEADER SEEKS TO CALM ELECTION FRICTIONS
abstract: In the wake of post-election disturbances Monday night that left one person dead and 40 injured, President Jorge Illueca appealed to Panamanians today to remain calm and refrain from further political demonstrations.    Nonetheless, supporters of both presidential candidates rallied in front of their respective headquarters this evening. The vote counting is continuing but both candidates have released unofficial tallies showing them winning the presidency.   By midevening, no clashes had been reported and demonstrators from both parties had begun to disperse. The plaza facing the Legislative Palace was empty except for soldiers guarding entrances to the building.

headline: PATENTS; MEASURING THE FORCE OF WINDS
abstract: A WIND measurement instrument originally designed for use on Mars was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The instrument, capable of measuring wind velocity up to 100 miles to the second, could be used to forecast dangers to towers and other tall structures.

headline: MAY SALES AT RETAIL ROSE 0.2%
abstract: Sales at the retail level rose just two- tenths of 1 percent in May, as the spring shopping spree moderated, the Commerce Department reported today.   Overall sales reached a record $107.3 billion, the Commerce Department said, but the total increase from the previous month was small compared with the 3.1 percent rise from March to April.   Michael K. Evans, president of Evans Economics in Washington, said the figures were ''certainly good news if you're looking for lower interest rates.''   That was a reference to fears by Wall Street investors, many private analysts and some Government officials that a continuation of rapid business growth might overheat the economy and drive up interest rates, as heavy private borrowing demands clashed with the Government's need to borrow money to finance the budget deficit.

headline: PATENTS ;
abstract: Psychic Game Involves Skill in Telepathy    A psychic game, in which the players exhibit their skill in telepathy, clairvoyance or other capacities, has been invented by Laurie G. Larwood of Montclair, Calif.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: FRIDAY, MAY 4, 1984   Companies    Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts bid $2.3 billion for Esmark, which did not immediately respond to the offer, apparently because it is waiting for a better offer. The bid by the New York investment house, $55 a share, pushed Esmark shares up $12.75, to $57.625, in heavy trading. One reason the market price shot past the offered price is that other companies may enter the bidding. (Page D1.)    A.G. Becker is to get an infusion of capital from Paribas, the nationalized French bank that is the main shareholder. Paribas has also proposed a buyout to give it complete control. (D1.)

headline: AT HOME, QADDAFI'S CONTROL IS LESS THAN PERFECT
abstract: Outside Libya the image of Col. Muammar el- Qaddafi appears to be primarily a result of his support for international terrorism and his uncompromising hostility to Israel.    At home, however, Colonel Qaddafi's image changes. Foreign affairs is little spoken of in the series of pronouncements and slogans that issue from Colonel Qaddafi's office. The accent is on domestic affairs, and in particular on Colonel Qaddafi's effort to push Libya down the road of social transformation.

headline: ARGENTINE MINISTER QUITS IN LABOR SHOWDOWN
abstract: The Minister of Labor resigned today in what Government officials said was an attempt to end a confrontation with the opposition Peronist party over labor policies and repayment of the country's foreign debt.   The minister, Antonio Mucci, is the first Cabinet member to resign since President Raul Alfonsin assumed power four months ago, ending nearly eight years of military rule.   Mr. Mucci announced his resignation at a news conference at which he took full responsibility for the confrontation in trying to overhaul the nation's powerful unions by ousting old bosses and imposing internal democracy. He said he would be replaced by Juan Manuel Casella, a 42-year old Congressman, who will be sworn in Wednesday.

headline: New Lindner Stake In United Brands
abstract: - The American Financial Corporation and its chairman, Carl H. Lindner, said today that they had increased their stake in the United Brands Company to the equivalent of 7,438,742 common shares, or 55.9 percent of the shares outstanding.   American Financial, a holding company based in Cincinnati, and Mr. Lindner said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that they bought 594,400 common shares of United Brands from March 7 to April 3, all for $27 a share.

headline: Danish Prices Rise 1.1%
abstract: An increase in housing expenses helped push consumer prices in Denmark up 1.1 percent in May from April for a 12-month increase of 6.5 percent, the Bureau of Statistics said today. In the year through May, Danish consumer prices rose at a slightly faster rate than a year earlier, but slower than in 1982 when prices rose at a rate exceeding 11 percent a year, the agency said.

headline: American Stores In F.T.C. Pact
abstract: The American Stores Company said it had entered into an agreement with the Federal Trade Commission under which the F.T.C. would not seek a temporary restraining order or preliminary injunction barring its offer for the Jewel Companies.   Under the agreement, American Stores will be required to hold separate - for at least 90 days after its acquisition of 50 percent or more of Jewel - all Jewel stores engaged in the retail sale of prescription drugs in areas where American Stores is also engaged in such sales. Jewel agreed last week to be acquired by American Stores for $75 a share, or a total of about $1.16 billion.

headline: ;  Arbitron Radio Survey
abstract: In the United States, blacks listen to radio 20 percent more than the general public, Arbitron Ratings reports. The research company said that on the basis of data collected from diaries kept by 3,716 black households in 11 major markets, it figures that blacks spend an average of 30 hours a week, compared with the general listeners' 25 hours.

headline: 4 Arabs in West Bank Given Life Sentences
abstract: An Israeli military tribunal in Nablus imposed life sentences today on four West Bank Arabs in the murder on July 7 of Aharon Gross, a Yeshiva student in Hebron.   After the sentence was pronounced on one of the Arabs, Ibrahim Abdul Rahman Sarjil of Hebron, who was described in the trial as the ringleader, a classmate of the victim cried out, ''That is why there is an underground.''

headline: HAIG CONTENDS U.S. FAILED IN LEBANON
abstract: Former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. asserts that in 1982, the White House wrecked ''a breakthrough'' agreement for a simultaneous withdrawal of Palestine Liberation Organization, Syrian and Israeli forces from Lebanon.   Mr. Haig says in his memoirs that the agreement was worked out in early July 1982 but fell through when the White House prematurely made ''an ill-conceived announcement'' that it was prepared to commit United States troops to a multinational force there.   ''All that we had labored so hard to grasp, and had come so close to grasping, slipped away, with consequences not yet wholly revealed,'' Mr. Haig says in the memoirs, ''Caveat: Realism, Reagan and Foreign Policy.'' Time magazine made public its concluding installment of the memoirs today. They deal with the Middle East, the Falkland Islands crisis, the Polish crisis, and Mr. Haig's resignation being accepted by President Reagan.

headline: BONN SHARPENS ITS CRITICISM OF DUTCH ON NATO MISSILES
abstract: The West German Government today sharpened its criticism of a Dutch move to delay a decision on deploying cruise missiles.    A Government spokesman said Bonn regretted The Hague's inability to carry out ''fully and according to schedule'' a 1979 North Atlantic Treaty Organization decision to deploy the new United States missiles.   The spokesman, J"urgen Sudhoff, said Bonn feared the Dutch decision would cause misunderstandings in Moscow.

headline: NEW WAY TO REACH MOTHERS
abstract: IF you think that a magazine dedicated to educating new mothers on    the care of their young would have trouble diversifying within that narrow realm, meet Alan Goldberg and Mark Levine, second generation management of American Baby, a 48- year-old publishing company, and Judy Nolte, their editorial chief.   Since Mr. Goldberg, publisher and president, and his cousin Mr. Levine, a vice president and son of Eli Levine, the inactive chairman, took over the operation seven years ago, they have come up with a new advertising medium on almost a yearly basis. And always within their own area of expertise.   The latest, the American Baby Hospital Network, should really appeal to advertisers interested in intimate one-on-one communication with young mamas, and surprisingly it has also caught the imagination of that leading proponent of mass communications, the Procter & Gamble Company.

headline: Bills Gain On School Investment
abstract: Reacting to the bankruptcies of two securities firms that could cost schools and municipalities $40 million, the state Assembly passed six bills today intended to avert future investment crises.   The Assembly also passed a seventh bill giving emergency borrowing power to school districts with funds frozen by the bankruptcy proceedings.   However, the borrowing bill is different from a version passed Tuesday by the Senate, so a common version will have to be worked out between the two bodies next week.

headline: New Fighting Erupts On Beirut's Green Line
abstract: Fighting between rival Moslem and Christian factions erupted tonight along the Green Line dividing Beirut.   Residents said flares lighted up the city's southern suburbs, and bursts of gunfire and explosions could be heard from the Green Line, where Moslem forces in West Beirut confront loyalist army units and the Christian ''Lebanese forces'' militia in the east.

headline: Mubarak's Party Wins Decisively in Egypt
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak's party won 391 of the 448 contested seats in the parliamentary election Sunday, according to official results announced today. The opposition gained the remaining 57 seats, its best showing since the 1952 coup.

headline: AMERICA'S ASTOUNDING JOB MACHINE
abstract: EVEN the French were impressed. ''They all, including the French, simply cannot get over it,''    said one pleased Reagan Administration official.   The setting was the recent London economic summit meeting. The subject was jobs. And the mood among the Europeans was one of envy.    No wonder. In the last decade, while Western Europe lost some 2 million jobs, the United States created about 20 million. And since the current American recovery got under way, the gap has widened. Major European countries continue to lose jobs, while payrolls grow in the United States - not just in the dominant services sector which has been virtually recession-proof for decades, but also in devastated manufacturing. Some 5 million Americans have found new work in non-agricultural jobs since the bottom of the recession, making this the best recovery on the job front since the 1950's.

headline: Bank Rates Post Rise
abstract: Annual effective yields on money market deposit accounts and six-month certificates of deposit rose nationwide, but most sharply in the New York market, in the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.   The New York yields on six-month instruments jumped to 11.41 percent from 11.32 percent. New York banks and thrift institutions also continued to offer the best yields on money market deposit accounts, paying an average of 10.05 percent, up from 10.04 percent.

headline: CAR BLAST IN SOUTH LEBANON KILLS DRIVER, HURTS 5 ISRAELIS
abstract: A car carrying explosives blew up near three Israeli armored personnel carriers on the Mediterranean coastal road in southern Lebanon today, the Israeli military command said.   The car's driver was killed and five Israeli soldiers were slightly wounded in the blast about eight miles south of the port city of Sidon, the command said.   The military announcement conflicted with Lebanese reports that described the driver as a suicide bomber, and said the automobile crashed into an armored personnel carrier.

headline: ;  Intermountain Power Bonds
abstract: The Intermountain Power Agency is offering $300 million of bonds with a maximum yield of 11 3/4 percent for bonds due in 2012, according to tentative prices set yesterday by underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.    Shorter maturities were tentatively priced, with yields ranging from 9 percent for bonds due in 1992 to 11 percent for those due in 1999 and 11 3/8 percent for bonds due in 2004.    A $100 million issue due in 2014 was offered with a lower 10 3/8 percent yield, because interest and principal were guaranteed by the Municipal Bond Insurance Association and therefore rated AAA by Standard & Poor's. The noninsured portion of the financing was rated A-1 by Moody's and Ax by S.& P.

headline: Rapid-American Woolworth Stake
abstract: The F. W. Woolworth Company said it considered the purchase of one million shares of its stock by the Rapid-American Corporation an investment.

headline: Venezuela Oil Price Rise
abstract: - Venezuela plans to raise its price for heavy crude by 50 cents a barrel in line with Mexico's 50-cent increase last month for its heavy Maya crude, to $25.50 a barrel, the newspaper El Nacional reported today. Quoting Government sources, the article said the increase reflected large profit margins at West Coast refineries in the United States.

headline: ARGENTINA IS REPORTED CLOSE TO PACT ON DEBT
abstract: Argentina is close to an agreement with its foreign bank creditors that would avoid a major debt crisis at the end of the second quarter, banking sources said yesterday.     Under a proposal said to have been made this week by the Argentine Government, Argentina would pay the banks $500 million in interest on its $47 billion in debt by the end of June so that payments on all of its loans would be no more than 90 days past due.    Argentina would use $350 million of its own money, and borrow the remaining $150 million from a group of 11 international banks. Under an arrangement similar to one reached at the end of the first quarter, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York would assure the banks that they would be repaid. This would be possible because the Fed would receive authorization from Argentina to withdraw the money from Argentina's account at the Fed to repay the banks when the payments became due.

headline: BEATRICE IS SEEKING ESMARK
abstract: The Beatrice Foods Company, one of the biggest food producers in the country, will offer $2.5 billion in cash to buy Esmark Inc., James L. Dutt, chairman of Beatrice, said late yesterday.     The offer, understood to have taken Esmark by surprise, is expected to be made officially after a special meeting of Beatrice's directors today.   The combination would involve two of Chicago's leading companies and create one of the world's biggest food and consumer products companies.    Asked what response Donald P. Kelly, chairman and chief executive of Esmark, would have to the Beatrice offer, a spokesman quoted Mr. Kelly as saying, ''It's always been our intention to do what's in the best interest of our stockholders.'' He declined to be more specific.

headline: Kelso Said to Raise U.S. Industries Bid
abstract: U.S. Industries said yesterday that it had received a sweetened offer of $24 a share in cash to take the company private.    The proposal was made by a group organized by Kelso & Company, a New York investment banker that had offered $20 a share in February.

headline: China-Australia Accord
abstract: China and Australia widened their relationship in iron and steelmaking today under an agreement signed by ministers of both countries. Lionel Bowen, Australia's Deputy Prime Minister, and Chen Muhua, China's Minister for Foreign Economic Relations and Trade, signed an agreement to bring Australian experts to China next month to survey older mills and report on refurbishing the plants.

headline: PATENTS ; Helmet Projector Helps To Orient Naval Pilots
abstract: Equipment has been invented for the Navy to train student pilots as to what they may see when flying.

headline: D'AUBUISSON IS FINDING A FRIEND ON CAPITOL HIL
abstract: Aides to Senator Jesse Helms said today that he has been defending Roberto d'Aubuisson, the Salvadoran rightist, because the Senator prefers Mr. d'Aubuisson's politics to those of President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador.    ''This is a classic case of 'the enemy of my enemy is my friend,' '' said an aide to the North Carolina Republican, who is holding a reception for the Salvadoran here this week.   Last month, Mr. d'Aubuisson, who has been linked to death squads, lost a presidential election to Mr. Duarte, a Christian Democrat who had the support of the Reagan Administration.

headline: EMBASSY EVACUATION TALKS GO ON
abstract: Britain deported a 34-year-old Libyan radical today who was described as the chief personal representative in this country of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader.    The representative, Abdul Khadir Baghdadi, who was placed on a Libyan Arab Airlines flight to Tripoli this afternoon, was the secretary of the four- man ''revolutionary committee'' that took over the embassy in February and rechristened it the Libyan People's Bureau. A second member, Saleh Ibrahim Mabruk, was sent home on Monday, and a third, Matooq Matooq, is being sought by Scotland Yard. The fourth member, identified as Ali Abujazieh, is believed to have returned to Libya.

headline: TRI-STAR'S BID FOR MOVIE STARDOM
abstract: LOS ANGELES THERE was all the excitement of    a bygone Hollywood for last   week's debut of Tri-Star Pictures' first production, ''The Natural,'' starring Robert Redford. The movie, shown at a gala premiere in New York and at a by-invitation-only screening here, is about a baseball hitter blessed with mythic power and cursed with bad luck - one who, invariably, either smashes the ball into the bleachers for a home run or strikes out miserably.    It's not a bad metaphor for Hollywood. Indeed, given the vagaries of the movie business, both Tri-Star and its film could meet either fate. But whatever the weekend box office, Tri- Star is determined to a become a force - an ''instant major,'' company executives call it - in the movie industry. A major, in the Hollywood lexicon, is a company that distributes upwards of 15 movies each year, some that it has produced itself, others ''picked up'' from producers elsewhere. By most counts, there are only six majors left today: Columbia, MGM-UA, Paramount, Warner Brothers, 20th Century-Fox and Universal (Walt Disney Pictures' production has dropped too low). And the odds against Tri-Star making a seventh are daunting. Not since 1924, with the formation of Columbia Pictures, has any company succeeded in becoming a major.

headline: Paperboard Makers Are Planning Talks
abstract: Southwest Forest Industries said yesterday that it plans to hold ''exploratory discussions'' with the Jefferson Smurfit Corporation about ''a possible transaction.''   W. A. Franke, Southwest's president, said he understood that Jefferson Smurfit had recently acquired about 9 percent of the 9.3 million shares outstanding of Southwest, a maker of paperboard and other products that use wood as raw material.

headline: CHINA VIEW MIXED ON REAGAN'S VISIT
abstract: President Reagan's visit to China represents a ''significant step forward'' in relations between the two countries, but Taiwan remains a major obstacle, the official New China News Agency said today.   ''Reagan's six-day state visit to China is viewed by observers here as having broken ground for an enduring and steady growth of Chinese-U.S. relations,'' the press agency said in an analysis issued hours after Mr. Reagan left China.   The agency said the visit produced concrete results, ''the most important of which, as both sides noted repeatedly, was the direct contact and dialogue between leaders of the two countries.''

headline: Toll at 31 in Taiwan Floods
abstract: Six more bodies were found in the aftermath of flooding caused by torrential rains in northern Taiwan over the weekend, pushing the death toll to 31, a police spokesman said today.

headline: China Reports It Drove Vietnamese From 2 Hills
abstract: China said today that it had ejected Vietnamese troops from two hilltop positions they had held since Vietnam and China fought a border war in 1979.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: POPE GETS SWISS PRIEST'S GRIEVANCES
abstract: A young Swiss priest presented a giant safety pin to Pope John Paul II today at a meeting in the Benedictine abbey here with Swiss priests, two of whom suggested concern that the Pope is too conservative on church issues.    The gift was symbolic, the Rev. Markus Fischer said as he removed it from a wooden case before presenting it. ''We want to show you our readiness and our good will,'' he said.

headline: South African Arms Plans
abstract: Defense Minister Magnus Malan told Parliament on Friday that South Africa was considering making its own submarines and helicopters in view of a United Nations embargo against selling the weapons to the Pretoria Government.

headline: Enstar Vote Tally Awaited
abstract: Roy M. Huffington said he believed that his dissident group had won its proxy contest against management of the Enstar Corporation. He made his remarks after Enstar adjourned its annual meeting until July 6 to complete counting the votes.

headline: Prices Down For Gasoline
abstract: Gasoline prices fell   slightly in the last two weeks   and the trend should continue   into the heavy summer driving   season as plentiful supply offsets concern about the war in   the Persian Gulf, an industry   analyst said today. The average price of gasoline   nationwide is $1.21.05 a gallon,   down 0.13 cents from two weeks   ago, said Dan Lundberg, who   surveys 18,000 service stations   nationwide.

headline: A SALVADORAN JOURNALIST IS SLAIN SAN SALVADOR, April 1 (Reuters) - A former member of El Salvador's Central Election Council, who resigned before last week's voting, was shot and killed Saturday night. Leftist rebels took responsibility.
abstract: The former official, Rafael Hasbun, a conservative newspaper columnist, was shot dead as he entered his office in central San Salvador, officials at the city morgue said.   The officials said witnesses told them that Mr. Hasbun was shot seven times by three gunmen who emerged from a bar across the street.

headline: MEDICAL SCHOOL AT BARBADOS AT CENTER OF CONTROVERSY
abstract: The St. George's University School of Medicine is at the center of a storm of charges and countercharges over the campus it set up here after its campus in Grenada was temporarily evacuated during the invasion of that island last October.    The controversy has produced wide- ranging allegations against the school, including low standards, improper importation of cadavers and financing by organized crime in New Jersey.   Permanent Campus Approved    The Barbados Government recently approved the establishment of a permanent campus for the American- owned school, viewing it as an economic asset that could pump millions of dollars into the island. Approval was given over the vociferous objections of the country's doctors, its opposition party and the University of the West Indies. They argue, among other things, that the school has substandard students and curriculum, will undermine medical education in the Caribbean region and lower the quality of health services.

headline: HAITIAN ARTISTS ARE HURTING AS TOURISTS TRADE FALLS OFF
abstract: -HAITIEN, Haiti - An artist who owns a Haitian art gallery said the other day that no cruise ship had docked in this northern port city for 18 months.   The artist, Jean-Baptiste Belizaire, owns the Flamingo Gallery in Cap- Ha"itien, where unemployment is astronomical and food riots broke out late in May.   The decline in tourism, he said, has meant hard times for Haitian artists, but not for the older masters, like Rigaud Beno^it, Philome Obin, Hector Hyppolite, Wilson Bigaud and Pref ete Duffaud, who have established international reputations and have brisk gallery sales abroad.

headline: IN SURPRISE VISIT, SHULTZ HAS TALKS WITH NICARAGUANS
abstract: Eden Pastora Gomez, the Nicaraguan rebel wounded by a bomb, was flown to Venezuela after Costa Rica asked him to leave. Page 3.         MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 1 - Secretary of State George P. Shultz made an unexpected visit to leaders of the Sandinista Government tonight and later said ''constructive'' discussions had resulted in the decision to pursue additional talks.   ''President Reagan sent me here to Central America on a mission of peace,'' Mr. Shultz said after emerging from a private meeting of more than two hours with Daniel Ortega Saavedra, coordinator of the Nicaraguan junta.

headline: East Siders Will GetFree Tabloid Paper
abstract: Ebullient Judy Price, who has made a success out of her controlled- circulation magazine Avenue, is now starting a neighborhood tabloid newspaper called On The Avenue. The magazine, which she started eight years ago, has been largely delivered to Manhattan's fashionable East Side apartment houses on Fifth and Park Avenues.

headline: D.D.B. Profits Rise
abstract: Doyle Dane Bernbach International said its net income increased 18.2 percent in the first quarter, to $1.3 million, or 21 cents a share, from $1.1 million, or 19 cents a share, a year ago. Revenues rose 5.9 percent, to $46.7 million, from $44.1 million a year ago.

headline: Port Authority Sets $100 Million Offerings
abstract: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is offering $100 million of bonds and $100 million of notes though underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Investment bankers said sales were modest with most of the buying by individual investors.

headline: HONDURAN ARMY REVIEWS ITS LINK WITH U.S.
abstract: The commander of Honduras's armed forces, declaring that his ousted predecessor had compromised the country's ''pacifist and democratic'' principles, called tonight for new limits on military spending and a new dedication to a peaceful solution of tensions in Central America.   The nationally televised speech by Gen. Walter Lopez Reyes appeared to signal an important change in the relationship the United States had enjoyed under Gen. Gustavo Alvarez Martinez, who was removed by the military on March 31.   Such a change might force the United States to re-evaluate its reliance on Honduras as a cornerstone of its military plans in the region, according to United States officials here.
